Bush, in an end-of-summit joint press conference with Gorbachev, said his decision to conditionally grant Moscow trade benefits had nothing to do with Lithuania. ``The linkage is between the emigration _ and that's it,'' Bush declared. Bush had barely waved goodbye to Gorbachev when his chief of staff, John Sununu, put it differently in an ABC television interview. ``There is no way the president of the United States is not going to consider a whole host of issues as he determines whether or not to send'' the trade deal to Congress, Sununu said on ``This Week with David Brinkley.'' Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said what happens to the trade agreement _ once it is sent to Congress _ hinges on a number of decisions facing the Kremlin in a period of turmoil. ``Members of Congress ... would be watching what goes on back in the Soviet Union and how they work it out in the next few weeks,'' he said. Earlier, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said ``some rather modest changes in his (Gorbachev's) policy toward the Baltic states'' could convince Congress to approve trade benefits. Meantime, Lithuania President Vytautas Landsbergis said Sunday that he hopes to sign a trade agreement with the republic of Russia, now headed by populist reformer Boris Yeltsin. Yeltsin is considered Gorbachev's political nemesis. Bush said he was blunt with Gorbachev about U.S. support for self-determination of the Baltic states, and he was ``encouraged to see discussions going on over there between various leaders.'' But he said the Soviet leader provided no assurances that he would lift the embargo against Lithuania. The Soviets say independence can only be attained through a drawn-out process involving a referendum. While Bush insisted it was in the United States' best interest to sign the trade deal, he acknowledged that Congress shares a role in deciding its fate. ``We've got a Congress that has its rights,'' he said. ``They have every right to look at what I've signed and every obligation to do that, and make their judgment as to whether it's in the best interests.'' Unlike a treaty which requires ratification by a two-thirds vote of the Senate, the trade pact is an executive agreement which requires approval by a majority of the House and Senate. One of the most vocal senators in the drive to tie trade to Lithuania is Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., who said there will be ``one tough battle'' in the Senate on trade unless the economic embargo on Lithuania is lifted. But Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., argued last month that it was pointless to link the issues. ``We need to be encouraging trade with the Soviet Union and other countries,'' he said. ``This is not some favor we are granting the Soviets. We are the world's largest debtor nation.''

DOC.HEAD: Arms Control, Germany Still Divide the Superpowers
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are unresolved summit issues the superpowers will be addressing in the coming months through formal negotiations:

_Strategic Arms: The leaders failed to removed three key obstacles to completing a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons. These include constraints on testing a new version of the Soviet SS-18 heavy missile, limits on the Soviet Backfire bomber and prohibitions on transferring strategic arms to third countries. The Strategic Arms Reduction Talks are to resume in Geneva on June 11. _Conventional Arms: Little progress was recorded on issues related to the Conventional Forces in Europe negotiations, which aim to sharply reduce levels of troops, tanks and other non-nuclear armaments. These talks, involving 23 nations, are continuing this summer in Vienna with a goal of finishing by year's end. _Germany: No compromise was reached between the U.S. position that a reunited Germany have membership in NATO and the Soviet demand that it not. Secretary of State James Baker is scheduled to resume discussing the matter with his Soviet counterpart in Copenhagen on Tuesday, and formal talks between the two Germanies and the four victorious World War II allies are to resume in Berlin on June 22.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Leaving Job to Others, But First One More Term
DOC.TEXT: When Morris Udall, environmentalist chairman of the House Interior Committee for nearly a quarter century, announced plans to retire, some people asked what that would mean to the protection of public land. Also, could a man who has been a leader in Congress, despite a long battle with Parkinson's disease, be happy outside the legislative process? Udall apparently is ready to pass the torch _ after one more term in the House. ``I've spent thousands of hours working to protect American lands and create national parks,'' said Udall. ``I regret I have not been able to spend a lot of time in those areas.'' He said he wants to take his bride, the former Norma Gilbert whom he married last year, to see the parks. ``I would like to pitch a tent and stay for a while.'' Udall, 67, announced last month that he will retire at the end of 1992, and Capitol observers believe he means it. Re-election this year should be no problem. For 11 years, the congressman has battled a disease that leaves one's mind intact, but savagely attacks muscular reactions, reducing the once upright and active former pro basketball player to a stooped-over old man. Yet Udall's refusal to surrender to the illness led people to believe he would never leave Congress voluntarily. ``I am always reluctant to write out a specific agenda,'' said Udall, but he added that before he leaves, ``There are a few key areas where I can play a positive role.'' He said he wants to participate in the debate on campaign finance reform. He serves on a House task force that will handle the legislation now being debated by the Senate. He also said he wants to see the American Heritage Trust bill passed to assure a permanent trust fund for federal acquisition of lands and to improve recreational areas. Before leaving as the most senior and powerful member of the Arizona delegation, Udall also plans to oversee a few more appropriations for the Central Arizona Project, a federally funded canal still under construction that provides water to arid areas of the state. The project is expected to be completed soon and Udall has said he wants to be in Congress when the water finally flows to Tucson. ``I've spent a lot of time on that effort and my parents always taught me to finish what I start,'' said the congressman. Once he's in retirement, Udall says he'll write another book. ``My latest, `Too Funny to be President,' was only one-third of my collection of jokes and stories,'' he said. Udall was elected to the House from Arizona's second district in 1961 to replace his brother, Stewart, who was appointed interior secretary by President Kennedy. He has been Interior Committee chairman since 1977. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., is heir-apparent to the job. ``Miller already has been taking over leadership,'' said Rindy O'Brien of the Wilderness Society. ``Miller has a very keen environmental interest. He's a hard fighter. Same as Mo.'' One of the most productive politicians of his generation, Udall also is perhaps the most popular among his colleagues. His unusual ability to bring enemies into agreement over legislation has gained him admiration from all parts of the political spectrum. ``We will miss having Mo there because he was always someone you could count on,'' said O'Brien.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Diane Duston covers environmental and other interior issues in Congress.

DOC.HEAD: House Members See the World for Free
DOC.TEXT: When former Iowa Sen. Dick Clark launched the Aspen Institute's congressional retreats five years ago, he chose a site not too far from Washington _ North Carolina's Eastern Shore. ``It was just a damned disaster, to be honest,'' he said. ``It was money wasted.'' The lawmakers came late and left early because of changing events in Washington, just a short flight away. ``And when they were there they were constantly on the phone with their offices,'' he said. So Clark searched the globe for a solution _ and found several. ``I found if I took people out of the country and invited the spouses I could get people to come,'' he said. Indeed, the latest financial disclosure forms of House members show the trips sponsored by the Aspen Institute are a favorite of the select group of lawmakers asked to serve on the group's panels on U.S. relations with the Soviet Union, southern Africa and Indochina. But the Aspen Institute is far from alone in bankrolling the travels of members of Congress. The House records show members took hundreds of free trips last year, visiting world capitals, tropical islands and some of the nation's finest resorts. And while on the road, many members also picked up thousands of dollars in honoraria. But the value of the trips appeared in most cases to be worth more than the $2,000 or so paid for speeches. This is the last year House members can accept honoraria. But in eliminating that perk last year, the House did not restrict the trips lawmakers can take at the expense of labor unions, trade associations and other interest groups that have substantial legislative interests. Other sponsors, like the Aspen Institute, are non-partisan think tanks whose seminars are praised by members of Congress and other participants. The itinerary for the 1989 Aspen retreats went like this: Jamaica in January, Bermuda in March, a mountain retreat in Switzerland in August, followed weeks later by several days in Dubrovnik, Yugoslavia. The four seminars cost the foreign policy organization $1 million. ``I take them nice places and I think they enjoy themselves,'' Clark said in a telephone interview. ``But we really work hard and long.'' Rep. Nancy Johnson, R-Conn., said her husband and most other invited spouses skip the beach for the Aspen seminars ``because of the caliber of the people they bring together.'' ``Yes, we could not go to Jamaica,'' Johnson said, mindful of the criticism some public interest groups direct at such travel. ``But one of the values of leaving the country is focus. Your office isn't constantly calling. Somebody isn't flying off for a quick speech. And one of the ways to get members to come is providing them something their families see as a pleasure.'' While about two dozen members of Congress attended the five-day Aspen conference in Jamaica, another 11 were elsewhere in the Caribbean at a conference sponsored by New Jersey's Fairleigh Dickinson University on the island of St. Croix. Trips that didn't take House members out of the country often brought them to the nation's best resorts. Republican Rep. Tom Campbell of California was among the guests of the American Bar Association at a meeting in Hawaii. Democratic Reps. Joe Moakley of Massachusetts and Beryl Anthony of Arkansas visited Nantucket in August for a National Association of Home Builders gathering. Moakley also visited Puerto Rico at the expense of the National Association of Government Employees union and was a guest of the Securities Industries Association at the Boca Raton Beach Club in Florida. A handful of House members reported free trips to participate in charity golf tournaments. ``It's a respite we really enjoy,'' said Indiana Republican Dan Burton, who participated in six tournaments last year. The House member with the most free trips in 1989, Rep. Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, rarely got near the beach. Schroeder, who was reimbursed for more than 50 trips, did get three nights in Hawaii to attend the ABA conference and spent a few nights in Florida. But she was more likely to be found in Newark, Des Moines or Minneapolis, speaking to conferences on family issues or Democratic Party functions. ``She chooses her trips by topic not by climate,'' said Schroeder spokeswoman Andrea Camp. ``And she has a lack of a tan to show for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Roh Tae-woo Arrives for Historic Meeting with Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with four grafs to UPDATE with Roh meeting with former President Reagan; picks up 2nd graf pvs, ``Some 200 ... her name.''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Korea-Soviet Bjt
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo arrived Sunday for an unprecedented meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev designed to promote normalized relations and trade. Roh met Sunday evening with former President Reagan, who, with his wife, Nancy, is scheduled to have breakfast Monday with the Soviet president and his wife, Raisa. Reagan and Roh met for 20 minutes, during which they discussed improving Seoul's relations with Moscow and easing tensions in the region. ``This meeting will be an important step towards bringing peace to Northeast Asia and on the Korean Peninsula, thereby ending the Cold War in that part of the world,'' Reagan said of Roh's planned session with Gorbachev. Some 200 people, both supporters and opponents of the visit, staged a noisy demonstration outside the Fairmont Hotel after Roh was safely inside. ``They're noisy, but nothing violent,'' said a police dispatcher who would not give her name. Roh's plane, flying U.S. and Korean flags from a hatch above the flight deck, was greeted by several hundred people, including San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos, former Secretary of State George Shultz and Korean Ambassador Hyun Hong-choo. Under a brilliant blue sky, Roh was handed a bouquet of flowers by 8-year-old Diane Lieu, a San Francisco youngster clad in a Korean costume of red and gold. ``I'm delighted to see this taking place,'' Shultz said just before the plane landed. ``From the standpoint of the United States, we have a great interest in peace and stability throughout the Asian-Pacific region.'' The city declared Sunday ``Roh Tae-woo Day,'' and Agnos was expected to present Roh with the key to the city. The meeting between Roh and the Soviet president would be the first time leaders of their countries have met since the Republic of Korea was created 45 years ago. Korean officials expect them to meet at about 4 p.m. Monday, when there is a 90-minute gap in Gorbachev's crowded 22-hour San Francisco schedule. ``The waves of reform now reshaping the world have started rushing toward Northeast Asia,'' Roh said as left Seoul. He said he hoped talks with Gorbachev would help ``pave the way for the peace and unification of the Korean peninsula.'' ``Korea now remains the only country on earth that is still divided as a legacy of the Cold War,'' Roh said. He is expected to invite Gorbachev to visit Seoul and may seek Moscow's help in arranging a summit meeting with North Korean President Kim Il-sung. Kim has refused to recognize the South Korean government, and the Soviet Union is North Korea's oldest ally. During his talks with Gorbachev, Roh said he would focus on bilateral issues, emphasizing the normalization of relations and measures to promote peace and unification of the divided Korean peninsula. Roh plans to leave Tuesday for Washington to meet with President Bush. Local Koreans see the meeting as a step toward the reunification of North and South Korea, an apparent goal of Roh and possibly Gorbachev. Both of the leaders see increased economic opportunities in such a move. Bilateral trade between the nations reached $600 million last year, up 106 percent from 1988 and a tenfold hike over 1985 levels, according to the Korean Embassy. The figure is expected to top $1 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: No Trade Revolution Seen in Upgraded Ties With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Improved trade ties with the Soviet Union are unlikely to usher in an export bonanza for the American farmer, says a new report from the Agriculture Department. The most favored nation status being sought for the Soviets ``may not greatly benefit U.S. farmers'' but also ``poses little danger to U.S. farmers,'' according to the report from USDA's Economic Research Service. ``Because of the limited increase in Soviet export earnings (with or without most favored nation from the United States), the continued Soviet commitment to increasing its degree of food self-sufficiency and the USSR's substantial need for nonagricultural imports, little increase in agricultural imports is likely to occur,'' it said. Most favored nation status would put the Soviets on the same footing in terms of tariffs and other matters as this country's top trading partners. President Bush agreed to upgraded trade ties between the two nations on Friday, pressing Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev for a new law protecting Jewish emigration as the price. American agribusiness had been pushing for such a move. Five former agriculture secretaries, three Republicans and two Democrats, issued a statement earlier Friday urging the upgraded trade status. They said it would ``help build a relationship that all sides can count on for the long term and be a basis for bringing the Soviet Union more fully into the world trading system.'' The statement also was signed by 27 groups ranging from the American Farm Bureau Federation to the import-export giant Cargill Inc. as well as assorted corn, wheat, soybeans, pork and other producer organizations. USDA economists in their report did cite a recent study by the U.S. International Trade Commission that said granting most favored nation status to the Soviets could mean an overall $1 billion gain for the United States. But it said other studies put the amount lower. USDA is currently forecasting total U.S. agricultural exports for this year at $40 billion and the Soviet Union's purchases of grain from this country already have made it the second largest single-nation customer. The report said that U.S. imports from the Soviet Union are typically commodities that enter duty-free, such as precious metals and compounds, anhydrous ammonia, art work, sable skins and tractors. The report said the Soviets are selling the same sorts of goods to Canada, which already has granted them most favored nation status. The report said the Soviet Union has a limited ability to produce the sort of consumer goods that would be most affected by lower tariffs. A notable exception: Most favored nation status would slash the tariff on imports of Soviet vodka between 60 percent and 90 percent and could lead to imports substantially above last year's $19 million. Most favored nation status would cut tariffs on Soviet energy shipments to the United States by 50 percent to 75 percent. ``However, the USSR energy sector has difficulty maintaining commitments to western Europe and other importing countries where little or no discriminatory tariffs now exist,'' according to the report.

A University of California economist says the real cost to consumers of the nation's sugar program is ``somewhere in the neighborhood of below $500 million.'' The American Sugar Alliance, which represents U.S. growers, is applauding the finding from Andrew Schmitz, chairman of the agricultural economics department at Berkeley. They claim that it ``refutes the often quoted figure of $3 billion as the cost to consumers of the U.S. sugar program.'' Consumer advocates urge an opening up of quotas that keep U.S. sugar prices above the world market and thus protect a few American growers from huge economic losses that would arrive along with a tide of cheap sugar produced in the Third World. They say the cost to consumers of high sugar prices is $3 billion a year. Schmitz unveiled his estimate at a recent State Department conference on sugar markets. He said the $3 billion figure ``is based on assumptions which are questionable'' and added that he used ``realistic assumptions'' to reach his conclusion. For example, he said the $3 billion estimate was calculated based on a world price ``at an all-time low in real terms.'' He said it also was questionable to believe that U.S. prices have no effect on the world sugar market _ meaning that without the American program world prices might rise. He also said the estimate fails to factor in a savings to consumers by their switch in some cases from sugar to lower-priced corn sweeteners. ``The greater the degree of substitution between sugar use and corn sweetener use, the lesser will be the impact of sugar quotas on U.S. consumers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jail Crowding Worsens as New Inmates Outstrip Construction
DOC.TEXT: Overcrowding in the nation's jails is steadily worsening, and part of the problem is that jails are holding inmates for overfilled state prisons, according to the Justice Department. On June 30, 1989, there were 395,553 prisoners held in jails operated by local governments designed to hold 367,769 people, according to a study released Sunday by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. That marked a 15 percent increase from the 343,569 prisoners in custody on the same day in 1988, when the jails had a rated capacity of 339,633. Meanwhile, the capacity of local jails expanded 8 percent between the middle of 1988 and midyear 1989, the study said. The average daily population of the nation's local jails for the 12 months ending June 30, 1989, was 386,845, also up 15 percent from an average of 336,017 for the same 12-month period ending June 30, 1988, the study said. The occupancy rate of the nation's jails increased from 101 percent to 108 percent between the two periods, the study said. In 1983, the occupancy rate of nation's jails was 85 percent and in 1976 it was 65 percent. Overcrowding was worse in the jurisdictions that had the largest number of inmates. The occupancy rate averaged 116 percent in the 508 local jurisdictions that held at least 100 inmates. These jurisdictions had 81 percent of the nation's jail prisoners. State prison overcrowding also contributed to the problem in local jails, according to the study. The study found that 88 percent of the 508 largest jurisdictions held 42,053 prisoners for other authorities, including 29,358 inmates that had been sent to local jails because of overcrowding elsewhere, the study said. Twenty-six percent of these jurisdictions were under a court order to reduce overcrowding at one or more jails and 23 percent had been ordered by judges to improve conditions. Despite the increased overcrowding, the number of inmate deaths declined from 469 during 1988 to 414 last year, the study said. The number of jail suicides declined from 147 to 121. There were 19 million admissions and releases from local jails during the 12-month period ending June 30, 1989. The average daily population of female jail inmates jumped 27 percent between 1988 and 1989. Women comprised 9 percent of all jail inmates in 1989, the study said. The study surveyed local jails that hold inmates after arraignment, usually more than 48 hours. Police lockups that house prisoners, usually drunks, for less than 48 hours were not included. State-run jails and the combined jail-prison systems of Alaska, Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Rhode Island and Vermont were not included in the survey.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Activities in Minnesota
With AM- and PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here at a glance are some of Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev's activities during their visit Sunday to Minneapolis:

_He urged some of the nation's captains of industry at a meeting in Minneapolis to help with his country's radical economic reforms. ``We feel we need American business because it is so big,'' he said. _He looked at $32 million worth of Control Data Corp. computers the Soviet Union has agreed to buy from the Bloomington, Minn., manufacturer in hopes of improving nuclear plant safety and preventing another Chernobyl. _He canceled a visit to a family farm run by Richard and Cecilia Brand in Farmington, outside Minneapolis. Gorbachev was said to be tired and behind schedule. _He repeatedly waded into crowds to shake hands and exchange small talk, prompting squeals of delight and chants of ``Gorby! Gorby!'' _He attended a luncheon at Gov. Rudy Perpich's mansion. British publisher Robert Maxwell announced he will donate $50 million to establish the Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology, a research center, in the Twin Cities area. _She visited a ``typical'' American family in Minneapolis, Steve and Karen Watson and their four children, for a chat around their dining table. _She made unannounced stops at a Mexican deli and a drugstore, where she bought macadamia nuts and Super Mario Brothers Nintendo bubblegum and asked about employee vacations, what's in a Snickers bar and the differences in nail polish.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting May Be Turning Point for Korean Peninsula
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand. Meeting not expected until 7 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Today's historic ``post-summit summit,'' a meeting between the Kremlin's Mikhail Gorbachev and South Korea's Roh Tae-woo, promised to be an important first step toward easing tensions on the Korean peninsula. The South Korean president arrived in San Francisco Sunday morning and, after a quick round of airport greetings, spent the day closeted at the Fairmont Hotel with a group of top-level aides, planning strategy for the first-ever meeting of top South Korean and Soviet leaders. He met briefly Sunday night with former President Reagan, whose schedule also included breakfast today with Gorbachev, fresh from a four-day summit in Washington with President Bush. During the 20-minute meeting, Roh and Reagan discussed prospects for improving Seoul's relations with Moscow and increasing stability in the area. ``This meeting will be an important step towards bringing peace to Northeast Asia and on the Korean peninsula, thereby ending the Cold War in that part of the world,'' Reagan said after the meeting. As he left Seoul, Roh said, ``The waves of reform now reshaping the world have started rushing toward Northeast Asia.'' He said he hoped talks with Gorbachev would open a new era in efforts ``to pave the way for the peace and unification of the Korean peninsula.'' ``Korea now remains the only country on Earth that is still divided as a legacy of the Cold War,'' Roh said. Korea was partitioned at the 38th Parallel after World War II. In 1950, the Soviet Union backed the communist North Koreans' three-year invasion of U.S.-supported South Korea. That bitter war turned the south into one of the United States' staunchest allies, but Koreans have always dreamed of reunification. The talks are the fruit of Seoul's bid to woo the rapidly reforming Warsaw Pact countries, aiming both to open new markets and to bring about an easing of hostilities with its northern neighbor. From all indications, the Gorbachev-Roh meeting was arranged hastily with the blessing of the United States, although it has been treated as a casual get-together, perhaps in deference to Soviet relations with North Korea. There was no firm agenda and even the time the two would meet was unclear. Roh planned to fly to Washington on Tuesday to brief Bush on the meeting before returning to Seoul. The 58-year-old South Korean leader reportedly was going to press for early and full diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, reinforcing Seoul's growing economic exchanges with Moscow. The South Korean president also was expected to urge a meeting among the Koreas and the four powers with interests in Northeast Asia _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Japan and China, news reports said. North Korea has an estimated 1.1 million troops and South Korea has 650,000. Last week, the North renewed its 1988 proposal calling for both Koreas to reduce forces to 100,000 armed men in three to four years. The United States, which has 43,000 troops stationed in South Korea, has declared strong support for improvement in South-North relations and is trying to improve its own relations with the North's government in Pyongyang. North Korea has denounced the Roh-Gorbachev meeting, calling it ``a serious political issue.'' For its part, Moscow may voice support of North Korea's call for the signing of a Korean peace treaty, withdrawal of all nuclear weapons from the peninsula and the pullout of all U.S. troops in South Korea. Seoul has established diplomatic relations with every East European country except Albania and East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Thomas Sutherland's Daughters Talk About Five Years of Waiting
DOC.TEXT: The yellow ribbon on Kit and Joan Sutherland's front-door knocker is now frayed and faded. But that doesn't mean the sisters have given up waiting for their father, held hostage five years in Lebanon. Thomas Sutherland, a Scottish-born American abducted by Shiite Moslem extremists in Beirut on June 9, 1985, has been described by former hostage David Jacobsen as ``one strong, tough Scottish farmer.'' And pessimism is not a family trait. ``I think, because Dad is so strong and ... really a happy-go-lucky, wild, ornery kind of person, that it's really difficult not to be that way,'' Kit Sutherland said. ``And so sometimes you reach the frustrations, but we learned from the very beginning not to get on the roller coaster, to watch what happens and wait until you see things.'' But Joan said: ``I really think something's going to happen. Maybe not tomorrow, but maybe by the end of the summer.'' Kit, 29, and Joan, 25, share a house in this university town at the foot of the Rocky Mountains. Sutherland's other child, Ann, 31, lives with her husband and daughter in California. Sutherland, 59, was the dean of agriculture and food science at the American University of Beirut and was on leave from Colorado State University in Fort Collins when gunmen kidnapped him as he drove in a convoy to Beirut Airport. His family stays hopeful by looking at the ``small things: the fact that some of them have died, and Dad hasn't,'' Kit said. ``A lot of things have happened that they (the hostages) could have been killed for,'' she said. ``So you have to stay optimistic that at least the most rational of groups, the most rational of terrorists, has him.'' Sutherland traveled from Scotland to the United States in the 1950s to continue his agriculture studies at Iowa State University. He met his wife, Jean, there and married. He became a U.S. citizen in 1963 but retained his love for his native land. ``He knows Robert Burns poems,'' recalled freed hostage Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, who shared a year's captivity with Sutherland. ``And he would recite them with that wonderful Scots accent.'' His daughters also credit the strength of their mother, Jean, with keeping their hopes high. Mrs. Sutherland, 56, teaches English at American University and, except for visits to see her daughters, has remained in Beirut. She was in Fort Collins finishing her doctoral thesis when her husband was kidnapped. Kit Sutherland, an animal-sciences research assistant at CSU, and Joan, who works at a Fort Collins lending company, say the last five years have not exactly been ``on hold.'' But they have learned what it means to be ``hostage daughters.'' ``It's gone fast in some ways because you realize that life goes really fast and in that sense, he's missed a lot,'' Kit said. ``But, in the other sense, it just seems to drag by because you want him to finally get out. It's only been every once in a while that it's difficult to keep optimistic.'' The release of two American hostages in April, and a recent report in a Beirut magazine saying Sutherland was ill and would be released soon, are encouraging signs, she said. ``Dad has never been the one to be `the next one,''' she said. ``We've never thought he was the one that was coming out. So this is the first time that we've had any indication'' that he might be freed. The sisters plan to mark the fifth anniversary of his captivity at events in the Fort Collins and Denver areas. They admitted that anniversary dates can be stressful, but said the university community and Fort Collins residents have been very supportive. Throughout Fort Collins, yellow ribbons flutter from trees, houses, offices, schools and churches. Those ribbons routinely are replaced with new ones. But the ribbon tied on the Sutherlands' door is weather-beaten. ``We're not taking it down until he's released,'' Joan said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev the Salesman Pays a Call on the Midwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to UPDATE with Gorbachevs' arrival in San Francisco; picks up 5th graf, ``Earlier in ... his limousine.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: After four days of superpower summitry, a glad-handing Mikhail Gorbachev dashed through this Midwestern metropolis like a traveling salesman Sunday, wooing street crowds and pitching the new Soviet Union to business leaders. The Soviet leader urged some of the United States' most prominent capitalists to continue to help with his country's radical economic reforms. ``When we begin such a project, we feel we need American business because it is so big,'' he said at an evening meeting attended by such corporate luminaries as the heads of Anheuser-Busch Co., Pepsico, Amoco Corp. and Dow Chemical Co. After a Minnesota visit of about seven hours, Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, flew to San Francisco, the last stop on their American tour. They arrived at 10:25 p.m. PDT. Earlier in the day, about 6,000 people, some waiting at least six hours, stood at the state Capitol in St. Paul just to see him zip past in his limousine. Gorbachev repeatedly waded into crowds to shake hands and exchange small talk, prompting squeals of delight and chants of ``Gorby! Gorby!'' Some admirers waved white handkerchiefs called ``GorbaChiefs,'' reminiscent of the ``Homer Hankies'' brandished by Minnesota Twins fans during the 1987 World Series. When Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, stepped from their limo and walked the last block to Gov. Rudy Perpich's mansion for a luncheon, most people shouted ``Welcome!'' but a few carried Lithuanian, Estonian and Latvian flags. Guests at the luncheon included Perpich, British publisher Robert Maxwell and Whitney MacMillan, chairman of the Minnesota-based Cargill Inc., the Soviets' largest private trading partner. To commemorate the visit, Maxwell announced the creation of a research center called the Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology, to be located in the Twin Cities area. ``I see this as yet another element of common cooperation which seems to be emerging and developing between our countries, between many countries of the world and at the human level, too,'' Gorbachev said. The Soviet president told the business leaders that his country has spent the past five years sorting out ways to reform the national economy and will need help, among other things, with changing decades-old management ideas. ``The important question is, `What kind of Soviet Union does the president and the U.S. people want to see?' '' Gorbachev asked. ``A Soviet Union that lacks confidence, that is not stable, that is in turmoil? Or does America want to see the Soviet Union as a noble democratic state which is moving toward new forms of life?'' He expressed gratitude for 150 joint business ventures now under way with companies in the United States, involving food distribution, automation, medicine and farming. American companies doing business in the Soviet Union will be rewarded with expanded business in the future, he said, but he warned that ``those who just stand on the sidelines, who do not want to risk,'' will remain on the sidelines when the Soviet economy is prospering. If his economic reforms are successful, he said, the civic unrest in the Soviet Union will end. ``I think we saw a leader who admitted that his country has made a lot of mistakes and they're willing to change,'' said best-selling author Harvey Mackay who owns an envelope business in Minneapolis. ``His leadership insisted on having all of these major business leaders here,'' said former Vice President Walter Mondale, who also attended the session. ``He obviously wants them to think about investing.'' Mrs. Gorbachev made a separate visit to the home of 13-year-old Lisa Watson, an actress who visited the Soviet Union last year in an exchange with a Moscow children's theater. Before Mrs. Gorbachev arrived at the house, she made two unannounced stops: to a Mexican deli takeout and to a drugstore, where she bought macadamia nuts and two packages of Super Mario Brothers Nintendo bubblegum. Gorbachev left Washington earlier Sunday after wrapping up his summit with President Bush. At a news conference, the leaders proclaimed their meeting a success, though they still disagree on the Kremlin's treatment of the Baltic independence movement and on plans for a united Germany. That preoccupation with international matters was left behind in Washington. In Minneapolis and San Francisco, Gorbachev planned to focus on American ways that might be used to rescue the lumbering Soviet economy. Minneapolis was festooned with red ribbons and welcome signs in Cyrillic to greet the Soviet leader, and the entire visit was aired live on local television. A visit to a family farm outside Minneapolis, reminiscent of Nikita Khrushchev's 1959 visit to an Iowa farm, was canceled. Khrushchev was the last Soviet leader to venture into the nation's heartland. Sunday's visit by Gorbachev capped off frenzied preparations begun in mid-May. Greeting signs popped up in the airport and on the interstate, companies took out welcome ads in Sunday's newspapers, stores sold T-shirts. But not everyone was enthusiastic. ``I don't understand the adulation. This is still a man who represents a regime that starved, tortured and killed many many people,'' said Martha Anderson, president of the Ukrainian-American Community Center in northeastern Minneapolis. Minnesota has emphasized its common bond with the Soviet Union. Both have mining and farming areas, frigid climates and a common heritage: many Eastern Europeans settled in the Iron Range in the northern part of the state. In Perpich's letter of invitation delivered Feb. 26 to the Soviet ambassador in Washington, he noted the Twin Cities had much of what might interest the Soviet Union: corporations that are leaders in medical technology, computers, microelectronics, agriculture, health-care and financial services. Advanced computer technology is another area in which the Soviets hope to make great leaps in a short time, and Gorbachev included a visit to Control Data Corp., which is producing computers for the Soviets to improve nuclear power plant safety. The state trade office says more than 35 Minnesota companies are doing business with the Soviets. Control Data, a company for which Perpich once worked, sold the first large computers to the Soviet Union in 1968. The trip by Gorbachev, who has been to New York and Washington in earlier visits, marks the first extended U.S. tour by a Soviet leader since Leonid Brezhnev visited in 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Goes to Billionaire's Banquet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with Gorbachev's arrival, 5th graf to DELETE reference to meeting with Minnesota farm family; picks up 6th graf pvs, ``U.S. companies ... economic issues.''
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev, stalking business for the failing Soviet economy, ventures into the West Coast den of capitalism Monday at a banquet for billionaires and millionaires. Gorbachev, who arrived in California at 10:25 p.m. PDT Sunday, will meet titans of industry in the plush Venetian Room of the Fairmont Hotel as he pursues investors in the Soviet Union's opening markets and seeks to position his country as a Pacific Rim trading partner. The lunch with 150 executives from more than 100 companies, including oil, banking, food, entertainment, airline, hotel, real estate and computer giants, is of crucial importance to the Soviet president and his audience. The Soviets need hard cash, manufacturing expertise and business alliances as they transform their staggering, centralized economy into one that incorporates free-market principles. Gorbachev's Sunday agenda included meetings in Minnesota with regional business and agriculture leaders and at the Minneapolis-based Control Data Corp. computer company. U.S. companies see opportunities in the Soviet Union but are worried about political uncertainty, monetary problems, bureaucratic tangles, and other social and economic issues. ``Anybody who says there's a bonanza out there for us doesn't know what he's talking about,'' said Walter Hoadley, senior economist at BankAmerica Corp. and a fellow at the conservative Hoover Institution. ``But my concern is that American companies will wait until it's safe. Then it'll be too late. The Japanese and Europeans certainly are probing. We have already moved too slowly. Wait-and-see may be the prudent thing, but it may not be the wisest thing.'' Even before Gorbachev arrived on the West Coast, Chevron Corp. on Saturday announced an agreement to explore and develop the Soviets' newly discovered oil field near the Caspian Sea. Its estimated oil reserves are more than double those of the Alaska North Slope. The deal, Soviet and American officials said, was an example of the commercial contacts that would flourish under the trade agreement President Bush and Gorbachev signed Friday. Gorbachev has another important meeting on his San Francisco agenda _ a first-ever meeting with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo. In addition to putting pressure on North Korea to open up and move toward unification with the South, the Gorbachev-Roh summit could accelerate Soviet-South Korean trade, which doubled to $600 million last year and is expected to surpass $1 billion in 1990. ``The Soviets desire to link themselves to the economic dynamism of the Pacific nations,'' said John W. Lewis, chairman of the International Strategic Institute at Stanford University, where Gorbachev is speaking before the business luncheon. ``They obviously are blocked from being full participants by the state of their own economy. But the Asian countries have no doubt that Gorbachev has a strong interest in the Soviet Union becoming a major player in Asia.'' The billionaires Gorbachev will dine with include William Hewlett and David Packard, co-founders of computer giant Hewlett-Packard Co.; Joan Kroc, primary shareholder of McDonald's Corp.; and Ernest and Julio Gallo, the world's richest winemakers. More than a dozen other guests are worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Nearly all are wealthy leaders of multibillion-dollar companies, such as Apple Computer Inc.'s John Sculley, Walt Disney Co.'s Michael Eisner, Oracle Systems Corp.'s Lawrence Ellison, Chevron Corp.'s Kenneth Derr, and Unocal Corp.'s Richard Stegemeier. Gorbachev, whose reported salary of $77,760 pales beside those of his lunchmates, may be the poorest man in the room. But he will be offering the promise of a potentially lucrative market for those companies willing to invest now in his country. ``I've watched the Soviets go from arrogance to humility,'' said Hoadley, 73. ``They've got some real problems. Their biggest problem is they have a system that is not designed to take risks. We've gotten a lot of burned fingers over there and we're reluctant to take risks. I'm afraid that America is becoming more of a provincial nation economically at a time when international business is so important.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says `Time Has Not Come' For Him To Visit Israel
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has rejected Israel's invitation to visit and see for himself whether many Soviet Jewish refugees are settling in the occupied Arab territories. ``I will be frank, the time has not yet come to go there,'' he said Sunday evening during a brief stop in the American heartland following his four-day summit with President Bush in Washington. In Jerusalem, Israeli Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz issued the invitation to Gorbachev after the Soviet leader threatened to cut the number of Jews allowed to leave the Soviet Union. During a joint news conference with Bush at the end of the summit Sunday morning, Gorbachev said the Soviet Union ``is being bombarded by a lot of criticism'' from Arab states because of the recent rise in the numbers of Jews leaving his country for Israel. Unless the Israeli government provides guarantees that the refugees will not settle in lands captured from Arab countries by Israel during the 1967 Six-Day War, he warned, the Soviet Union will consider reducing the flow. ``We must give further thought to it, in terms with what we can do with issuing permits for exit,'' he said. Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is at an all-time high. About 35,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel so far this year, and the figure is expected to reach as high as 150,000. About 1 million Soviets are seeking permission to emigrate. Israel responded to Gorbachev's statement by reiterating that it has no policy of settling Soviet emgirants in the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip, where Palestinians have been in revolt for 29 months. The occupied territories are home to 1.7 million Palestinians and about 70,000 Jewish settlers _ of which Israel says only about 200 are Soviet refugees. Israeli leaders have repeatedly said that new immigrants are free to settle anywhere they wish in Israel, but that the government does not attempt to steer them to the West Bank or Gaza Strip. Arab leaders have contended that Jewish emigration to the West Bank and Gaza Strip is a threat to Palestinian rights and peace in the region. ``I will tell you frankly, let the leaders of Israel think about what has been said today in Washington, so they don't turn out to be the only people in the world who don't understand,'' Gorbachev told reporters in Minneapolis. Gorbachev said he and Bush had discussed the situation in the Middle East ``several times'' during the summit. ``Recent years have seen major accomplishments in turning around the situation in the Arab countries ... and there is a very real chance of reaching agreement and unraveling this knot,'' he added. ``Look, there's been a lot of change in the Arab position. Realistic change.'' Israeli leaders said Gorbachev's warning violated the spirit of his own reforms in the Soviet Union. ``The Soviet Union is changing direction, and it cannot be that only regarding Jews it would take a step that leads it backward and not forward, to progress and freedom,'' Deputy Prime Minister David Levy said. The Soviet leader's remarks also were condemned by U.S. Jewish leaders. Malcolm Hoenlein, executive director of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, said the comments were undoubtedly ``a response to the unrelenting Arab campaign to halt Jewish emigration.'' ``But even to suggest a restriction of Jewish emigration to Israel is unacceptable,'' Hoenlein said. The United States has both opposed Israeli settlements in the occupied territories and pushed hard for freer Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union. During the summit, Bush signed a trade agreement giving the Soviets valuable trade privileges but said he would not submit it to Congress for ratification until the Soviet legislature enacted liberalized emigration laws.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Gorbachev quote from Minneapolis.
DOC.TEXT:
Selected quotes from the final day of the U.S.-Soviet summit:
``President Bush would have resolved an issue like this within 24 hours, and he would have restored the validity of his constitution within 24 hours on any state.'' Mikhail Gorbachev, commenting on his handling of Lithuania and how Bush would react if a U.S. state tried to secede in the same fashion.
``The linkage is between the emigration _ and that's it.'' Bush, on whether the administration wants Soviet concessions on Baltic independence _ in addition to liberalized Soviet emigration policies _ as prerequisites for a U.S.-Soviet trade pact.
``I don't think you have chosen the best place for clarifying our internal problems _ but c'est la vie, as they say,'' Gorbachev, to a Soviet journalist who asked him about disputes back home with his political rival, Boris Yeltsin.
``I agree there are settlements that go contrary to the United States' policy, and I will continue to represent the policy, reiterate the policy, and try to persuade the government of Israel that it is counterproductive to go forward with additional settlements in these territories.'' Bush, on new Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
``The Soviet Union is now being bombarded by a lot of criticism from Arab countries. ... Either after these meetings and exchanges with the president of the United States of America on this particular issue, our concern will be heeded in Israel and they will make certain conclusions. Or else we must give further thought to it in terms of what we can do with issuing permits for exit.'' Gorbachev, on Arab complaints that Jews leaving the Soviet Union are populating new Israeli settlements in the occupied Arab territories.
``The important question is, `What kind of Soviet Union do the president and the U.S. people want to see?' A Soviet Union that lacks confidence, that is not stable, that is in turmoil? Or does America want to see the Soviet Union as a noble democratic state which is moving toward new forms of life?'' Gorbachev speaking to U.S. business leaders in Minneapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Both Showman and Salesman in First Midwest Trip
LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: In his first trip to the nation's heartland, Mikhail Gorbachev charmed and cajoled, then got down to business _ the business of renewing old corporate ties and building new ones to revive the Soviet economy. In a seven-hour visit to the Twin Cities on Sunday, the Soviet leader, fresh from the Washington summit, was both showman and salesman, making impromptu forays into crowds chanting ``Gorby! Gorby!'' and then urging corporate luminaries to invest in his country. Mrs. Gorbachev, meanwhile, took an unexpected shopping trip, stopping at a Mexican deli and a drugstore, where she bought bubble gum and macadamia nuts, but turned away a Snickers bar, saying, ``Nyet, Nyet, I'm on a diet.'' She also got some insight into the mechanics of capitalism, questioning workers about salaries and work policies. The Gorbachevs flew late Sunday to San Francisco, where they'll spend the day today before heading back to Moscow in the evening. Their Minnesota visit included a luncheon at Gov. Rudy Perpich's mansion, a Twin Cities tour, a meeting with more than 100 business and agricultural leaders, and a stop at Control Data Corp., which is plannning to sell $32 million of computers to the Soviet Union to improve nuclear power plant safety. A scheduled trip to the Brand family farm in Farmington, south of Minneapolis, was canceled because of time constraints and blustery weather _ steady drizzle, strong winds and 50-degree temperatures. The family, however, met the Gorbachevs on the airport tarmac before their departure. ``You could see why they are loved as they are. They're very personable,'' said Richard Brand. The Gorbachevs also dazzled the thousands who lined up 15 to 20 deep in some spots, cheering, squealing and waving white hankies called ``GorbaChiefs,'' reminiscent of the ``Homer Hankies'' brandished by Minnesota Twins fans during the 1987 World Series. The couple left their limousine three times to work and woo the crowds with handshakes, waves and smiles _ and, for a lucky few, a word or two. Another local family, the Watsons, had a personal audience with Mrs. Gorbachev, who spent nearly an hour in their home chatting about such matters as mortgage and food costs. Their 13-year-old daughter, Lisa Watson, is in a children's theater group that has traveled to the Soviet Union. ``I felt love in that woman,'' Mrs. Watson said. ``She looked you right in the eye and locked you right in.'' Not everyone was so enamored of the couple, however. Small groups of protesters flashed such signs as ``Hands off the Baltics'' and ``Gorby Go Home'' in areas along the motorcade route. To commemorate the visit, British publisher Robert Maxwell, who attended the luncheon, announced the creation of a research center called the Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology, to be located in the Twin Cities area. ``I see this as yet another element of common cooperation which seems to be emerging and developing between our countries, between many countries of the world and at the human level, too,'' Gorbachev said. The serious side of Sunday's stop in the Midwest also was reflected in Gorbachev's meeting with more than 100 business and agricultural leaders, some of whom have longstanding relations with the Soviet leader. ``I see so many old friends, who even in the most difficult periods of our relations showed themselves to be real business people,'' he said as he looked out over the group. Noting the 150 joint business ventures under way with U.S. companies, he called for more partnerships in this turbulent time. ``When we begin such a project we feel we need American business because it is so big,'' Gorbachev said. He warned that those executives ``who just stand on the sidelines, who do not want to risk'' will remain on the sidelines when the Soviet economy is prospering. ``We'll make sure that is so,'' he said. ``The important question is, `What kind of Soviet Union do the president and the U.S. people want to see?' '' Gorbachev asked. ``A Soviet Union that lacks confidence, that is not stable, that is in turmoil? Or does America want to see the Soviet Union as a noble democratic state which is moving toward new forms of life?'' As he stood at the base of the stairway to the plane, preparing to leave for California, the Soviet leader was asked in English by a reporter: ``Mr. President, what did you think of your visit in Minnesota?'' His response: ``Prekrasno.'' In Russian, it means ``beautiful.''

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Candidates Exchange Sharp Barbs in First Debate
DOC.TEXT: In the first debate between Peru's presidential candidates, Alberto Fujimori accused Mario Vargas Llosa of taking drugs, and Vargas Llosa attacked his opponent for coming ``with his samurai sword held high.'' The two-hour televised debate Sunday night came a week before the runoff election between Vargas Llosa, the internationally known novelist, and Fujimori, an agronomist who has capitalized on his Japanese background and claimed it could help attract foreign investment to Peru. Fujimori, a political unknown when he launched his campaign, surprised the heavily favored Vargas Llosa in the first-round balloting on April 8. He finished with 24.6 percent of the vote to Vargas Llosa's 27.6 percent, forcing a runoff because no candidate received an absolute majority. But the 51-year-old Fujimori has since picked up support, and recent polls show him leading by five percentage points. Analysts viewed the debate as critical for Vargas Llosa, 54. Security was tight as more than 100 police stood guard during the debate at Lima's civic center. Authorities closed off most of the nearby downtown area to traffic. Leftist guerrillas have staged several attacks in the Peruvian capital in recent weeks. The exchanges in Sunday's debate were marked more by personal attacks than by specific policy proposals. In his opening statement, Fujimori accused Vargas Llosa's center-right Democratic Front coalition of conducting a dirty campaign and spreading insults against him. Vargas Llosa countered by claiming that Fujimori offered only ``generalities and banalities, instead of specific proposals.'' He said that Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, ``came with his samurai sword held high.'' The two candidates differed on their policies toward turning around Peru's moribund economy and controlling cocaine trafficking. Vargas Llosa reiterated his campaign pledges to get the government bureaucracy off the backs of private business and sell off state-owned companies. ``This is the great proposal of the Democratic Front: to privatize the public sector,'' he said. Vargas Llosa pledged to reduce inflation from the current 2,000 percent annually to 10 percent within one year. He also promised to pursue a program of crop substitution to guarantee peasants a good price for legal crops and wean them away from growing coca for the billion-dollar cocaine trade. Fujimori, who labels himself a centrist and independent, charged Vargas Llosa with proposing a program of ``economic shock'' that threatened jobs and salaries. ``To apply shock during a period of inflation serves only to make the problem worse,'' he said. He said he would maintain state companies and promised to ``drastically reduce inflation while maintaining salaries and jobs.'' He rejected any ``foreign intervention'' in the fight against drug trafficking. This was an apparent reference to the United States, which has offered to send military advisers to train Peruvian soldiers in anti-drug jungle warfare. Fujimori also referred to a magazine interview in which Vargas Llosa admitted to taking drugs. In response, Vargas Llosa said he tried drugs ``when I was 14 years old a couple of times.'' He said he had never used them since. In his closing statement, Fujimori provided the surprise of the evening when he held up a copy of Ojo, a newspaper that supports Vargas Llosa, which carried a headline saying the novelist had scored a ``knockout'' in the debate. ``How world communications have progressed,'' Fujimori quipped. After the debate, Fernando Viana, an executive of the newspaper, said the copy displayed by Fujimori was a fake.

DOC.HEAD: Michael Jackson Goes to Hospital Emergency Room for Chest Pains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout to UPDATE with spokesman saying Jackson has no history of heart problems, ADD background and byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Pop superstar Michael Jackson was admitted to a hospital emergency room Sunday night complaining of chest pains, officials said. Jackson, 31, was in stable condition and undergoing tests, said a statement issued by St. John's Hospital and Health Center spokeswoman Paulette Weir and Jackson spokesman Bob Jones. Lee Solters, another Jackson spokesman, said the singer and dancer has no history of heart problems. Solters would not comment further. Jackson was hospitalized in January 1984 after his hair caught fire when a smoke bomb misfired during the filming of a soft-drink commercial in Los Angeles. He suffered second-degree scalp burns. Jackson was catapulted into the public eye at age 5 with the Jackson Five family pop group. He went on to become a one-man phenomenon. He sold more than 100 million albums in the 1980s and won an unprecedented eight Grammy Awards for his 1982 release, ``Thriller,'' the most successful album of all time with sales of more than 40 million copies worldwide. His last album, ``Bad,'' released in 1987, spawned five No. 1 hits. The reclusive star, known for wearing one white glove onstage, has been celebrated as widely for his eccentricities as for his music and choreography. He has often gone out in public wearing a disguise, has had repeated cosmetic surgery, owns a menagerie of exotic pets and tried unsuccessfully to buy the bones of ``Elephant Man'' John Merrick.

DOC.HEAD: Mechanical Problems Leave NASA Wondering
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Mechanical problems are starting to take a toll on NASA's shuttle schedule, and the space agency is wondering whether the troubles are random or somehow related. Columbia stands silently at Launch Pad A this week, grounded first by a bad cooling valve and now by a mysterious hydrogen leak that threatens to push its astronomy mission into July or later. Hardly a month before, one of Discovery's power units had to be replaced at NASA's other shuttle launch pad, an unprecedented job that delayed the Hubble Space Telescope's ride into orbit. Despite the breakdowns, few blame the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``Imagining you can fly the shuttle without any problems is like trying to imagine you can drive to work without hitting any red lights,'' said John Pike, director of the Federation of American Scientists' space policy project. David Winterhalter, director of systems engineering and analysis for NASA, said the life of the shuttles _ the fact ``they've been around a while'' _ may be at the heart of the mechanical problems. John Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, says NASA should keep plugging away. ``What's the alternative? Quitting? We deal with the system we've got,'' he said. Problems with the thousands of components that comprise the shuttles _ nearly 90 tons without solid rocket boosters and external tank _ normally are discovered in the hangar. On Columbia and Discovery, the troubles were not spotted until they were at the launch pads. Replacing Columbia's cooling valve and Discovery's auxiliary power unit was the first time such work had ever been performed at the pad. Both resulted in two-week delays. And a shuttle launch had never been scrubbed during fueling until last Wednesday's Columbia scratch. ``I see it as the odds,'' said Brewster Shaw, deputy director of shuttle operations for NASA. ``It's complicated hardware. It's going to break once in a while. I don't get too depressed over that.'' NASA officials said they do not intend to scale down future flight plans as a result of this year's disruptions. Nine shuttle missions were scheduled for 1990, the same number as in 1985, which was the year before Challenger exploded and put the program on hold for 2{ years. One of the remaining six missions _ possibly Columbia's _ likely will slide into next year. ``You cannot anticipate all the problems,'' said NASA launch director Bob Sieck. A test is set for Wednesday in which Columbia's external tank will be partly filled with super-cold liquid hydrogen. Officials want to duplicate the conditions under which hydrogen escaped into the rear engine compartment during fueling for the scratched launch last Wednesday. Shaw said he doubts the test will pinpoint a cause that can be fixed easily at the pad. If so, Columbia will have to be returned to the hangar for repairs, making it July before the shuttle can lift off with seven astronauts and the $150 million Astro observatory. Columbia's last-minute problems would have halted the launch even if more stringent checks had not been added following the Challenger accident, NASA officials said. The same is true of Discovery's auxiliary power unit failure. NASA officials still believe each shuttle is capable of 100 flights. With a goal of 12 flights a year, that would keep the fleet aloft until the year 2020, said Keith Hudkins, chief of NASA's shuttle orbiter program. After that, he said, no one knows where the future lies. ``If tomorrow makes the anti-gravity machine that's always been in all the comic books, where you just push the button, obviously we would start working on that the day after tomorrow,'' Hudkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Family Meets Gorbachevs on Airport Tarmac Instead of in Barnyard
With PM-Gorbachev-Minn, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It was hardly the picturesque picnic-table setting the Brands had labored four days to perfect, but their airport tarmac meeting at least gave the farmers a chance to exchange gifts and conversation with Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev. Tired and behind schedule, the Gorbachevs canceled a scheduled 25-minute visit to the Brand farm Sunday in Farmington, about 20 miles south of Minneapolis. The Soviets had requested the farm tour as part of Gorbachev's seven-hour swing through the Twin Cities area. Instead, neighbors milked the cows Sunday night so the Brands and several family members could meet the Gorbachevs at the airport. ``You could tell they felt very badly they couldn't make it,'' Richard Brand said of the airport meeting. ``You could see why they are loved as they are. They're very personable.'' The Brands presented the Gorbachevs with pictures of their farm and family and a basket of Minnesota-made foodstuffs, including cheese, jellies and buffalo jerky. The Soviet first family brought dolls for the Brands' grandchildren. ``They spent a lot of time with my grandson and my granddaughter,'' Brand said. ``You could tell they love kids.'' The Brands said they're sorry Gorbachev wasn't able to visit their farm and get a taste of rural American life. ``Let's face it, this is Russia's main problem _ food production,'' Brand said. ``It's a real serious problem in Russia. I'm disappointed that we couldn't show him a typical, American average farm.'' The Brands, who run their 240-acre farm with their two sons, milk 75 cows and raise alfalfa, corn and soybeans. In all they have 250 cows. ``We'll go back to what we like best,'' Brand said after four days of readying the farm for their expected visitor. ``We're going to rest and move a little slower.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo to Seek Third Gubernatorial Term, Won't Rule Out White House Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Convention begins noon EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo formally declared he'll seek a third term but wouldn't promise he'll complete it. He refused to rule out running for president in 1992. Cuomo's announcement Sunday of his re-election bid had been widely anticipated, and he is expected to win virtually unanimous support from delegates at the two-day state Democratic convention opening today in Albany. His acceptance speech is planned for Tuesday. His Republican challenger will be Pierre Rinfret, a millionaire economist and political newcomer nominated at the GOP convention last week. Herbert London, a dean at New York University, is running on the Conservative Party ticket. Cuomo told cheering supporters that his heart was in being governor. ``The truth is, Matilda and I don't want to do anything else,'' Cuomo, 57, said as he and his wife visited the convention hall Sunday. But he kept open the possibility he'd run for president in 1992. He refused to pledge to serve the full four-year gubernatorial term. ``That wouldn't work at all,'' he said. ``What would make you believe it?'' There was widespread speculation that Cuomo would run for president in 1988, but he decided against it. This year, state fiscal problems apparently have not deterred him from another gubernatorial bid. Three other Democratic governors beset by fiscal problems in the Northeast _ Massachusetts' Michael Dukakis, Connecticut's William O'Neill and Vermont's Madeleine Kunin _ have announced they won't seek re-election this year. Facing his third straight year of deficits, Cuomo recently approved a record $1.8 billion tax increase package to keep his budget balanced. That package included a 15 percent business tax surcharge and the delay of a scheduled income tax cut that had been due New Yorkers this year. The Canadian-born Rinfret, 66, has pledged to make Cuomo's handling of New York's economic problems a campaign issue. He has already begun comparing Cuomo to Dukakis, the failed 1988 Democratic presidential candidate. Cuomo has the advantage of incumbency and a national reputation as one of the Democratic Party's most eloquent speakers. He also has more than $7 million in his campaign warchest and a stable of veteran political operatives, led by son Andrew Cuomo. Cuomo and Rinfret both advocate abortion rights but disagree on capital punishment. Cuomo eight times has vetoed legislation to restore the death penalty in New York state. Rinfret has called for the electric chair to be used against murderers and major drug dealers. In 1982, Cuomo pulled a major upset when he beat then-New York City Mayor Edward Koch for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Cuomo narrowly defeated millionaire Republican businessman Lewis Lehrman in the general election. Cuomo gained national prominence in 1984 when he delivered a rousing keynote address at the Democratic National Convention. Two years later, he won re-election to a second term as governor with a record 65 percent of the vote to 32 percent for Republican Andrew O'Rourke.

DOC.HEAD: `Typical' Family Delighted by Raisa's Visit
With PM-Gorbachev-Minn, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A ``typical'' American family with four kids and a dog shared coconut macaroons with Raisa Gorbachev around their dining room table and said the moment was ``too wonderful'' to bother taking photographs. ``It exceeded anything we could have expected. We won't sleep for a week,'' said Steve Watson, 39. The Watsons chatted about family finances with Mikhail Gorbachev's wife during her visit Sunday, part of the Gorbachevs' seven-hour stopover in Minnesota. The visit to the white stucco home with green awnings was supposed to last 20 minutes, but the Soviet first lady stayed an hour. ``I think for the same reason that we wouldn't take autographs, we didn't need pictures. It was too wonderful an experience,'' Watson said. ``I think she is wonderful,'' declared 13-year-old Lisa Watson, whose performance as part of a children's theater exchange in Moscow last year helped lead to her family being chosen as Mrs. Gorbachev's hosts. Wearing a red and white striped dress and a bow in her hair, Lisa greeted Mrs. Gorbachev in Russian and gave her a bouquet and a hug on the sidewalk before introducing her parents, sister and two brothers. Karen Watson, 38, said Mrs. Gorbachev put everyone at ease right away. ``She had all of the press people sit on the floor and said, `Let's have a private chat,''' said Mrs. Watson, an obstetric nurse. Watson, an elementary school art teacher, praised Mrs. Gorbachev's ability to communicate despite the language difference. ``She would reach out her hand, and it was almost like that was a third language. I really liked holding that hand. It was a beautiful hand,'' he said as his wife began to laugh. ``I'll tell you, I felt love in that room,'' said Mrs. Watson. Lisa wound up with a pen pal. ``I told her that I would like to go back and she seemed happy about that. She gave me her address so I can write to her,'' she said. An estimated 6,000 people jammed yards, sidewalks and streets and even climbed trees for a better view of Mrs. Gorbachev as she arrived. The Watsons had been recommended to Gov. Rudy Perpich's staff as a typical middle-class family by Jon Cranney, artistic director of the Children's Theater Co. of Minneapolis, which took part in the theater exchange. Still, the family is hardly typical _ Lisa and 11-year-old sister Stephanie appeared in an ABC miniseries filmed in the Twin Cities, ``The Voices Within: The Lives of Truddi Chase.'' The family also includes 7-year-old Tom, 6-year-old Will and dog Bonnie, who was kept out of sight during the visit. Mrs. Gorbachev inquired about the family's income and food budget and asked whether they had completed payments on their home. ``She went to the back door, looked out and wanted to know if that was all of our yard and if that was our garage, which the Secret Service men were all in,'' Mrs. Watson said. Earlier, Mrs. Gorbachev paid unscheduled visits to a Mexican ``takeout'' and a drugstore, where she picked up macadamia nuts, Super Mario Brothers Nintendo bubblegum and insight into the capitalist system. ``Does your salary depend on the merchandise you sell?'' she asked employees. She also asked how much vacation time employees are given. The Soviet first lady was curious about the contents of a Snickers bar. But in the end she rejected the candy. ``Nyet, Nyet,'' she said. ``I'm on a diet.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachevs Reward Chilly, Wet Minnesotans With Handshakes, Greetings
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shouts of ``Gorby! Gorby!'' and a ``Mr. Gorbachev is a Cool Dude'' sign helped lure Mikhail Gorbachev away from his official escorts and onto Minnesota streets. Not that he really needed any urging. The Soviet president lived up to his reputation for spontaneously wading into crowds Sunday despite the presence of protesters whose chants competed with cheers from most onlookers. ``Thank you all for your feelings,'' Gorbachev said through an interpreter during one hand-shaking foray in St. Paul. ``I wish happiness and well-being to the people of Minnesota and this state.'' At one stop, Gorbachev's wife accepted from an onlooker a hand-painted sign that read, ``We love Mikhail, Raisa.'' ``I've never seen any reception like that for a political figure,'' said Gov. Rudy Perpich. Gorbachev smiled and often stopped to say a few words. ``My heart started pounding so fast,'' said Jan Michel of Hopkins, who shook Gorbachev's hand. ``He said a word, but we don't know what it was,'' said Michel, part of a 77-member bell-ringing group that performed as the Gorbachevs arrived. When the Gorbachevs first emerged from their limousine near the governor's mansion, they approached a group of about 200 protesters but did not talk to them. The protesters flew flags of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. ``He's a very charming man, but you have to remember he does have iron teeth,'' said protester Karin Berkholtz. Others demonstrated against Soviet involvement in Afghanistan, Vietnam and Ethiopia and Soviet treatment of Jews. Police had to scramble as Gorbachev jumped out of his limousine or crossed a street to shake a hand. At the state Capitol, however, some 6,000 supporters and demonstrators who had waited up to seven hours got only disappointment. Gorbachev stuck his hand out his car window and waved, but his motorcade didn't even slow. Many people ran the length of the Capitol lawn, leaping hedges and jumping curbs, to get a look. ``It did go pretty fast,'' said Shelly Hanson, who with her husband, son, daughter and nephew made the 2{-hour trip from Alexandria and waited two hours for the motorcade. ``Obviously, it would have been nicer if he shook hands with some people here, but we would make the same trip again. We got such a good look and him, it made him seem so real. We were pretty excited.''
