DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats Wind Up 9-Year Life in British Politics
DOC.TEXT: The Social Democratic Party has dissolved itself after nine years of trying to create a moderate third force in British politics. ``You have to realize, sadly, that our membership is not large enough to lay claim to be a democratic party,'' party leader David Owen told reporters Sunday after the party's national committee voted 17-5 to suspend its constitution. Owen said party membership had collapsed to 6,200 from a peak 68,000 soon after the Social Democrats were launched in January 1981. Party organizers said a number of members had not paid dues for the year. Owen is one of three legislators the party has in the 650-member House of Commons. The three will continue to hold their seats as Independent Social Democrats. Owen and three other former Cabinet ministers, then leading members of the Labor Party, had formed the new party promising to ``break the mold of British politics.'' They sought the middle ground between the dominant Conservative and Labor Parties, hoping to eventually displace Labor, which they accused of going too far to the left. Many analysts predicted Labor would never achieve power again after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservatives won a second general election victory in 1983, then consolidated it in 1987. But the Social Democrats not only never got within sight of their target. They never even managed to displace the old centrist Liberal Party, with whom they formed an uneasy alliance that won 22 parliamentary seats in the 1987 general election. Owen refused to merge with the Liberals, but a majority of his party agreed and formed the Social and Liberal Democrats. David Sainsbury, a grocery chain multimillionaire, told Owen he was no longer willing to continue his financial backing of the fading party. Meanwhile, Labor has undergone a rejuvenation under leader Neil Kinnock. It has dumped leftist policies and extreme leftist members and benefited from a slump in popularity for Mrs. Thatcher's governing Conservatives stemming from inflation, cuts in the National Health Service and a new tax to finance local services levied on all adults instead of just property owners.

DOC.HEAD: Events in the Soviet Union
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Latest developments in the Soviet Union:

POLITICS _ The Supreme Soviet legislature was to hear a report on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the United States. The Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian republic, chaired by renegade Communist Boris N. Yeltsin, also meets and is to select a vice president and first vice president.

SUMMIT COVERAGE _ From live coverage of the Washington summit to close-up reports showing the Soviet first lady kissing American children, Soviet television carries hours of reports about Gorbachev's high-profile trip. There have been special broadcasts, interrupting regular programming, of Gorbachev's activities and a regular summit feature called ``American Diary,'' including light reports about life in the United States.

HUMAN RIGHTS - The International Helsinki Federation, a group that monitors compliance with the Helsinki Accords, ends two days of hearings on Soviet human rights in a test of whether the Soviet Union will tolerate greater public discussion of its past record of abuses.

EMIGRATION _ Soviet refuseniks are indignant over Gorbachev's warning that he might reduce the number of Jews allowed to emigrate if Israel continues to settle them in occupied territories. ``It is a human right to be able to emigrate,'' says Leonid Stonov, a spokesman for Soviet Jews.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Given Letter From California's Armenians
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian welcomed Mikhail Gorbachev to California with a letter on behalf of the state's Armenians conveying their hope for greater safety in the violence-torn Soviet republic of Armenia. Gorbachev, who flew to San Francisco late Sunday after spending much of the day in Minneapolis, canceled a late evening tea with the governor, but the two spoke outside the Soviet consul general's residence. Deukmejian told the Soviet president that California wants to expand trade with the Soviets. The governor, who is of Armenian descent, also presented Gorbachev with a letter from Deukmejian about the desires of California's Armenians. ``They're very supportive of what (Gorbachev's) trying to do in the Soviet Union and hope that he will be able to provide greater protection and safety for the people there,'' Deukmejian said. Many Armenians have been killed in ethnic and political strife in the southern U.S.S.R. Deukmejian gave the Soviet leader a clock bearing the governor's seal, and Gorbachev gave Deukmejian a medal in honor of Californians' assistance to Armenian earthquake victims. A high school marching band played the Soviet national anthem as Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, stepped off a plane that landed at 10:25 p.m., more than an hour late. Gorbachev greeted Mayor Art Agnos and other local politicians as he moved across the tarmac. A motorcade sped the Gorbachev to the Soviet consul general's home, where about 1,000 people gathered outside police cordons. Many began chanting after the motorcade sped past. Some held candles or waved placards expressing their secessionist wishes for some Baltic states. One sign read, ``Act Like Lincoln, Free Slave Nations.'' Gorbachev failed to make one of his frequent unannounced forays into the crowd. ``I'm from East Germany. I should have met him,'' said Marie Istel, who lives across the street from the consul general. ``He's a great guy. I'm glad he took the (Berlin) Wall down. It's just amazing. It would have never happened without him.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say King Shows Signs of Improvement
DOC.TEXT: Doctors said today that there were signs of improvement in the paralysis condition of Norway's King Olav, who suffered a stroke late Saturday. But they warned of an approaching infection of his lungs. ``Under the circumstances His Majesty the King had a quiet night and slept a good part of the night. There is still a paralysis in the left side of his body, but an improvement has occurred so that His Majesty to a certain extent can move his leg,'' doctors Rolf Nyberg-Hansen and Erling Brodwall announced in a press statement. They said the king is fully conscious and can communicate. ``Early Monday the king had a light increase in body temperature, and there is sign of an approaching infecton of his lungs,'' the doctors said. King Olav, at 86 the world's oldest reigning monarch, was taken to Rikshospitalet last Tuesday with a mild infection of his pericardium. The stroke came one day after the hospital decided to let the king remain at the hospital for observation.

DOC.HEAD: Journal Report Faults Death Penalty System in South
DOC.TEXT: Many defense lawyers in capital punishment cases in the South are inexperienced in handling such cases, a law publication reported today. The National Law Journal, which studied nearly 100 death-penalty cases in six states, also said standards for appointing lawyers to poor defendants are ``inadequate or nonexistent.'' Texas, Mississippi and Florida have no statewide standards, Georgia's are not enforced by courts or the law and Louisiana's allow for the appointment of lawyers with no experience in criminal law, it said. Lawyers' requests for money to hire investigators and experts often are denied, the journal added. The weekly publication studied cases in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas, in which nearly 80 percent of the executions in the United States have been carried out since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976. Of 60 lawyers interviewed who had clients on death row, half of them said it was their first such case, the journal said. The law newspaper also said it checked the professional records of about 1,000 trial lawyers in states that have handled capital punishment cases since 1976 and found that death-penalty lawyers were more likely than other lawyers to have been disciplined. But the disciplinary actions, ranging from minor reprimands to disbarment, were not necessarily related to the capital punishment cases, it said. In Louisiana, 8.9 percent of the capital-punishment lawyers who were checked had undergone some form of professional discipline, compared with 0.19 percent of all Louisiana lawyers, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Stocks Inch Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen for the fifth consecutive trading day today, while share prices inched up on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 152.42 yen, up 0.25 yen from Friday's close of 152.17 yen. After opening at 152.65 yen, it ranged between 152.27 yen and 152.80 yen. The dollar now has gained 2.97 yen in five days. Currency dealers attributed today's rise to the successful summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Washington. ``The market expects that disarmament will help the United States shed its budget deficit, and it encouraged the purchase of the dollar,'' said a trader at Daiichi Kangyo Bank. THe dollar rose sharply in morning trading, but declined somewhat later on profit-taking. ``The market is not ready to push the dollar up beyond the 153-yen mark yet,'' said the dealer, speaking on condition of anonymity. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said overall sentiment is running in the dollar's favor because of fewer expectations of lower U.S. interest rates despite a decline in the latest U.S. unemployment figures. The U.S. Labor Department reported Friday that the nation's unemployment rate in May fell to 5.3 percent from 5.4 percent in April. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 34.25 points, or 0.10 percent, closing at 32,925.37. Securities dealers said shares rose because of a strong showing by the New York Stock Exchange at the end of last week. ``The Nikkei index rose moderately, but there really aren't any outstanding incentives other than bullishness in overseas markets,'' said Keiichi Nishida of Kidder Peabody. A dealer with Nikko Securities, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the market environment is improving. ``The key question is how long we can make this atmosphere last,'' he said. Dealers said large-capital shares, such as construction, heavy industries and petroleum, were rising while electronic shares were declining. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds edged up to 88.36 points at 5 p.m. from Friday's close of 88.04. The yield fell to 6.895 percent from the previous 6.960 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Awards Boat Use Rights in Divorce Case
DOC.TEXT: Boat custody, not child custody, was the sticking point in the Blairs' divorce. Circuit Judge Muriel Robinson settled it, ruling Friday that Michael Wayne Blair could keep the former couple's boat, motor and trailer, but Donna Lynne Blair could use them on one weekend each month. Attorneys agreed that Mrs. Blair should get the boat during the hours frequently set for child visitation in divorce cases, between 6 p.m. Friday and 6 p.m. Sunday. The judge also ordered Blair to show Mrs. Blair how to operate the boat safely, and ordered her to return Blair's motorcycle. Mrs. Blair has been granted custody of the couple's 6-year-old son, and Blair was ordered to provide child- and other support payments.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Of Thousands Rally Around the World On Crackdown Anniversary
LaserPhoto HK1
With PM-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 people in Hong Kong and thousands more in cities around the world held demonstrations to remember the hundreds who fell one year ago when Chinese troops crushed the pro-democracy movement. ``We won't forget June 4'' and ``We are not scared,'' read banners carried by demonstrators in Hong Kong who marched several miles Sunday from a downtown park to the local headquarters of China's Xinhua News Agency, the Communist government's de facto embassy. Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. About 200 demonstrators staged an overnight sit-in and candlelight vigil outside the Xinhua building. Several tried to force their way to the main entrance of the building but were blocked by police. Rallies also were staged in cities across the United States and in Britain, Czechoslovakia, Canada, France, Taiwan and Japan. Police estimated 100,000 people joined in the Hong Kong march, but organizers put the figure at more than 200,000. It was the biggest rally in the British colony since nearly 1 million people demonstrated last summer in support of China's pro-democracy movement. ``Only democracy can save China and we won't back down despite pressure from Beijing,'' said Szeto Wah, chairman of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movement in China, which organized the protest. China has labeled the alliance ``subversive'' for helping dissidents fleeing the mainland. In the United States, protest rallies were held in New York, Washington, San Francisco, Atlanta, Chicago, Boston and Buffalo, N.Y., among other cities. Nearly 2,500 people gathered on the steps of the U.S. Capitol in Washington to hear Chinese student leaders evoke the horror of last June 3-4, when Chinese troops moved against demonstrators in Beijing and other cities, killing hundreds and perhaps thousands. ``There have been many tears ... the tears will become the seeds of change, the seeds of human rights, the seeds of freedom and democracy,'' said Chai Ling, who has been credited with organizing last year's hunger strikes in Beijing. In New York City, about 1,500 people demonstrated across the street from the Chinese Consulate. A sign naming the corner ``Tiananmen Square'' was authorized by Mayor Edward I. Koch before he left office. Tiananmen is the vast square in central Beijing that was occupied for weeks by pro-democracy protesters. The protesters later marched uptown to the Chinese Mission to the United Nations. More than a 1,000 people rallied outside the Chinese consulate in San Francisco. They carried a replica of the Goddess of Democracy statue, the symbol of the pro-democracy movement that was erected in Tiananmen and torn down during the military crackdown. About 400 people attended a rally at the University of Illinois at Chicago, where they heard Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., attack President Bush's announcement last month renewing China's most favored nation trading status. ``When the Chinese government murders its students and denies democracy to Chinese people, it does not deserve the most favored nation status and we will fight to see it does not receive it,'' Dixon said. In Prague, Czechoslovakia, where students helped lead last November's peaceful revolution that ousted the country's hard-line Communist leadership, hundreds of young people marched Sunday night to the Chinese Embassy, the state CTK news agency said. The demonstrators carried banners reading ``Freedom for China'' and ``You Cannot Crush Freedom with Tanks,'' CTK said. In Toronto, one of several Canadian cities where weekend rallies were held, about 8,000 people gathered at City Hall Sunday to mark the anniversary. Several hundred protesters in Paris led by fugitive student leader Wu'er Kaixi lit candles at the Plaza of the Rights of Man, dedicated to the declaration of human rights during the French Revolution in 1789. ``Last June 4 the Goddess of Democracy statue (in Tiananmen Square) was crushed by a tank. But not long afterward what was crushed was the Berlin Wall,'' said Wu'er, who is vice chairman of the Paris-based Federation for a Democratic China. ``I am convinced the Goddess of Democracy will once again stand in Tiananmen Square,'' he told the crowd. In Taiwan, organizers set up an altar for last June's victims as about 400 Taiwanese, braving rain, rallied in a Taipei park. Demonstrators in Tokyo gathered in a park with wreaths and banners in Chinese and Japanese saying, ``Long live freedom and democracy in Tiananmen Square'' and ``The June 4 massacre is the world's shame.'' In London, a Chinese student who said his friends were killed in the crackdown told an estimated 2,000 people outside the Chinese Embassy that the pro-democracy movement will rise again. ``China is a vast country and you cannot control the people with tanks and machine guns,'' said Li Lu, wearing a white flower to commemorate the dead.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Inventor of Semiconductor Chip Dead at 62
DOC.TEXT: Robert Noyce, an inventor of the computer chip that revolutionized electronics and helped usher in the Information Age, has died of a heart attack at 62. The computer pioneer died Sunday at Seton Medical Center. Working separately in the late 1950s, Noyce and Jack S. Kilby invented the integrated circuit, which made possible rapid gains in computer technology by putting the power of multiple transistors on a single, tiny chip. Computer chips, or semiconductors, are used in everything from personal computers and pocket calculators to microwaves and medical equipment. ``Very few things have changed the world as dramatically as the integrated circuit,'' said Robert M. White, president of the National Academy of Engineering. ``The development of the integrated circuit was the single most important event that helped to usher in the Information Age.'' Noyce was a founder in 1968 of Intel Corp., the nation's third-largest semiconductor producer. In 1988, he was appointed chief executive and president of Sematech, the government-industry group set up to help the United States recover world leadership in semiconductor manufacturing from the Japanese. Noyce was ``a legend within the electronics industry,'' spokesman Jim Jarrett said from Intel's Santa Clara, Calif., headquarters. ``Bob was an instrumental figure in creating what has become a $50 billion industry, and semiconductors are the driving force behind a $500 billion electronics industry,'' said Stan Victor, spokesman for Texas Instruments Inc. Noyce once said American leadership in semiconductor manufacturing is essential to the nation's economic and military security. He said U.S. companies must adopt the cooperative practices of their Japanese competitors to regain it. Noyce was born in Burlington, Iowa. He earned bachelor's degrees from Grinnell College in Grinnell, Iowa, in physics and mathematics. Noyce earned a Ph.D. in physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1953. He became a researcher at Philco Corp., then moved to the Shockley Semiconductor Laboratory. He co-founded Fairchild Semiconductor Corp. in 1957. He was working at Fairchild and Kilby at Texas Instruments when they invented the integrated circuit. Noyce was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame in 1983. Survivors include his wife, Ann Bowers, four children and 12 grandchildren. Funeral plans were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Pawnshops Seen as Lenders to Poor
DOC.TEXT: Jewelry, guns and guitars are the most common wares. Look around Stanton Myerson's pawnshop, and you'll also find a telescope, a diabetes monitor and a television marked ``prison approved.'' A steady stream of visitors moved through the store on a recent weekday afternoon in this economically depressed city near Philadelphia. Some were seeking loans; some were buying goods left as collateral and never reclaimed. ``Basically, it's blue-collar people, who live from paycheck to paycheck, who need at times extra funds to carry them over to the next paycheck,'' said Myerson, owner of Lou's Loan Inc. in Chester and Upper Darby. Although widely overlooked by policymakers and researchers, pawnshops are an important but costly source of credit to the poor, according to a recent study by Swarthmore College economics professor John P. Caskey and student Brian J. Zikmund. Millions of Americans borrow about $50 at a time, typically reclaiming their goods in two to three months, the study found. They pay interest and fees ranging from an annual 36 percent in Pennsylvania and New Jersey to 240 percent in Oklahoma. ``Most pawnshop customers come from low-income economic groups and are probably ineligible for bank or finance company credit,'' Caskey and Zikmund write in the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City's Economic Review journal. Pawnshops are on the rise in response to bank deregulation, falling real wages for production workers and a growing poverty rate, the researchers say. They deal in smaller amounts than traditional lenders like to handle and are seeking enhanced respectability in suburban shopping centers. Most pawnbrokers own perhaps two or three shops. Cash America Investments, a Fort Worth, Texas-based company with 100 pawnshops in three states, is traded on the American Stock Exchange. ``Policymakers obviously don't think a lot about pawnshops,'' Caskey said in an interview. ``There's a great deal of attention to banks and now, of course, savings and loans. But there's a phenomenon growing here that people aren't aware of. I think they ought to be paying some attention to it.'' An estimated 6,900 pawnshops provided about $689 million in loans in 1988, the study said. The amount was less than 0.1 percent of the nation's $744 billion outstanding consumer credit that year. But at an average of $50 each, some 35 million loans were spread among as much as 10 percent of the nation's adults, allowing for multiple loans to some customers. During the 1980s, the pawnbroking industry grew in almost all states for which data could be obtained, the researchers say. ``There is a movement now among pawnbrokers to try to clean up their image,'' Caskey said. ``They're trying to move out to the suburbs, provide well-lit, very clean, professionally managed stores, with squeaky clean images.'' He said he found little evidence to back up the popular perception that pawnshops are fronts for stolen goods. ``Obviously it happens, but it's very rare,'' he said. Pawnshops must register pawned goods and the names of individuals pawning them with police. Authorities can seize stolen items, costing the brokers both their collateral and the loaned money. In Oklahoma, just 0.15 percent of pawned goods were confiscated by police as stolen property, the study said. State and local governments regulate how much pawnshops can charge for interest, storage and insurance. In more than half the states, pawnshops can levy an effective 120 percent interest rate or more on the average-sized loan, the researchers say. State and local laws also determine what can be pawned. In Delaware, false teeth and artificial limbs are off-limits. Pennsylvania pawnshops must see proof of ownership before accepting workers' tools.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacist Gets Punches, Then Endorsement, From Black Activist
LaserPhoto LR2
DOC.TEXT: A black activist punched a white supremacist in the face on camera at a television studio, then endorsed him over a black candidate in the Republican primary for lieutenant governor. Little Rock activist Robert ``Say'' McIntosh said he wanted to get back at GOP runoff candidate Ralph Forbes for preventing him from burning an American flag during a demonstration on the steps of the state Capitol last July. ``That's for stepping on my rights,'' McIntosh said Sunday after he had stopped hitting Forbes and the candidate got up off the floor of the KARK television studio. McIntosh said the blows were not thrown for Forbes' views on race. Forbes supports racial segregation. Forbes said later he would press charges. The station broadcast the fracas on its night newscast. Forbes faces a black real estate salesman, Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris, in the June 12 runoff for the GOP nomination. Forbes got 46 percent of the vote and Harris 36 percent in last week's primary. McIntosh said he was going to vote for Forbes in the runoff. ``I've always favored white people who will tell you they don't like you,'' McIntosh said. ``If he prosecutes me, I'm still going to vote for him. I'm going to vote for the man for telling the truth of how he believes. ``Mr. Forbes can't do black people no harm; he hasn't got any money,'' McIntosh said. He offered no other reasons for endorsing Forbes. Forbes went to the studio for an interview during the station's evening newscast, and McIntosh arrived afterward. Forbes was about to present a Stars and Stripes, folded military style, to McIntosh in a symbolic gesture when he was sent flying, KARK anchor Jack Martin said. Martin said McIntosh showed up uninvited. ``I didn't know what to expect,'' Forbes said. ``I didn't know why he was endorsing me, and then he wanted to have the media, have the camera take a picture of Mr. Forbes presenting the American flag to him, and I'm standing there, holding the flag, and he comes up and sucker punches me. ``He came at me like a windmill,'' Forbes said. ``He got me down on the floor. I didn't attack him back.'' Newscast producer Melinda Dunston said the police were called, but that officers refused to make an arrest because they had not witnessed what happened. After the incident, she said, the two men ``calmed down and talked some more.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Sends Greetings to Soviet Bone-Marrow Recipient, `Our Hero'
With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet helicopter pilot being treated for radiation damage from the Chernobyl disaster got a get-well note from Mikhail Gorbachev praising him as a national hero who risked his life in the line of duty. The note to Anatoly Grishchenko was delivered Sunday by Yuriy Osipyan, a member of the Soviet President's Council and vice president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Grishchenko is recuperating at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, where he underwent a bone marrow transplant April 27. Osipyan, who is traveling with Gorbachev on a U.S. tour following the summit with President Bush, said Grishchenko was looking well and praised him as ``our national hero.'' In the handwritten note, translated by Osipyan, Gorbachev told Grishchenko, ``All the people know that you didn't spare your life in the line of duty.'' Grishchenko stood up inside a plastic isolation tent, which protects him from infection, and chatted for about 20 minutes, Osipyan said. Grishchenko, 53, developed a pre-leukemia condition after flying through hot radioactive gases to dump sand and wet concrete on the stricken reactor at Chernobyl, which exploded in 1986. The accident was blamed for at least 31 deaths. After arriving two months ago, Grishchenko underwent radiation and chemotherapy to kill his bone marrow, which produces blood cells. He then received a transfusion of marrow taken from a woman in Besancon, France. Despite a mouth inflammation and a lung infection common among transplant recipients, Grishchenko has shown no signs of rejecting the donor marrow, said Dr. Patrick Beatty, who heads Fred Hutchinson's Unrelated Transplantation Program. ``We're very pleased with how he's doing,'' Beatty said. Most transplant patients stay in the hospital about 100 days before moving to hospital-owned apartments nearby as outpatients. While doctors don't consider a patient cured until five years of remission, ``all signs we have now point to a recovery,'' said Dr. Robert Hansen, center associate director. The Soviet government paid for Grishchenko's transplant, including the $185,000 required to be deposited before the procedure begins, Beatty said.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge Pieces Damage Cars
DOC.TEXT: Chunks of concrete from an aging bridge fell onto a heavily traveled highway, damaging at least 20 vehicles and injuring four people, police said. The debris from the bridge over Interstate 376 on the city's southeastern outskirts crashed through the windshields of several cars on Sunday afternoon. ``A rock came out of the sky, bounced off our hood and smashed the windshield,'' motorist Laura Nizankiewicz said. ``There was glass all over the car.'' The debris damaged the hoods, roofs, windshields and bumpers of vehicles passing under the bridge. ``A lot of them were damaged when cars kicked the debris up, smacking windshields,'' said state Trooper W. Hughes. A woman occupant of one car that struck debris in the road suffered neck and shoulder injuries when debris flew through the windshield, Hughes said. She was listed in stable condition at Presbyterian-University Hospital, he said. Two other people were treated at the scene, and at least one other person was hurt, he said. City engineer Fred Reginella said pieces started falling Thursday from the bridge's supporting arches, some of which were repaired in 1980. The bridge is at least 75 years old, he said. Al Neri, a spokesman for Mayor Sophie Masloff, said engineers were unsure late Sunday if the debris fell from the bridge or from collection nets placed under the span during the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``This is the kind of person to do business with.'' _ Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, of President Bush.

``We're now at a stage in the U.S.-Soviet relationship and, indeed, in world history where we should miss no opportunity to complete the extraordinary tasks before us.'' _ President Bush, of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
``It looked to me like there had been a bombing run made right through the middle of Petersburg.'' _ Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh, after viewing the town wracked by weekend tornadoes.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Leaves Hospital After Minor Surgery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with xx grafs to UPDATE with Mandela off on trip. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A day after ending a six-day hospital stay, Nelson Mandela was off today on the first leg of a 13-nation tour through Europe, North America and Africa to promote his anti-apartheid efforts. At the hospital, doctors removed what they said was a benign cyst from the African National Congress leader's bladder. Dr. Gus Gecelter, who performed the operation, said the 71-year-old Mandela is in good health. ``We don't look at patients chronologically any more, in terms of their age. We look at them biologically. And Mr. Mandela is a man of about 50,'' Gecelter said. ``I feel well,'' Mandela said as he left the Park Lane Clinic in Johannesburg, South Africa, on Sunday. Mandela's began his six-week trip with a visit to Botswana, his first since time in the country since his release from prison Feb. 11 after spending 27 years in jail for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. He was to hold talks with President Quett Masire before addressing a rally at the National Stadium. He is then to visit the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Ireland, Switzerland, Italy, Ethiopia, Uganda, Kenya and Mozambique. Gecelter said Mandela had been given vitamins and antibiotics for the trip. Speaking Saturday at the Park Lane Clinic, where he was hospitalized for seven days, Mandela said he would urge the international community to maintain sanctions against South Africa. He said there had been no significant changes to the apartheid laws and that President F.W. de Klerk had not presented a true picture of South Africa during his recent European tour. Later Saturday, Mandela held talks with De Klerk at his offices in Pretoria. Dicussions centered on progress which had been made on last month's government-ANC accord and the need to reduce violence in the country. His ANC is the leading group fighting the apartheid system of racial segregation. Mandela was admitted to the private Park Lane Clinic on May 27 for what ANC officials initially described as a routine physical examination. After an announcement he had undergone a minor operation, the exact nature of the surgery was kept a secret for five days.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down In London
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher in Europe late this morning and trading was quiet due to the Whit Monday holiday celebrated in many parts of the Continent. Gold fell in London. ``There's hardly any business in the market,'' said one trader in Milan, Italy. The market also lacks direction because it ``is basically happy where the dollar is right now,'' he said. In Japan, the dollar rose 0.25 yen to a closing 152.42 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 152.60 yen. Currency dealers in Tokyo attributed the rise to the successful summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Washington. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.7016 West German marks, up from 1.6940 _1.4393 Swiss francs, up from 1.4358 _5.7365 French francs, up from 5.7180 _1,251.50 Italian lire, up from 1,247.25 _1.1755 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1728 The British pound was quoted at $1.6725, cheaper for dealers than $1.6840 late Friday. Gold opened in Britain at a bid price of $358.30 a troy ounce, down from $361.25 late Friday. At midmorning, the city's gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $358.75. Zurich markets were closed for Whit Monday. Gold in Hong Kong fell 68 cents to close at a bid $360.68. Silver was quoted in London to a bid price of $5.05 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Heat on in Southwest, Cool in East
DOC.TEXT: The heat was on today in the Southwest, while much of the Northeast and parts of the Midwest faced a threat of severe thunderstorms. Forecasters predicted highs today of 110 degrees or more in Southwest deserts and highs of more than 100 in parts of Texas and central California. Cool, dry air pushed into the East today and was expected to spawn more thunderstorms after portions of the Midwest were devastated by tornadoes during the weekend. Strong thunderstorms developed Sunday night along and ahead of a cold front in the Atlantic coast states. Strong thunderstorms developed along a second cold front in the Ohio Valley and lower Great Lakes region. Thunderstorms were expected in New York and New England. Light winds and mostly sunny skies were forecast for the Midwest today, with scattered showers and thunderstorms by tonight in Iowa and surrounding states. Today's highs in the Pacific Northwest and the Great Lakes states were forecast in the 50s and 60s. Rain fell early today in Maine, Texas and Washington state. Midland, Texas, set a record high Sunday for the date with a reading of 103 degrees. The high Sunday in the Lower 48 states was 110 degrees in the Arizona towns of Bullhead City, Phoenix and Yuma and in Palm Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Bluegrass Legend Receives Hero's Welcome
DOC.TEXT: Musician Bill Monroe earned a hometown hero's welcome at the Bluegrass Festival, where he was honored with plaques, proclamations and a medley of kind words. ``It's hats off to Bill Monroe, the boy that made Rosine famous,'' festival organizer Stoy Geary told a cheering crowd Saturday at the ``Hats Off to Bill Monroe'' ceremony in the western Kentucky town. About 25 people crammed onto the stage to give the 78-year-old Grammy award winner gifts ranging from a solid brass key to the nearby town of Owensboro to a petition signed by 30,000 fans in North Carolina. He also received an honorary brick with his name on it that is to be placed in the sidewalk at a bluegrass museum planned for Owensboro. ``When you get your name in concrete, you're doing all right,'' said Monroe, who paid tribute to his fans and touched briefly on the impact of bluegrass music. ``Bluegrass music has made more friends than all the other kinds of music put together,'' he said. ``Rosine, Kentucky, owns this music,'' said Monroe, who performed some of his favorite songs. ``It belongs right here.''

DOC.HEAD: Live Broadcasts, Up-Close Reports, Mark Soviet TV Coverage of Summit
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt ^By ANDREW KATELL
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev had to travel all the way to the United States for Soviet TV viewers to get a rare glimpse of their president in a more casual setting. The 59-year-old Kremlin chief was shown Saturday and Sunday on Soviet TV driving a golf cart at Camp David, Md., the American presidential retreat, with President Bush at his side. In the past, Soviet summit coverage has included only the formal comments made by the leaders. But in a break with tradition, Soviet television carried Bush's and Gorbachev's informal remarks to reporters before and after their meetings. The added comments appeared designed to stress to Soviet viewers that their president would not be coming back to Moscow empty-handed. The midday Soviet television news broadcast today showed Gorbachev touring the Control Data Corp. computer plant in Minneapolis and meeting with capitalists. It also showed him amid crowds of well-wishers on Minneapolis streets. Gorbachev's U.S. trip has dominated regularly scheduled newscasts on government television. Television also has interrupted regular programming to carry special broadcasts of Gorbachev's activities and a regular summit feature called ``American Diary,'' including feature reports about American life. Some of the TV commentary has pointedly drawn attention to changes in international relations under Gorbachev. ``Only five years have elapsed since'' Gorbachev held his first summit with then-President Ronald Reagan in Geneva, Switzerland, the Soviet announcer said as Gorbachev prepared to board a helicopter that would carry him from the Washington Mall to Andrews Air Force Base en route to Minneapolis. ``And how many changes there have been both in our relations with the United States and in world politics overall, how unrecognizable the world has become in these years,'' the announcer said just before a 21-gun salute marked Gorbachev's departure from Washington. None of the Soviet television coverage has contrasted Gorbachev's triumphs abroad with his troubles at home, although broadcasts did carry his answers to U.S. questions about the Soviet economy and ethnic unrest. Sunday's TV highlight was a live hourlong broadcast of Gorbachev's news conference with Bush. It included reporters' probing questions about Gorbachev's opposition to allowing a united Germany to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, emigration of Soviet Jews to occupied territories and his sanctions against secessionist Lithuania. Other special broadcasts have included Gorbachev's arrival ceremony in Washington and his talk Friday with American writers, scientists and other dignitaries at the Soviet Embassy in Washington. Soviet newspapers also have played up the summit. Pravda, the paper of the Communist Party Central Committee, has carried daily front-page stories. On Sunday, just below the masthead, Pravda headlined its summit coverage ``A Step to a Safe Future.'' A black-and-white Tass photograph showing a smiling Bush and Gorbachev standing side by side was splashed across the fold of page one. The presidential wives have not been left out of the coverage, either. Raisa Gorbachev was shown touring an exhibition of Russian manuscripts at the Library of Congress in Washington and _ joined by Barbara Bush _ kissing children and speaking to students at Wellesley College in Massachusetts. ``People's diplomacy,'' the TV correspondent called it. Not all was perfect in the TV coverage, however. Gorbachev's remarks to huge crowds that flocked to him during two unscheduled stops on the streets of Washington were not audible. The message was all visual: Gorbachev shaking hands, and Americans cheering for him.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills 3 Children
DOC.TEXT: A bomb planted by suspected Sikh militants killed three children during a Hindu religious ceremony today and two suspected separatists died in another explosion, officials said. Police said the explosions occurred in Patiala, 140 miles southeast of Amritsar. At least 34 people, including 18 women and children, were injured, police said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Villagers celebrating a Hindu religious festival were crowding around booths selling sweetened water when the first blast occurred this morning. Three children were killed immediately, police said. A short time later, two suspected Sikh extremists wheeled a motorscooter into the festival site. A bomb on the scooter exploded, killing the two men instantly, police said. Police said they believed the men had planned to plant the bomb at the festival grounds. The deaths brought to 1,002 the number of people killed this year in the Sikh separatist fight in Punjab state, a rich agricultural region in India's north. Sikhs have a slight majority in Punjab, but nationwide they comprise just 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Sikh militants have been fighting for an independent nation since 1982, claiming members of their sect are discriminated against by Hindus, who make up 82 percent of India's population.

DOC.HEAD: Cayenne Spray Adds Spice to War on Thugs
DOC.TEXT: A pocket-sized spray version of cayenne pepper is being used by growing numbers of police agencies to temporarily disable drunks, drug addicts and snarling dogs, the device's manufacturer says. Gardner Whitcomb, owner of Cap-Stun Inc., said his company's sales have quadrupled this year to more than $1 million. More than 1,000 police agencies have switched from mace to Cap-Stun since the FBI decided to switch to the pepper spray last fall, The Denver Post reported today. Women concerned about a 57 percent surge in rapes in the Denver area over the past year also are turning to Cap-Stun. But some Denver police officials have doubts about its effectiveness. ``Unless it hits you right in the open eyes, it takes too long to incapacitate you,'' said Sgt. Dave Abrams, supervisor of the Denver Police Department's SWAT team. ``I've seen it take more than a minute.'' Whitcomb said Denver police spray at too close a range to allow formation of a mist that can be inhaled. A Maryland chemist developed the spray 20 years ago when his wife, summoned to court to testify about a holdup she witnessed, wanted nonlethal protection against thugs who threatened her life. Cap-Stun is supposed to stop dogs and intoxicated or drugged criminals, who often are unaffected or angered by mace. The pepper attacks membranes inside the nose. The spray does not have lasting effects, promising reduced brutality charges against police.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Cut Short When Khmer Rouge Failes To Appear
DOC.TEXT: Talks aimed at reaching agreement on a cease-fire in Cambodia's 11-year-old civil war recessed after just 25 minutes today when the Khmer Rouge representative failed to appear. Japanese Foreign Ministry officials awaited contact from the four warring factions on a resumption of the first peace conference held in Japan since World War II, but prospects did not appear encouraging. The Khmer Rouge, militarily the strongest group in the loose three-party guerrilla coalition fighting the Vietnam-installed government of Premier Hun Sen, had said it came to Tokyo ready to sign a cease-fire accord. But it said it could not participate in negotiations that it described as two-sided peace talks led by Hun Sen and Prince Norodom Sihanouk, head of the guerrilla coalition. Hun Sen has refused to accept the Khmer Rouge as a potential equal participant in an interim government, suggesting the radical communists could return to power and preside over another reign of terror. Previous Cambodian peace talks also have floundered over a future government role for the Khmer Rouge. Hundreds of thousands of Cambodians died during the Khmer Rouge's 1975-1979 rule, when it tried to turn the country into a primitive agrarian commune. Vietnam invaded the country and drove the Khmer Rouge from power. It claims to have withdrawn all its troops from the country last fall. Japanese Foreign Ministry officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they could not comment on the reasons for the recess in today's brief talks or their content. ``Everything now is stagnant because of this question,'' one said. Asked about prospects for the talks' resumption, he said, ``We don't know yet and we don't know yet what happened today.'' After the talks recessed, the participants continued to hold informal discussions in other rooms of the Akasaka Palace, the ministry officials said. Japan agreed to a suggestion from Thailand in April that it act as host to talks between Hun Sen and Sihanouk to maintain momentum in the Cambodian peace process. But Sihanouk said the Khmer Rouge's nominal leader, Khieu Samphan, and conservative former Premier Son Sann, leader of the third guerrilla faction, also should take part. Japanese officials prepared a circular negotiating table that they hoped would solve the problem of a negotiating format, with Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama surrounded on one side by Hun Sen and three representatives of his government, and on the other by Sihanouk, Son Sann, Sihanouk's son Prince Ranariddh, and Khieu Samphan. But the Khmer Rouge said the formula still resulted in talks between two sides, not among four warring parties. Also in Tokyo to observe the talks was Thai Defense Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, a key mediator between the Cambodian groups who was instrumental in drafting the proposed cease-fire. While other faction leaders were meeting in Akasaka Palace, Khieu Samphan paid a 20-minute visit to Chavalit's hotel room in another part of Tokyo. Both sides refused to comment on their discussions, but the Khmer Rouge leader told reporters afterward he had boycotted the peace talks ``because there are many problems.'' ``I'm here to sign the peace agreement,'' he said. Sihanouk has repeatedly pledged he will sign a cease-fire agreement in Tokyo regardless of what happens, but also has said the Khmer Rouge should be included. Fighting has intensified in Cambodia in recent weeks, with the guerrillas claiming victories in many parts of the country. The cease-fire agreement scheduled for signing in Tokyo reportedly has no measures for supervising a truce or new elections. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China _ are to hold talks on Cambodia in Paris in July. The United Nations has recognized the guerrilla coalition as the legitimate government of Cambodia, and Hun Sen has therefore resisted U.N. participation in peace plans.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS New York-dated last item in rdp to CORRECT spelling of (Dr.) Dolittle in lead and last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Actor Sir Rex Harrison, lauded by colleagues as a master of high comedy who talked with the animals as the lovable Dr. Dolittle, died Saturday of pancreatic cancer. He was 82. The award-winning actor is remembered for his wit and charm as well as his versatility and skill during a 66-year career on the stage and screen. Harrison died in his sleep at his Manhattan home. Harrison debuted on Broadway in 1936 and last performed there May 11 as Lord Porteous in the revival of ``The Circle,'' W. Somerset Maugham's 1920s comedy. Harrison became inexorably linked with the Henry Higgins character in ``My Fair Lady,'' winning a Tony award in 1957 for the Broadway version and an Academy Award in 1964 for the film version. Another of his more notable roles was that of Dr. Dolittle, who talked with the animals and taught them to speak back in the 1967 movie named for his character.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Praises Superpower Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0515 to remove duplicate slug. ^With PM-Summit-Roundup, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Although President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev remain at odds over the future alignment of a unified Germany, leaders of the two Germany states say the superpower summit has improved conditions for merging their countries. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Sunday that the Washington summit ``has further improved the international conditions for the unity process between the Germanys.'' His foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere also said they saw the summit as improving conditions for German unity and disarmament. ``The resolution of the uttermost aspects of German unity requires new and far-reaching progress in the CSCE-process, in disarmament, and in the overall cooperation between West and East, especially in the area of economics,'' Kohl said in a statement. The CSCE, or 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, deals with military security, economic cooperation and human rights. Kohl said progress in reducing long-range nuclear weapons, the beginning of a worldwide ban on chemical weapons and the ending of nuclear testing were equally important. In addition, Kohl said U.S. readiness to expand trade with the Soviets was of ``psychological importance ... to promote the reform politics of President Gorbachev.'' In an interview with West German TV, Genscher called the summit ``a great success with its positive aspects that will also have positive results on the developments in Europe. ``And that means also for the Europeans and the unification of Germany, because relations of the two superpowers with each other have fundamentally improved.'' De Maiziere, also interviewed by West German TV, said the summit showed the superpowers were rethinking their approach to security. ``The deciding message that I think I heard is that in the area of stabilizing security they are having new and very different ideas,'' de Maiziere said of Bush and Gorbachev. ``They are trying not to define the security theme militarily _ not end it with rocket counting _ but with considerations of economic ties, with cultural ties,'' de Maiziere said. During their summit, Bush and Gorbachev signed a treaty that drastically slashes chemical weapons. The two leaders also issued a statement breaking the deadlock on efforts to reduce long-range nuclear arms. In addition, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and his Soviet counterpart Eduard Shevardnadze have indicated that prospects for reduction of conventional forces in Europe had improved. The Soviet Union had been balking at a plan to cut the superpowers' troops to 195,000 for each side in Central Europe. Gorbachev, concerned about the military strength of a united Germany, has opposed Bush's demand that the new nation be a full member of NATO. The issue was discussed extensively on Thursday, the first day of the summit, but was set aside so the leaders could focus on other matters. At their joint news conference Sunday, Bush said he and Gorbachev had a better understanding of their differences on the issue of German alignment. ``But I'm not sure we narrowed them.'' Bush said. Gorbachev had threatened to review the Soviet defense strategy and delay the pullout of Soviet troops from Eastern Europe if a united Germany insists on joining the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Baker was to give Genscher a full report in Copenhagen, Denmark, during a meeting that began today of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. As of July 2, the two German nations will start to merge their economies, and the West German mark will replace the virtually worthless East German currency. East Germany's first non-Communist government came to power after elections in March, following the ouster of hard-line Communist leaders late last year.

DOC.HEAD: `City of Angels' and `Grapes of Wrath' Take Top Tonys
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to recast. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `When we...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Tony-List
LaserColor NY41, LaserPhotos NY37, NY6
DOC.TEXT: ``City of Angels,'' a satire of gumshoe fiction and Hollywood, was named best musical of the Broadway season, and the Tony Award for best play went to an adaptation of John Steinbeck's ``The Grapes of Wrath.'' ``City of Angels'' won six Tonys overall, more than any other production, in a ceremony Sunday at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. ``Grand Hotel'' won five. The event was televised by CBS. The big loser was August Wilson's ``The Piano Lesson,'' which won no Tonys even though it had five nominations, including best play, and had won both the Pulitzer Prize and New York Drama Critics Circle award. Tyne Daly, formerly of television's ``Cagney and Lacey,'' was named best actress in a musical as the brassy stage mother Mama Rose in ``Gypsy,'' a role originated by Ethel Merman 30 years ago. The show also won as best revival. Robert Morse won as best actor in a play for his portrayal of writer Truman Capote in ``Tru.'' Morse's competition included Charles S. Dutton in ``The Piano Lesson'' and Dustin Hoffman as Shylock in ``The Merchant of Venice.'' ``I'm just so grateful to be back here,'' said Morse, who last won a Tony in 1962 for ``How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' Maggie Smith won as best actress for ``Lettice & Lovage.'' Margaret Tyzack, in the same play, won for best featured, or supporting, actress. Charles Durning, Big Daddy in the revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' won the best featured actor Tony. ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' an adaptation by Frank Galati of the novel about Dust Bowl Okies, also won a directing Tony for Galati. In accepting his award, Galati paid tribute to Steinbeck's widow, Elaine, and his ``enduring genius.'' ``City of Angels'' a jazzy production set in 1940s Hollywood, picked up the best actor prize for James Naughton, the show's hardboiled detective. ``How sweet it is,'' he cracked. The musical also won awards for featured actress, Randy Graff as a love-starved secretary; best book, Larry Gelbart; score, composer Cy Coleman and lyricist David Zippel; and set design, Robin Wagner. Among the five awards for ``Grand Hotel,'' set in Berlin in the years before Hitler, were two for Tommy Tune for direction and choreography. ``When we were out of town, I didn't quite have the choreography right,'' Tune said. ``I would like to thank the director for not firing me.'' ``Grand Hotel'' also won Michael Jeter a Tony as best featured actor in a musical for his role as a dying bookkeeper dancing wildly on a last fling. ``If you have got a problem with alcohol and you can't stop and think life can't change and dreams can't come true, I stand here as living proof that you can stop,'' he said in accepting the award. ``It changes a day at a time and dreams come true.'' Costume designer Santo Loquasto and lighting designer Jules Fisher both won Tonys for ``Grand Hotel.'' Ron Silver, a presenter, made a speech supporting the National Endowment for the Arts, which is under attack for funding art some consider indecent. Silver also mentioned the anniversary of the crackdown at Beijing's Tiananmen Square. During a commercial break, executive producer Joe Cates asked for no more references to those subjects. ``To take advantage of a live television show that way does incredible harm,'' he said. But a winner after that, Galati, mentioned the endowment. ``Were he alive, there would be no louder voice in support for the National Endowment for the Arts than John Steinbeck,'' Galati said. Alfred Drake, who starred on Broadway in ``Oklahoma!'' ``Kismet'' and ``Kiss Me, Kate,'' received a special Tony. The Seattle Repertory Theater won a special Tony and $25,000 for outstanding regional theater. The Tony Awards were begun in 1947 by the American Theater Wing and are named for actress Antoinette Perry. They are voted on by people working in Broadway theater and by theater journalists.

DOC.HEAD: Killer Who Wanted to Die Executed After Supreme Court Cancels Stay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to recast. Picks up 14th graf, `Andy Anderson...'. Baal is pronounced Ball.
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Baal sent love to his parents before he was put to death by lethal injection. It was an execution he fought for over his parents' court objections. Baal, 26, was executed Sunday for fatally slashing a Las Vegas bus driver. His parents had tried to intervene, saying he was mentally incompetent and should not have been allowed to decide for himself to die or appeal. ``Send my love to my mama and my papa,'' Nevada State Prison Warden Pete Demosthenes quoted as Baal's last words. State Prison Director Ron Angelone said Baal told him to tell his parents, Edwin and Doris Baal of Mesa, Colo., that ``Jesus was taking him home and he was not scared.'' The execution came 10 hours after the U.S. Supreme Court voted 5-4 to allow it. At Baal's parents' request and over his objections, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco had stayed the execution Saturday, saying a lower court erred in not holding a hearing on whether Baal was mentally competent to appeal. The Supreme Court majority held there was no basis for that conclusion. Baal was executed for the Feb. 26, 1988, killing of bus driver Frances Maves, 34. She was robbed and stabbed while inspecting her bus at an airport in Las Vegas. According to Baal, she gave him $20 when he asked for money, but he demanded more and a struggle ensued. ``You shouldn't have done that,'' he said, according to his confession. ``Now you pay. I sentence you to death.'' Before the execution got under way, Baal looked through viewing windows at the 24 witnesses and tried to speak to Dan Seaton, the prosecutor in the case. Seaton said he couldn't make out what Baal was saying. After that, Baal appeared to talk to himself, then closed his eyes as the lethal injections began. Baal spent a sleepless night in a cell next to the death chamber and made a last confession to the prison chaplain, prison spokesman Glen Whorton said. ``He was glad it was finally going forward and he started to make phone calls to friends and relatives,'' Whorton said. Andy Anderson of Reno, an opponent of abortion and capital punishment, was one of several people protesting the daybreak execution. He knelt for two hours on the hood of his car in the parking lot outside the prison. A votive candle on the hood beside him was blown out by a gust of wind, ``just like the life that was snuffed out this morning,'' he said. Baal's execution was Nevada's fifth and the 129th nationally since the U.S. Supreme Court in 1976 cleared the way for states to resume use of the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Global Research Institute Announced During Gorbachev Visit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 1 graf at end to include description of Maxwell's company.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: British publishing magnate Robert Maxwell is putting up $50 million to help establish a global research center named for Mikhail Gorbachev. Te $100 million Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology was announced Sunday during the Soviet president's visit to Minnesota. The institute will mix U.S., Soviet and European scientists and will be in the Twin Cities. It will cope with issues ``that matter to humanity,'' such as environmental warming, communications, health and food, Maxwell said. The remaining $50 million is to be raised by Gov. Rudy Perpich and a committee of Minnesotans. The project got an immediate lift from Dwayne Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland Co., who donated $1 million. Gorbachev said the institute represents ``yet another element of common cooperation which seems to be merging and developing between our countries, between many countries of the world, and on the human level, too.'' ``We join our efforts to address and come to grips with problems that are of concern to all of us,'' he said. Maxwell, chairman and chief executive officer of London-based Maxwell Communication Corp., said the institute is a tribute to the thawing of relations between the superpowers. ``I know of no better way to show that we in Europe are grateful to President Gorbachev, as well as President Bush for ending the Cold War, because what happened at Yalta was not particularly to our liking,'' he said. Maxwell Communications' North American headquarters are in the Twin Cities. The governor has been pressing for a major research center in Minnesota for several years. He met with Maxwell in London in September. Maxwell Communications holds 20 percent equity in St. Paul's Webb Publishing Co., which specializes in general printing and publishing company-owned magazines. Maxwell, who bought Macmillan Inc. in New York two years ago, is chairman and chief executive officer of Britain's Mirror Group PLC, which publishes the Daily Mirror, the United Kingdom's second-largest newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher-of-the-Year Faces Losing Her Job
DOC.TEXT: Weeks after winning a statewide teacher-of-the-year award, Eleanor Larrabee was called out of the classroom and told she was losing her job to budget cuts. The City Council has since won her a reprieve. ``It took two minutes. I was mute. I could only nod,'' said Mrs. Larrabee, recalling how Westfield school authorities told her last month she was being ``bumped'' from the job by a middle-school teacher with greater seniority. In March, she had been named the top teacher in Massachusetts by Junior Achievement, a group that fosters entrepreneurship in young people. She also finished fourth in the organization's national competition. Mrs. Larrabee and 41 other city teachers were handed layoff notices when the School Committee proposed cutting 120 jobs out of nearly 650 in the district. The committee also proposed eliminating athletics and busing for students living within two miles of school. Cuts are necessary because the school's $20 million operating budget is being cut by $2.2 million. Local government districts around Massachusetts are grappling with cuts because of a state budget crisis. But the way the School Committee proposed to make up the shortfall was too much for the City Council. It condemned the schools' decision as ``irresponsible'' and voted 9-2 Thursday to send back the proposed budget. The council ordered the School Committee to reorder its spending priorities so no teachers would be let go. School Superintendent William C. Allard said he couldn't make the cuts in any other way. ``We are not crying wolf,'' he said. The School Committee is due to meet Tuesday to discuss the council's order. Mrs. Larrabee said ``it would be wonderful'' if the council action would help her and other teachers keep their jobs. She had worked in a bank for 18 years before becoming a teacher at Westfield High five years ago. She said her experience in what she calls ``the real world'' aided her development of innovative school projects that aimed at teaching youngsters economics by having them set up small businesses. ``Everyone was shocked when I went back to school. But I love children and I thought `I have nothing to lose,''' she said. ``And when I finally got into teaching, I realized this was it. This was what I was meant for.''

DOC.HEAD: Frederick's of Hollywood Founder Frederick Mellinger Dead at 76
DOC.TEXT: Frederick Mellinger, whose Frederick's of Hollywood designed women's lingerie from a man's point of view, has died of pneumonia at age 76. The exuberant purveyor of purple satin bustiers, edible panties and peekaboo bras died Saturday night at his Los Angeles home, said Morton Field, the family attorney. Private services were scheduled for today, he said. ``He truly revolutionized lingerie in this country,'' said Ellen Appel, a publicist. ``When other people were making traditional, white, boring lingerie, he was making very glamorous lingerie: peignoirs, baby dolls.'' Born in New York City, Mellinger got his start when he lied about his age _ then 14 _ to get a clerical job at an ``intimate apparel'' firm. It was there that he learned the art of mail-order merchandising. In 1946, he opened Frederick's Fifth Avenue in New York, a mail-order business selling products that his World War II Army buddies told him they would like to see their girlfriends wear. A year later, Mellinger moved the store to Los Angeles. Over the next four decades, the bright purple, Art Deco headquarters on Hollywood Boulevard became a landmark. In the 1960s, Mellinger began to open outlets in malls. There are now 160 stores and sales reached more than $80 million last year, said Ms. Appel. Mellinger was the guiding spirit of the company, designing brassieres with names like ``Rising Star'' and ``Cadillac,'' and teaching himself French, Spanish and German in order to work with European suppliers. Frederick's explicit catalogs, offering scantily-clad models, sex toys, body oils and X-rated videos, were mailed to thousands of American homes, making Frederick's of Hollywood a household name. From the sex-kitten '50s, women moved into the liberated '60s and '70s, but Frederick's continued to offer its collection of padded and ``pointed missile'' bras, as well as garter belts and G-strings. ``He stuck by his principles,'' Ms. Appel said. ``Women in the '70s, during the heights of the liberation movement, were picketing Frederick's of Hollywood. He used to say, `Fashions may change, but sex appeal is always in style.''' These days, rock star Madonna sports Frederick's-style lingerie on her concert tours, and most department stores stock clingy ``unmentionables.'' Yet styles do change, and in 1984, the firm suffered its first yearly loss, a $148,000 shortfall. Mellinger stepped down as chairman and chief executive, and the new management set about changing Frederick's image, deleting sexual aids and X-rated videos from company catalogs and adding more wholesome-looking models. Last fall, the purple Hollywood headquarters was painted gray. Mellinger is survived by his wife, Harriett; a son; a daughter; and five grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Premiers to Meet Again in Effort to Save Meech Lake Accord
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney says Canada's provincial ministers have agreed to continue closed-door discussions to try to settle a constitutional rift that has prompted talk of Quebec's secession. An informal dinner meeting Sunday night in Hull, Quebec, across the Ottawa River from the national Parliament, was called in hopes of moving toward a full-scale conference. Mulroney emerged from the five-hour meeting to say ``we still haven't finished our work'' and that provinical leaders would reconvene this morning in Ottawa. The provincial leaders are discussing the Meech Lake agreement, a proposed amendment designed to convince Quebec to sign Canada's 1982 national constitution. Quebec refused to sign the document, saying that the French-speaking province's distinct nature had not been taken into consideration. ``I remain optimistic,'' said Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa. ``It seemed there was a will to break the impasse. All the premiers realized the seriousness of the situation.'' In 1987, the 10 provincial premiers and Mulroney signed the five-point Meech Lake accord _ named for the site of the signing at a lake near Ottawa _ as a way to protect Quebec's culture and language. They set a deadline of June 23, 1990, to win ratification by all 10 provincial legislatures. Since then, however, governments in three provinces have changed and the new premiers have refused to go along with the agreement, throwing the country into crisis and leading to talk about Quebec secession and even a breakup of Canada. The most controversial of the five points in the accord is the one designating Quebec as a ``distinct society.'' The other four points concern methods of amending the constitution, the power of provinces to opt out of some federal-provincial spending programs, nominations to the supreme court and Senate reform. Bourassa insisted that ``the Meech Lake accord must be ratified as is.'' Quebec's concessions were made in 1987, he said, and ``it's not realistic to presume that I can go before the national assembly to ratify an amended Meech Lake.'' Nationalism has been on the rise in recent months in Quebec, where many feel they are being rejected by English Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Wallet, Missing 40 Years, Returned to Owner
DOC.TEXT: Students here found a ticket for a ride down memory lane in a wallet they returned to the owner who lost it 40 years ago. Three Central High School students were helping their French teacher clean out a closet Friday when one of the students, Arvis Owens, found a torn, fake-alligator-skin green wallet. The four didn't find any money, but did find yellowing photographs, a 3-cent stamp and a hand-written driver's license dated Jan. 30, 1950, the Beaumont Enterprise Journal reported Saturday. Teacher Kris Galles made a few phone calls using the phone book and the name and Beaumont address listed on the license _ Patricia Graves, 385 Gober Road. After three calls, Ms. Galles found Ms. Graves' stepmother, who gave her the current phone number. Ms. Graves, now married and named Patricia Henderson, said she did not recall losing the wallet. But her face lit up when she pulled out 40-year-old pictures of her little sister and her 17-year-old self in ``pin-up girl'' poses. ``We thought we were quite something back then,'' she said. She also found a picture of her first date. Mrs. Henderson, now a drainage district commissioner in Beaumont, said she was thrilled to have the wallet back and to find the students so interested. ``I feel great. It has brought back a lot of very fond memories,'' she said. ``Imagine that somebody else would be excited about a part of my past.''

DOC.HEAD: Primary Candidates Head to the Wire in Nine States
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new 8th graf, One Helms ad, to include details of Helms ads
DOC.TEXT: Rival Democrats Harvey Gantt and Mike Easley, entering the closing hours of their Senate runoff primary, are concentrating their fire on Republican Sen. Jesse Helms. But across the continent, California Democrats are slamming each other. North Carolina and California are among nine states holding primaries on Tuesday, the busiest day so far of the 1990 election year. The other states are Alabama, Iowa, Mississippi, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota. As they entered the final 24 hours before voters cast their ballots, candidates checked opinion polls, unleashed their final television ads and tried to stir support with a closing round of personal appearances. Two new polls of potential voter sentiment in the bitterly fought race for the Democratic nomination for governor of California showed former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein maintaining a lead over state Attorney General John Van de Kamp. The Los Angeles Times poll said Feinstein had a 13-point lead _ a gain of two points over a similar survey early in May. The poll gave the former mayor 42 percent and Van de Kamp 29 percent. There were 29 percent still undecided or supporting one of the nine minor candidates on the Democratic primary ballot. Mervin Field's California Poll, which gave Feinstein a slim 3 percent lead earlier this month, reported that margin had opened up to 8 points over Van de Kamp, 42-34, in polling that concluded Sunday. New polls also were out in Iowa and New Mexico. In North Carolina, Easley accused Helms of attacking him with ``personal character assassinations'' in radio ads. ``They are personal and very negative,'' the Brunswick County prosecutor told supporters Sunday. One Helms ad accuses Easley of waffling on the issues and another suggests that he plea-bargained a drug case involving a campaign contributor's son who was caught with nearly a pound of cocaine. Easley said he was countering with ads saying, ``This year North Carolina must say no to Jesse Helms and mudslinging.'' ``I think Charlotte people believed long before anyone else that we are going to bring Jesse Helms home,'' Gantt told supporters Sunday night in Charlotte, N.C. Abortion was the issue of the day in California where Sen. Pete Wilson had only token opposition for the GOP nomination to succeed fellow Republican George Deukmejian in the governor's office. Deukmejian declined to seek a third term. Van de Kamp appeared on the steps of the Los Angeles County Courthouse with Norma McCorvey, the ``Jane Roe'' of the landmark U.S. Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade abortion rights decision. ``I have no criticism of Mrs. Feinstein's record (on abortion),'' McCorvey said. ``But I believe John Van de Kamp is the candidate who will do the most to protect a woman's right to choose. I trust John Van de Kamp.'' Feinstein also stressed her long support of abortion rights, telling fund-raisers in West Hollywood that ``I believe that a woman is best protected by another woman who believes in the right to choose.'' The two candidates were running television commercials harshly attacking each other. Van de Kamp's commercials described Feinstein as a ``Republican in Democratic clothing,'' while the former mayor's ads accused the attorney general of refusing to ``talk about his own record.'' Abortion also has been a major issue in Iowa's Democratic primary for governor. The National Abortion Rights Action League endorsed Iowa House speaker Don Avenson in a move designed to help him against anti-abortion rival Tom Miller, the state attorney general. Republican Gov. Terry Branstad is an abortion opponent. A new poll, published Sunday in the Des Moines Register, said Avenson had moved into the lead with support from 32 percent of those surveyed, compared with 25 percent for Miller. Former banker John Chrystal was at 19 percent, and 20 percent said they were undecided. The newspaper said the sampling was among 629 likely primary voters and had a margin of error of 3.9 percent. ``It's breaking our way, obviously,'' said Avenson. In New Mexico, large fields were seeking the gubernatorial nomination in both parties. Incumbent GOP Gov. Garrey Carruthers was ineligible to seek re-election, but the person elected to succeed him will be the first New Mexico governor allowed to serve two successive terms. A new poll published Sunday in the Albuquerque Journal said state Senate Minority Leader Les Houston and former legislator Frank Bond each had the support of 29.2 percent of the registered Republicans surveyed. On the Democratic side, former Gov. Bruce King had the backing of 42.7 percent, while state Attorney General Paul Bardacke was supported by 31.5 percent. The poll was conducted for the Journal by Research and Polling Inc. of Albuquerque, which surveyed 664 registered Democrats and 402 registered Republicans. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percent for the Democrats and 5 percent for the Republicans. A large field was battling in Alabama for the Democratic nomination to oppose GOP Gov. Guy Hunt, the first Republican to hold that office since the post-Civil War Reconstruction period. Among the Democratic contenders was former Gov. Fob James who was taped recently by a public television crew while telling a Republican Party official that ``there ain't but one damn Goldwater Republican in this race, and you know who that is.'' An aide to James, a former Republican, said the remark was ``a joke more than anything.'' In Montana, four Republicans were vying for the nomination to oppose Democratic Sen. Max Baucus. In Mississippi, Republican Sen. Thad Cochran was as good as re-elected to a third term. He had no primary opposition and no Democrat has filed to run against him in the fall. Democratic Sens. Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Howell Heflin of Alabama had only token primary opposition. The same was true of Republican Sens. Larry Pressler of South Dakota and Pete Domenici of New Mexico. Gantt and Easley worked hard to get out their core supporters. ``There are a lot of voters out there, especially in the East, that we ought to be able to pick up,'' Easley said while campaigning in the eastern part of the state. ``If we have a big turnout in the East, Mike Easley will win the runoff. If we don't it'll be real close.'' Gantt sought votes in the same region over the weekend, especially in the northeast, which has a high percentage of black voters who were critical in the May 8 primary when the former mayor of Charlotte led a six-man field. But Gantt fell short of the 40 percent threshold he needed to avoid a runoff and become the first black candidate for statewide office in North Carolina this century.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Rex Harrison Dead at 82
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT spelling of crotchety; ADDS graf on funeral plans.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Harrison-Filmography, PM-Harrison-Stage
DOC.TEXT: Fellow actors mourned Sir Rex Harrison as a master of high comedy who played the crotchety elocutionist in ``My Fair Lady'' and talked with the animals as the lovable Dr. Dolittle during a 66-year career. The Tony- and Oscar-winning actor, remembered for his wit and charm as well as his versatility and skill on the stage and screen, died in his sleep early Saturday at his Manhattan home. He was 82. Harrison had been ill only a short time and did not know he had pancreatic cancer, said his attorney, Harold Schiff. His doctors had told him he was suffering from gallbladder trouble. ``He didn't want to know,'' Schiff said. Harrison debuted on Broadway in 1936 and last performed there on May 11 as Lord Porteous in the revival of ``The Circle,'' W. Somerset Maugham's 1920s comedy. ``He died with his boots on, no question about it,'' said Elliot Martin, producer of ``The Circle'' and three other Harrison shows. Harrison became inexorably linked with the Henry Higgins character in ``My Fair Lady,'' winning a Tony award in 1957 for his Broadway run with Julie Andrews and an Academy Award in 1964 for his screen version opposite Audrey Hepburn. ``To watch him and to work with him was a joyful experience. I doubt there was anyone before like him,'' Andrews said. ``The theater has lost an extraordinary one-of-a-kind.'' Hepburn called him ``the quintessential actor.'' Actress Lynn Redgrave called Harrison ``the master of high comedy playing.'' ``Nobody knows how to do what he did. He gave high comedy a danger, accuracy and razor sharpness, and at the same time it appeared to be completely effortless. You could never see the joke coming,'' she said from San Diego. ``My Fair Lady,'' a musical version of George Bernard Shaw's ``Pygmalion,'' was revived in 1981 with Harrison reprising his role for $50,000 a week. ``Mr. Harrison is perfect in the part _ crisp, lean, complacent and condescending until at last a real flare of human emotions burns the egotism away,'' reviewer Brooks Atkinson of The New York Times wrote at the time of the premiere in 1956. Harrison, who characterized his vocal range as ``one and a half notes,'' crooned ``I've grown accustomed to her face'' hundreds of times as the stuffy language professor who falls in love with a Cockney waif after teaching her to speak proper English. ``I could have played Higgins for 20 years, but I wanted to do other things,'' Harrison said in 1985. ``And I did, in fact.'' Among them was his role as Dr. Dolittle, the man who talked with the animals and taught them to speak back. The 1967 film introduced Harrison to a new generation of young moviegoers. His other best-know movies included ``Major Barbara'' in 1940 and ``Blithe Spirit'' in 1945. ``He had the best sense of humor of almost any actor I have ever known,'' said his agent, Lawrence Evans, who worked with Harrison for more than 40 years. ``He was a lovable, irascible man.'' Harrison was born in Huyton, near Liverpool, on March 5, 1908, and joined the Liverpool Repertory Theatre in 1924. His first appearance on the London stage was in 1930. By the end of the decade he emerged as a star, appearing in Sir Terence Rattigan's ``French Without Tears'' from 1936 to 1938. The actor last appeared on the London stage in ``The Admirable Crichton'' in 1988. In addition to his awards for ``My Fair Lady,'' Harrison won a Tony for his portrayal of Henry VIII in Maxwell Anderson's ``Anne of the Thousand Days'' and a special American Theater Award for his overall stage achievements. He was knighted last year by Queen Elizabeth II. Harrison was married six times. He is survived by his current wife, Mercia Tinker; two sons by previous marriages, Noel and Carey, and their children; and his sister. His third wife, actress Kay Kendall, died of leukemia in 1959.
