Years later, Harrison starred in Rattigan's ``In Praise of Love,'' the story of a man whose wife is dying of an incurable disease and is forbidden by doctors from telling her. Harrison's funeral service will be private, but there will be a memorial get-together June 18 at a Manhattan church. Schiff said Harrison had requested that it be called a ``memorial celebration'' and feature jazz.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide If Passengers Can Sue in Near-Crashes
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether passengers on international flights may sue airlines for emotional distress allegedly suffered in near-crashes that cause them no physical harm. The court said it will review a ruling that Eastern Airlines may be forced to pay passengers on a flight that landed safely in Miami after all the plane's engines failed briefly in the air. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last year that the so-called Wa an international air travel treaty, permits airlines to be sued in such cases rsaw Convention,by passengers who suffer only psychological trauma. An airline is required by the treaty to pay up to $75,000 per person, depending on the severity of injuries. The liability ceiling is lifted only if the airline is shown to have committed willful misconduct. The treaty only covers international flights. In domestic flights, the law of the state in which a lawsuit was filed would apply. Lawyers for Eastern Airlines said in most states passengers on domestic flights who can prove negligence _ but not willful misconduct _ would be barred from recovering damages for emotional distress unaccompanied by physical injury. The 11th Circuit court ruled in the case of Eastern Flight 855, which left Miami on May 5est in Hong Kong where about 100,000 demonstrated. Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. Smaller demonstrations were held in Taiwan, Japan, Britain, Canada and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Court Agrees to Hear Case Involving Immigrant Farmworkers
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at giving federal officials more power to deny temporary legal status to immigrant farmworkers. The court, without comment, said it will review a ruling that said the workers are entitled to various procedural protections when applying for such residential permits. The case stems from a 1988 lawsuit by the Haitian Refugee Center, the Migration and Refugee Services of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Palm Beach, Fla., and 17 applicants for temporary residence. The class-action suit is intended to benefit thousands of aliens. The suit said applicants for temporary residency were being denied their rights under a 1986 federal law that established a program for admitting foreign farmworkers to the United States. To be eligible for the program, aliens must have applied during an 18-month period that ended Nov. 30, 1988, and have done migrant farm work for at least 90 days during a one-year period that ended May 1, 1986. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year upheld a federal judge's ruling that required the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) to take a number of steps to assure applicants are treated fairly when interviewed for temporary residency. Thosnslators, permitting applicants to present witnesses and requiring INS interviewers to explain what evidence they relied on in ruling on applications. The appeals court said the 1986 immigration law ``granted aliens a constitutionally protected right to apply for temporary residency as well as a right to substantiate their claims for eligibility. Once Congress chooses to create such a system of entitlements ... a property interest is created that is accorded procedural due process protection.'' Bush administration lawyers, in the appeal acted on today, said the law does not give federal judges such sweeping authority. The 11th Circuit Court ruling ``has sanctioned the improper intervention of federal district courts into the day-to-day business of administering the immigration laws,'' the government lawyers said. The appeal said INS has received more than 1.3 million applications under the 1986 law for temporary residency and approved 93 percent of them. But the appeal said tens of thousands of applications for temporary permits could be affected by the appeals court ruling. The appeal added that the 11th Circuit court's ruling could have a bearing on additional thousands of applications for permanent residential status under the 1986 law. The case is McNary vs. Haitian Refugee Center, 89-1332.

DOC.HEAD: Poughkeepsie Managing Editor Killed in Traffic Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lo-anne in last graf is CQ
DOC.TEXT: John C. Quinn Jr., managing editor of the Poughkeepsie (N.Y.) Journal, was killed when a van driven by his brother slammed into a tree, state police said today. Quinn, 34, was pronounced dead Sunday night on arrival at Westerly Hospital, said state police Capt. Donald Kettelle. Quinn's 26-year-old brother, Christopher, who was driving the van, was treated and released, Kettelle said. The men were sons of John C. Quinn, former editor of USA Today, who retired as a Gannett Co. Inc. executive in April. John C. Quinn Jr. joined the Journal in January 1987 after 5{ years at The Providence Journal-Bulletin, where he started as a copy editor and rose to become assistant managing editor for Sunday sections, his father said. Quinn, a 1977 graduate of Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., also served internships at Gannett papers in Huntington, W.Va., and Agana, Guam, and in editing positions at the Statesman-Journal in Salem, Ore. The van hit a tree on a curve along a rural stretch of State Highway 112 north of the village of Carolina. The state police report said that what appeared to be bottles and cans of beer were found in the car and officers were investigating whether the accident was alcohol-related. Christoper Quinn would be charged with refusing to take a blood-alcohol test, Kettelle said. He refused to do so on advice of his attorney, the captain said. Quinn Jr. also is survived by another brother, Richard, of Washington, D.C., and by a sister, Lo-anne Quinn Cellar of Richmond, his father said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Whistleblowers to Sue Employers for Personal Injury
DOC.TEXT: Nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue their employers under state personal injury laws, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court unanimously said such lawsuits are not pre-empted by a federal law protecting such whistleblowers. Today's ruling carries significant effect. The federal law does not provide awards of punitive damages, often the most lucrative part of a successful suit under the corresponding state laws. ``We conclude that (a) claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress does not fall within the pre-empted field of nuclear safety,'' Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote for the court. The decision is a victory for Vera English of Wilmington, N.C., who worked as a laboratory technician for General Electric at its nuclear fuels manufacturing plant there for almost 12 years before she was fired in July 1984. Today's decision reinstates her suit after it was ordered dismissed by a federal appeals court. Earlier that year, Ms. English had complained to both the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission and to her GE supervisor about what she considered serious violations of federal safety standards. When no corrective action was taken, she deliberately failed to clean up radiation contamination at her work station in an effort to prove that such contamination was not being detected by safety inspectors. Although Ms. English's efforts led to corrective action, she was disciplined and eventually fired. Ms. English sued GE in 1987. Her suit sought, under North Carolina law, reinstatement with back pay and monetary damages for wrongful discharge and intentional infliction of emotional distress. Despite being based on state law, Ms. English's suit was filed in federal court because GE's headquarters are outside the state. A federal judge threw out the state-law suit, ruling that it was pre-empted by ``whistleblower provisions'' of the federal Energy Reorganization Act. The law bars nuclear industry employers from firing or otherwise disciplining employees for publicly pointing out alleged safety problems. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal of Ms. English's suit last year. Today's decision reversed that ruling. The case is English vs. GE, 89-152.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Leader Blasts Bush for Trade Pact with Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT typo in first name of Lithuanian president; pickup 4th, `Moscow has...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's decision to give Mikhail S. Gorbachev the trade agreement he wanted will allow the Soviet leader to continue his economic embargo of Lithuania, the Baltic republic's president said today. The trade agreement was announced during the superpower summit in Washington. It ended Sunday with a joint news conference, and Bush said his decision to grant Moscow trade benefits had nothing to do with Gorbachev easing pressure on the breakaway republic. ``By this agreement, he's allowed to prolong the blockade against Lithuania,'' Vytautas Landsbergis told the Voice of America, the U.S. government radio station. Moscow has slapped an embargo on the republic, halting food and fuel supplies, in retaliation for Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. Bush had said earlier he would not ask Congress to approve new trade agreements with the Soviet Union until Moscow dropped restrictions on emigration and ended its blockade of Lithuania. But he changed his mind after meeting with Gorbachev. Bush said he would send the trade measure to the U.S. Congress if the Supreme Soviet passed a liberalized emigration law. He did not mention Lithuania. ``The linkage is between the emigration _ and that's it,'' Bush said at the news conference. The trade agreement would be a first step toward slashing tariffs on Soviet goods sold in the United States. It would also expand opportunities for U.S. companies in the Soviet Union by reducing red tape and providing greater protection against copyright piracy. The proposal is expected to get a cool reception on Washington's Capitol Hill. Many members of Congress have said they would not allow the Soviet Union to become a most-favored-nation trading partner until Gorbachev ended his economic squeeze on Lithuania. The most-favored-nation designation qualifies a trading partner for the lowest U.S. tariffs. The U.S. Senate passed a non-binding resolution last month seeking to halt any U.S.-Soviet trade agreements while the crackdown on Lithuania continues. Rep. Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, told NBC-TV that Bush faced ``growing unhappiness'' from conservative Republicans. He said they see Bush's actions as too conciliatory toward the Soviets. ``The pot has been stirred up even more'' by pushing trade without obtaining concessions on Lithuania and not linking the issues, Aspin said. Kazimiera Prunskiene, Lithuania's prime minister, told VOA that Gorbachev must know ``it is a big question yet'' whether Congress will approve the trade pact. ``Moscow cannot be sure of ratification while the Lithuanian question is unresolved,'' said Mrs. Prunskiene, who has met separately with Bush and Gorbachev in past weeks. She said Bush may have taken a tougher line against the blockade in private talks with Gorbachev and that the U.S. president might not have wanted to make that approach public.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Follow Worst Indiana Tornadoes in 16 Years; Death Toll 14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with second boy dying in Indiana, death toll up to 14 nationwide, governors seeking federal aid, UPDATES and CORRECTS Indiana death toll from 8 to 10; clarifies that damage in Illinois not limited to two counties named. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `In Albion...'. INSERTS 1 graf after 17th graf pvs, `More severe ..., to include car pileup; picking up 18th graf, `At least ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS2
DOC.TEXT: Tornadoes and thunderstorms throughout the Midwest killed 14 people, injured scores and left hundreds more homeless. Ten of the dead were in Indiana, where about 50 twisters touched down. The most disastrous tornado tore a five-mile swath through the southwestern Indiana town of Petersburg on Saturday. It killed six people, injured at least 57 and destroyed more than 150 homes. ``It looked to me like there had been a bombing run made right through the middle of Petersburg,'' said Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh, who viewed the town from the air Sunday. ``I'm confident we'll rebuild, but it will be tough.'' Residents of the mining and farming community of 3,000 already had been without fresh water for two weeks because of flooding that tore through levees along the White River and severed the water main. Bayh, who had requested federal disaster assistance after the floods, signed an amended request Sunday and sent it to President Bush. Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste also asked for disaster assistance after dozens of families in two Ohio counties were left homeless by the storm there. Tornadoes also were reported in Illinois, Minnesota, Kentucky and Michigan on Saturday. More deadly weather struck the Midwest on Sunday. Wind-toppled trees killed a 21-year-old woman camper in a state park in south-central Wisconsin and two boys, ages 6 and 8, in a town park in the central Indiana town of Mulberry. In Illinois, the storm Saturday destroyed about 50 homes and damaged more than 100, most of them in Jasper and Shelby counties. Authorities reported one woman died. In Albion, Ill., a new $4 million electronics warehouse was leveled, Edwards County Coroner Mark Curtis said. ``It's just total devastation,'' Curtis said. ``It's unbelievable. Everything they tell you about tornadoes _ the roar like a train, the wind _ is true.'' Also Saturday, a 10-year-old boy drowned in a storm-swollen river in Milwaukee and an 82-year-old man was killed by a wind-blown tree branch in the northwestern Missouri town of Stewartsville. A tornado in Harrison, Ohio, outside Cincinnati, destroyed 20 houses and 10 businesses and damaged another 100 houses and 50 businesses, police Sgt. Carl Butler said. No serious injuries were reported. Winds up to 70 mph in Kansas knocked down power lines, leaving nearly 50,000 homes without electricity and sparking grass fires. In Arkansas, thunderstorms dumped heavy rain, causing flash flooding that closed roads. Across Indiana, officials reported eight dead and at least 150 people injured Saturday in storms that left 24 cities in 15 counties with significant damage. Officials tracked about 50 tornado touchdowns during a four-hour period. The outbreak was the worst in Indiana since a tornado barrage in 1974 killed 47 people. A series of twisters on Palm Sunday in 1965 killed 137 people in 18 Indiana counties. The other Indiana tornado deaths were in Bedford, in the southern part of the state, and in Putnam County in west-central Indiana, said Jerome Hauer, director of the State Emergency Management Agency. Hauer said the tornadoes were particularly devastating because they spent long periods of time on the ground. One twister, he said, was on the ground 38 minutes. More severe thunderstorms and at least one tornado raked central Indiana on Sunday, downing trees and power lines. Clouds of black dust blown from freshly plowed fields created blackouts on highways in the northern part of the state, causing an 18-car pileup on U.S. Highway 31 outside South Bend. Five people sustained minor injuries, police said. At least 150 homes and 18 businesses in Petersburg were destroyed and 120 homes and 58 businesses were damaged when Saturday's tornado ripped through town, said Al Miller, field operations coordinator for the State Emergency Management Agency. At least 57 people were injured. There was no electricity in the town, and residents were urged to stay away from their damaged homes after dark. State police and the National Guard staffed roadblocks at the edge of town and used generators to shine floodlights on Main Street. ``We want to keep out the sightseers and looters and people who don't need to be here,'' said police Sgt. Norm Weber. Petersburg resident Mary Hall, 63, picked through the rubble of her collapsed home early Sunday. She and her husband, Clifton, had taken cover in the basement porch when the storm hit. ``The insurance man told us to save what we could, but there's really nothing left,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Leader Opens US Visit; First in 26 Years
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with Baker comments, grafs 1-7, picks up 5th graf pvs bgng: ``The agreement...''
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today after a meeting with Greek Premier Constantine Mitsotakis that U.S.-Greek relations have undergone a marked improvement since the new government took office in Athens two months ago. ``What we see is a prime minister and a government who is moving expeditiously, moving aggressively to cement and improve what have historically been good relations between the United States and Greece,'' Baker said. Baker spoke briefly with reporters at the Greek Embassy after an hour-long meeting with Mitsotakis, the first Greek head of government to be invited to the White House since 1964. A meeting with President Bush is scheduled for Wednesday. Baker gave Mitsotakis a rundown on the discussions Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev had over the weekend on the situation in Cyprus, where Turkish troops have been deployed since 1974. Calling the relationship with Greece ``very much improved,'' Baker cited the recent initialing of a U.S.-Greek base agreement and Greece's decision to establish relations with Israel. U.S. and Greek negotiators initialed the accord after just two rounds of talks. It will allow the U.S. military presence in Greece to continue, but two of the four U.S. bases in Greece _ Hellenikon Air Force Base near Athens, and a naval communications station _ will be closed. The agreement fulfilled a pledge by Mitsotakis to reach a base agreement with the United States. He leads the conservative New Democracy Party, which has 150 seats in the 300-member Parliament. One deputy who represents a small conservative grouping is backing Mitsotakis' party. The terms of the agreement will be made public once mutually acceptable translations are completed. Formal signing is expected in July. During the Socialist government of Premier Andreas Papandreau, the two sides were unable to conclude a base agreement despite 17 rounds of negotiations. U.S.-Greek relations were stormy during much of Papandreau's eight-year tenure. As a NATO ally, Greece is slated to receive $345 million in military aid during the next fiscal year. Both sides have refused comment on the financial aid aspects of the new agreement. The visit is listed as private but Mitsotakis has a number of meetings with U.S. government representatives. He will meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, among other administration officials, and several members of Congress. Mitsotakis, who was imprisoned by Nazi forces during World War II and by the Greek military dictatorship in the late 1960s, will attend the graduation of his son from Harvard on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says Jews Can Live Where They Want
LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Shamir defending right of Jews to live where they want; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today defended the right of Soviet Jews to live in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, saying Israel as a democracy could not keep new immigrants from the occupied territories. Shamir's statement came after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev threatened to limit the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel if they continued to settle on land seized from the Arabs in the 1967 Middle East war. Speaking in Washington after the summit with President Bush, Gorbachev said some Soviets have urged the government to ``postpone issuing permits for exit,'' unless Israel stops Soviet Jews from moving to the territories. Israeli officials said, however, that international and internal pressures probably would keep Gorbachev from carrying out the threat. The occupied lands _ where Palestinians have been in revolt against Israeli rule for 29 months _ are home to 1.7 million Palestinians and 70,000 Jewish settlers. Arab nations don't want large-scale settlement of Soviet Jews there. Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is at an all-time high. About 35,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel so far this year and the figure is expected to reach as high as 150,000. About 1 million Soviets are seeking permission to emigrate. Shamir told Israeli manufacturers in Tel Aviv that his government's policy was to allow Jews to live anywhere in ``the land of Israel,'' including the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank. ``If the U.S.S.R. of President Gorbachev does not think she can today tell her citizens where to live ... it is as clear as the sun that we, as followers of freedom and democracy, cannot limit this category or another of settlers.'' Benjamin Begin, a leading member of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, told Israel radio that Israelis must fight for the right of Jews to live in the occupied territories. Unless they do, he said, Jews would have to defend their right to live in Jerusalem's Jewish suburbs, land annexed by Israel. Most Western countries have not recognized that annexation. ``We must persuade the international community not to place in doubt the right of any Jew to settle anywhere in his homeland,'' Begin said. Although Israeli officials have defended the right of Soviet Jews to settle in the territories, they have also said few have chosen to do so. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said only about 200 of the Jews who have arrived this year moved to the West Bank and Gaza. Simha Dinitz, head of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, which handles immigration, said that since April 1989, 285 Soviet Jews have moved to the territories. But the Hebrew daily Haaretz today quoted a Jewish Agency document as saying that in the 12 months ending March 31, 1,300 new immigrants, most of them Soviets, had moved to the Jerusalem suburbs. After Gorbachev's comments on Sunday, Israeli Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz invited the Soviet leader to visit and see for himself that no sizable numbers of Soviet refugees are settling in the occupied territories. Gorbachev rejected the invitation. ``I will be frank, the time has not yet come to go there,'' he said in Minneapolis late Sunday. Israeli officials said Gorbachev's warning that he might limit Jewish emigration may undermine his image and credibility in the West. ``The policy of free emigration, including Jewish emigration, conforms with the Soviet Union's policy to end the Cold War,'' said Dan Naveh, adviser to Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. ``It's therefore hard to imagine that Gorbachev meant to reconsider the policy of free immigration and by that harm the trust and appreciation that he has earned in this field in the free world,'' Naveh said. Deputy Prime Minister David Levy said the Soviet Union ``is changing direction and it cannot be that only regarding Jews it would take a step that leads it backward and not forward, to progress and freedom.'' In the United States, the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, which lobbies for Soviet immigration, strongly rejected Gorbachev's warning as a violation of ``fundamental human rights.'' A Soviet move curbing emigration could put Gorbachev on a collision course with the United States and jeopardize a trade pact signed at the U.S.-Soviet summit. Bush said the trade agreement would not go to Congress for its required approval without liberalized Soviet emigration laws.

DOC.HEAD: Booksellers Say Business Better Than Ever
DOC.TEXT: No one seems to have time to read anymore, illiteracy is growing and censorship has become a burden, but other than that the book business has never been better. That was the report from a meeting of the American Booksellers Association, where publishers, authors and store owners are trying to guide their difficult industry into the 1990s. Delegates to the 90th annual trade show insist that any accounts of a publishing slump are premature, if not altogether wrong. ``The book trade in general _ from the booksellers' point of view _ is very healthy,'' said Ed Morrow, president of the group and a store owner in Manchester Center, Vt. ``People are responding to serious works, looking for the soul enrichment that they're not getting in other mediums.'' Morrow's optimism was reflected on the crowded convention floor. Pre-registration for the convention, which runs through Tuesday, was a record 24,000. That was a 47 percent increase for booksellers and a jump of 12 percent for exhibitors over last year. The convention floor was a mix of the literary and the loud. In one booth, an actor dressed as Spiderman complained about the burden of being a superhero. Just a few aisles away, the University of California Press touted its book, ``My Tibet,'' one of two major titles at the show written by the Dalai Lama. Fans lined up 100-deep to receive autographed copies of ``Get Shorty'' from mystery writer Elmore Leonard, and Grateful Dead drummer Mickey Hart was busily promoting his new book ``Drumming at the Edge of Magic: A Journey Into the Spirit of Percussion'' For the first time, there is a special section for children's books and a separate section called ``In Other Words: Books in Different Languages.'' The booksellers also organized a foundation to fight censorship, announcing the launch just a few days after a delay in the decision to publish the paperback version of Salman Rushdie's ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie has been in hiding since February 1989, after the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called his book blasphemous and said he should be killed.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers May Advertise Their Specialties, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today made it easier for lawyers to advertise themselves as specialists in some areas of the law. By a 5-4 vote, the justices said Illinois officials improperly censured an attorney who said on his professional letterhead he is a civil trial specialist certified by the National Board of Trial Advocacy (NBTA), a private organization. Justice John Paul Stevens, in the court's main opinion, said states may not ban potentially misleading information if the information also may be presented in a way that is not deceptive. He was joined by Justices William J. Brennan, Harry A. Blackmun and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Thurgood Marshall provided the fifth vote to overturn the censure of Gary E. Peel of Edwardsville, Ill. But Marshall said states could take steps _ short of an outright ban _ to assure that lawyer advertising is not misleading. Marshall said Peel could be required, for example, to say on his letterhead that the NBTA is a private group. Dissenting were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Byron R. White and Antonin Scalia. The Illinois Supreme Court, which disciplines that state's lawyers, had upheld a state rule against advertising oneself as a certified civil trial specialist. The state court censured Peel, who since 1983 included the specialist reference on his letterhead. The state court said Peel's use of the reference is misleading because it makes it appear he is more qualified than other lawyers who do the same type of work. Stevens said today, ``The facts stated on (Peel's) letterhead are true and verifiable. We are satisfied that the consuming public understands ... that a host of certificates ... are issued by private organizations. It seems unlikely that (Peel's) statement about his certification as a specialist by an identified national organization necessarily would be confused with formal state recognition.'' In Illinois, only lawyers who specialize in patent, trademark and admiralty law have been allowed to advertise their specialities. The Illinois Supreme Court said the reason for allowing those exceptions was to help the public find attorneys who practice those unusual specialities. The NBTA, based in Boston, said it uses ``rigorous standards'' to determine whether any civil or criminal trial advocate is entitled to its certification. It said it has certified more than 1,000 lawyers nationwide. The Supreme Court in 1977 struck down a ban on all lawyer advertising, ruling that it violated free-speech rights. Since then, the court has upheld some regulation of lawyer ads but struck down other rules. The case is Peel vs. Attorney Registration and Disciplinary Commission of Illinois, 88-1775.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Supreme Court Upholds Moratorium on Jury Trials For Civil Cases
DOC.TEXT: Justice delayed is not always justice denied, the Vermont Supreme Court said today as it upheld a six-month moratorium on civil jury trials in the state. The moratorium was imposed by the court in January as a way to cope with budget cuts prompted by the state's sagging economy. In today's decision, the state's highest court said constitutional guarantees to speedy trials do not mean instant ones. In its ruling, the court noted that the moratorium is temporary and it provides for exceptions ``where justice requires.'' The Supreme Court imposed the ban after it was ordered to cut about $300,000 from its current year budget to help avert a state deficit. The ban affected only civil cases _ such things as divorces, property disputes, personal injury claims, malpractice suits and breaches of contract. It did not affect criminal matters and will expire July 1. The 220-member Vermont Trial Lawyers Association filed a class-action lawsuit on behalf of 18 Vermonters seeking to overturn the ban. The association's suit claimed that both the federal and state constitutions guarantee Vermonters the right to a speedy trial. ``It violates the constitutional rights of everyone who has asked for a civil jury trial in the state of Vermont,'' association president Jerome O'Neill said. ``You can't simply decide that you're not going to provide civil jury trials.'' But the Supreme Court decision, written by retired Chief Justice Albert Barney, said that ``caseloads cannot be managed on the simplistic position that everyone is entitled to an immediate trial whenever they are ready for one.'' The Vermont Supreme Court decision is counter to a federal court ruling in California that held that civil jury trials in U.S. District Court could not be suspended because of fiscal restraints. But the Vermont justices said the federal ruling centered around the length of the moratorium, not the moratorium itself, and that Vermont moratorium delayed civil jury trials for ``a relatively short period of time.'' The moratorium on civil jury trials should save about $75,000, said Lee Suskin, director of trial court administration.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Refuses to Reconsider Oregon Drug-Religion Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected a request by an unusual coalition of religious groups that it reconsider its decision letting states outlaw the use of illegal drugs as a religious practice. The court, as expected, turned down the ``petition for rehearing'' without comment. Such requests are almost never granted. Groups including the American Jewish Congress, the National Association of Evangelicals, the National Council of Churches, the Presbyterian Church USA, Lutheran Church Missouri Synod, American Friends Service Committee, Americans United for Separation of Church and State and the Christian Legal Society had joined in filing the request. The April 17 high court ruling in an Oregon case said members of the Native American Church have no constitutional right to take the hallucinogenic drug peyote during religious ceremonies. Religious leaders said they were more disturbed by the court's method of deciding the case than by the decision's bottom line. Five members of 6-3 court majority agreed that religious beliefs cannot excuse failure to comply with ``otherwise valid laws prohibiting conduct states are free to regulate.'' The April decision did not require states to have a ``compelling reason'' before forcing someone to comply with laws interfering with religious beliefs. The case is Employment Division vs. Smith, 88-1213.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Catholic Man
DOC.TEXT: Masked gunmen killed a Roman Catholic man in his home and wounded two of his sons early today, police said, arousing fears of a new outbreak of sectarian violence. The attack came after the mainly Roman Catholic IRA, fighting to end British rule of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, said it was responsible for killing two British soldiers since Friday. In London, police investigating Irish Republican Army attacks detained several people under the Prevention of Terrorism Act, Scotland Yard reported. They can be held for a week without charge. Gunmen today killed 60-year-old Patrick Boyle when they burst into his home near Portadown in County Armagh, 25 miles southwest of Belfast, police said. One of the sons was severely wounded in the stomach and was in a serious condition, police said. The two or three attackers escaped in a stolen van that was found abandoned about a mile from the family home. Police said none of the Boyle family was a member of the security forces, and they knew of no motive for the attack. The Social Democratic and Liberal Party, the main Catholic party in Northern Ireland, blamed the attack on Protestant extremists. ``There is absolutely no reason why this family should have been singled out,'' said Seamus Mallon, deputy party leader and the local member of Parliament. ``It was a savage and sectarian attack on a totally innocent family.'' More than 2,700 people have been killed since sectarian violence erupted in Northern Ireland in 1969. The IRA has said members shot and killed an off-duty British army recruit at a train station in Lichfield, central England, on Friday afternoon. The group also said its gunmen on Saturday killed a British soldier near a British base in Dortmund, West Germany. In a stepped-up campaign in England, IRA bombers attacked two British army offices in London last month, killing a recruiting officer at one. Media reports in Britain said up to six suspects were rounded up over the past few days, some in raids in London and two on Friday as they were about to board a ferry to the Republic of Ireland. The IRA is fighting to unite Northern Ireland, a British province, with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland under a leftist administration.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Racial-Bias Challenge to Virginia School Board Practice
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected a racial-bias challenge to Virginia's practice of appointing, not electing, county and city school board members. The justices, without comment, let stand rulings that upheld the appointive system even though unlawfully discriminatory motives at times played a role in retaining it. Seven black Virginia residents and two groups, Citizens for a Better America and the Virginia unit of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, sued state authorities over the appointive system. The lawsuit alleged that the system unlawfully blunts the political clout of blacks in the state. How the members of Virginia's local school boards are appointed varies but the state-mandated appointive system dates back to 1870. U.S. District Judge Richard L. Williams in Richmond found no racially biased motive in the initial adoption of the system. But he said racial discrimination figured prominently in the state's decision at a 1901-02 constitutional convention to retain the system. The state General Assembly in 1947 passed a law permitting the election of school board members in some counties, and voters in Arlington County did so. But when the Arlington County school board voted in 1956 to racially desegregate its school system, the General Assembly repealed the 1947 law. Judge Williams found that the legislature's action was ``an effort to impede Arlington's ability to comply with court-ordered desegregation.'' But the judge, upheld last Nov. 24 by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, ruled that the appointive system's challengers had failed to prove that racially biased motives survive today. The appeals court ruled that state officials ``have proved that racial discrimination no longer motivates Virginia's decision to retain an appointive system for selecting school board members.'' The appeals court said that while statistics indicate some adverse impact on black representation, the challengers had failed to prove some discriminatory intent as well. ``The defendants have proved that the state does not currently maintain the system ... for discriminatory reasons,'' the 4th Circuit court said. The number of blacks serving on school boards across the state matches their percentage of the state's population _ about 18 percent. But in the appeal acted on today, the justices were told that blacks are underrepresented by at least one school board seat in 26 counties and four cities. Blacks are underrepresented on school boards in 20 of the state's 40 school districts where they comprise more than 30 percent of the population, the court was told. There are no black members on 50 of the 136 local school boards. ``There is continuing overt racial discrimination in the appointment of school boards,'' the appeal contended. The seven individuals who sued are Darius Irby and John S. Neal of Nottoway County, Charles W. White of Buckingham County, the Rev. James S. Wiliams Jr. of Prince Edward County, Cora Tucker of Halifax County, Willie Powell and Milton Richardson in Petersburg. The case is Irby vs. Virginia State Board of Elections, 89-1612.

DOC.HEAD: About 3 Million Throng Tomb on Anniversary of Khomeini Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 8th pvs, `As dawn...' to UPDATE crowd estimates; pickup 9th pvs, `A few...'
DOC.TEXT: More than one million mourners gathered today around the gold-domed tomb of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to mark the first anniversary of his death, some beating their chests in a frenzy of grief. ``Death To America,'' blared loudspeakers around the compound. ``Death To Israel.'' Inside the packed shrine, mourners listened as speakers recited verses from the Koran, the Islamic holy book. The gray-bearded Khomeini seemed to stare sternly at the crowd from pictures hung on the pillars. ``While There Is Islam, We Will Not Forget The Imam'' read one banner. Khomeini was considered the imam or supreme spiritual leader. Some, including a group of Pakistanis, beat their chests in a traditional Shiite Moslem sign of mourning as others sat under makeshift tents. One group of old men in white shrouds with red-and-green headbands, many of them toothless, also beat their breasts and chanted Islamic slogans. Helicopters carried officials to the shrine. The event, which climaxed a four-day mourning period, gathered no more than 3 million people around the shrine on the outskirts of Tehran, according to foreign reporters who flew over the scene by helicopter. Iran's official news media, however, said the occasion drew 8 million to 9 million people. A few of those arriving had official invitation cards, some wounded veterans of the Iran-Iraq war in wheelchairs pushed by Revolutionary Guards wearing black armbands. Maryam, a woman in her early 30s, lamented that ``I really loved the imam, he was the true and only leader of this revolution.'' Khomeini died at 10:45 p.m. on June 3 last year. When his death was officially announced the next day, millions poured into the streets, pounding themselves, scratching their faces and beating their breasts in grief. In a replay of those frenetic scenes, mourners thronged to his tomb in the Behesht-e-Zahra cemetery on the outskirts of Tehran on the anniversary. Hundreds of people, most of them conscripts or other civil servants who had been ordered to attend today's ceremonies, walked for days to arrive at the tomb. A young soldier who displayed the blisters on his feet from three days of walking said only that ``I came last year, and I had to come again this year.'' Two hundred thousand mourners were brought to Tehran from villages, towns and other cities in thousands of buses, the commander of the highway police told Iranian news media. Hundreds of Shiite Moslems from other countries such as Pakistan, Bangladesh, India, Syria and Lebanon were invited to attend. Elsewhere, hundreds gathered inside the mosque adjoining Khomeini's old house in the northern Tehran suburb of Jamaran on Sunday, sobbing and beating themselves as they looked at the small, empty balcony from which Khomeini used to address the nation. Only a year after Khomeini's death, many of his followers who actively participated in the 1979 revolution that ousted Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi have become disillusioned. But many Iranians contend that although the revolution has soured, Khomeini was sincere in what he wanted to achieve for his people. There are many who are disgruntled with the country's economic conditions, widespread official corruption and the unfulfilled promises of the revolution. Most of the economic woes are due to the eight-year war with Iraq and Khomeini's implacable anti-Western stance, which Iran's present leaders are having a difficult time circumventing in order to get foreign investment and Western technology. Khomeini's staunch followers, like his only surviving son, Ahmad, an important figure in the so-called radical camp within the leadership, want no deviation from his teaching.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Alabama Business Tax Intact
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact an Alabama tax attacked as ``grossly discriminatory'' against out-of-state businesses. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that the tax interferes unduly with interstate commerce and violates equal protection rights. The Alabama Supreme Court, while acknowledging that the tax is more onerous for out-of-state businesses, concluded that it is valid. ``There is no unconstitutional unequal treatment of foreign corporations and no unconstitutional discrimination against them,'' the state court ruled last Dec. 21. The tax was challenged by General Motors and its subsidiaries and by Reynolds Metals Co., which is based in Richmond, Va., and is a producer of aluminum. Alabama imposes a franchise tax on all business conducted in the state. Companies based outside the state pay a tax of $3 for every $1,000 worth of capital in the state. In-state companies pay $10 for every $1,000 worth of all outstanding stock. Lawyers for GM and Reynolds Metals told the justices that the two methods of calculating the tax result in enormously higher taxes for out-of-state businesses. ``The reason ... is that while the amount of business activity conducted and total capital employed in Alabama means everything in determining the foreign corporation's tax liability,'' GM's appeal said, ``business activity and total capital employed mean nothing in determining the domestic corporation's liability.'' For 1982 and 1983, Alabama collected $94 million in franchise taxes from out-of-state businesses based on 28,792 tax returns and less than $10 million from in-state businesses based on 81,698 returns. Adjustments to the tax law took effect in 1984 but that year out-of-state businesses paid $49.6 million in franchise taxes and in-state businesses paid $14.7 million. Reynolds Metals paid about $1.2 million in franchise taxes for 1982 and 1983, the years for which it sued for refunds. GM sued over the years 1983 through 1988, in which it paid $6.3 million in Alabama franchise taxes. The two appeals acted on today were supported by the State Tax Council of the State Chambers of Commerce and an organization called the Tax Executives Institute. ``The broad implication of the (state) court's holding is that ... discrimination against out-of-state taxpayers will be tolerated,'' lawyers for the Chamber of Commerce's council said. ``If interstate business is to be protected from discriminatory state taxes, the decision of the Alabama Supreme Court must be reviewed.'' The cases are GM vs. Alabama Department of Revenue, 89-1574, and Reynolds Metals vs. Sizemore, 89-1587.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Addresses Business Leaders During Minneapolis Stopover
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 3 to include Gorbachev comments warning businessmen not to wait to enter into agreements with his country.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the speech of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to a group of U.S. business executives on Sunday:

A few hours ago President Bush and I together at our press conference summed up the results of the Washington summit. I personally believe that this summit will go down in history as a summit of hope and optimism. ... It took us some time, a long time and a long road, to reach this stage in our relationship. I don't know. Sometimes when we express big hopes we have to knock on wood. Anyway, let me say that we do have high hopes. We hope that there will be very important political and political-military consequences of this summit and also very positive consequences in all other spheres of relations between our countries. ... The important question is what kind of Soviet Union do the president and the U.S. people want to see? Does America want to see a Soviet Union that lacks confidence, that is not stable, that is in turmoil? Or does America want to see the Soviet Union as a noble democratic state which is moving toward new forms of life within the overall framework of humanism and democracy _ a Soviet Union that is working with the entire global civilization, integrated in that civilization? So this is the alternative, and basically the same alternative confronts us. That is to say, what kind of U.S. do we want to see? I have thought about that for a long time. ... A world that is not comfortable for the U.S. is not comfortable for us. ... The president and I spent several hours together, the two of us, during this visit. Our final discussions were in Camp David without neckties, our sleeves rolled up, and we discussed things in a very intensive way and I feel that as a result we have a new degree of confidence and mutual understanding. ... Now my second point is about the process of change in our economy, about perestroika in our economy. I would like to be brief. Many of you, I think, must have visited Moscow or, I don't know, maybe quite a few have not. I listened and talked to members of the Economic Council in Moscow and I tried to tell them what we intend to do with our economy, and how we plan to do it. The last five years is a period that has not been simple for us. We had to sort things out to understand what kind of a society we have. What are the good things that we are able to do and what are the misjudgments that we have to abandon. We were trying to do that in a very thorough way, and also in a very tough way toward ourselves. In a self-critical way toward ourselves. And, in addition to studying ourselves, we were trying also to test certain new elements and new forms of economic management. ... We tried quite a few things in order to gain experience and tried to place our management people and production units into a new situation, new conditions, new circumstances and we have seen that the whole process moved ahead with great difficulty. Why? Because of that command system that we have. The command system in politics and in the economy. Our economic managers, many of them very good people who know how to work, were used to a system of commands, to a system of taking orders from above, and that really happened (for) many, many years, many decades. And a certain type of individual, a certain type of economic manager evolved, and it is very difficult to abandon those old ways, particularly for people who are not that young. ... But in the same way the command system worked as regards those who actually worked the machines, who actually drive the tractors, who work in the research labs, all of them too basically are that type of individual. They of course wanted freedom and economic autonomy but once they got that, they were afraid. They didn't know how to use that much freedom. So this gives you an idea of the scope of the problems. And this is how we began. ... Changing a system means changing people, intelligent people. It's not just a system, some kind of layout that you see on a piece of paper and you can just tear up that piece of paper. A system is people, people who live, people who have their own interests, who have their own lives and we have this conflict of interest and really had a problem trying to move these new economic forms ahead. And we were only able to approach that when we began a political reform that involved the masses of the people in the political process. ... If the economic reform is successful, then people will not need rallies, demonstrations, and so on, although, of course, quite a few rallies and demonstrations I think are going to happen before we are successful in economic reform. ... We have made mistakes, this is true. There has been some damage done to our economy. We have had some problems in management because the old system of running the economy has become weaker and the new economic leaders, the new economic forms of a market economy, have not yet evolved properly. The entire structure of a market economy is only beginning to evolve. So therefore we need to adopt a number of other laws and documents that will make it possible for our economy to really work among market principles. So I think that we are now at this watershed when we are ready to move resolutely toward the market. This is what we are doing now, this is I think what will be decisive for the entire perestroika, the future of perestroika. ... We are having now a very crucial situation in which we would like to hope for your cooperation and for your understanding. ... Those who are with us at this time have a good prospect of cooperation in our great country, in our great market because of its tremendous potential. But those who just stand on the sidelines, who do not want to risk, who want to wait and see, who don't want to risk their dollars _ well, they will remain I think observers for years to come. We'll make sure that that is so. ...

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Student Prayer Groups Must Be Allowed in Public Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 6-18, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: Student prayer groups must be allowed to meet at public schools that permit other organized extracurricular activities, the Supreme Court ruled today. The justices, voting 8-1, said a 1984 federal law aimed at permitting religious clubs in public schools does not violate constitutionally required separation of church and state. The court overruled Omaha, Neb., school officials who refused to approve a high school Bible-reading club. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing for the court, said the Equal Access Act of 1984 passes the court's long-standing three-part test aimed at assuring separation of church and state. The law grants equal access to both secular and religious speech, does not have the primary effect of advancing religion and does not cause excessive entanglement between government and religion, she said. In other action, the court: _ Ruled that police undercover agents may seek to elicit confessions froms jailed criminal suspects without first having to give so-called Miranda warnings. By an 8-1 vote, the justices said jailed criminal suspects need not be told about their right to remain silent or to get a lawyer's help before4 being questioned by someone secretly working for the police. _ Used a dispute over Haitian refugee rights to strengthen a federal law requiring the government to pay legal fees to winning opponents in lawsuits. The court unanimously rejected Bush administration arguments aimed at limiting the attorneys' fees. _ Ruled that nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue their employers under state personal injury laws. The court unanimously said such lawsuits are not pre-empted by a federal law protecting such whistleblowers. _ Agreed to hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at giving federal officials more power to deny temporary legal status to immigrant farmworkers. The court, without comment, said it will review a ruling that said the workers are entitled to various procedural protections when applying for such residential permits. _ Agreed to study the government's power to lift price controls on some natural gas, a case that has tens of millions of dollars at stake for consumers. The justices said they will review federal regulations that, among other things, allow gas producers to raise some prices charged to pipeline companies. _ Agreed to decide whether passengers on international flights may sue airlines for the emotional distress they allegedly suffer in near-crashes that cause them no physical harm. The court said it will review a ruling that Eastern Airlines may be forced to pay passeng4ers who were on a flight that landed safely in Miami after all the plane's engines failed briefly in the air. In the school-prayer case, O'Connor said there is little risk that students will view an extracurricular Bible-reading club as indicating school officials endorse religion. ``The possibility of student peer pressure remains,'' she said. ``But there is little if any risk of official state endorsement or coercion where no formal classroom activities are involved and no school officials actively participate.'' Congress in the Equal Access Act said public high schools accepting federal aid must not discriminate against groups based on ``the religious, political, philosphical or other content of the speech at such meetings.'' The law requires access to school facilities for religious clubs if other ``non-curriculum-related student groups'' are allowed to meet. At Westside High School in Omaha, officials authorized some 30 such activities, including chess, scuba diving and photography clubs. The officials said the clubs are related to classroom work or other aspects of the school curriculum. For example, they said chess helps students learn mathematics and logic and scuba diving is tied to the school's physical fitness program. The officials said the 1984 act, therefore, should not apply to them. But they also argued that if the law does apply, it should be declared unconstitutional as a government-sponsored establishment of religion. Some groups who supported the school officials, such as the National School Boards Assocation, said the 1984 law is a thinly disguised move to return prayer to the public schools. The Supreme Court in 1962 banned organized, school-sponsored prayer sessions for students. The Bush administration defended the 1984 law as a legitimate attempt to protect religious liberty for students. Students at Westside High sought recognition in 1985 of a Christian Bible study club to meet after school hours on school grounds. Officials refused to approve it, and suggested the students meet instead at a church next door. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1989 overruled a federal judge and said the club must be allowed to meet on school premises. The Supreme Court in 1981 said state-run universities cannot ban student groups from using campus facilities for religious worship and study. But before today, the justices had not decided whether the same rule should apply to public high schools. Today, Justices Thurgood Marshall and William J. Brennan concurred in the outcome of the Westside High School case, but expressed some serious reservations. Marshall, in an opinion joined by Brennan, said schools such as Westside must be careful to ``effectively disassociate themselves from the religious speech that now may become commonplace in their facilities.'' Justice John Paul Stevens dissented. He said today's ruling could force schools to open their doors ``to every religious, political or social organization, no matter how controversial or distasteful its views may be.'' The case is Board of Education vs. Mergens, 88-1597.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Asks For Bush Administration Input On Football Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration to offer its opinions about key limitations on free agency in the National Football League. The court asked Justice Department lawyers to comment on a lower court's ruling that NFL restrictions on a player's switch to another team do not violate federal antitrust law. The justices are not expected to say whether they will review that ruling until hearing from the government lawyers, which could take months. No further court action in the case is likely before October, when the justices return from their summer recess, scheduled for late June or early July. The antitrust case is an outgrowth of a 24-day strike in 1987 by the National Football League Players Association. The walkout ended without a new contract between the players and the league's 28 team owners. But the owners continued to enforce an expired contract, signed in 1982, containing provisions that restrict free agency. The provisions limit a player's ability to negotiate and sign with a new team. The player's original team is given the right to match a competing club's offer. If the original team declines to match the offer, the player's new team must compensate the other team with draft choices. The provisions are called the league's first refusal-compensation system. The NFL has a separate provision, known as Plan B, in which teams protect 37 players and permit the rest to become free agents. The players association filed a federal lawsuit in 1987, accusing the league and team owners of violating antitrust law by enforcing the first refusal-compensation system after the expiration of the 1982 contract. The owners said they are exempt from antitrust law, arguing that the old collective bargaining agreement still is valid. They said the players union is trying to win in court what it was unable to win at the bargaining table. U.S. District Judge David Doty of Minneapolis in 1988 ruled in favor of the players, ordering a trial to determine whether the owners were guilty of antitrust violations. But the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned Doty's decision last November. In a 2-1 ruling, the appeals court said the league and owners were exempt from antitrust law because of the previously negoiated union contract. The players' choice now is between further negotiations or a strike, the appeals court said. Permitting them to sue under such circumstances would upset the ``level playing field'' created by federal labor law, it added. In a dissenting opinion, Judge Gerald W. Heaney said the appeals court ruling ``permits the owners to violate the antitrust law indefinitely.'' The 8th Circuit court's decision was hailed by the owners as a major victory that would spur the players to return to the bargaining table. The players association responded by de-certifying itself as the players bargaining agent, a move designed to nullify the 1982 contract and revive the antitrust suit. Nine current and former union officials substituted themselves for the association in filing the appeal acted on today. They said the 8th Circuit court ruling amounts to ``a virtually unlimited antitrust exemption for employers in unionized industries.'' Eight states supported the appeal, saying their efforts to curtail anti-competitive behavior could be hampered by the appeals court ruling. The states are New York, Arizona, Hawaii, Louisiana, Michigan, Texas, Utah and Wyoming. The case is Powell vs. NFL, 89-1421.

DOC.HEAD: Court Strengthens Federal Law on Legal Fees
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today used a dispute over Haitian refugee rights to strengthen a federal law requiring the government to pay legal fees to winning opponents in lawsuits. The court unanimously rejected Bush administration arguments aimed at limiting the attorneys fees. The justices said the government generally must reimburse winning opponents not only for the legal fees they incur in the main lawsuit, but also for subsequent litigation over the size of those fees. The Haitian refugees sued the government in 1981 over its policy of locking up aliens caught while trying to enter the United States illegally. Until 1981, the government generally allowed the aliens to go free on parole pending hearings on their applications for admission to the country. The Haitians said they almost never were paroled before their applications were acted upon, a process that can take longer than a year. The refugees accused the government of discriminating against them because they are black and also said the Immigration and Naturalization Service violated federal rules by summarily adopting harsher treatment for Haitians than other aliens. The refugees ultimately won an important, though not total, victory. The did not win on the discrimination claim. But the government conceded that the INS may not consider race or national origin in determining parole and adopted new rules on refugees. Federal courts that reviewed the case said there is no doubt that the Haitians won their freedom because of the lawsuit, and those refugees later returned to custody were detained under new, fairer rules. The government argued that the Haitians did not win key elements of their lawsuit and should not be entitled to recover legal fees under the Equal Access to Justice Act. The act generally requires reimbursement of legal fees for those who prevail in suits against the government. A federal judge ruled against the government on the fees question in the Haitian case and awarded more than $1 million to lawyers who represented the refugees. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals substantially upheld the judge's decision and ordered further hearings to recompute the amount owed the lawyers. The appeals court also said the government must reimburse the Haitians' lawyers for fees they incurred litigating the fees issue _ what the appeals court called the ``fees-for-fees'' issue. The Supreme Court today agreed, rejecting the government's argument that the ``fees-for-fees'' claim should be denied because the government's position in the fee litigation was ``substantially justified.'' Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, said that since the government lost the principle part of the case it is not entitled to relitigate the fees issue. The case is Commissioner of INS vs. Jean, 89-601.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Actor Jack Gilford Dies of Stomach Cancer At 81
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, `Other movie..., with 16 grafs of background. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Jack Gilford, a sad-eyed comic, dramatic actor and vaudevillian who shone in featured roles on stage, television and movies, died at his Manhattan home this morning, a spokeswoman said. He was 81. Gilford died after a long struggle with stomach cancer and had last been at a hospital two weeks ago, according to Merle Debuskey, a family friend and publicist. He was at his Greenwich Village home with his actress wife, Madeline Lee, when he died about 8 a.m., Debuskey said. Gilford was twice nominated for Tony awards in Broadway musicals _ as Hysterium, the slave who ends up in drag in ``A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' and as Herr Shultz in ``Cabaret.'' He was Hysterium again in the movie film version of ``Forum.'' He received an Academy Award supporting-actor nomination for the movie ``Save the Tiger,'' in which he played the partner to Jack Lemmon's garment manufacturer. Lemmon won an Oscar for the film. On Broadway he was seen also in ``The Diary of Anne Frank,'' ``The Tenth Man,'' ``The World of Sholom Aleichem'' and ``Romanoff & Juliet.'' He performed as the mute king with Carol Burnett in stage and television versions of ``Once Upon A Mattress,'' and did guest turns on numerous TV comedy and dramatic series, including ``The Defenders,'' ``All in the Family,'' ``Rhoda,'' ``The Love Boat,'' ``Taxi,'' ``Soap,'' ``Head of the Class'' and ``Golden Girls.'' Gilford could convulse an audience with slapstick or bring tears with portrayals of ``little'' men overwhelmed by circumstance. One off-beat triumph in his 55-year career was in the non-singing role of the drunken jailer in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ``Die Fledermaus.'' He did the part in the 1950 production and many later ones. ``I also played a single act at the Palace in that same year. There are not too many people who played the Met and the Palace in the same year,'' he once told an interviewer. But work in front of cameras dried up for the versatile Gilford during the McCarthy era, as it did for numerous show-business people with leftward political sentiments. ``One day the phone just stopped ringing and I didn't do TV or films for 10 years,'' Gilford said after the telephone resumed ringing in the late 1960s. Small parts on Broadway and nightclub work saw him through. Among his other movie credits were ``Cocoon,'' ``Enter Laughing,'' ``The Incident,'' ``Catch-22,'' ``They Might Be Giants'' and ``Who's Minding the Mint.'' A commercial he appeared in for Crackerjack in the 1970s was an award-winner at the Cannes Festival. In 1982 he starred in a one-hour cable television production, ``The Very Special Jack Gilford Special.'' Born Jacob Gellman and raised in Brooklyn, Gilford began his career in 1934 at an amateur night on a stage in the Bronx. He got work in vaudeville and nightclubs, toured four years with Milton Berle and Ina Ray Hutton and began appearing in Broadway revues in 1939. Gilford married Miss Lee, a producer, actress and writer, in 1949, and they had three children, Lisa, of Denver; Joseph, of New York; and Samuel, of Montague, Mass. Services were to be private. In lieu of flowers, the family asked that donations be sent to the Actors' Fund of America in Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Capture Key Checkpoint Near Airport, Doe Appeals for U.S. Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with checkpoint falling, Doe appeal. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `Many of...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebels today captured a key army checkpoint near the international airport outside Monrovia, an airline official said, and President Samuel Doe appealed for U.S. help as the rebels advanced on the city. More than 50 U.S. Embassy workers, missionaries and their families and hundreds of Liberians crowded another airport inside the capital amid fears there would be a bloodbath if the rebels took the city. British Airways manager David Ranger said rebels seized the army checkpoint seven miles east of the international airport, which is 35 miles southeast of the capital. Ranger said his airline canceled its flights to the West African nation for the rest of the week, but other airlines still planned to fly. Four warships of the U.S. Navy's 6th Fleet, carrying 2,000 marines, were expected to arrive off the coast today or Tuesday in case an emergency evacuation of the estimated 2,000 remaining Americans becomes necessary. Doe called on ``all peace-loving nations,'' including the United States, ``to come to the aid of the Liberian people.'' ``It is the wishes of the people of this country that America can do something to stop the bloodshed,'' he said in a telephone interview from Liberia with Cable News Network. The U.S. State Department has accused rebel leader Charles Taylor of receiving some support from Libya, but it also has said Marines will not intervene in support of Doe's government. He has ordered his troops into their barracks because of charges they were assaulting and killing members of tribal groups who have supported the rebels. No defense lines were visible in the capital or on the road to the airport. Doe's military commander, Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar, appeared to be counting on the Marines to step in and save the capital. ``The armed forces of Liberia would not consider a Marine landing an invasion,'' he said. ``We are very happy about them coming. It is long overdue. The rebels are Libyan-backed so we felt the United States should come to our aid immediately. Just the presence of the marines here will scare the rebels away.'' The rebels are mostly members of the Gio and Mano tribes and invaded the country of 2.5 million people from the neighboring Ivory Coast about five months ago. The State Department last week ordered all non-essential U.S. government personnel and their families to leave immediately. About 75 Americans remained at the embassy, said spokesman David Krekke. At Spriggs Payne Airfield, about five miles from the city center, about 50 Americans, 20 South Koreans and a few British and Canadians left aboard a chartered Boeing 737 to Freetown, capital of Sierra Leone. In the city, people of the Mandingo and Krahn tribes loyal to Doe piled their belongings into taxis, trucks and buses, fleeing reprisals by rebels threatening to attack the capital. ``If they come, they'll massacre us. So we're going,'' said a father of four children as he stacked a mattress onto the back of a truck. He and two other Mandingo families were heading for Sierra Leone. Taxi drivers said the exodus had caused a traffic jam at the border. Many of the hundreds of fleeing Liberians were families of soldiers trying to get on two planes that have been used for the past week to ferry people of President Doe's Krahn tribe to their eastern Grand Gedeh County stronghold. Grand Gedeh has not been affected by the civil war. Doe has been holed up in his presidential mansion in the capital. He is protected by about 1,000 Israeli-trained troops. Diplomats say a high desertion rate has helped shrink the Liberian army, which was believed to number 4,500 at the beginning of the conflict, to roughly 3,000 to 4,000 fighters _ about as many as the rebels. Rebels have killed Krahn and Mandingo civilians in retaliation for government troop atrocities against Gio and Mano civilians. International human rights organizations say the soldiers have killed hundreds of civilians and the rebels scores. About 2,000 Gios and Manos overflowed the compound of St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Monrovia today, where they have been put under the protection of the International Committee of the Red Cross. Dozens of cars lined up for gasoline in the capital Sunday. There were fistfights at some gas stations. Taxi drivers said there were reports that a gas shortage would worsen because no new supplies were expected before the end of the week. The government tried to end the panic in a state radio broadcast, reassuring residents that plenty of gasoline was available. Doe, who seized power in 1979 in a bloody coup, announced on Friday that he would not run in scheduled 1991 elections. The announcement was an apparent bid to bring the rebels to the negotiating table. Both Doe and rebel leader Taylor refuse to negotiate directly. ``It is turning into a personal conflict between Doe and Taylor at the expense of a tribal bloodbath,'' said an expatriate who has worked in Liberia for 20 years. Taylor was a close aide of Doe who headed the government agency responsible for disbursing public funds. He fled the country after the Liberian leader accused him of stealing $1 million from state coffers. Taylor has denied the charges, but Doe says he will not negotiate with a criminal. Descendants of freed U.S. slaves founded Liberia in 1822, and it became Africa's first independent country in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Against California Bar in Lawyers' Suit
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers may withhold their state bar association dues if the association uses the money to campaign for political or social causes, a unanimous Supreme Court ruled today. The court said a California bar group violated the free-speech rights of 21 lawyers who did not want their dues spent to promote such causes as a nuclear weapons freeze and handgun control. ``Compulsory dues may not be expended to endorse or advance a gun control or nuclear weapons freeze (ballot) initiative,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. Conversely, he said, the free-speech rights of lawyers are not violated when their dues are used to help discipline members of the bar or to propose ethical codes for the profession. The justices overturned a California Supreme Court ruling last year that said the bar association was free to use the money for practically anything but financing campaigns of candidates for public office. The California court said the bar association, with power to help license and discipline lawyers, is more like a state agency than a labor union. The U.S. Supreme Court previously has limited the power of unions to spend dues money for public-issue lobbying. Today, Rehnquist said the bar association is more like a union than a typical government agency _ noting the lawyers group is funded not by the taxpayers but by members dues. Also, he said, the bar association was formed primarily as an advisory organization. Lawyers are licensed or disciplined by the state Supreme Court with advice from the association. The ruling buttresses decisions by courts outside of California that have limited the power of state bar associations to use members' dues for ideological purposes. The case is Keller vs. State Bar of California, 88-1905.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Says He is Optimistic About Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT name of college to Williams sted Wilkins.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis says the state's fiscal woes and his defeat in the 1988 presidential election have not quelled his optimism about the future. The shift toward democracy in Eastern Europe augured a promising era for the nation's newest graduates, Dukakis said in a commencement speech Sunday at Williams College. ``For someone who graduated from college in the '50s when Joe McCarthy was terrorizing the nation and Joe Stalin was terrorizing the world, I think the graduates of the class of 1990 are entering an era in world history more promising, more hopeful and more likely to reflect democratic values than at any time in this century,'' he said. ``That may sound a bit puzzling, coming from someone who suffered a very disappointing loss in the last presidential campaign, and returned to a state that has had serious fiscal difficulties for the past year and a half,'' he said. However, Dukakis sounded a warning about the health of democracy in the United States. Voters in Czechoslovakia stood in line for hours to cast their ballots and exercise their newfound democratic rights, he said. But in the United States, voter turnouerturned a California Supreme Court ruling last year that said the bar association was free to use the money for practically anything but financing campaigns of candidates for public office. The California court said the bar association, with power to help license and discipline lawyers, is more like a state agency than a labor union. The U.S. Supreme Court previously has limited the power of unions to spend dues money for public-issue lobbying. Today, Rehnquist said the bar association is more like a union than a typical government agency _ noting the lawyers group is funded not by the taxpayers but by members dues. Also, he said, the bar association was formed primarily as an advisory organization. Lawyers are licensed or disciplined by the state Supreme Court with advice from the association. The ruling buttresses decisions by courts outside of California that have limited the power of state bar associations to use members' dues for ideological purposes. The case is Keller vs. State Bar of California, 88-1905.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Off to Denmark to Pursue US-Soviet Dispute Over Germany
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs U.S. plan on Germany; picks up 4th graf pvs, The human ...
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is flying to Copenhagen today to take up a nine-point Western plan for resolving an impasse over the military future of Germany with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Baker also will meet in the Danish capital with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. The separate sessions will be held on Tuesday amid a 35-nation conference on human rights. Among the ideas Baker will pursue is a possible ``political agreement'' between NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact as one way of reassuring Moscow, should it drop its objections to a unified Germany joining the Western military alliance, Baker said Sunday. Other approaches also under discussion include a strengthening of the 35-nation European Security Conference, which the Soviets have demanded, and a timetable for negotiations on tactical nuclear missiles, U.S. officials said. Additionally, Baker will assure the Soviets that NATO troops would not be stationed on what is now East German territory, while the Red Army could remain for some time, the officials told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. Baker and the 15 other NATO foreign ministers, including Genscher, will take up the difficult German problem again on Thursday at a meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Turnberry, Scotland. The human rights conference and the meeting of the Western allies were already on the agenda before President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met for their four-day summit, which ended Sunday in Washington. But the Bush-Gorbachev dispute over Germany's military future gave Baker's trip extra significance. Baker plans to meet with Shevardnadze again, in Berlin, later in the month. Gorbachev wound up his talks with Bush saying the two superpowers would work toward a mutually acceptable solution. Baker said ``there are some ideas.'' One of them, he said, might be a ``political agreement of some sort '' between the two alliances _ the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. Baker, on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' said the proposals under study came from the United States, the Soviet Union and the NATO allies. Among them were some previously aired: a more political, rather than military, spin on German membership in NATO and Genscher's proposal to keep NATO troops out of the territory that is now East Germany. ``We'll keep wrestling with it,'' Baker said. Gorbachev, for his part, declared Sunday that ``I cannot say that we have reached agreement, but that does not mean that our efforts were futile. Many new arguments emerged as a result of these discussions, and new possible perspectives.'' ``We will continue our discussion in order to find a mutually acceptable solution,'' Gorbachev said. Gorbachev has repeatedly insisted that a unified Germany not be aligned with NATO. He argues that in an era of democratic change, his own people see the alliance as an anti-Soviet remnant of the Cold War, and, having lost 27 million lives to Nazi Germany in World War II, would be offended by the membership of a new, more powerful Germany in that organization. Bush, at a joint news conference, said that a united Germany in NATO ``would be stabilizing.'' He said he did not think his differences with Gorbachev on the issue had been narrowed during the summit. U.S. officials said last week that Gorbachev had proposed creation of a new all-European council to consider military questions arising from the impending merger of East Germany and West Germany. Among them would be the size of the German army.
