Late Sunday, a senior U.S. official said Gorbachev was ``in full accord'' with Bush that Germans had the right to make a decision about NATO membership by virtue of the 1975 Helsinki agreement signed by 35 nations. ``It's the first time he has done that with the president,'' said the official, who sought out reporters while insisting he not be quoted by name or otherwise identified. ``He said that he agreed that this was up to the German people to decide,'' the official said. ``We'll have to see what that means.''

DOC.HEAD: Bunny Behind Bars
DOC.TEXT: A small, white rabbit was jailed after being found loitering around this sleepy town in south Finland, police said Monday. A man on his morning walk Saturday spotted the bunny and alerted local police. A patrol fetched the animal and put it in custody, a police spokesman said. ``We have nowhere else to keep it, so we put it in jail. We are just doing our duty,'' Sgt. Antero Pennanen said. Pennanen said police officers were feeding the animal dandelion leaves. He said the animal is a suspected pet on the run. ``There have been lots of phone calls and offers to give it a home, but we are still looking for its right owner,'' Pennanen said. After studying a book on pets, police concluded the rabbit was of Russian stock.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Clash With Police; 30 Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Scores of skinheads armed with baseball bats and sticks brawled with East Berlin police, and 30 people were arrested, the East German government news agency said Monday. About 100 of the young right-wing radicals gathered around houses where they believed leftists lived, ignored a police order to leave and attacked the officers, ADN said. One officer suffered a broken nose in the Saturday night clash. Thirty of the radicals, three of them West Germans, were arrested, the news agency said. The gang of youths, their ages between 16 and 19, also threatened passsers-by and damaged two cars, it said. The clash was the latest in a recent series of violent attacks in East Germany by skinheads, youths with closely shaved heads who espouse a hatred of foreigners, leftists and homosexuals.

DOC.HEAD: 31 Die in Boat Accident
DOC.TEXT: An overcrowded boat sank off the northern coast of Mozambique, and at least 31 people died, the AIM news agency reported Monday. Thirty people were known to have survived when the boat sank Saturday in the Bay of Pemba, AIM said. Maritime officials were still searching for survivors but did not know how many people were aboard the boat. The boat was carrying more than double its capacity at the time of the disaster.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese to be Among Last to Taste Beaujolais Nouveau
DOC.TEXT: Japanese wine lovers will be among the last in the world to taste the 1990 Beaujolais Nouveau in November due to the enthronement ceremony for Japan's Emperor Akihito. No chartered cargo flights into Japan will be allowed for security reasons during a period of 10 days around the Nov. 11-12 ceremony, an official of the French Embassy said, speaking anonymously. Japanese drinkers normally enjoy the privilege of being the first to taste the Beaujolais Nouveau -- eight hours earlier than in France. Consumption of the new wine is usually put on sale after midnight on the third Thursday of November because of a marketing strategy by the Union Interprofessionelle des Vins du Beaujolais in France. This year's wine will be available in Japan on Nov. 22, a week behind the rest of the world, the official said. An official of Suntory Ltd., a major Japanese distiller and importer of the wine, predicted that sales in Japan will not be affected by the one week's delay because the company has found that ``Beaujolais Nouveau's popularity increases year after year'' in Japan. Suntory imported some 58,880 cases of the 1989 Beaujolais Nouveau. ``Japanese won't make much fuss about being the first'' in tasting the wine, Hisao Matsushita, manager of Foods and Beverages for the Narita View Hotel, near Tokyo's Narita airport. Last year the hotel sponsored wine-tasting parties to mark the beginning of the wine season.
DOC.HEAD: END
Two Iraqi Passenger Jets Run Off Runway, Five Injured
DOC.TEXT: Two Iraqi passenger jets overshot the runway at Istanbul's Ataturk airport Monday in separate incidents, and five people were injured, the Anatolia news agency reported. The dispatch said the two planes, both flying from Baghdad, were involved in almost identical accidents 90 minutes apart. After overshooting the runway, the planes came to a halt in a field, Anatolia said. Five people were injured when passengers were evacuated through escape chutes, it said. One plane, a Boeing 707, was carrying 155 passengers and the second one, a Boeing 727, had 58 aboard, Anatolia reported.

DOC.HEAD: Jon Akass, Fleet Street Columnist, Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Daily Express newspaper columnist Jon Akass, a 30-year veteran of Fleet Street, died of cancer early Monday, his editor said. He was 56. Akass began his career as a teaboy, or messenger, for the Glasgow Herald. He worked for regional newspapers and came to national attention at the Manchester office of the now defunct Daily Herald when he was asked to write a front-page story about a plane crash at Munich Airport. The crash killed 21 people, including half the Manchester United soccer team. His editor admired his writing style and, at age 24, Akass was called to the paper's head office in London to write a column four times a week. ``He was a brilliant writer who had a quite unique touch and he will be irreplaceable,'' said Daily Express editor Nicholas Lloyd. Akass is survived by his wife Peggy and four children: Jon, William, Mark and Jackie.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes in Chilean Treasury Building, Kills Policeman
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a second-floor hallway of the downtown Treasury Building on Monday morning, killing a police explosives expert who was trying to remove it, authorities said. No one took responsibility for the attack. A treasury employee arriving for work alerted the bomb squad when he noticed a suspicious package outside an elevator, according to an Interior Ministry aide, Jorge Burgos. The building, next door to the presidential palace, was evacuated and police explosives experts had moved in when the blast occurred, Burgos said. He said a lieutenant, Fernando Toledo, was killed and a corporal, Javier Chavez, was seriously wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Ambassador Returns to North Korea
DOC.TEXT: North Korea's ambassador to Moscow has returned home, apparently in reaction to talks between the leaders of South Korea and the Soviet Union, the national news agency said Monday. In Moscow, however, a North Korean Embassy official said the ambassador had gone back to North Korea to attend a meeting of the nation's parliament, of which he is a member. South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev were scheduled to meet Monday in San Francisco for talks on normalizing relations and easing hostilities on the divided Korean peninsula. The talks would be the first between the top leaders of the two countries, which have no diplomatic relations. The Soviet Union is an arms provider and chief ally to Communist North Korea, an archenemy of capitalist South Korea. Yonhap, the South Korean news agency, quoted an unidentified highly placed government official as saying North Korean Ambassador Son Song Pil left Moscow May 25 when rumors of the Roh-Gorbachev meeting began to spread. Yonhap quoted the Seoul official as saying North Korea may soon make bold proposals concerning a summit between Roh and North Korean leader Kim Il Sung. Roh was expected to ask Gorbachev to help set up a summit with Kim. In Moscow, a second secretary at the North Korean Embassy's protocol department, who gave his name only as Liu, said the ambassador left the Soviet capital May 22 for a Supreme People's Assembly session that began May 24. He said the ambassador was expected back in Moscow next week. A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said he was unaware of any North Korean protest that might have led to the ambassador's departure from Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN ELIMINATION

DOC.HEAD: Court Strengthens Government's Power to Keep Withheld Taxes
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today strengthened the government's power to keep the taxes withheld from businesses about to declare bankruptcy. Voting 9-0, the justices ruled that the trustee of bankrupt American International Airways is not entitled to recover $700,000 in taxes paid to the Internal Revenue Service. The airline had become delinquent by the spring of 1984 in withholding Social Security and income taxes from employee wages and excise taxes collected from passengers. The IRS then ordered the airline to file monthly, instead of quarterly, tax returns and open a special bank account to handle the tax deposits. American International filed for bankruptcy in July 1984 to try to reorganize the business and pay off some of the money owed creditors. That effort failed and three months later a trustee was appointed to liquidate the company. The trustee sought to recover $1.6 million in taxes paid to the IRS in the months leading up to the liquidation. A bankruptcy judge in Pennsylvania permitted the trustee to recover $700,000 from the government and the IRS appealed to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals based in Philadelphia. The appeals court said the trustee may not recover the $700,000. The balance collected by the IRS was not at issue in that ruling or today's decision. Justice Thurgood Marshall, writing for the high court, said the $700,000 was not the property of American International, but rather was being held in trust for the IRS. The case is Begier vs. IRS, 899-393.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Wanted to Started Bible Study Club Hails Decision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `I'm very...', to CORRECT spelling of Mergens; SUBS 10-11th grafs, `Mrs. Mayhew said...', with 4 grafs to add comment from principal contending current students have little interest in Bible club. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `Mrs. Mayhew, who...'. Name Di Saggau is cq in 8th graf.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Scotus-Bible Club
DOC.TEXT: A woman who wanted to start a high school Bible study club five years ago said a U.S. Supreme Court decision today will send a clear message to schools that they can't discriminate against religion. In an 8-1 decision, the high court ruled that student prayer groups must be allowed to meet at public schools that permit other organized extracurricular activities. The court said a federal law aimed at permitting religious clubs in public schools does not violate constitutionally required separation of church and state. ``I'm very glad it was an 8-1 decision. It makes it very clear that way,'' said Bridget Mergens Mayhew. ``It's got to be clear to all school officials that they can't discriminate against religion any more,'' she said in a telephone interview her home at nearby Offutt Air Force Base, where her husband is stationed. Mrs. Mayhew, now 23, was a senior at Westside High School in 1985 when school officials turned down her request to start an extracurricular club _ something like the chess club _ in which members would discuss the Bible. ``I never thought that it would go this far,'' she recalled. ``Goodness gracious, it was January 1985. I was a senior in high school and I thought the day after I asked we would have a club started.'' But school officials said allowing a Bible study group to meet at the school after class would violate the constitutionally required separation of church and state. ``Naturally, we're disappointed with today's ruling but we're unable to comment further until we have had an opportunity to study the high court's opinion ... and see how it will affect our district,'' said Di Saggau, a spokeswoman for the Westside Community Schools District. ``Of course we will comply with the ruling, but we just want to analyze it further to see how it affects what we have in place,'' she said. Mrs. Mayhew said there are still students at the 1,530-student high school interested in starting such a club. ``I wish we could have had it,'' she said. ``I think it would have changed the course of things, I think, for a lot of people. I think it would have strengthened a lot of people.'' Westside High Principal James Findley said today that he knew of one student _ a senior who graduated this year _ who had been interested in starting a Bible study club. Classes ended last week for the school year and don't resume until August. ``I don't know if we'll have students interested in it or not,'' Findley said. Mrs. Mayhew, who was raised as a Roman Catholic but became a member of the Assembly of God Chuch, said discussing and sharing religious beliefs strengthens people and that is important for teen-agers. ``It's a source of strength to be able to share your faith and share what you believe. I think it's a very important part of that age because you're a kid and you've got all these things coming at you,'' she said. She said it would make an alternative available ``to all those different things you can get involved with _ drugs or whatever.''

DOC.HEAD: Phone Company Poll Finds Many Want Cable TV Competitors
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans would welcome cable television competition, according to a Gallup Poll released Monday by one of the telephone companies eager to get into the business. A majority of those surveyed also said they would like to have two-way video services _ such as movies on demand, library services and office-in-the-home _ that could be provided through a network of high-capacity, fiber-optic telephone lines. ``This is a clear indication that the public would favor competition and innovation,'' said Kent B. Foster, president of GTE Telephone Operat GTE also offers phone service. Burns' proposal would amend a draft proposal by the Senate Commerce Committee staff that would allow phone companies to offer only a ``video dial tone'' to subscribers _ to transmit video programming, but not to own it. The committee was scheduled to vote on the proposals Thursday. A House bill by Rep. Rick Boucher, D-Va., also would allow phone companies to own video programming in their service areas, but those provisions weren't included in a draft bill offered last month by the House Energy and Commerce Committee staff. However, committee chairman Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., has promised Boucher he'll consider such an amendment, Larry Clinton, Boucher's legislative director, said Friday. Most observers think it's unlikely a bill with such telephone provisions will pass Congress this year. The Gallup Poll, conducted April 30-May 2 by telephone with 1,000 people, found that: _Sixty-eight percent of those polled thought they would benefit if other companies provided cable service. _From 50 percent to 59 percent said they would use services such as office-in-the-home, home banking and medical consultation services; 69 percent to 74 percent said they would use classroom instruction and library services and choose movies at any time of the day. The survey did not tell respondents what such services would cost. The poll's margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points. Some sources have estimated that as little 3 percent of the nation's approximately 9,000 cable TV communities have more than one cable TV franchise. Cable executives contend it's not economically feasible to have more than one video wire going into homes.

DOC.HEAD: Police Close off Roads to Beijing University Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with university area closed off, EDITS to conform; pickup 7th graf pvs, `The Beijing...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TOK2
DOC.TEXT: Police closed off roads leading to Beijing's university area tonight following a protest in which hundreds of students hurled bricks and bottles at security forces on the anniversary of the bloody suppression of the pro-democracy movement. Rifle-toting police set up roadblocks near universities in northwest Beijing and stopped most cars from entering. All foreign journalists were turned back. One Western reporter saw three truckloads of riot police, armed with shields and rifles, entering the university area. Security forces armed with AK-47 rifles also patrolled near Beijing University. About midnight Sunday, Western reporters outside Beijing University heard glass breaking and students clapping. Students hurled bottles and other objects at security forces on the street beneath their dormitory windows, setting off a campus rally of about 1,000 students. The protest was the boldest anti-government demonstration since troops crushed the pro-democracy movement one year ago, and it defied the heaviest security Beijing has seen since martial law was lifted in January. Several Western journalists were roughed up and briefly detained by police. Thousands of soldiers and police were out in force throughout the city during the day. For a fourth straight day, Tiananmen Square was sealed off by paramilitary police to prevent any attempt to honor victims of the June 3-4 crackdown. Hundreds and possibly thousands of unarmed civilians were killed in last year's army attack, which cleared the square and the rest of central Beijing of pro-democracy demonstrators. Students led last spring's pro-democracy protests, attracting workers, intellectuals and some peasants to their campaign for reform and against official corruption. For weeks, they occupied Tiananmen, China's symbolic center. Today, vanloads of police guarded streets near the 100-acre square. At the rally at Beijing University, hundreds of student protesters shouted, ``Get rid of Li Peng!'' The Chinese premier, of all the leaders involved in the crackdown, is the most widely blamed and hated. The Beijing University campus was quiet the rest of the day, and students went to class. University authorities told students they could face repercussions if they ignored orders to stay on campus. The great majority, cowed by a year of intimidation, obeyed. But some students said they were prepared to join any protest that occurred. ``We're tightly controlled, but we haven't given in,'' said one. Thousands of political activists were arrested nationwide in the months that followed the June 3-4 assault, and many remain jailed without charge. The government has purged Communist reformers and staged a massive ideological campaign to stifle dissent. All students are required to take courses in Marxism and Mao Tse-tung and a clean political record has become key to getting a good job or a passport to visit overseas. Only a few isolated protests have since been attempted, although anger over the army crackdown remains widespread. The Communist Party's official People's Daily, in a front-page editorial today, said the government's decision to use force to end last year's demonstrations was ``absolutely correct and necessary'' to preserve stability. Despite the tight security, a middle-aged Chinese man attempted to pass out leaflets near the entrance to the Forbidden City across the street from the square, foreign witnesses said. He was quickly taken away by police. A Buddhist monk and a disciple who were chanting and beating a drum on a bridge at the entrance to the Forbidden City were also chased off by police. It was not clear if they were detained. On Sunday, two people were arrested near the square for trying to deliver protest messages to Western television crews. Convoys of police vehicles with flashing lights and soldiers on foot circled the university district Sunday evening, while security forces checked vehicles at major intersections. Witnesses said the Beijing University protest began when a small group of students hurled bottles, rusty bicycle wheels and other objects at security forces on the street beneath their dormitory windows. The students then marched to other dormitories, gathering hundreds of supporters and singing the Internationale, the anthem of the international socialist movement. Several students gave speeches calling for an end to corrupt government and respect for intellectuals. In one address, Li Minqi, a junior majoring in economics management, demanded that land be returned to the peasants and factories to the workers. Li was seen being led away, possibly by plainclothes police, but students said later it was not known whether he had been arrested. The demonstration ended peacefully at about 1:30 a.m. But security forces detained about a dozen foreign journalists who had just left the campus, and forced them to line up against a wall, according to one American in the group. ``Guns were in our faces,'' the American said on condition of anonymity. He said the security officials knocked Los Angeles Times correspondent David Holley to the ground and hit his wife, Fumio, before allowing the group to leave. The Holleys later were detained again but released after 15 minutes. Around the world, demonstrations were held Sunday to mark the anniversary of the military crackdown, the largest in Hong Kong where about 100,000 demonstrated. Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. Smaller demonstrations were held in Taiwan, Japan, Britain, Canada and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese to be Among Last to Taste Beaujolais Nouveau
DOC.TEXT: Japanese wine lovers, usually among the first to taste Beaujolais Nouveau, will be among the last this year due to the enthronement ceremony for Emperor Akihito, a French official said. Because of a marketing strategy by the Union Interprofessionelle des Vins du Beaujolais in France, the wine is uncorked after midnight on the third Thursday of November. Japan is ahead of most countries in the time difference. But no chartered cargo flights into Japan will be allowed for security reasons during the 10 days before and after the Nov. 11-12 ceremony, said an official of the French Embassy on Monday. This year's wine will be available in Japan on Nov. 22, a week behind the rest of the world, said the embassy official, speaking anonymously in line with custom.

DOC.HEAD: Court Makes It Easier for Prosecutors to Use Seized Items in California Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today made it easier for prosecutors to use items seized by police without court warrants as evidence against criminal defendants. Items discovered ``in plain view'' during warrantless police searches may be used as evidence even if the discovery was not inadvertent, the justices said by a 7-2 vote in a California case. Clarifying its 19-year-old plain view doctrine, the court said inadvertent discovery ``is not a necessary condition.'' The two keys to whether such warrantless seizures are constitutional, the court said, are that an item's incriminating character be immediately apparent and police had lawful authority to be where the item was found. ``Even though inadvertence is a characteristic of most legitimate `plain view' seizures, it is not a necessary condition,'' Justice John Paul Stevens wrote for the court. Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented. Brennan wrote for the two that such seizures by police violate the Constitution's Fourth Amendment, which bans unreasonable searches and seizures. ``The court today ignores the explicit language of the Fourth Amendment, which protects possessory interest in the same manner as it protects privacy interests,'' Brennan said. The decision upheld the criminal conviction of Terry Brice Horton, sentenced to eight years and eight months in prison for the 1985 holdup of Erwin Paul Wallaker, the treasurer of a San Jose coin club. Wallaker was returning home from a coin show with two briefcases containing $10,000 in cash and $20,000 worth of coins. He was accosted by two people wearing Halloween masks who stunned him with an electrical device and robbed the cash, coins and his jewelry. Wallaker told police he recognized Horton's voice, a distinct Southern drawl. The police searched Horton's home and found, among other things, two stun guns. But the court warrant authorizing the search of Horton's home mentioned only the cash, coins and jewelry _ not the weapons. While searching for the robbery's proceeds, which they did not find, police officers found the stun guns out in plain view. California courts allowed the guns to be used as evidence against Horton, and those rulings were upheld today. ``The items seized from (Horton's) home were discovered during a lawful search authorized by a valid warrant,'' Stevens wrote for the court. He added: ``When they were discovered, it was immediately apparent to the officer that they constituted incriminating evidence. He had probable cause ... to believe that the weapons ... had been used in the crime he was investigating. The seizure was authorized by the plain view doctrine.'' The case is Horton vs. California, 88-7164.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Town Creates 6.5-Mile Long Sand Castle
LaserPhoto pursuing
DOC.TEXT: With sore knees and aching backs, residents of this tiny resort town declared victory Monday in their Sand Castle War with Myrtle Beach, S.C. ``We came, we fought, we are victorious,'' Nabiel Shawa, administrator of this town of 1,500, said after surveyors measured a sand castle built during the weekend. The castle, which included dragons and Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles, measured 34,503 feet, or 6.53 miles _ enough for Long Beach to retain title to the world's longest sand sculpture. A continent away, Myrtle Beach officials conceded that the sand castle its residents had created was only 26,834 feet, or 5.1 miles. But the South Carolina sand builders didn't take defeat lying down on the beach. ``We've decided we are going to go again _ (on the) Fourth of July,'' said Eric Eiseland, spokesman for the Myrtle Beach Chamber of Commerce. ``All we're saying is it'll be longer than 6.5 and less than 100.'' Shawa said he wasn't sure Long Beach was ready to rejoin the battle in a month. ``We might let them hold the title, at least for awhile,'' he said. ``We're a little sore in the knee from being in the sand, we're a bit wind-burnt and, quite honestly, tired.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Braces for Hill Fight Over Summit Pact
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 6 grafs from Fitzwater briefing after 9th graf pvs, ``We'll have ...; picks up 10th graf pvs, The Cabinet...; edits at bottom to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today U.S. allies gave the superpower summit a ``very, very positive'' review even as he acknowledged ``there's some problems'' that remain to be solved. Bush said he had conferred late Sunday by phone on the outcome of the summit with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and former President Reagan _ who was meeting in San Francisco today for breakfast with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Bush dispatched Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Copenhagen, Denmark, today to meet with his Soviet counterpart and Germany's foreign minister about European security following the unification of Germany. ``I am pleased with the results and I think the reception from the American people was rather clear,'' Bush said as he began to brief his Cabinet on the four-day meeting with Gorbachev. He won a sustained round of applause from the Cabinet _ the friendliest audience in town _ as be braced for a congressional cold shoulder over the provisional trade agreement that so pleased Gorbachev. `There's some problems,'' Bush told the Cabinet at brief remarks during a picture-taking session. ``I never said there wouldn't be.'' The president said he talked to Reagan _ who had five summits of his own with the Soviet leader _ to ``give him a briefing as to what he might anticipate at his breakfast.'' ``The mood ... from the allies so far, the ones I've talked to, has been very, very positive,'' Bush said. ``We'll have to wait and see what the response is from around the world. But so far our experts have been very pleased,'' Bush said. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said later today that Gorbachev's threat to suspend exit visas for Soviet jews could cause ``some problems,'' suggesting it did not square with the Soviet leader's assurances of freer emigration policies. Gorbachev on Sunday suggested he would consider suspending the visas if Israel continues to settle the emigrants in occupied territories. ``We view it with concern. We want open emigration,'' Fitzwater said. He said the status of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is one thing that Bush will consider when he makes a final judgement on sending to Congress the trade pact he formalized with Gorbachev at the summit. Meanwhile, Fitzwater announced that East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere will visit Bush at the White House next Monday on June 11. It is the first time an East German leader has ever been to the White House, Fitzwater said. The two will discuss a number of topics related to German unification, the spokesman said. The Cabinet applauded Bush before reporters were let into the Cabinet Room. Asked what the applause was about, Bush cracked to reporters: ``My scintillating personality, I guess.'' Despite sharp differences remaining on the fate of the Baltics and on the military alignment of a reunified Germany, Bush and Gorbachev are heralding their summit gains and predicting another 1990 session to nail down arms treaties that eluded them this time. They ended their second summit on Sunday, speaking warmly of each other and proclaiming the meeting a big success. ``Neither of us tried to cover over the differences,'' Bush said. Bush's decision to sign a trade pact with Gorbachev without first winning concessions on Lithuania has drawn reproach from both parties. However, Bush has said he will only send the measure to Congress if the Supreme Soviet passes a liberalized emigration law. And a gesture by Gorbachev in lightening up on Lithuania _ in exchange for the prize of the trade treaty _ could quickly turn the situation around in Congress. Both leaders voiced hope that they can meet again before the end of the year _ Gorbachev invited Bush to Moscow _ to sign treaties to cut long-range nuclear missiles and trim conventional forces in Europe. Bush and Gorbachev also talked about having regular, perhaps annual, meetings without the usual summit fanfare of 21-gun salutes, state dinners and military bands. Bush said, ``We're now at a stage in the U.S.-Soviet relationship and, indeed, in world history where we should miss no opportunity to complete the extraordinary tasks before us.'' Gorbachev said of his summit host, ``This is the kind of person to do business with.'' The two leaders made significant progress on the nuclear pact, signing a framework agreement to cut arsenals by 30 percent and pledging to sign the completed Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) by year's end. ``This is the first time that we're not just limiting, but we will be reducing the most devastating means of warfare,'' Gorbachev said. But deep divisions remained between them on levels of troops and tanks in Europe, a dispute directly related to another disagreement over the future political and military face of a unified Germany. Other disputes also loomed _ in particular, the continuing stalemate over Lithuania and the other rebellious Baltic republics. Bush called the Baltic standoff ``one of the thorns in the side of an overall relationship.'' For his part, Gorbachev _ who gave no ground on Lithuania at the Washington talks _ brushed off the topic. He repeated a favorite recent line _ that Bush would have restored constitutional order ``within 24 hours'' had a state in the United States declared independence as did Lithuania. Lack of major progress on the Baltic stalemate is building substantial congressional opposition to the trade pact, and Bush conceded that Gorbachev had given him no assurances that Moscow was any closer to lifting its economic embargo against Lithuania. ``I'm not sure anything has changed,'' Bush said.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
BIBLE CLUBS
The court ruled student prayer groups must be allowed to meet at public schools that permit other organized extracurricular activities. The justices, voting 8-1, said a 1984 federal law aimed at permitting religious clubs in public schools does not violate constitutionally required separation of church and state. The court overruled Omaha, Neb., school officials who refused to approve a high school Bible-reading club. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing for the court, said the Equal Access Act of 1984 passes the court's long-standing three-part test aimed at assuring separation of church and state. The case is Board of Education vs. Mergens, 88-1597.
MIRANDA
The court ruled that police undercover agents may seek to elicit confessions from jailed criminal suspects without first having to give so-called Miranda warnings. By an 8-1 vote, the justices said jailed criminal suspects need not be told about their right to remain silent or to get a lawyer's help before being questioned by someone secretly working for the police. The case is Illinois vs. Perkins, 88-1972.
SEARCHES
The court made it easier for prosecutors to use items seized by police without court warrants as evidence against criminal defendants. Items discovered ``in plain view'' during warrantless police searches may be used as evidence even if the discovery was not inadvertent, the justices said by a 7-2 vote in a California case. The case is Horton vs. California, 88-7164.
LEGAL FEES
The court used a dispute over Haitian refugee rights to strengthen a federal law requiring the government to pay legal fees to winning opponents in lawsuits. The court unanimously rejected Bush administration arguments aimed at limiting the attorneys' fees. The case is Commissioner of INS vs. Jean, 89-601.
NUCLEAR SAFETY
The court ruled that nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue their employers under state personal injury laws. The court unanimously said such lawsuits are not pre-empted by a federal law protecting such whistleblowers. The case is English vs. GE, 89-152.
IMMIGRANTS
The court agreed to hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at giving federal officials more power to deny temporary legal status to immigrant farmworkers. The court said it will review a ruling that said the workers are entitled to various procedural protections when applying for such residential permits. The case is McNary vs. Haitian Refugee Center, 89-1332.
NATURAL GAS
The court agreed to study the government's power to lift price controls on some natural gas, a case that has tens of millions of dollars at stake for consumers. The justices said they will review federal regulations that, among other things, allow gas producers to raise some prices charged to pipeline companies. The cases are Mobil Oil vs. United Distribution Companies, 89-1452, and FERC vs. United Distribution Companies, 89-1453.
AIRLINES
The court agreed to decide whether passengers on international flights may sue airlines for the emotional distress they allegedly suffer in near-crashes that cause them no physical harm. The court said it will review a ruling that Eastern Airlines may be forced to pay passengers who were on a flight that landed safely in Miami after all the plane's engines failed briefly in the air. The case is Eastern Airlines vs. Floyd, 89-1598.

DOC.HEAD: Referendum Invalid Due to Lack of Voter Participation
DOC.TEXT: Two environmentalists threatened Monday to set themselves on fire to protest low voter turnout in a national referendum on environmental issues, news agencies reported. The turnout was so low it appeared the results of the referendum would be declared invalid. According to results from 90 of 95 provinces, just 42.5 percent of voters turned out to cast ballots Sunday and Monday, the Interior Ministry said. More than 50 percent of the 46.8 million eligible voters had to participate for the referendum to be valid. Voters were asked whether they wanted to restrict hunting and the use of pesticides in food production. Environmental groups urged ``yes'' votes. However, major political parties did not take strong positions on the issues, and the campaign was low-key. In Milan, the two environmentalists blamed the turnout on ``poor information'' by state-run television and threatened self-immolation in front of the TV station's offices. As police, firefighters and ambulances arrived, the demonstrators changed their minds, according to Italian news agencies. Historically Italy has had high voter participation. More than 80 percent of eligible voters cast ballots in the last national election in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein Buoyed By Polls In California Campaign's Final Days
DOC.TEXT: Former San Francisco mayor Dianne Feinstein got encouraging news Monday from two new polls in the California governor's race as she and scores of candidates played out the final hours of primary campaigns in nine states. In the often nasty Democratic primary campaign, Feinstein maintained a lead over state Attorney General John Van de Kamp in the latest statewide surveys. For months the two candidates have attacked each other on issues ranging from abortion and crime to who could best handled the state's fiscal affairs. Other new polls showed close races Tuesday for gubernatorial nominations in Alabama, Iowa and New Mexico. In North Carolina, a runoff between two Democrats will determine who challenges Republican Sen. Jesse Helms, while four Montana Republicans were vying for the chance to run against Democratic Sen. Max Baucus. Baucus was among seven incumbent senators facing token primary opposition at most on Tuesday. The others were Democrats Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Howell Heflin of Alabama and Tom Harkin of Iowa, and Republicans Thad Cochran of Mississippi, Pete Domenici of New Mexico and Larry Pressler of South Dakota. Except for Cochran, who will have no Democratic opponent in November, renomination isn't necessarily a free ticket to another term. Harkin faces a tough re-election race against GOP Rep. Tom Tauke, while Heflin and Pressler also are under challenge from potentially strong opponents. Heflin's foe in November will be Republican Bill Cabannis and Pressler will come up against Democrat Ted Muenster. With his outspoken conservative views, Helms attracts both intense support and equally strong opposition. The Democrats, who must decide between Harvey Gantt and Mike Easley for their nominee, hope to capitalize on the latter in the general election campaign. Gantt led a six-candidate field in the May 8 primary but failed to reached the 40 percent needed to avoid a runoff. The former mayor of Charlotte is seeking to become the first black nominated for statewide office in North Carolina. The race for the Democratic nomination for governor of Alabama was headed for a runoff, with none of the five contenders likely to get the 50 percent needed to win outright in the first round. The top two finishers would be on the ballot for a runoff June 26 to decide who challenges Republican Gov. Guy Hunt. A Birmingham News-Huntsville Times poll published Sunday said former Gov. Fob James had the support of 26.1 percent, followed by state Attorney General Don Siegelman with 25.6 percent, Rep. Ronnie Flippo 20.5 percent, teacher-lobbyist Paul Hubbert 20.1 percent and state Sen. Charles Bishop 3.3 percent. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. The biggest 1990 prize is the California governor's office. Republican Gov. George Deukmejian is retiring after two terms and the GOP recruited Sen. Pete Wilson to enter the race to succeed him. Re-elected to the Senate in 1988 with 53 percent of the vote, Wilson became the immediate favorite to keep the office in Republican hands. With the 1990 Census likely to give California six new House seats starting with the 1992 election, control of the governor's office could determine which party draws the new district lines. Democrats already control both legislative chambers. In addition to targeting the governor's race, Republicans also are sponsoring two ballot initiatives on redistricting in California. One would take it out of the hands of the legislature, the other would give the governor an absolute veto over any plan. A new Los Angeles Times poll said Feinstein had a 13-point lead _ a gain of two points over a similar survey early in May. The poll gave the former mayor 42 percent and Van de Kamp 29 percent. There were 29 percent still undecided or supporting one of the nine minor candidates on the Democratic primary ballot. The survey had a 5 percentage point margin of error. Mervin Field's California Poll, which gave Feinstein a slim 3 percent lead earlier this month, reported that margin had opened up to 8 points over Van de Kamp, 42-34, in polling that concluded Sunday. It had a 3.5 percentage point margin of error. A new Iowa poll in the race for the Democratic nomination for governor was published Sunday in theDes Moines Register and said Iowa House Speaker Don Avenson had moved into the lead with support from 32 percent of those surveyed, compared with 25 percent for state Attorney General Tom Miller. Former banker John Chrystal was at 19 percent, and 20 percent said they were undecided. The survey had a margin of error of 3.9 percentage points. The winner of the Democratic primary will face Republican Gov. Terry Branstad in the general election. In New Mexico, a new poll published Sunday in the Albuquerque Journal said state Senate Minority Leader Les Houston and former legislator Frank Bond each had the support of 29.2 percent of the registered Republicans asked their preference in the GOP gubernatorial primary. On the Democratic side, former Gov. Bruce King had the backing of 42.7 percent, while state Attorney General Paul Bardacke was supported by 31.5 percent. The New Mexico survey had a margin of error of 4 percentage points on the Democratic side and 5 percentage points on the GOP side.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Gather for Protests as Gorbachev Begins his Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Shultz in 12th graf bgng ``Five thousand''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: Capitalism reared its head at Stanford University today, as students scrambled for the last remaining tickets to see Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and the wealthy offered fistfuls of cash for those ducats. Students Erik Jorgensen, 21, and Alex Levy, 20, stood in line from 2 a.m., hoping for a shot at tickets that had not been picked up. A lottery had been held to distribute 1,700 seats for Gorbachev's talk, and 6,000 other tickets to the rest of the events on his university visit. ``Gorbachev probably would have felt right at home this morning,'' said Jorgensen. ``The lines we stood in were very much like the food lines in the Soviet Union.'' They decided to hang on to their tickets, but a friend sold his for $425 to a San Jose doctor, Jorgensen said. The university set up an official computer lottery system to distribute the coveted tickets May 29, but free enterprise immediately florished with talk of scalping tickets for as much as $1,800 apiece. Two sophomores, Jeff Vierling and Marlowe Johnson, said they had heard the top price was $1,800. They could only attest personally to a $1,400 sale. Vierling, a 19-year-old electrical engineering major, and Johnson, a 21-year-old international relations major, sat on a curb today with a sign asking for serious offers only. They told those who stopped they wanted $1,000 or more for each of their two tickets. ``It's airplane tickets. It's a lot of things. It's a CD player,'' said Vierling. Added Johnson, who wants to finance a European trip: ``I can probably see him better on TV.'' Stanford officials programmed computers to randomly decide who among the university's staff and students would attend the events. Students accounted for about 60 percent of the winners' list, which was published in university publications. However, students were allocated only 550 seats in the 1,700-seat memorial auditorium for Gorbachev's speech. The other were divided among faculty, staff, dignitaries and the media. Five thousand ticket-holding members of the Stanford community were allowed to pass through security lines to see Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, greeted by Stanford President Donald Kennedy and former Secretary of State George Shultz. About 550 others were allowed access to the cordoned-off lawn of the business school to watch as the Soviet president was escorted to the auditorium for his scheduled half-hour speech. Students, gawkers and Soviet security guards gathered outside Stanford's Memorial Auditorium several hours before Gorbachev was scheduled to arrive. Sonoma resident Robin Nyder said she had a pass to stand near the auditorium _ but not to see the speech. ``I told my fiance if I have a choice between shaking his hand and taking a picture, forget the photo,'' Nyder said.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian President Hopes Gorbachev Softens His Stand When He Returns
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president said today he hoped Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would reassess his stance toward the breakaway Baltic state after returning from the Washington summit. But President Vytautas Landsbergis added in an interview with the Voice of America radio that he did not hear any encouraging words from Gorbachev during his meeting with President Bush. ``The worst would have been if Mikhail Gorbachev came out with the impression that everything he is doing vis-a-vis Lithuania is permitted,'' Landsbergis said in the interview, a transcript of which was provided in English to The Associated Press. Landsbergis said he hoped the Soviet leader would ``thoroughly review'' the matter when he returned home. He accused Gorbachev of using ``propaganda methods'' in dealing with the republic, which declared independence from Moscow March 11 and triggered a Kremlim economic embargo of all fuel and most food supplies. Gorbachev has demanded that the republic revoke the declaration before starting negotiations on Lithuanian secession on the basis of the Soviet constitution. Landsbergis today reitereated Lithuania's refusal to reverse its declaration, saying ``I don't think we'll ever be able to take this step,'' according to the U.S. government-run VOA. At the summit, Bush and Gorbachev agreed to a trade pact that Bush said is conditioned only on the Soviet government's approval of liberalized emigration laws. Bush previously had said Moscow also must end its blockade against Lithuania, but he changed that position Sunday. Landsbergis told VOA that if the West continues to allow Gorbachev's ``destructive'' policies toward Lithuania, the Baltic state would seek more support from the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Kazimiera Prunskiene, Lithuania's prime minister, told the VOA that Lithuania is looking forward to dealing with ``democratic Russia.'' She said a delegation from Russia was in Lithuania preparing to negotiate direct agreements outside Soviet authority. Populist reformer Boris Yeltsin, the Communist Party maverick who has openly challenged Gorbachev, was elected to the Russian Federation presidency last week and promised to support Lithuania after he forms his new government. Mrs. Prunskiene, who has met separately with Bush and Gorbachev in recent weeks, said she believed Gorbachev would modify his position on Lithuania after returning home. ``It's one thing to talk tough in America's forums and to disply this firm position by the U.S.S.R. and Gorbachev himself, but it is another thing to understand that the U.S. Congress, as well as the situation in the Soviet Union, are unfavorable to his rigid position ...,'' she told VOA. The U.S. Congress must still approve the trade pact, and some lawmakers already have said they would not allow the Soviet Union to become a most-favored-nation trading partner until Gorbachev ends his economic squeeze on Lithuania. The most-favored-nation designation qualifies a trading partner for the lowest U.S. tariffs.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Gets Under Way as Mayor Blasts Prosecutors
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 8th graph pvs, bgng, The U.S... to show prosecutors had no comment
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began today in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion Barry as the mayor blasted federal prosecutors for using tactics more befitting a ``totalitarian kind of society.'' Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to all 14 charges against him. Sources close to the case have said his lawyers have been conducting plea bargain talks with federal prosecutors. The mayor, accompanied by his wife, Effi, entered the courthouse through a side door without speaking to reporters. Inside the courtroom, more than 100 potential jurors were given questionnaires to fill out designed to gauge their fitness for the jury that will hear the case. In an interview hours earlier with a local radio station, the third-term mayor launched a pre-emptive strike against the prosecution. ``Its frightening that since 1983 my family have had to go through my mail being opened, my bank accounts checked, my tax return looked at, my phones tapped. ``Can you imagine, you can't even have a conference in your bedroom with your wife for fear that they're listening to anything you may say? ... It's been a thing that you thought may happen in a totalitarian kind of society.'' The mayor also said ``a local television station has gotten a copy of the tape from the prosecutors. They're trying to figure out now how to show it,'' he said in an apprent reference to the videotape that made during the FBI sting operation that resulted in Barry's arrest on drug charges on Jan. 18. Judy Smith, spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens, said the office would have no comment. The station, WRC-TV, also said it would have no comment. Outside the courthouse, nearly two dozen Guardian Angels paced silently, wearing their trademark red berets, holding aloft signs calling for the mayor to resign. The Guardian Angels are a self-appointed anti-crime group. About 125 prospective jurors began filling out a lengthy questionaire designed to evaluate their fitness to sit on the 12-member jury, and another group of 125 was slated to fill out the same paperwork this afternoon. The press and public were not permitted in the courtroom of U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. Interviews of the prospective jurors were expected to begin Tuesday. In addition to the dozen jurors, six alternates will be picked. Federal prosecutors have indicated for months that they are as interested in getting Barry out of office as they are in winning a jury verdict. Sources said Sunday that Stephens was holding out for a felony plea and a deal that would have the mayor leave office, while Barry was willing to consider only misdemeanors. A felony plea or conviction would bar the mayor from holding office and from seeking re-election. A misdemeanor conviction would not. Barry is charged with 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use, and one misdemeanor conspiracy count that alleges he consorted with at least 10 people on 20 occasions over the past five years to buy and use cocaine. Barry has pleaded innocent to all charges. Barry attended a church rally Sunday night and called the months since his Jan. 18 arrest ``the most difficult time in my life.'' ``I ain't gonna waste time,'' Barry said. ``I've come too far from where I started from.'' After a standing ovation from the crowd, he expressed confidence that his legal crisis will not bring him down. Prospective jurors were being asked to fill out detailed questionnaires today and were expected to undergo questioning by the defense and prosecution starting by Tuesday. Twelve jurors and six alternates will be picked from the pool, and it is expected that a week or more will be needed to empanel the group. While Barry has said he only needs one juror to vote against convicting him, some of his top aides and political advisers have indicated they are extremely reluctant to see the case come to trial. Sources familiar with the mayor's legal situation said Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, and Stephens were continuing plea-bargain negotiations that began 10 days ago. Barry has not publicly revealed his re-election plans, but he has made a series of campaign-style appearances around the nation's capital since returning in March from seven weeks of substance abuse treatment. A source familiar the plea-bargain talks said Sunday the two sides ``are still far apart,'' but that neither Mundy nor Stephens felt pressure to strike a quick deal. ``There is a feeling that they have until the end of jury selection, at least,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They are continuing to talk, and they are not so bogged down as to cut off the discussions.'' The papers jurors were given to fill out asks more than 100 questions _ around their knowledge of the Barry case, their general feelings about the mayor, the city government, and the various federal law enforcement agencies that participated in the lengthy investigation that led to Barry's arrest and indictments. At the church service, a mixture of top Barry aides and his former civil rights colleagues paid tribute to the mayor. ``I wouldn't trade this evening for anything in the world,'' said Barry, who praised his wife Effi and his mother, Mattie Cummings, for their support. Restaurateur Jeffrey Gildenhorn, said afterward, ``This was a summation of his career, all the things he's done. ... Where we go from here, no one knows.''
Editors: Please note PM-Summit-Baltics, which moved as a0633. The story replaces a0558, which was eliminated because a Landsbergis quote attributed to the Voice of America was incorrect. The AP

DOC.HEAD: Michael Jackson Admitted To Hospital; Undergoing Tests for Chest Pains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with spokesman saying Jackson admitted, undergoing tests. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Catapulted into...'.
DOC.TEXT: Michael Jackson was hospitalized with chest pains today and his doctor ran a battery of tests to determine what felled the superstar entertainer, who had been ill for several days. ``He's undergoing several important tests today,'' said Jackson spokesman Bob Jones. ``I don't think it was a heart attack. He just experienced some discomfort. He had been feeling bad the past two or three days.'' Jackson, 31, was taken to the emergency room at St. John's Hospital and Health Center about 9 p.m. Sunday, complaining of chest pains. ``Michael Jackson remains hospitalized (and) his physician, Dr. Steven Hoefflin, states that he will be undergoing several diagnostic tests,'' hospital spokeswoman Paulette Weir said in a hospital statement. No other details were released by the hospital, which referred inquiries to Jones. Lee Solters, a publicist for Jackson, wouldn't comment except to say the singer had no history of heart problems. Jackson was staying in the same hospital as his friend Elizabeth Taylor, who has been recovering from a near-fatal bout of pneumonia and complications for nearly two months. Catapulted into the public eye at age 5 with the Jackson Five family pop group, Jackson went on to become a one-man phenomenon. He sold more than 100 million albums in the 1980s and won an unprecedented eight Grammy Awards for his 1982 release, ``Thriller,'' the most successful album of all time with sales of more than 40 million copies worldwide. His last album, ``Bad,'' released in 1987, spawned five No. 1 hits. The reclusive star, known for wearing one white glove onstage, has been celebrated as widely for his eccentricities as for his music and choreography. He has often gone out in public wearing a disguise, has had repeated cosmetic surgery, owns a menagerie of exotic pets and tried unsuccessfully to buy the bones of ``Elephant Man'' John Merrick. Jackson was hospitalized in January 1984 with second-degree scalp burns after his hair caught fire when a smoke bomb misfired during the filming of a soft-drink commercial in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Combat Artist Recorded War on Canvas
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When Alexander P. Russo returned from his stint as a World War II combat artist, he couldn't bear to draw people. He had seen too many soldiers riddled with gunfire, too many mangled bodies. ``I couldn't paint a figure for years,'' said Russo, who witnessed the Allied invasion of the Normandy beaches on June 6, 1944. ``I wanted to do landscapes. I was trying to get my mind back to a positive focus.'' Russo was one of eight artists in the Navy's combat art section, which he joined after the D-day invasion. They lived with the troops, and followed them into battle, capturing the fighting on sketchpads and later on canvas. ``I think good art, or great art, captures the sense of the situation. In this case, it was the essence of battle, the horror of battle,'' said Russo, a retired art professor from Hood College in this western Maryland city. But Russo, who taught at the Corcoran School of Art in Washington, D.C., and chaired Hood's art department for 15 years, does not want to be known solely as a combat artist. His contemporary art, which bridges realism and abstraction, is in collections and museums in the United States and Europe. ``I'm a functioning artist. The war was just one phase,'' he said last week. ``It was an opportunity to be creative, but it was just a beginning.'' Russo was 20 when he joined the Navy in October 1942 after completing art studies at Pratt Institute in New York City. As part of an amphibious intelligence unit, he made shoreline drawings and plaster terrain models. He sketched troops landing in Sicily, and fires raging in London after German bombing attacks. Russo's ``Firefighters in London at Night,'' is part of an exhibit at the Washington Navy Yard in the nation's capital. The painting, in brown, black, red and orange tones depicts firefighters dousing flames that dart from windows and roofs toward a dark sky. Forty-four years ago Wednesday, Russo landed with thousands of troops on the beaches of Normandy. ``I was moved by some things that the others were not _ subtle things like troops waiting or grave diggers pausing,'' Russo said. In his work from Normandy, Russo painted ``To the Burial Ground,'' which shows soldiers tending to the dead on a hillside. Four soldiers rest from digging. Two carry a covered stretcher to a cemetery studded with crosses. Later, as part of the combat art section, Russo spent months in Washington developing his sketches into complete works. The unit was founded by Griffith Baily Coale, who persuaded the Navy to let artists accompany ships into action and record the battles in ways that photographers and journalists could not. ``There was practically no color photography done during World War II. It was too bloody expensive,'' said John D. Barnett, curator of the Navy Art Collection at the naval yard. ``The color wasn't (true) so they figured they were better off with black and white.'' Russo completed 250 drawings, sketches and paintings that are part of the Navy's historic record of the war. ``It was the beginning of a search for deeper values that I'm still searching for and still trying to represent in my work,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Turmoil of Wright Days Gone _ But at What Price?
DOC.TEXT: Speaker Thomas S. Foley has restored calm, even boredom, to a House of Representatives that a year ago was torn by the downfall of his predecessor, Jim Wright. Some Democrats complain the price of peace is too high. ``It is still holding,'' Foley said of the serenity that he made his top priority after being sworn in as speaker a year ago Wednesday. ``I think there's a better communication and a better feeling between the parties and the leadership on each side.'' Few would disagree. Sparks seldom fly during floor debates in the way they did under Wright, who was seen as imposing his agenda on the House and squelching dissent among both Democrats and Republicans. Wright resigned May 31, 1989, after being formally accused of 69 instances of violating House rules, including charges he had circumvented limits on outside income through bulk sales of a book he wrote and charges he had improperly accepted $145,000 in gifts from a Fort Worth, Texas, businessman with a direct interest in legislation. ``I don't have the sense that I have to fight this leadership,'' said Rep. Tim Penny, D-Minn., a maverick conservative who often was at odds with Wright. Foley and his leadership team, Penny said, don't feel driven to play every floor vote as if it were a fight to the death. ``There is more of an attempt to be fair to all sides,'' he said. House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said there is a new atmosphere of bipartisan trust. ``We're more inclined to try and solve any differences between the two of us, with nobody around,'' he said. But calm is not everything, said Penny and several others who are either House members or close observers of the institution. As they look ahead to congressional elections this fall, and down the road to the 1992 presidential campaign, they see a lack of any issue that could help define the Democratic Party. Under Foley's leadership, the House has in recent weeks passed major legislation on child care, clean air and civil rights for the handicapped. But on the year's highest-profile issue, Bush's capital gains tax cut, Foley was defeated last September when he lost the support of one in four House Democrats. No one wants to return to the debilitating last months of Wright, when the institution was paralyzed. But griping is growing louder that Foley _ the nation's highest-ranking elected Democrat _ is too slow to take on a popular president and be his party's political, as well as legislative, leader. ``I don't think there's a sense across America that we're doing anything about anything,'' Penny said. ``We are too focused on ourselves. Getting along with each other is fine. ... But what we are communicating to the American public is that we're afraid to make any decisions.'' ``We want the leaders to lead,'' said Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., another conservative. ``We want to know what the priorities are, what the agenda is, and to move out aggressively on that agenda.'' Foley and his top lieutenants, Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Whip William H. Gray III, D-Pa., were understandably gun-shy after watching Wright's demise and the abrupt resignation of former Whip Tony Coelho, McCurdy said. But the team now has established itself, and it is time to move ahead, he said. Wright himself, now living in Fort Worth, Texas, and doing some speaking and writing, obviously sees some shortcomings in his successors, but declined in an interview to go into any detail. ``Things are not moving with perceptible clarity and direction,'' he said. But he said Foley's conciliatory style is ``in some ways much better'' than his own impatience and predicted, ``Tom will be speaker for a long time.'' In many ways, the lack of a schism between Democrats and Republicans is the product of a political scene that goes far beyond Foley. The Democrat-controlled Congress faces a popular president in George Bush, and one who himself is naturally averse to confrontation. ``I can't stop him from adopting Democratic ideas, endorsing Democratic philosophies, conceding Democratic priorities,'' Foley said in an interview. ``I can't say, `Stop. Get across the road. Stop talking about child care and clean air and the environment and be a Republican in the same old nasty way''' as the last president, Ronald Reagan. Foley said he is well aware of the unrest in his party among those who desire conflict. But he said times have changed. ``It would be a bad mistake for us as a party to sharpen the lines by being something we aren't,'' he said. ``I think the issues are going to define themselves. There will be differences ... but maybe not as hard and clear as they were with Ronald Reagan, who had an ideological cut in a different direction.''

DOC.HEAD: Stuffed Toy Blamed for Death of Rare White Bengal Tiger
DOC.TEXT: The death of a rare white Bengal tiger was caused by a stuffed toy that it swallowed weeks ago, officials said. The 2-year-old male tiger named Mwelu drowned Sunday while apparently suffering severe stomach pains. Visitors noticed the tiger struggling in a pool before it sank, said David Conrod, a spokesman for Busch Gardens theme park. The remains of a small stuffed animal were found in the tiger's upper intestines, said Dr. John Olsen, chief veterinarian. Since the tiger apparently ate the toy three to six weeks ago, two gallstones had formed around it, further blocking digestion and creating what must have been painful stomach attacks, Olsen said. ``We ask that visitors not feed the animals or put things in the displays, but sometimes it happens,'' Conrod said. ``Sometimes things will be thrown in that people think the animals will play with.'' The tiger was one of about 140 white Bengals left in the world, all of them in captivity, park officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Decoy Hunting _ A Crime or Entrapment?
DOC.TEXT: Officer Buck has been shot six times in the line of duty, which doesn't bother his fellow officers a bit. The people who have shot him aren't very happy about it, though. Officer Buck is a decoy deer who lives _ well, exists _ to get shot. The 1{-year-old decoy, which was given its nickname by officials at the Pennsylvania Game Commission, is placed along roads to help wardens nab people who illegally hunt from the highway. Critics say the ploy amounts to entrapment; game wardens consider it a stroke of genius. ``He's saved a lot of deer,'' said Dale Sleasman, a state game official. ``You'd be surprised how many guys came up to us and said, `We saw your decoy, but we didn't shoot it.' The decoy wasn't even there.'' Aaron Stiffey Sr., 46, of Bolivar, and James Wagner Jr., 31, of New Florence, recently were convicted of shooting Officer Buck from a road in rural Westmoreland County, just east of Pittsburgh. Their attorney is appealing their convictions, saying the fake deer is used to entrap people. ``That's the only reason that deer was there _ to entice someone to shoot at it,'' said lawyer Richard Pohl. ``This five-point rack is a neon sign saying, `Come shoot me.''' Patrick Noonan, an assistant district attorney in Westmoreland County, said Officer Buck merely gives people an opportunity to commit a crime. ``This is no different than an undercover officer dressed up to solicit prostitution,'' he said. Sleasman said Officer Buck once started an argument between two men. One carried a rifle and was preparing to shoot while a friend tried to talk him out of shooting the bogus buck. The unarmed man ``took off running down a hill, shouting and clapping his hands and trying to scare it away. He must have run about 60 yards, shouting and screaming the whole time,'' Sleasman said. ``He finally got to about 10 feet of the deer and turned around and said, `You might as well shoot it. I think it's frozen.'''

DOC.HEAD: American Workers' Productivity Plunges at an Annual Rate of 2.7 Percent
DOC.TEXT: American workers' productivity has plunged at a 2.7 percent annual rate so far this year, the poorest showing since the 1981-82 recession, as labor costs have continued to increase, the government said Monday. ``It's the worst of both possible worlds,'' said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. Increased productivity, or getting each worker to produce more for each hour he or she works, is vital to increasing Americans' standard of living without inflation, many economists say. ``The first quarter is a very dismal statement on that score,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. Donald Ratajczak, director of Georgia State University's economic forecasting center, said poor productivity might mean Americans' standard of living ``is going to drift backward.'' It also weakens the nation's ability to compete internationally, analysts said. While productivity was falling, unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, shot up at an annual rate of 7 percent. That's putting a squeeze on profits, Sinai said. ``Businesses can't keep on employing people at those costs with so little production,'' he said. The 2.7 percent productivity drop was the worst performance since productivity fell at a rate of 5.5 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, the Labor Department said. Private analysts said much of the decline was related to the overall slowdown of the economy and was typical of an economy at the end of expansion. The gross national product _ the total output of goods and services _ grew at a sluggish 1.3 percent annual rate for the first quarter. Monday's report, which provided revised figures on the first quarter of 1990, showed the nation's lagging productivity was far worse than earlier reported. Original data showed productivity falling 1 percent. The GNP growth of 1.3 percent had also been revised downward from preliminary data showing 2.1 percent growth. The 7 percent jump in unit labor costs for the January-March period compared with a 4.5 percent increase during all of 1989. Hourly labor costs _ a major inflation measure for businesses _ rose at an annual rate of 4.1 percent in the first quarter of 1990. Those costs increased by 5.5 percent for all of 1989. The report provided one bit of good news _ productivity in the manufacturing sector climbed 4.9 percent so far this year, a huge improvement over the 2 percent increase during all of 1989. Unit labor costs in that sector dropped 1.3 percent, compared with the 2.2 percent increase during all of last year. Jones said factory workers' productivity was encouraging because it might mean ``businesses have become leaner and meaner with the financial restructuring of the 1980s.'' ``Maybe the one positive fallout of the takeover craze has been the cutbacks of excessive management and layoffs of unproductive workers,'' Jones said. Ratajczak said manufacturers ``are feeling the heat of foreign competition the strongest.'' ``We don't know what it's going to take for retailers to become more efficient,'' he said. Total business productivity, including farming, fell 2.1 percent for the first quarter compared with a 1.1 percent gain for all of 1989. Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged 1.8 percent a year. While a slight improvement over the 1.2 percent average growth rate in the 1970s, it was still far below th 3.3 percent rate of increase posted in the two decades after World War II. During all of last year, productivity rose just 0.9 percent, the poorest showing since the 1981-82 recession. Monday's report showed that output in the non-farm sector rose 1 percent during the first quarter of 1990, well below the 3.9 percent increase in the number of hours worked.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Protege Elected Ukrainian Republic President
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party chief of the Ukraine was elected the republic's president on Monday over protests from legislators and demonstrators who said he would have too much power, local activists reported. Volodymyr Ivashko, a protege of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, received 60 percent of the votes in the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet parliament, according to Rukh Press International, or Rukh. It is an arm of the nationalist Ukrainian people's front. Opposition members and protesters objected to Ivashko's holding both the Ukrainian party leadership and the republic's presidency, according to the unofficial Rukh press, which has proved reliable in the past. Gorbachev also has been criticized for holding both the presidency and the post as general secretary of the Communist Party. Thousands of protesters gathered outside the parliament building Monday in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev and chanted ``Ivashko out!'' and ``Shame on Communists!'' the report said. Activists in the Supreme Soviet said they may boycott future sessions and form their own ``shadow parliament,'' Rukh reported. The Ukraine is the second-largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, with 51 million people. Its extensive heavy industry and rich soil have earned it a reputation as the ``breadbasket'' of the Soviet Union. Like other Soviet republics, the Ukraine has a nationalist movement that has blossomed since Gorbachev came to power in 1985. Ivashko, 58, took over as Ukrainian party chief last September from hard-liner Vladimir Shcherbitsky and was made a full member of the party's ruling Politburo in December. He replaces Valentina Shevchenko as president, formally known as the parliament chairman. Ivashko is considered a relative moderate in the Communist Party and a protege of Gorbachev. He has spoken out against growing nationalism in the Ukraine. That puts him at odds with Rukh, the popular movement whose platform includes both pro-democracy and nationalist elements. Ivashko won 278 of 341 votes cast in the 449-member body, according to the Interfax News Agency, which is affiliated with state-run Radio Moscow. He defeated academician Igor Yukhnovsky, who had most radical deputies' support; Vladimir Grinev, also a professor; and Kiev Communist Party official Ivan Saly, Interfax said. Rukh said Communist officials predicted that Ivashko soon would step down from his party post to defuse the controversy. There has also been speculation that Gorbachev may resign as Communist Party general secretary at a national party congress in July, although he has denied such rumors. Gorbachev says holding both the presidency and party leadership is necessary for political stability.

DOC.HEAD: 1991 Tour Taking Mormon Tabernacle Choir to Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: The Mormon Tabernacle Choir will perform in the Soviet Union for the first time, during a concert tour of Europe next summer, church officials announced. The 13-concert tour will open in Frankfurt, West Germany, on June 10, 1991, and conclude with three concerts in the Soviet Union, two at the Kremlin in Moscow and one in Leningrad. The tour also will include the choir's first appearances in Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Austria. The tour schedule was announced Sunday by Gordon B. Hinckley, a church president who serves as counselor to the governing body of the 7.3 million-member Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Hinckley said planning for the tour had taken more than two years, and included negotiations with Yuri V. Dubinin, former ambassador to the United States, who visited Salt Lake City in April. The choir, whose 320 volunteer members participate without pay as a service to the church, has gained international renown through its radio, television and satellite broadcasts, recordings and numerous concert tours.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian President: World Belongs to Entrepreneurs, Not Generals
DOC.TEXT: Colombian President Virgilio Barco told new graduates of MIT, his alma mater, on Monday that the world of the future belongs not to the generals but to the entrepreneurs. ``It seems that the long-running match between Karl Marx and Adam Smith is finally coming to an end,'' said Barco. But the 68-year-old Barco also cautioned: ``Free market policies should not be used as an excuse for the lack of political will, whether it is assuring justice or fighting drug trafficking or providing basic education and health care. ``Free market economics is not a magic wand which somehow will relieve us of the obligation to care for our fellow human beings.'' Barco's 25-minute address in English was the main speech to 1,712 degree recipients and 8,000 guests. He was interrupted repeatedly by applause for his comments on human rights, the world's new and still-fragile democracies and the environment. Barco received an engineering degree from MIT in 1943. A decade later, he did graduate work in economics. From 1970 to 1980, he served on the board that runs the school, the MIT Corporation. Barco finishes his four-year term in August and is to be succeeded by Cesar Gaviria, who won election last month after a campaign season that was scarred by vicious drug-related violence. Barco said he didn't want to talk only about drug violence. His theme was more global. When the postwar world concentrated its attention on East-West tensions and the contest for military advantage, he said, the developed world ignored oppression in Latin America. ``We are now able to look beyond the myopia of the Cold War, beyond our previously clouded horizon to where a new world is waiting ... a world where entrepreneurs and innovators will lead the way, not the generals of yesterday.'' On Tuesday, Barco meets with President Bush. The two men are expected to continue discussions that arose at February's anti-drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Reagan, Raisa Gorbachev Hold Meeting
LaserPhoto Covering
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Reagan and Raisa Gorbachev exchanged smiles and handshakes today and renewed a relationship that Mrs. Reagan said had been misunderstood. As former President Ronald Reagan and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev chatted on a sofa in the Soviet counsel general's home, their wives perched on chairs and talked. Afterward, Mrs. Reagan characterized her hourlong meeting with Mrs. Gorbachev as ``very nice.'' ``I think there's been a great misunderstanding about our relationship,'' Mrs. Reagan told reporters. She wore a black and white outfit, while Mrs. Gorbachev had donned a more businesslike gray suit. Mrs. Reagan's kind words for Mrs. Gorbachev contrasted with her characterization of her in ``My Turn,'' her memoir of her White House years. ``From the moment we met, she talked and talked and talked _ so much that I could barely get a word in, edgewise or otherwise,'' Mrs. Reagan wrote. ``Perhaps it was insecurity on her part, but during about a dozen encounters in three different countries, my fundamental impression of Raisa Gorbachav was that she never stopped talking. ``Or lecturing, to be more accurate,'' Mrs. Reagan wrote. And the last time Mrs. Gorbachev visited Washington before this trip, in December 1987, she irritated Mrs. Reagan by observing that the White House was more a museum than ``a regular house.''

DOC.HEAD: Researcher Examining Why Some Can't Carry a Tune
DOC.TEXT: A neurologist who plays the trumpet wants to know why some people have perfect pitch and others can't carry a tune in a bucket. ``It is talent, or it is teachable?'' asks Dr. Louis S. Russo Jr., a member of the First Coast Pop Orchestra. He's looking for clues by studying a group of professional musicians and a group of people who have never had a music lesson. ``As children, we develop language and grammar skills by listening to our parents talk,'' said Russo. ``Why is it that people develop these (music) skills long before they go to school, yet many people can't even hum a tune? We all listen to music, even though we all can't play it.'' Russo first tested eight right-handed musicians with the Jacksonville Symphony Orchestra. All were connected to a brain mapping device and monitored while reading a magazine article, sight-reading music, singing a simple song from memory and while listening to Bach piano music. The brain maps showed when each musician read words, the left part of the brain was activated. Research has shown language is processed by the left side of the brain. The right side was activated when they sang or listened to music. But when the musicians were asked to sight read a piece of music, both sides of the brain began working. ``So the right side of the brain is necessary in all musical functions, but the left side is activated as the functions become more complex,'' he said.
