Seven people without musical training were given the same test. And while Russo is still analyzing the results from that group, he said preliminary examinations indicate that all the non-musicians lack is training. ``Everyone can be taught to learn to read music,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two British Hikers Died in Rocky Mountain Snowstorm
With AM-Storms
DOC.TEXT: Two British citizens died in a mountain snowstorm near here, but a companion survived the ordeal, authorities said. David Paddon, 21, a University of Colorado at Boulder exchange student from Farnborough, England, and Katherine Choules, 21, of Hertfordshire, England, died Friday near South Arapaho Peak west of Nederland, authorities said. Another exchange student, Paul Fretwell, 19, survived the storm and managed to hike to safety the next day, said Boulder County Sheriff's Lt. Les Trever. Fretwell's hometown wasn't known. Paddon died of head injuries and Choules of exposure, said Greg Weisbrod, medical investigator for the county coroner's office. Fretwell suffered minor injuries. A storm system that raked the state with rain and wind Friday night also brought wind-whipped snow above 8,000 feet in some areas, officials said. Paddon and Fretwell attended CU as exchange students from the University of Lancaster in England, said Pauline Coker, CU spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: East-West Conference on Human Rights Begins Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: Foreign ministers from 35 nations open an East-West human rights conference Tuesday, hoping to rewrite the ground rules in Europe so they protect ethnic minorities and guarantee the rule of law. Backstage, U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will press ahead with talks on Germany's future, picking up the thread from the weekend summit in Washington. The month-long conference is likely to produce a final document endorsing principles that just one year ago were out of reach: free elections, pluralist politics, and freedom of speech, assembly and religion. More radical proposals, such as establishing a committee to mediate ethnic disputes and possibly a security force, are likely to meet resistance. ``It is still too early to say if we can find a consensus. But all governments now agree to move ahead'' toward a human rights declaration, said Per Fergo, who heads the host delegation. The chief of the U.S. delegation, Max Kampelman, said in an interview the conference will discuss creating a mechanism to mediate disputes involving ethnic minorities. He gave as an example complaints of discrimination by ethnic Hungarians living in Romania. Foreign ministers will meet in Copenhagen for two days. Delegations led by senior diplomats will draft the final conference document. The Copenhagen conference is an outgrowth of the 1975 Helsinki Final Act, which reduced tensions in Europe and set minimum standards of behavior by states toward their citizens. The 35 signatories of the Helsinki accords form the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. They are the United States, Canada and all European nations except Albania, which now wants to join. The first conference was held in Paris last June and ended without a final document. The final meeting will be held in Moscow in 1991. First on the agenda for the meeting of foreign ministers is creating a committee that will prepare for a summit later this year. All European nations except Bulgaria were sending foreign ministers. The Copenhagen conference takes place in a new Europe ripe for agreement. It also comes as new pillars are being sought to support a reshaped Europe. Many leaders look to the conference as the foundation of the new structure. Baker and Shevardnadze were to continue talks on whether a unified Germany can be a member of NATO. President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S Gorbachev held extensive but inconclusive talks on the German question in Washington. Gorbachev, fearful of a powerful Germany on the Soviet border fully integrated into the Western military alliance, has said he wants the issue discussed in a pan-European council, possibly evolving from the Conference. The United States also has spoken of a wider monitoring role for the international group.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Security Stifles Dissent on Anniversary of Crackdown
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB graf 5, `In sharp...' to CORRECT 1988 to 1989. Pickup 6th, `Thousands who...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEJ6
DOC.TEXT: Police with rifles blocked roads to Beijing's university area Monday and heavy security elsewhere in the city stifled dissent on the first anniversary of the bloody demise of China's democracy movement. All gates to Beijing University, a center of last year's political activism, were locked at 8 p.m. The public was barred from Tiananmen Square, the center of the protests, for the fourth day. The few individuals who tried to protest the military crackdown were quickly arrested. Outside China, people from Mongolia to Paris and Czechoslovakia remembered the anniversary with hunger strikes, marches and candlelight vigils. The largest commemmoration was in Hong Kong, where tens of thousands of people jammed Victoria Park and watched videotapes of Chinese dissidents in exile urging people not to forget the Beijing killings. In sharp contrast to the dramatic reforms of Eastern Europe in the past year, China has retreated into ideological orthodoxy since the June 3-4, 1989 crackdown. All students are required to take courses in Marxism and Mao Tse-tung thought, and a clean political record has become key to getting a good job or a passport. Thousands who participated in last year's uprising remain behind bars, many without being charged or tried. Police set up roadblocks near universities in northwest Beijing on Monday night and would not allow foreign journalists to pass. One Western reporter saw three truckloads of riot police, armed with shields and rifles, entering the university area. Security forces armed with AK-47 rifles patrolled outside Beijing University. Plainclothes police, many with walkie-talkies, kept an eye on students. For the third night, students smashed beer bottles _ ``bottle'' in Chinese sounds much like senior leader Deng Xiaoping's name. But there was no repetition of the campus protest Sunday night that attracted as many as 1,000 students. ``Nothing will happen tonight,'' one student said. ``It would just be a repeat of last night and it would not be meaningful. Yesterday was the time for it to happen.'' It was on the night of June 3, 1989 that the People's Liberation Army stormed Beijing, killing hundreds and perhaps thousands of people on the way to ending the occupation of Tiananmen Square by students pressing for reform. Beijing University students marched around campus Sunday night singing The Internationale _ the anthem of the international socialist movement which became a theme song during last year's demonstrations. The one speaker at the rally, 21-year-old economics major Li Minqi, disappeared Monday and was believed to be hiding. Several Western journalists were roughed up and briefly detained by police during the protest. The State Department on Monday denounced the action and said it had advised the Chinese government ``that such actions are clearly unacceptable.'' A few candles burned in some graduate dormitories Monday night, possibly in memory of those killed. Several people hooted and spat out a dormitory window when a convoy of security drove by. The 100-acre Tiananmen Square, the symbolic center of China, is usually open to the public, but it was surrounded by paramilitary police. A man who tried to hand out leaflets at the gate of the Forbidden City, across from the square, was quickly seized by police, foreign witnesses said. Western reporters saw police drag off another person, apparently a woman, near the square. Some students called for a hunger strike to mark the anniversary, but it apparently did not take place. ``Some people said they'd get drunk,'' one student said. A hunger strike in May last year began the occupation of Tiananmen Square. Seven protesters outside the Chinese Embassy in Paris held a 36-hour hunger strike that was to end Monday night. ``I decided to do something concrete for the anniversary, so that we won't forget what happened, and that political prisoners in China may be released,'' said Yvon Thomas, 19, who wore a headband with ``Freedom'' and ``Democracy'' written on it in Chinese. Another gathering was held outside the Chinese Embassy in Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, which has recently undergone democratic changes after decades of Communist rule. Twenty Mongolian students staged a one-hour sit-in and tried to deliver a petition to the embassy, but they were not allowed to, the East German news agency ADN said. They left after pasting on the mission's wall a poster condemning the June 4 bloodshed. The official Xinhua News Agency reported late Monday that Beijing was stable and life was normal on the anniversary. ``Millions of Beijing residents peacefully spent this Monday in busy work and pleasant rest,'' it said. Xinhua reported the Sunday night protest but stressed that Beijing campuses ``were in good order today, and quiet as usual.'' The government continues to insist that the military crackdown was justified, saying it faced a counterrevolutionary plot to overthrow Communist Party rule. The party's official People's Daily said in a front-page editorial Monday that the suppression of the democracy movement was ``absolutely correct and necessary.'' It said that without resolute action against the demonstrators, ``China would be in great chaos now.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Gave $114 Billion to Charity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT, time set by source; counsel is cq, 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: Americans gave $114.7 billion to charity in 1989, a 10.43 percent increase over 1988, according to a report released Monday. Religious groups got the biggest chunk _ $54.32 billion, the AAFRC Trust for Philanthropy said. ``Once again, Americans demonstrated the centrality of philanthropic giving not only to our culture but to our individual lives,'' said the report. The increase in giving actually was 5.5 percent when adjusted for inflation, said the trust, an arm of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. The group was founded more than 50 years ago to advance philanthropy. Individual donations, which amounted to 84.1 percent of the total, increased 11.67 percent over 1988 _ or 6.7 percent, when adjusted for inflation. They totaled $96.43 billion. ``For every $5 we spent on food, we gave more than 80 cents, almost $1, to a worthy cause,'' said the report. ``For every $2 we spent on shoes and clothing, we gave $1 to philanthropy.'' ``Clearly, these comparisons show that philanthropy is not ancillary to our lives, not something we do on the side.'' it said. Part of the generosity was attributed to an 8.9 percent rise in personal income. The report also said a 21.1 percent stock market upswing in 1989 probably evoked bigger gifts from the affluent. It also cited growing awareness of AIDS, homelessness, the environment and other concerns, and intensified fund-raising efforts. Two natural disasters in 1989, the San Francisco earthquake and Hurricane Hugo, generated an outpouring of financial aid. The American Red Cross, for example, received $155 million for both disasters, mostly from small, individual donations. In all, 1989 contributions saw $6.7 billion from foundations, up 8.93 percent, or 4 percent when adjusted for inflation; $6.57 billion from bequests, the same overall but down 4.5 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars; and $5 billion for corporations, up 4.17 percent overall, but down 0.5 percent over 1988 in inflation-adjusted dollars. Overall, 47.4 percent of the year's donations, or $54.32 billion, went to houses of worship, religious organizations and the social services they provide. That was up 12.95 percent from 1988, or 7.4 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars. Catholic Charities, a coalition of 700 social service agencies, joined a trend that has grown among secular groups. It sponsored a credit card called ``Caritas''; one-half percent of each purchase price is earmarked as a donation. In addition to religious groups, donations were divided among: _Human services, $11.39 billion, up 8.58 percent, or 3.7 percent when adjusted for inflation. _Education, $10.69 billion, up 4.49 percent, or ``a slight drop'' when adjusted. _Health, $10.04 billion, up 4.8 percent, or 0.1 percent when adjusted. _Arts, culture and humanities, $7.49 billion, up 10.31 percent, or 5.4 percent when adjusted. _Public and society benefits _ including the environment, traffic safety, animal rights, urban and rural development, and countless other categories _ $3.62 billion, up 12.77 percent, or 7.7 percent when adjusted. _All other uses, including overseas services, $17.13 billion, up 10.8 percent, or 5.9 percent when adjusted. It was the fourth consecutive year that corporate giving did not keep pace with the rising costs faced by non-profit organizations. Conversely, the report said that Japanese corporations ``showed a growing interest during 1989 in fostering their own philanthropic efforts in this country.'' No figures were cited, however. A majority of the contributions from American corporations is earmarked for education. Now, that money is increasingly benefiting children and alternative education programs, rather than colleges. In 1988, 64 percent of all corporate education donations went to colleges and universities, compared with about 70 percent in 1988. In 1989, Coca-Cola, General Electric, IBM and RJR Nabisco announced education grants that will total $130 million over the next decade. They place heavy emphasis on elementary and secondary schooling, and higher education for minorities.

DOC.HEAD: A Little Controversy Sparks the 1990 Tony Awards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf to CORRECT spelling of `wittiest'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Tonys-List
DOC.TEXT: There was more drama off-camera than on at the 1990 Tony Awards, although ``The Grapes of Wrath'' was the upset winner for best play over ``The Piano Lesson.'' The flap occurred during a commercial break at the televised award show when producer Joseph Cates blasted presenter Ron Silver for his lengthy defense of the embattled National Endowment for the Arts and for his remembrance of the massacre in Beijing one year ago. ``I support the NEA,'' Cates explained to the black tie audience at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, but added: ``To take advantage of a live TV show like that does us all incredible harm. This is not the show on which to make those comments.'' Cates' comments were met with scattered boos and some applause by theatergoers. If ``The Piano Lesson,'' which had won the Pulitzer Prize and the New York Drama Critics Circle Award, was Sunday evening's biggest loser, ``City of Angels'' was the biggest winner. It took home six awards including best musical. The show also won for actor-musical, James Naughton; score, Cy Coleman and David Zippel; book, Larry Gelbart; featured actress-musical, Randy Graff, set design, Robin Wagner. ``The Grapes of Wrath'' only won two honors, including a directing award for Frank Galati, but they were important prizes. What counts in terms of box office is the best play award, and the honor should help business at the stage adaptation of John Steinbeck's epic novel about Depression-era Okies. Until now, the play has been doing respectable but not sell-out business. Other highlights: _Best speech: Tommy Tune's second Tony of the night, a prize for his direction of ``Grand Hotel.'' The lanky Tune strode to the stage, smiled, waved at the audience and walked off. He also picked up a Tony for the show's choreography. Tune has won seven Tonys during a Broadway career that has brought him prizes in four different categories, actor-musical, featured actor-musical, director-musical and choreography, a Tony record. _Worst speech: Tyne Daly's rambling thank you in which she kept reminding the audience that she only had 30 seconds in which to speak and then proceeded to ignore her own time limit for several minutes. Daly won the actress-musical award for her portrayal of Mama Rose in a revival of ``Gypsy.'' _Most emotional speech _ Michael Jeter's tearful plea, ``If you have got a problem with alcohol and drugs and you can't stop and think life can't change and dreams can't come true, I stand here as living proof that you can stop,'' he said in accepting the featured actor award-musical for ``Grand Hotel.'' ``It changes a day at a time and dreams come true.'' _Wittiest speech: Charles Durning, who picked up the supporting actor prize for his portrayal of Big Daddy in a revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' Saying he didn't deserve the award, he added, ``but I don't deserve arthritis either.'' _The evening's strangest omissions: No mention during the telecast of Rex Harrison, the debonair star of ``My Fair Lady,'' who died at age 82 Saturday, one day before the Tonys show. And the closing of ``A Chorus Line'' didn't rate a footnote even though the final performance of Broadway's longest running show on April 28 was one of the highlights of the season.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Angered By Gorbachev Threat; Peres Blames Shamir For Conflict
LaserPhoto TLV4
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Monday defended the right of Soviet Jews to live in Israeli-occupied territory, saying a democracy could not limit where people live. Shamir was reacting to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's comment Sunday that he may limit Soviet Jewish emigration to Israel if the immigrants settle on land seized from Jordan and Egypt. Speaking to Israeli manufacturers in Tel Aviv, the right-wing Shamir said his government's policy is to allow Jews to live anywhere in Israel, including the occupied West Bank, Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem. ``If the Soviet Union of President Gorbachev does not consider itself empowered today to dictate to its citizens where to live... it's as clear as the sun that we, educated by democracy and freedom, cannot impose limitations on this or another category of settlers in the state of Israel,'' he said. ``We shall not create ghettos and areas of residence in this country,'' Shamir added. In the West Bank settlement of Ariel, Michael Klimovitsky, a recent arrival from Leningrad, supported Shamir's statements. ``Israel is a free country. It's not the Soviet Union, thank God. In this country, a man has to decide for himself where he will live,'' the 25-year-old computer programmer said. Ariel officials estimate that 200 Soviet immigrants have moved to the settlement. It is 10 miles southeast of Nablus, the West Bank's largest city and a focal point of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. Shimon Peres, head of the center-left Labor party and Shamir's strongest political rival, said Gorbachev's statement was a result of the government's failure to move toward a peace settlement with the Palestinians. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler doubted the Soviet president would carry out his threat. ``We're not sure what President Gorbachev meant by his comments,'' Ms. Tutwiler said a day after the Soviet leader ended his summit with President Bush. ``Nothing that was said during the private summit discussions indicated in any way that the Soviets won't live up to their commitments to permit Soviet Jewish emigration,'' she said. ``We expect that they will continue to do so. They know how very important this is to us.'' In all, Israeli officials said, fewer than 300 of the 40,000 Soviet Jews who have arrived in Israel this year have moved to the West Bank and Gaza. This figure does not include an estimated 3,200 Soviet immigrants living in annexed areas of Jerusalem. Explaining his threat to limit immigration, Gorbachev said he was under intense pressure from Arab nations, which fear settlement of Soviet Jews on occupied land will displace Palestinians. Currently, 1.7 million Palestinians live in the West Bank and Gaza Strip along with 70,000 Jewish settlers. Immigration is at an all-time high as a result of relaxed Soviet restrictions, and as many as 150,000 Soviet Jews are expected to arrive by the end of the year. About 1 million Soviets are seeking permission to emigrate. Ariel is home to about 8,000 Jewish residents. Simcha Dinitz, head of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, which helps immigrants, said that since April 1989, some 285 Soviet Jews have moved to the occupied territories. Dinitz's figure on those living in the occupied lands excludes the Soviets who have moved to a ring of Jewish suburbs around Arab east Jerusalem on war-won land that Israel annexed. Most Western nations do not recognize Israeli sovereignty over the area, and earlier this year President Bush said he viewed Jerusalem's Jewish suburbs as part of the occupied areas. Neighborhood council officials in the suburbs that have taken the bulk of the Soviet immigrants told The Associated Press at least 940 Soviet families, or an estimated 3,200 people, have moved into the areas in the wave of immigration that began in spring 1989. The four suburbs involved are Pisgat Zeev, Neve Yaacov, Gilo and Ramot. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said the future of Soviet trade with the United States could hinge on the treatment of Soviet Jews and that this could determine whether Gorbachev carries through on his threat. ``The Soviet Union knows that the trade agreement it signed with the U.S. is conditional on free emigration from the U.S.S.R., and it is very hard to imagine that the process initiated by Gorbachev in the Soviet Union, with perestroika and free exit being integral parts of this process, would undergo some change,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Off to Denmark to Pursue US-Soviet Dispute Over Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Shevardnadze comment, subbing 2 grafs for 2nd graf pvs, and subbing 4 grafs for 11th graf pvs, `We've had
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III headed for Copenhagen Monday to take up a nine-point Western plan on Germany's military future with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. The plan would allow the Red Army to keep troops in East Germany for now. Shevardnadze, in Copenhagen, said that no quick agreement was likely and that the matter should eventually be taken to a broader meeting of European nations. The U.S. goal is to induce the Soviets to drop their objections to NATO membership for the new and stronger Germany that will emerge when East Germany is combined with West Germany. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev registered his concerns about the Soviets' mighty neighbor and onetime deadly foe in his summit talks here with President Bush. They parted agreeing to disagree, but with the Soviet leader also saying he had surveyed some ``new possible perspectives'' with Bush. Now Baker intends to flesh them out with Shevardnadze while they are attending a conference on human rights, said U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Baker also will confer in the Danish capital with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the innovative diplomat who originated many of the ideas. The Western plan includes a lowering of NATO`s military profile as East-West tensions subside and an acceleration of negotiations to ban short-range nuclear weapons in both alliances. Also, the officials said, Soviet troops could remain in what is now East German territory for some time, the West Germans would help Gorbachev with his herculean program to pep up the Soviet economy and the new Germany would affirm its intention to acquire neither nuclear nor chemical weapons. NATO forces would not be deployed in the East German area; the European Security Conference would be strengthened and NATO and the Warsaw Pact would negotiate deeper cuts in troops and non-nuclear weapons once current reduction talks in Vienna produce a treaty, the officials told The Associated Press. Additionally, Baker said on Sunday that the two alliances might exchange a political statement of assurances. As Baker was leaving Washington, Shevardnadze was asked about the U.S. plan in Copenhagen. ``I wouldn't say that we agreed with the Americans on all things,'' he said. ``I couldn't say it (an agreement) will be possible already here. We didn't pretend. It is very difficult to find a solution on the external parts of the German unity.'' Shevardnadze said any accord over Germany's military future should be presented to a pan-European meeting, and officials in Copenhagen said the foreign ministers' meeting will plan preparations for a November meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. In Washington, a U.S. official said, ``We've had the broad philosophical discussion at the summit,'' a U.S. official said. ``Our effort now is to try to engage them on the specifics.'' Basically, the official said, Baker is approaching Shevardnadze this way: Tell us what your concerns are and we'll try to find a way of meeting them. But, the official said, the Bush administration would not agree to ``discriminatory limitations on a unified Germany,'' After the Copenhagen sessions, Baker and the 15 other NATO foreign ministers, including Genscher, will take up the difficult German problem again Thursday at a meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Turnberry, Scotland. The human rights conference and the meeting of the Western allies were already scheduled before Bush and Gorbachev held their four-day summit, which ended Sunday in Washington. But the Bush-Gorbachev dispute over Germany's military future gave Baker's trip extra significance. Baker plans to meet with Shevardnadze and Genscher again, in Berlin, later in the month. ``We'll keep wrestling with it,'' Baker said Sunday. Gorbachev, for his part, declared at the summit windup: ``I cannot say that we have reached agreement, but that does not mean that our efforts were futile. Many new arguments emerged as a result of these discussions, and new possible perspectives.'' ``We will continue our discussion in order to find a mutually acceptable solution,'' Gorbachev said. Gorbachev has repeatedly insisted that a unified Germany not be aligned with NATO. He argues that in an era of democratic change, his own people see the alliance as an anti-Soviet remnant of the Cold War. Having lost more than 20 million people to Nazi Germany in World War II, and with the East European allies now a less reliable buffer, Gorbachev is anxious about being confronted by a stronger Germany. Bush, however, at a joint news conference with the Soviet leader, said having Germany in NATO ``would be stabilizing.''

DOC.HEAD: Monarch Has Pneumonia After Paralyzing Stroke
DOC.TEXT:
Norway's 86-year-old King Olav V, partially paralyzed by a stroke over the weekend, has developed pneumonia, doctors said Monday. The world's oldest reigning monarch suffered the stroke Saturday while in the Oslo's Rikshospitalet. Doctors called his condition ``unsafe.'' Earlier Monday, they said the paralysis of his left side improved slightly but they warned of ``an approaching infection of his lungs.'' A later statement said it was pneumonia. Well-wishers in Norway, a constitutional monarchy, sent a flood of flowers, telegrams and letters to the popular monarch, often called ``The People's King,'' said the palace in a statement. The king formally installs the prime minister and Cabinet but has no real political power. Churches throughout Norway included prayer for Olav in services Monday. Crown Prince Harald, in line to succeed Olav, stayed with his father during the weekend. All members of the royal family visited the king Sunday and Monday. His oldest daughter, Princess Ragnhild, flew in from her home in Brazil Monday, despite having influenza. Olav had been hospitalized last Tuesday for treatment of a mild infection of his pericardium, a membraneous sac surrounding the heart. The stroke came one day after Olav was advised to remain in the hospital for observation through the weekend. King Olav, who has ruled Norway since 1957, became the world's oldest reigning monarch when Japan's Emperor Hirohito died in January last year at age 87. A 1928 Olympic gold medalist in yatching, King Olav spent his 86th birthday last July sailing in an Oslo regatta aboard his 18-foot sailboat. He last sailed in the Oslo fjord a few weeks ago.
Polls regularly rank Olav as Norway's best-liked person. About 90 percent of the 4.2 million people in this egalitarian welfare state still favor the monarchy, according to surveys.
Queen Martha, his Swedish-born cousin and wife, died in 1954. He never remarried.
The Norwegian king, born Prince Alexander Edward Christian Fredrik of Denmark, was two years old when Norway left its union with Sweden in 1905 to become an independent monarchy. His father, Danish Prince Carl, took the name King Haakon VII when he was invited to take the Norwegian throne.

DOC.HEAD: British Lawmakers Refused Entry to China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT spelling of Macao, ADDS that Macao a Portuguese colony
DOC.HEAD: With AM-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two British lawmakers said Monday they were refused entry into China and left stranded on the China-Macao border after their tour bus continued on without them. The incident Sunday coincided with the first anniversary of China's suppression of a pro-democracy movement. The lawmakers, Brian Sedgemore and Dale Campbell-Savours, both members of the opposition Labor Party, said they would complain to the British and Chinese governments. Sedgemore said the two had planned to go sightseeing after an official visit to Hong Kong when they arrived at China's border with Macao, a tiny Portuguese colony. ``To the astonishment of those traveling with us, we were forced to leave our bus and were left stranded by the roadside on the border'' with Macao, he said. ``This was despite the fact that we had been told that we were on a group visa.'' He said the two believe they were stopped because Chinese authorities believed they might become involved in protests of the anniversary of the crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Post Summit Talks, Bjt
Ford Says Baltic Problems Will Persist Despite Bush-Gorbachev Friendship
DOC.TEXT: The future of the Baltic republics will continue to be a thorny U.S.-Soviet issue despite a beneficial personal bond forged between President Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev, former President Gerald Ford said Monday. ``I believe a personal relationship that is based on good faith, understanding and kindliness makes a major difference in trying to resolve some of these international problems,'' Ford told the National Press Club. ``It's my judgment that President Bush and Mr. Gorbachev have established that kind of rapport, and it would be my estimate that it will pay dividends and benefits in the months ahead,'' he said in a question-and-answer session with club members and guests. Ford also was asked whether he believed the Soviet economic embargo of Lithuania, in retaliation for its March 11 declaration of independence, would continue to be an obstacle to a U.S. grant of most favored nation trading status to the Soviet Union. ``The problem of the Baltic nations _ Estonia and Latvia and Lithuania _ is going to be a very difficult one for Mr. Gorbachev to solve, and it will be a continuing problem between the government of the United States and the Soviet Union,'' he said. Bush announced during the superpower summit that ended Sunday in Washington that he would grant most favored nation status to the Soviet Union if Moscow drops restrictions on emigration. But Bush made no mention of Lithuania. The agreement is subject to approval by Congress. The United States has never recognized the incorporation of the Baltic states into the Soviet Union after the Hitler-Stalin pact during World War II. ``Our position today has to be consistent with that point of view, and that of course is not reconcilable with Mr. Gorbachev's problems,'' Ford said. The former president said he believed the United States should be ``somewhat understanding of what Mr. Gorbachev faces and how he can handle it'' and give him ``time, in a reasonable sense'' to seek a solution. As to the trade proposal, Ford said, ``The Congress, very likely, will try to roadblock it. Whether they can or not, whether the votes are there, I am not in a position to assess that at the moment.'' Ford spoke after presenting the annual $5,000 Gerald R. Ford journalism awards, sponsored by the Gerald R. Ford Foundation. Gerald Seib of the Wall Street Journal received the award for reporting on the presidency and Debra Polsky of Defense News was recognized for reporting about defense issues.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Human Rights Abuses Still at High Level, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Despite reforms that have won Mikhail S. Gorbachev praise and admiration in the West, human rights abuses still abound in the Soviet Union, a monitoring group said Monday. Freedom of religion, the press and emigration remain restricted; there are as many as 188 alleged political prisoners; and refugees from ethnic strife in various Soviet republics are forced to live in miserable conditions, according to the International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights. The group, meeting in Moscow for the first time in its eight-year history, said it encountered no harassment or intimidation during two days of hearings. But its chairman, Karl J. von Schwarzenberg, said it was denied access to a psychiatric institute after insisting upon bringing along Soviet human rights activists who were members of the federation. ``They declined to see us, telling us our Russian members are insane,'' von Schwarzenberg said, ``which was a remarkable statement, I must say.'' The federation will present its formal report on human rights in the Soviet Union at a meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that opens Tuesday in Copenhagen. The meeting is an outgrowth of the 1975 Helsinki Final Act. Moscow will be the host next year for another such gathering, and the federation's members viewed the weekend meetings as a test to see whether it was possible to meet and talk about human rights in the Soviet Union. ``We are not satisfied with the conditions as they exist now,'' said David Matas, a chairman of the Canadian Helsinki Committee, when asked about the prospects for a successful 1991 meeting in Moscow. But Nikolai Uspensky of the Soviet Foreign Ministry told a separate news conference Monday that ``there is no opposition to holding this meeting in Moscow.'' ``At the same time, I must say that at the very beginning, Americans and the British were cool and reluctant to hold such a meeting in Moscow because they were afraid they would be unable to maintain the standard of such a conference,'' Uspensky said. ``Well, they have no doubts now.'' Irwin Cotler, a law professor at McGill University in Montreal and a chairman of the Canadian committee, illustrated how far the Soviet Union had come by noting that longtime dissident Lev Timofeyev presided at Monday's news conference for the Helsinki federation. At a human rights meeting in 1988, Timofeyev was not allowed to speak. The federation said the human rights abuses that exist today are left over from the days before Gorbachev's reforms but added: ``The abuses nonetheless remain at such a high level to be a cause for great concern.'' The federation noted there are between 50 and 188 identified cases of alleged political prisoners and noted the case of Mikhail Kazachkov of Leningrad, who was arrested in 1975 on charges of treason after applying to emigrate. Cotler said Kazachkov has been denied the right to counsel, has been allowed only three visits from his 88-year-old mother in 14 years, and has spent five years in solitary confinement. Kazachkov has been given such harsh treatment, he said, because he has stood up for the rights of political prisoners and because he is a Jew. ``While people are no longer imprisoned for anti-Soviet propaganda alone, they are convicted of crimes of hooliganism for apparent political activities,'' the federation said. It also said there was concern about continued detention through abuse of psychiatry. Turning to the press, the federation said independent newspapers cannot buy newsprint, use printing presses or distribute via kiosks and have had their offices burglarized and ransacked. It noted what it called ``severe restrictions'' on freedom of religion, saying the ``leadership of the Russian Orthodox Church is in effect appointed by the Communist government.'' It also said the state has taken property from the Ukrainian Catholic Church, which was banned by Stalin, and that there is no legal way to return it.

DOC.HEAD: State Officials Banter Over Tennessee Tax on Maine Taxes
DOC.TEXT: A letter from Tennessee officials suggesting that Maine's Taxation Bureau may be subject to a new Tennessee tax touched off a tongue-in-cheek debate over taxes and tourism. The form letter from the Tennessee Revenue Department was accompanied by a summary of the law imposing the tax on out-of-state financial institutions that do business in Tennessee. Lawmakers there enacted the measure this year. ``Financial institutions which you represent or with which you are associated in some way, may be subject to taxation under the act,'' reads the letter received by the Maine Taxation Bureau last month. Maine State Tax Assessor John D. LaFaver realized that the tax bureau itself could not be taxed by another state, but the temptation to respond to Tennessee Revenue Commissioner Joe Huddleston proved irresistible. ``If you have found a way to tax other states' revenue departments, I would like to know what the secret is,'' LaFaver wrote. He noted that Maine and other New England states were forced to pare spending substantially this year because of an unanticipated economic slump. ``Maybe we could claim that any state whose residents eat Maine lobsters or consume our famous potatoes or enjoy our unsurpassed scenery and hospitality would have their taxation departments contribute their fair share to supporting the state that makes all that possible.'' Huddleston said Monday the letter was sent to Maine officials to inform them about the law. ``It was not necessarily asking the Maine department to register'' to pay the tax, he said in a telephone interview from Nashville. Huddleston took good-natured issue with LaFaver's assertion that Maine's scenery is unsurpassed, saying he was ``more than willing to put our scenery up against Maine's.''

DOC.HEAD: Health Care is Biggest Threat at Bargaining Table
DOC.TEXT: Spiraling health care costs _ labor and management's biggest sticking point in collective bargaining _ are forcing companies nationwide to take extraordinary steps such as setting up their own medical clinics or physician networks. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., for instance, has three medical clinics at plants in Oklahoma, Ohio and Alabama where workers can visit a physician, eye doctor or pharmacist for $15. Follow-up visits are $5. ``There are two ways to go _ decrease benefits and jack up premiums for workers or find a better and cheaper way,'' says consultant Victor Williams. More than a dozen Fortune 500 companies have called Williams in the past year inquiring about Goodyear's experience in the medical business, he said. Goodyear estimates it saves $1 million a year on its $163 million health care bill. ``It just scratches the surface, but it helps,'' said spokesman Bob Mercer. Employees benefit as well, said J.R. Countryman of the United Rubber Workers, which represents Goodyear workers in Alabama. ``It sure has cut down on our costs,'' he said. But not all management efforts to trim health care costs are being embraced by workers. In fact, union workers nationwide increasingly find themselves trying to fend off management efforts to shift health care costs to workers; the issue was at the heart of 78 percent of the strikes waged last year by unions, according to one study. Most recently, a two-year battle to resolve health care costs in the railroad industry proved unsuccessful _ last month President Bush was forced to appoint an emergency board to try and prevent a strike. In that dispute, the major railroads _ which for decades have provided workers with a solid, low-cost health care package _ wanted the 235,000 brakemen, engineers and other workers who keep the nation's freight system moving to pay higher deductibles and make payroll contributions. ``Then they have to think twice because it's not something someone else is going to pay for 100 percent,'' said Charles Hopkins, chairman of the National Railway Labor Conference, which represents management in the dispute. Union officials contend shifting health care costs to workers does little to solve a greater problem that merits Congress' attention _ how to rein in runaway medical costs. ``To try to pin the blame on some poor worker worried about their kid in the middle of the night is really outrageous,'' said Bob Master of the Communications Workers of America, which fought a health care battle for telephone workers in the Northeast last year. Hopkins said management has no choice but to try to shift part of the burden to workers because ``we are being consumed by the cost of our so-called fringe benefits.'' Besides trying to shift premium costs to workers, companies are also moving to restrict a worker's right to choose a doctor. Some also are auditing patients' bills. Many companies are now setting up ``preferred provider arrangements,'' medical networks that provide services to workers at a negotiated price. Often, employers provide financial incentives for workers to use the PPO rather than their own family doctor. Other companies, such as Florida Power & Light, are hiring nurses to visit hospitals to audit patients' bills to make sure money isn't being wasted. The effort, said spokesman Michael Millhorn, is an attempt to save money without hurting workers. ``We don't want to mess with the level of benefits if we can avoid it,'' Millhorn said. Paul O'Neill, chairman of ALCOA, the Aluminum Company of America, told a House panel recently that he didn't feel comfortable intervening in workers' medical care decisions. O'Neill noted that employers do not have a say in what type of car or food a worker buys. ``Yet here I am in the middle of personal medical care,'' he said. Union leaders, who have long been pushing for some type of national health care system, hope the problems will lead business to join them in supporting health care reform, rather than merely trying to pass costs on to workers. ``That's simply a blame-the-victim strategy that may look good in the short term and for the balance sheet. But what we should be saying is, `Hey, let's try to get a permanent solution to this problem,''' said Karen Ignagni, the AFL-CIO's expert on health care. According to a study by the Service Employees International Union, workers' out-of-pocket expenses for health care grew faster than wages from 1986 to 1989. The biggest increase was in employee contributions to premiums for family health coverage, which rose from $14.30 to $24.12. If current trends continue, the study found, health insurance premiums will consume 27 percent of take-home pay by 1998. ``It's a national problem and must be addressed nationally,'' AFL-CIO president Lane Kirkland said recently. Ignagni and other union leaders said government involvement is crucial because there's a limit to how creative labor and management can be at reducing health care costs. For instance, she said, little can be done at the bargaining table to bring down the cost of a $900 hospital room. ``The lesson of the '90s is that there is a limit to what you can do to change the slope of the curve,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Told Not to Press Drunken-Driving Charges
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday barred Connecticut officials from pressing drunken-driving charges against a man acquitted of manslaughter in a fatal traffic accident. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the second prosecution would violate the motorist's double-jeopardy constitutional rights. The justices ruled in a similar case May 29. By a 5-4 vote, they said a New York man who pleaded guilty to drunken driving and related traffic offenses in a fatal car crash may not be prosecuted later for homicide and assault. In the case acted on Monday, John Lonergan was driving a car in Hartford on May 22, 1985, when he collided with a motorcycle driven by Scott Sementilli. Sementilli died the next day from his injuries. Longeran was charged with manslaughter and driving while intoxicated, and the state decided to try him only on the manslaughter count. A judge ruled that the state had failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Lonergan's alleged intoxication caused Sementilli's death, and ordered Lonergan acquitted. State prosecutors then sought to try Lonergan for driving under the influence of liquor. But a judge threw out the prosecution; that ruling was upheld by the Connecticut Supreme Court last year. The state court said retrying Lonergan would violate the Constitution's ban on multiple prosecutions for the same crime. ``The record clearly indicates that in the second prosecution for operating while under the influence the state will rely on and seek to prove the same act of operating while intoxicated that was necessary to prove the manslaughter charge in the first prosecution,'' the state court said. The case is Connecticut vs. Lonergan, 89-1295.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Puts On Grand Show For Raisa
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Raisa Gorbachev and Nancy Reagan renewed old acquaintances Monday, and anyone expecting a sudden frost in San Francisco saw only warmth instead. As Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev chatted for an hour on a sofa at the at the home of the Soviet consul general, their wives talked nearby. ``Very nice,'' Mrs. Reagan said afterward. She denied suggestions that she and Mrs. Gorbachev once were uncomfortable with each other: ``I think there's been a great misunderstanding about our relationship,'' she said. ``It was a very different time,'' Mrs. Reagan said. ``We were plowing new ground.'' There was no sign of the irritation that Mrs. Reagan betrayed in December 1987, when the visiting Mrs. Gorbachev observed that the White House was more a museum than ``a regular house.'' And there was no repetition of Mrs. Reagan's complaints, in her book ``My Turn,'' that Mrs. Gorbachev ``never stopped talking. Or lecturing, to be more accurate.'' The morning meeting was the start of an eventful day for the wife of the Soviet leader. A whirlwind tour of the city was planned, whisking her past the War Memorial Opera House, Davis Symphony Hall and other sights. Fisherman's Wharf also was on the itinerary, along with a stop at the Bank of America tower. Mrs. Gorbachev's tour of the city was to be escorted by Tatyana Kamenev, wife of the Soviet consul general. The wife of Mayor Art Agnos, Sherry Agnos, also was expected to join them. Mrs. Gorbachev has earned respect on her own, said Patricia Montandon, who was to visit with Mrs. Gorbachev at a Friends of Raisa gathering after the tour. The group includes women who have met Mrs. Gorbachev on trips to the Soviet Union to promote peace. ``She has a mind of her own. ... She's not just a supporter of her husband, she's in partnership with him,'' said Montandon. One tourist attraction _ the Golden Gate Bridge _ was saved for the end of the day. The Gorbachevs were scheduled to meet there just prior to their departure for home.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Jury Selection Begins; He Calls Prosecutors `Totalitarian'
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Monday in Mayor Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial as Barry accused prosecutors of pursuing him with the tactics of ``a totalitarian kind of society.'' The mayor, accompanied by his wife Effi, went to the U.S. Courthouse as the first of two groups of 125 potential jurors filled out questionnaires designed to uncover any bias for or against him. Two of Barry's security guards and several businessmen who have benefited from city city contracts are among those included on a list of potential witnesses, according to the questionnaires. The trial is expected to last about a month. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 charges of cocaine possession, three counts of lying to a grand jury and one count of conspiracy. The three charges of lying are felonies. Sources close to the case have said Barry's lawyers have been conducting plea bargain talks with federal prosecutors, but one source said the two sides are at an impasse. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens ``wants the mayor to plead to a felony, but that's not likely to happen,'' said a city official who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Barry is willing to consider pleading guilty only to misdemeanors, the official said. If Barry were jailed on a felony conviction or guilty plea, he would be barred from holding office or running for re-election to a fourth four-year term this November. ``Since 1983, my family have had to go through my mail being opened, my bank accounts checked, my tax return looked at, my phones tapped,'' Barry said in an interview with radio station WOL. ``You can't even have a conference in your bedroom with your wife for fear that they're listening to anything you may say,'' he added. ``It's been a thing that you thought may happen in a totalitarian kind of society.'' The mayor also said a local television station had obtained from prosecutors a copy of the FBI videotape that sources close to the case say shows Barry smoking crack cocaine in a hotel room Jan. 18. ``They're trying to figure out now how to show it,'' he said. Judy Smith, spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Stephens, said prosecutors would not comment on that. The station, WRC-TV, also said it would have no comment. On the list of 48 names of possible witnesses were Charles Lewis and Rasheeda Moore as well as Barry security guards James Stays and Fred Gaskins. Lewis, in a plea agreement involving drug charges against himself, testified last November that he supplied Barry with crack cocaine. Moore, a former model, persuaded Barry to come to the hotel room where he was arrested. The questionnaires ask whether potential jurors think lying while under oath is justifiable. Barry has acknowledged he suffers from alcoholism, and the potential panelists were asked whether they think that could be used to excuse criminal activity. The questionaire also included a section asking the respondents to give their feelings about undercover sting operations, the method used to produce Barry's arrest. In addition, they were asked whether they thought the case agains the mayor was racially or politically motivated. Barry supporters and opponents gathered outside the courthouse as efforts began to select 12 jurors and six alternates. Two dozen Guardian Angels, a self-styled anti-crime group, carried signs demanding Barry's resignation. They were taunted by several Barry supporters who said the black mayor was the victim of racially motivated prosecution and had been entrapped by investigators. ``If anyone should be on trial it should be (U.S. Attorney) Stephens,'' said Florence Smith of the National Welfare Rights Organization. Barry attended a church rally Sunday night and called the months since his Jan. 18 arrest ``the most difficult time in my life.'' ``I ain't gonna waste time,'' Barry said. ``I've come too far from where I started from.'' After a standing ovation from the crowd, he expressed confidence that his legal crisis will not bring him down. While Barry has said he needs only one juror to vote against convicting him, some of his top aides and political advisers have indicated they are extremely reluctant to see the case come to trial.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Corey Feldman Pleads Innocent to Drug Counts
DOC.TEXT: Actor Corey Feldman pleaded innocent Monday to four felony drug charges. Feldman, 18, entered his plea before a Superior Court judge who set a pretrial hearing for July 9. The actor was charged with possession of heroin for sale, transportation of heroin, possession of cocaine and transportation of heroin, said Deputy District Attorney Peter Cagney. Feldman remains free on $5,000 bail. Feldman was arrested March 9 after police allegedly found the narcotics in his car during a downtown traffic stop. Police said 25 balloons of heroin and cocaine were in his car. The actor starred in such films as ``Stand By Me,'' ``The Goonies,'' ``Dream a Little Dream'' and ``The 'burbs.'' During a court appearance in April, Feldman read a statement urging children to stay away from drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesotans Recovering From Three-week Bout of `Gorbymania'
With AM-Gorbachev-Business Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The headlines proclaimed, ``Gorbachevs wow Twin Cities crowds,'' and Gov. Rudy Perpich declared he'd had one of the best days of his life when the Soviet leader came to town. ``It was almost scary things went off so well,'' said State Patrol Chief Kevin Kittridge, who spent most of Sunday in a helicopter hovering over the motorcade and visit sites. ``It was as perfect as any trip I've ever seen,'' chief Minnesota advanceman Paul Ridgeway said Monday. Ridgeway said he could not estimate the cost of the Gorbachevs' visit, but Minnesota businesses are footing most of the bill. ``I'll tell you, whatever it was it was worth it, because it showcased Minnesota in the best light,'' Ridgeway said. The Star Tribune and the Saint Paul Pioneer Press published special sections Monday, recounting in thousands of words and dozens of pictures the seven hectic hours that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, spent Sunday on Minnesota soil. ``From a `summit of hope' to a Summit Av. welcome,'' proclaimed the Star Tribune over a full, front-page color photograph showing the Gorbachevs waving to onlookers from the steps of the governor's mansion in St. Paul. ``Gorbachevs wow Twin Cities crowds,'' the Pioneer Press said. The pictures and words likely were familiar to any Minnesotan who wasn't on one of the state's 10,000 lakes fishing Sunday. Twin Cities television and radio stations carried the visit live from Gorbachev's airport arrival at 1:38 p.m. through his 8:38 p.m. departure for San Francisco. In between were a luncheon with Perpich and his wife, Lola, at the governor's mansion on Summit Avenue, impromptu forays into crowds of delighted people lining the motorcade route, Gorbachev's address to business and agricultural leaders, his talk with employees at Control Data Corp., and Mrs. Gorbachev's visit with a Minneapolis family and unscheduled stops at a drugstore and Mexican food shop. Except for the weather, windy and wet with temperatures in the 40s, the only hitch was caused when time constraints canceled a visit to a farm south of the Twin Cities. ``It was a great, great day, one of the best days of my life,'' Perpich said Monday on ``CBS This Morning.'' ``I think the world is better off because of his visit to Minnesota,'' Perpich said late Sunday night. ``I think he has a better feeling about the U.S. because of the visit, the warmth of the people. ``I've never seen any reception like that for a political figure,'' he added. ``You're lucky if they don't hit you in the head with a tomato.'' Tangible results included an announcement by British publisher Robert Maxwell of the creation of a research center called the Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology, to be located in the Twin Cities area. Maxwell's North American headquarters are in the Twin Cities. At his meeting with business leaders, Gorbachev noted the 150 joint ventures under way with U.S. companies and called for more. Kittridge said it was impossible to estimate the number of people who lined up to catch a glimpse of the famous visitors. However, he said, the turnout was far smaller than the thousands who jammed streets and the Capitol mall to celebrate the Minnesota Twins' World Series win.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Wanted to Start Bible Study Club Hails Decision
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It was a high school senior's request for a Bible study class that led to Monday's U.S. Supreme Court ruling that allows prayer groups in public schools. Bridget Mergens Mayhew, who has long since graduated from high school, rejoiced at her legal victory. She said it made her feel better about the education awaiting her 1{-year-old daughter. ``I never thought that it would go this far,'' Mrs. Mayhew said in a telephone interview from Offutt Air Force Base, where her husband is stationed. The base is just south of Omaha. In an 8-1 decision, the high court ruled that student prayer groups must be allowed to meet at public schools that permit other organized extracurricular activities. The court said a federal law aimed at permitting religious clubs in public schools does not violate constitutionally required separation of church and state. Mrs. Mayhew, now 23, was a senior at Omaha's Westside High School when school officials turned down her request to start an extracurricular club in which members would discuss the Bible. Mrs. Mayhew said there are still students at the 1,530-student high school interested in starting such a club. ``I wish we could have had it,'' she said. ``I think it would have changed the course of things, I think, for a lot of people. I think it would have strengthened a lot of people.'' Summer vacation began Friday at the school. Principal James Findley said he knew of one student _ a senior who graduated this year _ who had been interested in starting a Bible study class. A spokeswoman for the Westside Community Schools District said officials were disappointed but would comply with the high court ruling. ``We just want to analyze it further to see how it affects what we have in place,'' said the spokeswoman, Di Saggau. Mrs. Mayhew, who was raised as a Roman Catholic and later became a member of the Assembly of God Church, said her 1{-year-old daughter, Meghann, made her fight more important. The high court's ruling makes her less fearful about Meghann's future, she said. ``I would like her to be active in church. I would like her to hang onto her values when she's in high school because there's so few kids that do,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-apartheid Leader Begins World Campaign To Push For Continued Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela began a world tour Monday to urge countries not to drop sanctions against South Africa even though the country's white-dominated government has abandoned some racist policies. ``Apartheid is still alive,'' the African National Congress leader told an overflow crowd of 25,000 people who took the afternoon off to hear him speak in the Gabarone National Stadium. Mandela's 13-nation, six-week trip, which includes stops in the United States, follows a tour last month by South African President F.W. de Klerk. During the trip, de Klerk said he expected European leaders to reduce or end some economic, social and diplomatic sanctions against South Africa in response to the reforms his government is carrying out. But Mandela, whose ANC is the main black group working to end white rule, said, ``To stop sanctions now would be a stab in the back.'' Also Monday, officials at the United Nations said Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will send a team of senior U.N. officials to South Africa on Saturday for 10 days to discuss ending apartheid. The team will meet members of the South African government, representatives of political parties, movements and other organizations on the latest developments concerning apartheid, a statement said. Mandela said he intends to give leaders in Africa, Europe and North America ``the correct picture'' of what is happening in South Africa. He said that despite relaxation of restrictions on political activity and repeal of some apartheid laws, the main issue of black voting rights and self-determination has not been addressed. Under apartheid, the black majority has no vote. While Mandela is trying to persuade world leaders to keep up the pressure on the South African government, de Klerk is expected to be making dramatic changes at home. The government has already announced that later this month, it expects Parliament to pass a bill repealing the Separate Amenities Act, which allows the segregation of public facilities such as parks, libraries and restrooms. Sometime this week, many observers and newspapers have predicted, de Klerk will either lift the 4-year-old national state of emergency or repeal most of it. Ending the state of emergency has been one of the main conditions the African National Congress has set as a prerequisite for the lifting of sanctions and for formal constitutional negotiations with the government. ``If the state of emergency is lifted, that will be a victory for us,'' Mandela told reporters as he boarded a 12-seat, twin-engine Botswana government plane in Johannesburg. ``We have been demanding the lifting of the state of emergency which has been identified by us as an obstacle to negotiations. The lifting was part of the agreement reached during our (May 2-4) talks with the government,'' he said. Mandela told the Gabarone rally that sanctions and the ANC's armed struggle would end when fundamental and irreversible changes occur in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Lujan, Yeutter Agree to Help Hispanics
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Interior Manual Lujan and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter agreed Monday to improve recruitment and employment opportunities in their agencies for Hispanic students. Lujan and Yeutter signed separate Memorandums of Understanding with the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities to develop a ``Hispanic Serving Institutions Partners Program'' within the two agencies. The agreements are a first for Hispanics. The Interior Department already has special programs for blacks attending Historically black land grant colleges. ``We must take every step possible to ensure that the full potential of all Americans is developed, so that we can successfully meet the complex challenges of the 21st century,'' Lujan said. Association President Antonio Rigual noted that President Bush has described the low educational attainment by Hispanics ``a crisis.'' ``I can tell you that the consequence of the Hispanic education crisis will affect the entire nation,'' said Rigual. ``If all of us _ the federal government, the education associations, the private sector and school systems _ don't begin immediately to pull together as a team on behalf of Hispanic students and Hispanic families to create some real remedies to the problems of Hispanic education, then we will all suffer.'' The documents take effect immediately and require the agencies to provide job information, work-study programs and internships, and to assist the association in developing relevant curricula, conduct career fairs and other recruitment activities. The memorandums also call for creation of a committee to advise the two federal agencies and the association on policies, procedures, programs and services to improve the scope and quality of educational programs for Hispanics. Lujan said a minimum of $5 million will be spent over the four-year life of the contract and all 10 Interior bureaus will participate. Rigual said similar pacts also are in the works with the Department of Energy and Labor. The association, founded in May 1986 in San Antonio, Texas, represents colleges and universities where Hispanics constitute at least 25 percent of the total student enrollment. The 113 institutions, located in 10 states and Puerto Rico, enroll almost one-half of all the Hispanic college students in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev's Visit, Trade Pact Sparking Flurry of Deals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 12 grafs with Stanford speech, pickup 10th pvs bgng ``Also left''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev had a warm reunion today with former President Ronald Reagan, then told an enthuasiastic audience at Stanford University: ``The Cold War is now behind us. Let us not wrangle over who won it.'' The reunion in a midmorning coffee klatch with their wives gave Gorbachev an opportunity to enlist Reagan's help in winning conservative support for arms and trade pacts signed last week by President Bush. For Reagan, Gorbachev's partner in breaking the Cold War ice in five summits, the meeting marked one of his few moments back in the limelight since leaving office last year. The two men met at the home of the Soviet consul general, where the Gorbachevs slept after flying in late Sunday from Minneapolis-St. Paul, and spent a few minutes at the start gazing at a view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Reagan said he and Gorbachev discussed the independence drive of the Baltic states and other issues during their 40 minutes together. ``We discussed the obstacles that must be overcome,'' Reagan said as he left holding a medal Gorbachev gave him for the American people in thanks for their help following the Armenian earthquake. Reagan declined to discuss specifics of their talk or comment on the summit between Gorbachev and Bush. Gorbachev, who told U.S. officials he was tired and delayed the start of the Reagan breakfast 45 minutes, left immediately afterward for a speech at Stanford University, south of San Francisco. Gorbachev's 50-car motorcade reached Stanford shortly before noon, about an hour behind schedule. He was greeted by former Secretary of State George Shultz, university President Donald Kennedy, and Sens. Alan Cranston and Pete Wilson of California. Thousands of students, cheering ``Gorby, Gorby,'' welcomed the Soviet leader as he walked through the inner quad of the scenic campus. Gorbachev waded into the crowd, shaking hands with the students and smiling. Greeted by a standing ovation as he began his speech, Gorbachev drew more cheers when he told his audience: ``The Cold War is now behind us. Let us not wrangle over who won it.'' ``Let us think about the future,'' he said. ``Our two countries have more than enough reasons to be partners in building it.'' Also left in his schedule were: lunch with 150 captains of industry in oil, banking, food, entertainment, airlines, hotels, real estate and computers; and a meeting with the South Korean president. The Soviet president heads home from San Francisco late today, wrapping up a seven-day North American visit. Former first lady Nancy Reagan bristled at a question suggesting she and Raisa Gorbachev once had a cool relationship. ``I think there's been a great misunderstanding about our relationship,'' she said. Shortly before the meeting, about 25 demonstrators hoisted five Lithuanian flags and banners reading ``Freedom for Lithuania'' and ``Honk for Freedom'' at the south end of the Golden Gate Bridge. A blue-and-gold biplane flew above the residence hauling a banner calling for freedom for Armenia. Gorbachev's trip already has yielded two dividends _ pacts with Chevron Corp. and IBM Corp. At a meeting with business leaders Sunday in Minnesota, Gorbachev called for more U.S.-Soviet joint ventures and warned that executives ``who just stand on the sidelines, who do not want to risk'' will remain on the sidelines when the Soviet economy is prospering. ``We'll make sure that is so,'' he said. The Gorbachevs were welcomed to California by Gov. George Deukmejian, who presented him with a letter from the state's Armenian community conveying hopes for the future of the Soviet republic of Armenia, where activists are seeking greater autonomy from central authority. The governor, who is among 350,000 Californians of Armenian descent. Many Armenians have been killed in ethnic and political strife in the southern U.S.S.R. After the speech at Stanford, Gorbachev was to return to the city to pitch perestroika and opportunities for U.S.-Soviet joint ventures to the banquet of billionaires and millionaires. Trade also was expected to dominate Gorbachev's late-afternoon summit with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, the first meeting between leaders of the two countries since the Korean peninsula was partitioned. Their talks were expected to help pave the way for an easing of tensions on the peninsula. On Sunday, Gorbachev stopped for seven hours in Minneapolis, wooing street crowds and business leaders and calling for help with his country's radical reforms. ``When we begin such a project, we feel we need American business because it is so big,'' he said at an evening meeting attended by such corporate luminaries as the leaders of Amoco Corp., Kellogg Co., Unisys Corp. and General Mills. In summit discussions last week in Washington, Bush and Gorbachev agreed to a trade deal that was the result of classic Washington-style horse trading, in which Gorbachev proved himself as skillful a dealmaker as Bush. Bush agreed to give the Soviets full, normal trade rights, receiving in return an implicit timetable to put liberal emigration policies into Soviet law. The trade pact faces an uncertain future in Congress, where many insist it will not gain approval unless Gorbachev eases economic pressure against Lithuania. But Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich said today that Gorbachev won some allies in his meeting with business leaders Sunday. There was ``a very clear message'' that ``the business community ... really are going to put pressure on Washington that the Soviet Union be granted most-favored-nation status,'' Perpich said on ``CBS This Morning.'' In addition to being a necessary first step toward drastically cutting tariffs on Soviet goods sold in the United States, the trade agreement would expand opportunities for U.S. companies in the Soviet Union by reducing red tape and providing greater protections against copyright piracy. Gorbachev is perhaps more popular in the West than he is at home, where his people face bare store shelves in a failing economy. He made a point, before leaving Washington, of touting agreements signed with Chevron and International Business Machines, saying they provided a ``solid pillar of support'' for a new era of superpower cooperation. Both the Chevron and IBM agreements were examples of commercial contacts that would be facilitated by the trade agreement signed by Bush and Gorbachev. The agreement the Soviets signed with Chevron on Saturday would grant the San Francisco-based oil company exploration rights for development of the Soviet Union's largest newly discovered oil field, an 8,900-square-mile region near the Caspian Sea. The other agreement was for IBM to sell 13,000 personal computers for use in Soviet schools. Stock analysts said the deal could be worth around $25 million to IBM.

DOC.HEAD: Events in the Soviet Union
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at events Monday in the Soviet Union:

POLITICS _ The Supreme Soviet legislature met, and deputies observed a minute of silence to honor the memory of the 600 people who died a year ago in a railway accident on the Ufa-Chelyabinsk line. The Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian Federation, also meeting in the Kremlin, continued the process of selecting a vice president and first vice president.

HUMAN RIGHTS _ The International Helsinki Federation, a group monitoring compliance with the Helsinki Accords, ended two days of hearings in Moscow on Soviet human rights. The group said it encountered no harassment or intimidation but said human rights abuses still abound in the Soviet Union.

BALTICS _ President Vytautas Landsbergis of the breakaway Lithuanian republic said he heard no encouraging words from Mikahil S. Gorbachev during the summit meeting with President Bush, who signed a trade agreement with the Soviet leader despite the Kremlin's embargo on the Baltic republic. ``The worst would have been if Mikhail Gorbachev came out with the impression that everything he is doing vis-a-vis Lithuania is permitted,'' Landsbergis said in an interview with Voice of America radio.

UKRAINE _ The Communist Party chief of the Ukraine was elected the republic's president by the parliament over protests from opposition leaders and thousands of demonstrators, local activists reported. The Ukraine is the second-largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, with 51 million people. Opponents of the election said the new president, Volodymyr Ivashko, should not be both president and Communist Party chief.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Say Barry Prosecuted Unfairly
With AM-Barry-Trial
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of Mayor Marion Barry said Monday outside the courtroom that prosecuting him on drug and perjury charges is an unwarranted invasion of his personal life. ``What he did, he did to himself. ... We all have some skeletons in our closet,'' said retiree Lavergne Marshall, who came to the U.S. Courthouse in a show of support for the mayor. His case began with 250 prospective jurors filling out questionnaires. If the case concerned misappropriation of funds or some crime against the city, ``it would be a different thing altogether'' and she would favor aggressive prosecution, Mrs. Marshall said. Some Barry supporters taunted two dozen members of the Guardian Angels, a self-styled anti-crime group which demonstrated outside the courthouse. ``Barry smoked crack, We don't want him back,'' said a sign carried by one red-bereted member. ``The man himself is doing drugs'' and should step down because he is an important role model for young people in the District of Columbia, said Unique King, a regional coordinator for the Angels. The focal point of the government's case is an FBI videotape that sources close to the case say shows Barry smoking crack cocaine in a hotel room where an ex-model, Rasheeda Moore, had persuaded him to come. ``When I think of the entrapment'' used by the government ``to bring him to his knees, I think that is wrong,'' said Mrs. Marshall. The process of bringing Barry to trial on 14 criminal charges is ``racist at its very heart,'' said Chukwuma Onyeije, 24, a medical student at Howard University. ``I think it's a very racist act ... just because of who he is,'' Dwight Terrell, a Washington resident, said in front of the courthouse. The Barry prosecution is part of ``a conspiracy against black political leaders,'' said Donald Coble, also of Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Landsbergis Hopes Summit Aftermath Brings Gorbachev Softening
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's president said Monday he hoped Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev would soften his stance toward the breakaway Baltic republic after returning from the superpower summit. But Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis added in an interview with the Voice of America radio station that he did not hear any encouraging words from Gorbachev during four days of talks in Washington with President Bush. ``The worst would have been if Mikhail Gorbachev came out with the impression that everything he is doing vis-a-vis Lithuania is permitted,'' Landsbergis said in the interview, a transcript of which was provided in English to The Associated Press. He charged Gorbachev with using ``propaganda methods'' toward Lithuania, which declared independence March 11. Gorbachev has ordered an economic embargo of fuel and many other supplies on the republic of 3.8 million residents. Soviet media reported Monday that Moscow authorities were enforcing the embargo even on supplies Lithuania bought abroad. Soviet border guards turned away trucks carrying sorely needed gasoline from Poland late Friday, said the Interfax news agency, which is affiliated with state Radio Moscow. It said the Lithuanian government had bought about 1.1 million gallons of gasoline from Poland for hard currency, but couldn't get the shipmet across the Soviet-controlled border. The independent Estonian News Service reported a similar incident. It said a train carrying gas obtained through bartering with Poland was idled Monday in the neutral zone between the two borders, and it was unclear whether border guards or customs authorities were holding it. Gorbachev has demanded Lithuania revoke its declaration before the blockade can be lifted and negotiations begun over secession on the basis of the Soviet constitution. But Landsbergis on Monday reiterated Lithuania's refusal to reverse its declaration, saying, ``I don't think we'll ever be able to take this step,'' according to government-run VOA. At the summit, Bush and Gorbachev agreed to a trade pact that Bush said is conditioned only on Moscow's approval of liberalized emigration laws. Bush had been saying Moscow also must end its blockade against Lithuania, but he changed that position Sunday. Kazimiera Prunskiene, Lithuania's prime minister who met with Bush and Gorbachev separately in the past weeks, said she believed Gorbachev would modify his position on Lithuania after returning home. ``It's one thing to talk tough in America's forums and to disply this firm position by the U.S.S.R. and Gorbachev himself, but it is another thing to understand that the U.S. Congress, as well as the situation in the Soviet Union, are unfavorable to his rigid position,'' she told VOA. Congress must still approve the trade pact, and some U.S. lawmakers have said they would not allow the Soviet Union to become a most-favored-nation trading partner until Gorbachev ends his economic squeeze on Lithuania. The most-favored-nation designation qualifies a trading partner for the lowest U.S. tariffs.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Police Can Use Jailhouse Informants
With Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court assured police Monday they may continue using jailhouse undercover agents, ruling that such agents may trick suspects into confessing without first warning them of their rights. By an 8-1 vote, the justices said jailed criminal suspects need not receive so-called Miranda warnings about their right to remain silent and get a lawyer's help before being questioned by undercover agents. In its famous 1966 ruling, the court ruled that police must give such warnings before interrogating suspects who are in custody. But writing for the court in an Illinois case Monday, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said, ``Miranda warnings are not required when the suspect is unaware that he is speaking to a law enforcement officer and gives a voluntary statement.'' Kennedy added: ``Conversations between suspects and undercover agents do not implicate the concerns underlying Miranda. The essential ingredients of a police-dominated atmosphere and compulsion are not present when an incarcerated person speaks freely to someone that he believes to be a fellow inmate.'' Justice Thurgood Marshall, the lone dissenter, said the ruling ``may well result in a proliferation of departmental policies to encourage police officers to conduct interrogations of confined suspects through undercover agents. The decision's impact is confined to jailed suspects not yet charged with the crime about which they are questioned. The court in 1980 ruled that law enforcement officials cannot hire jailhouse informants to elicit confessions from those already charged with a crime or those who have invoked their right to a lawyer's help. Monday's ruling is a defeat for Lloyd Perkins, who unwittingly made incriminating remarks about a murder to an undercover agent at a Hillsboro, Ill., jail. Perkins later was charged with fatally shooting Richard Stephenson on Nov. 8, 1984, in Fairview Heights, Ill. ``Miranda was not meant to protect suspects from boasting about their criminal activities in front of persons whom they believe to be their cellmates,'' Kennedy wrote for the high court, adding that Perkins ``spoke at his own peril.''
