The decision reversed an Illinois appeals court ruling that the statements Perkins made to Parisi could not be used as trial evidence.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet media continued their rapturous coverage of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's U.S. visit Monday, focusing on the excited whoops of welcome that met the president and his wife, Raisa, in Minnesota. The nightly news program ``Vremya'' devoted a half-hour out of 45 minutes to the Gorbachevs' stay in the midwestern state. In one segment, a reporter asked Gorbachev for his impressions of the American midwest, and he answered: ``Terrific!'' Soviet TV showed Mrs. Gorbachev sitting down for tea in an American family's home, and she announced afterward that the visit had a major effect on her. ``I spent one hour with that family and I love America and Americans a thousand times more now,'' the normally reserved Mrs. Gorbachev said while hugging one of the children. ``Vremya'' cameras lingered on Minnesota crowds that met the Soviet couple with the kind of euphoric welcome they never receive in their own country, where citizens are embittered by empty store shelves and painful reforms. They zoomed in on Minnesotans wearing sweatshirts with ``Welcome'' in Russian emblazoned on them and waving ``Gorbychiefs'' _ handkerchiefs distributed specially for the visit. The government newspaper Izvestia devoted almost its entire front page to the summit Monday, with one story headlined ``Gorbachev _ in the Heart of America!'' Soviet TV showed one potential disagreement: Gorbachev answering an Israeli correspondent's question about the Soviet leader's threats to limit Jewish emigration if Soviet Jews continue settling in Israel's occupied territories. Gorbachev insisted that Israel ban settlement of Soviet emigres on the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Asked if he would accept an Israeli government invitation to visit, he said frankly, ``The time has not come.''

DOC.HEAD: Effects of Poverty May Linger for Generations, Study of Babies Suggests
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Middle-class black women with college educations are twice as likely to bear low-birth-weight babies as whites of the same income and education, a study found. The study of more than 100,000 births in Chicago suggests that the effects of poverty linger for generations, the researchers said Monday. Low birth weight is the most important predictor of whether babies will die, said the lead researcher, Dr. James W. Collins Jr., who specializes in newborns at Children's Memorial Hospital. The United States, which ranks 22nd among developed countries in infant survival, is losing its fight to reduce the infant mortality rate, Collins said. He and a colleague, Dr. Richard J. David of Cook County Hospital, examined 103,072 birth records _ about half of them for whites and half for blacks _ for the years 1982 and 1983. They found that low-birth-weight babies _ those less than 5{ pounds _ were born to blacks at twice the rate they were to whites at virtually every income and educational level. In households earning less than $10,000 a year, 15 percent of the black babies were of low birth weight, compared with 8 percent for whites. In households earning $30,000 to $40,000 a year, the rate was 10 percent for blacks and 5 percent for whites. Among mothers with less than a high school education, the rate was 16 percent for blacks and 7 percent for whites, and for mothers with a college ecucation the rate was 10 percent for blacks and 5 percent for whites. ``If you're middle class and black, despite having education, being of optimal age (to have children) and living in a $20,000 to $30,000-a-year household ... you still do twice as bad as whites similar to you,'' Collins said. The study appears in the June issue of the American Journal of Public Health, where the two researchers write: ``We suspect that the persistently high rate of low birth weight infants among blacks reflects generations of poverty.'' The researchers added they also suspect that ``it may require more than one generation of non-poverty and adequate services to see an impact upon infant birth weight.'' The researchers didn't examine specific factors that might have caused the differences, but Collins said he believed nutrition during adolescence may be key. ``I think psychosocial stress is also a factor, but it's very hard to measure,'' said Collins. Another may be that fewer blacks than whites seek prenatal care, even when both can afford it, he said. He cited a study published in November 1988 about 31,000 largely middle-class women in a California health maintenance organization. It found that prenatal care could narrow the gap between rates of low-birth-weight babies between blacks and whites, but that blacks sought such care less often. ``I don't know how much racism comes into it,'' Collins said, speculating that some blacks may have had so many bad experiences with medical institutions that they tend to avoid them. Dr. Kwang-sun Lee, a University of Chicago professor of pediatrics and obstetrics-gynecology, said he believed none of the factors that has been studied, such as improved prenatal care, reduced teen-age pregnancy or improved nutrition, would eliminate the discrepancies. Improvement in all those areas might help, said Lee, who wasn't involved with the study. ``The study which has not been clearly done is what is the effect of a stressful life situation,'' he said. ``When women in low social classes have repeated stressful events, what happens to the womb has not been defined yet.'' American Indians have normal-weight babies as often as whites, even though they are poorer than whites or blacks, Lee said, suggesting that none of the effects of poverty usually blamed for low-birth-weight babies appears to be affecting them. Lee and Collins noted that British researchers showed as long as 20 years ago that the rate of low birth weights didn't decline until the second generation after a woman attained more affluence. ``It is more important how you are brought up than whether you marry a millionaire,'' Lee said.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Thomas E. Brown, `Gunsmoke' and Soap Star, Dies at 75
DOC.TEXT: Actor Tom Brown, whose career included a 10-year stint as rancher Ed O'Connor on TV's ``Gunsmoke'' as well as movie roles with such stars as Wallace Beery and Tyrone Power, has died of cancer. He was 75. Brown died Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in suburban Woodland Hills, where a memorial service was planned for Tuesday, said spokeswoman Louella Benson. Brown's career spanned 73 years, starting as a child sensation who appeared in highly visible advertisements personifying the Arrow Collar Boy, the Buick Boy and Buster Brown. His motion picture credits included ``Buck Private Comes Home'' with Abbott and Costello, ``Navy Blue and Gold'' with Jimmy Stewart and Lionel Barrymore, ``Sgt. Madden'' with Wallace Beery and ``Old Chicago'' with Tyrone Power and Don Ameche. On television, he played the local rancher on ``Gunsmoke'' for 10 years and he was a regular on the daytime soap series ``General Hospital,'' portraying Al Weeks, and ``Days of Our Lives,'' playing Nathan Curtis. Survivors include two sons and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aides Detail Financial Condition
DOC.TEXT: Sig Rogich, the former Las Vegas public relations man who is President Bush's chief image-maker, is a multimillionaire with holdings in radio, real estate, advertising and other businesses, according to his White House financial disclosure report. At the other end of the spectrum, Marlin Fitzwater, the president's press secretary, reported assets ranging from $17,005 to $55,000 and outside income of $2,722 to $4,520. He also reported getting a $60 pair of binoculars as a gift from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Rogich reported assets of at least $3.9 million to $5.5 million or more, and net income on his holdings in the range of $180,549 to $238,544 or more. His interests included an advertising firm, radio stations, mobile billboards and a bar in Truckee, Calif. The forms were released Monday by the office of White House general counsel Boyden Gray. Rogich, in a telephone interview from California. where he was lending a hand to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the final stops of his post-summit tour of America, said he had put his holdings in a blind trust and ordered his trustee to sell off his stocks. Among the interests being sold were the bar and stock in a Las Vegas corporation, W.C.W. Corp., which owns two casinos, the form showed. Rogich, who helped put together the ads for Ronald Reagan's re-election drive in 1984 and for the Bush campaign in 1988, became Bush's assistant for ``special activities and initiatives'' last October. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu reported on his disclosure form that he is on leave as an associate professor of engineering from Tufts University, but does not accept tuition breaks or other faculty benefits for his children while he works in Washington. Sununu, the former governor of New Hampshire, reported assets ranging from $422,008 to more than $1 million, and income apart from his White House salary ranging from $15,506 to $55,000, plus $34,272 that his wife, Nancy, made working for the Republican Governors Association, $3,269 she made from an insurance agency and $9,151 in salary that Sununu himself earned in his final weeks as governor in early 1989. Sununu also reported getting $173 in gifts from Gorbachev in the form of a lacquered samovar, two bottles of Russian vodka and four ounces of black caviar. Robert Gates, the deputy national security adviser to the president and former career CIA man, reported assets ranging from $33,005 to $115,000 and outside income of $2,305 to $8,000. He also had a home equity loan ranging from $15,001 to $50,000, and reported gifts of two dozen roses worth $100 from the ambassador from Bahrain and a $160 vase from the Chinese ambassador. The forms do not require top government executives to disclose the value of their main residence or principal mortgage. Chase Untermeyer, the White House personnel director, disclosed assets of $196,013 to $560,000, and outside income ranging from $18,519 to $43,610. Untermeyer, a former Texas state representative from Houston, said he also had $33,218 in a leftover state campaign fund. Andrew Card, the deputy chief of staff, reported assets of $104,005 to $270,000 and outside income of $15,304 to $28,000. He also had a mortgage on property he owns in Holbrook, Mass., of $15,001 to $50,000, plus a home equity loan on an adjacent property that allows him to borrow up to $170,000.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Representative Asks Latin Nations' Help in Busting Barriers
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills on Monday sought Latin American support for a U.S. effort to eliminate barriers to agricultural trade. She said that Latin America had a major stake in the outcome of the current global trade talks, due to conclude at the end of this year, because of the dependence of many nations in the region on farm exports. The United States is pushing a proposal that would eliminate all trade-distorting agricultural subsidies over the next 10 years. However, the 12-nation European Community is leading a fight to preserve farm subsidies because of its network of small farms. In a speech to Organization of American States meeting in Paraguay, Hills said the European Community was refusing to budge in its opposition and she appealed for support from Latin America. ``If, by working together, we can cause our reform proposal to prevail, the developing world will no longer have to compete against the treasuries of the developed world,'' she said in remarks released in Washington. ``We should put an end to the astronomic export subsidies by which governments bribe the marketplace.'' Unless there is movement on the contentious issue of farm subsidies, many fear that the four-year round of trade liberalization talks, being held under the auspices of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, will end in failure. Hills was unable to make progress on the farm issue during meetings in Paris last week with EC officials. She said the administration still viewed reform of agricultural subsidies as critical for achieving a successful package of new trading rules. Hills hailed the dramatic economic and political changes occurring in such countries as Paraguay, Argentina, Brazil, Bolivia, Chile, Costa Rica and Mexico. She said that the Bush administration stood ready to forge a new partnership to promote economic growth. She said the United States had a major stake in what occurs in Latin America because nearly 60 percent of total U.S. direct foreign investment was concentrated in the region. Central and South America also represented a huge market for U.S. exports, she said. ``The lost decade of the 1980s was not only your tragedy, but also ours,'' she said. ``It is estimated that U.S. exporters lost as much as $130 billion (in possible sales) in the region from 1982 to 1988. It wasn't until 1988 that our exports climbed back to their 1981 level.'' She said the partnership she was proposing with the United States would involve negotiating commercial agreements to liberalize trade and investment and working to promote a ``hemispheric zone of open trade.'' The United States is in the process of removing all trade barriers with Canada and there are preliminary discussions concerning a possible free trade zone with Mexico as well.

DOC.HEAD: Vt. Supreme Court Upholds Moratorium on Jury Trials
DOC.TEXT: The Vermont Supreme Court upheld a six-month state moratorium on civil jury trials such as divorces and said the budget-cutting measure didn't interfere with the right to a speedy trial. The moratorium, intended to save $75,000 to help the state avoid a deficit, did not affect criminal trials. The constitutional guarantee of a speedy trial must be considered in context, the court said, adding that speedy need not be instant. The ban only affected civil cases, which usually involve divorces, property disputes, personal injury claims, malpractice suits and breaches of contract. It could be overriden in specific cases by the administrative trial judge. The moratorium, which will expire July 1, was imposed by the court in January as a way to cope with budget cuts prompted by the state's sagging economy. The court was ordered to reduce its budget by about $300,000. The 220-member Vermont Trial Lawyers Association filed a class-action lawsuit seeking to overturn the ban. It said that the federal and state constitutions guarantee the right to a speedy trial. However, the court said its action was constitutional and a prudent way to manage caseloads and resources. ``Our precedents do not support the absolutist view of the jury trial right that the petitioners espouse,'' said the decision, written by retired Chief Justice Albert Barney. Even with the moratorium, Barney noted, most cases will come to trial faster than in past years. The petitioners' remedy of instant access to a jury ``cannot be found in the constitutional jury trial rights on which they rely. Caseloads cannot be managed on the simplistic position that everyone is entitled to an immediate trial whenever they are ready for one,'' Barney wrote. The Vermont Supreme Court decision is counter to a federal court ruling in California that held civil jury trials in U.S. District Court could not be suspended because of fiscal restraints. But the Vermont justices said the federal ruling centered around the length of the moratorium, not the moratorium itself. The justices said the Vermont moratorium delayed civil jury trials for only ``a relatively short period of time.'' The trial lawyers' association had sought to disqualify the entire five-member Supreme Court from the case, arguing that the justices issued the moratorium and therefored had a conflict of interest. The court disagreed, but two members disqualified themselves because of personal relationships with some of the law firms involved in the challenge. Barney and another retired justice took their places on the court.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says He Can Form Ruling Coalition
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Monday he will have a majority in parliament to form a right-wing coalition government and that he expects to swear in the new Cabinet next week. Shamir, 74, head of the Likud bloc, said he expected 61 to 65 members in the 120-seat Knesset, or parliament, to approve the coalition. If his prediction proves accurate, Shamir would be sworn in next week as premier for the fourth time since 1983. Shamir's aide Yossi Ahimeir said the new Cabinet would maintain Israel's commitment to U.S.-backed peace proposals despite expected opposition from ultranationalist coalition partners. Shamir has spent the past 39 days trying to forge a new alliance with smaller religious and right-wing parties. It would replace the national unity government with the center-left Labor Party, which was toppled March 15 by a vote of no confidence in parliament. Asked when he would submit his new government for parliament approval, Shamir told reporters: ``I cannot give you a precise date. But it will certainly be early next week.'' A Labor official close to Labor Party leader Shimon Peres said he believed there was an 80 percent chance Shamir would succeed in forming a narrow government. But he said since Shamir's hopes hinged on a single vote ``anything could still happen'' as it did in April when Peres lost a bid to form a Labor-led government after a member of a religious faction in parliament defected at the last moment. Shamir was expected to delay formal announcement until he irons out details of his agreements with other factions, Ahimeir said in a telephone interview. He faces a deadline of midnight Thursday when the mandate given to him by President Chaim Herzog expires. Ahimeir said ``some points with smaller parties'' were still pending negotiation and declined to elaborate. ``There is nothing sure in Israeli politics, but at the moment we can say he has a majority with 61 seats.'' Likud has the support of three Orthodox factions and two independent members who are also religious. Ahimeir said Likud hoped to add four members of the Agudat Israel ultra-Orthodox party after the coalition was approved by parliament. That would give Shamir control over 65 seats. Agudat Israel has conditioned support on Likud assurances that it would ban the sale of pork in Israel and curtail public transportation on the Jewish Sabbath. The deciding votes for Shamir came Monday from the two-seat Moledet or ``Homeland'' faction that advocates expelling Palestinians from Israeli-held territory. The party held out for weeks, demanding control of the police ministry and cancellation of an initiative to hold Palestinian elections in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Moledet leader Rehavam Zeevi said he would support the new Cabinet without formally joining. Because of the differences, he declined to sign a coalition agreement as is customary. Shamir's peace plan is also opposed by two other right-wing coalition partners, the pro-settlement Tehiya and Tzomet factions. But Ahimeir insisted the plan would be included in the new government's policy guidelines. ``We are committed to the plan without any doubts,'' said Ahimeir. ``This (new) government, although it is called narrow and right-wing, will work to advance the peace process.'' Despite the tenuous agreements reached, Likud leaders feel confident the right-wing parties would prefer compromising with Likud rather than seeing a possible new Likud union with Labor.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Sales Claimed Only a Fraction of Potential
DOC.TEXT: The grain agreement signed by President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev continues the principal trade between the two countries that is nowhere near its potential, a food processing executive said Monday. ``We could be doing $250 billion a year in trade,'' said George Melnykovich, president of the Food Processing Machinery and Supplies Association. Bush and Gorbachev signed a five-year agreement Friday to increase the annual minimum shipments of U.S. grain to the Soviets to 10 million metric tons from 9 million tons. Recent shipments have greatly exceeded the minimums. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds, about 36.7 bushels of wheat or 39.4 bushels of corn. The current pact, which has been in effect since 1983, expires Dec. 31. Such grain agreements have existed since 1976. The agreement is worth roughly $6 billion to $8 billion to farmers and exporters over the five years, said Agriculture Department analyst Cina Radler. It's impossible to pinpoint the exact value because of fluctuations in market price, she said. ``Take out the grain agreement and the rest of trade between the two countries in infinitesimal,'' said Melnykovich. But he said the Soviets want so much and the United States has so much to offer that trade should mushroom. The main problem is money, he said. The Soviet ruble is not worth much outside the Soviet Union, so American companies don't want to be paid in Soviet currency. Melnykovich predicted that in the next five years, the Soviet government would make the ruble a freely convertible currency that could be used in world trade. Melnykovich is one of the organizers of a three-day conference in Washington that is bringing together 55 Soviet ministers to discuss the state of the Soviet food system and with U.S. food companies. ``It's an unprecedented meeting between leaders of one U.S. industry and top Soviet officials,'' said Anthony J.F. O'Reilly, chief ececutive officer of the H.J. Heinz Co. and conference chairman. Though Germany and Japan also are probing the Soviet market, Melynkovich said the Soviet Union would rather do business with the United States. The fact that the countries were allies in World War II against Germany and Japan is important, but also because the countries are both geographically large and need efficient food distribution systems. ``It doesn't take much to get from one point to another in small countries like Japan and Germany,'' said Melnykovich. ``The Soviets are asking, `How is it that the U.S. does it?'' he said. Vladilen Nikitin, the Soviet equivalent to the U.S. secretary of agriculture, said the conference was the first step toward increasing sale of agricultural commodities to the Soviet Union. As for the grain agreement, he said: ``We got what we expected.'' He noted that Wednesday he would be signing an agreement on food processing with Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher. ``We need all types of products,'' he said, speaking through an interpreter. Soviet grain purchases in most years have exceeded the required minimums. In 1988-89, for example, sales were more than double the specified minimum. Much wheat _ recently all of it _ has been sold to the Soviet Union with the help of export subsidies. A sale of 9.2 million bushels (250,000 metric tons) in May for June delivery carried a subsidy of 50 cents per bushel ($18.18 per ton). No. 2 red wheat now sells for about $3.50 per bushel ($128.45 per ton) on the Kansas City spot market. No other grains are eligible for the export subsidies. The Kremlin will have some greater year-to-year flexibility under the new arrangement by being allowed to choose between wheat and feed grains, although over the life of the pact the minimums will be met, officials said. The Soviets will be committed to buying at least 4 million tons each of wheat and feed grains. However, in any one year Moscow may substitute up to 750,000 tons of one commodity for the other. For the first time, the pact includes barley and sorghum as feed grains. Additional flexibility also was provided by giving Moscow automatic permission to buy up to 14 million tons of grain annually without further discussion with Washington. The automatic limit under the current pact is 12 million tons, although the United States has routinely increased that to fit Soviet needs. As of May 31, the Soviets had bought more than 16.7 million tons of U.S. wheat and corn under the current agreement for delivery this year. Last year's sales totaled a record 21.7 million tons.

DOC.HEAD: Michael Jackson Hospitalized With Chest Pains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to update with Jackson falling ill at home, doctor driving him to hospital, get-well call from White House, brother Jermaine's visit and sister's statement that similar attacks in the past were blamed on stress. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Three flower-bearing...
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Michael Jackson was hospitalized in stable condition Monday and undergoing tests for chest pains. His sister, LaToya, said he was fine and she sent him a dozen black roses. The 31-year-old Jackson, who had been ill for several days, became alarmed Sunday evening at his Los Angeles home when pain gripped his chest. His doctor drove him to the hospital. ``He wasn't moaning or turning over in pain or anything, but I could tell there was discomfort,'' Jackson spokesman Bob Jones said after seeing the entertainer at St. John's Hospital and Health Center. ``He's undergoing several important tests today. I don't think it was a heart attack. He just experienced some discomfort. He had been feeling bad the past two or three days,'' said Jones. Brother Jermaine Jackson left the hospital Monday afternoon and said, ``He's lying in bed, resting comfortably.'' The ailing singer received a get-well message from the White House. ``President Bush just called to wish Michael Jackson well,'' said Jones. Jackson is in the same hospital, on the same floor as his friend, Elizabeth Taylor. The actress has been recovering from a near-fatal bout of pneumonia and complications for nearly two months. Miss Taylor was in stable condition on Monday, according to Chen Sam and Associates, the New York City public relations firm representing the actress. The hospital released a statement Monday saying Jackson remained hospitalized and ``his physician, Dr. Steven Hoefflin, states that he will be undergoing several diagnostic tests.'' No other details were released by the hospital, and inquiries were referred to Jackson's spokesman. ``I think he's fine. He just checked in because he wasn't feeling well,'' LaToya Jackson said in a telephone interview from London. ``I sent him some roses, a dozen black roses. I think they are beautiful,'' said Miss Jackson, an older sister of Michael who is also a singer. She said her brother has had similar chest pains in the past that required hospitalization and his doctor blamed the attacks on stress. Three flower-bearing Jackson fans spent the night outside the hospital. ``We just want to know how he's doing. I'm a dedicated fan and I just want to know he's OK,'' said Lonnell Williams, 21, of suburban North Hollywood. Jackson was catapulted into the public eye at age 5 with the Jackson Five family pop group. He later left his brothers and became a one-man phenomenon. The reclusive star has been celebrated as widely for his eccentricities as for his music and choreography. Jackson won an unprecedented eight Grammy Awards for his 1982 release, ``Thriller,'' the most successful album of all time with sales of more than 40 million copies worldwide. His last album, ``Bad,'' sold more than 19 million copies and spawned five No. 1 hits. It was released in 1987. Jackson was hospitalized in January 1984 after his hair caught fire during filming of a Pepsi-Cola commercial in Los Angeles. The accident caused by a misfiring smoke bomb left him with second-degree scalp burns.

DOC.HEAD: Report Shows Dwindling Salmon Numbers On Columbia, Snake Rivers
DOC.TEXT: Salmon runs on two western rivers have steadily declined over the past 20 years and populations at some dams last year were the lowest ever observed, a report released Monday said. Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., asked the National Marine Fisheries Service and the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife to study the runs on the Columbia and Snake rivers. ``Clearly, we know from this report that the runs are in trouble. Clearly, the fish are declining. Particularly on the Snake River, the stocks are way down,'' said Bill Calder, Hatfield's press secretary. Oregon Trout, a Portland-based conservation group, has asked the NMFS to place four salmon runs in the Columbia River basin on the endangered species list. The four are the native runs of Lower Columbia coho salmon as well as the Snake River's spring, summer and fall chinook salmon. Hatfield said in March he wanted the report in hand to help get a head start on the listing process and avoid some of the political rhetoric that has surrounded the debate over whether to list the northern spotted owl as a threatened species. The report provides a ``perspective on the salmon runs in question'' but does not provide a basis for definitive judgments on the status of the runs under the Endangered Species Act, its authors said. In a letter to Hatfield, NMFS regional director Rolland Schmitten and Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife Director Randy Fisher said, ``We share your concern over salmon runs and other users of Columbia River water.'' Mark Chilcote, natural production program manager for the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, said the report basically compiled previous studies to give an overview on the status of the fish in the region. The report based its population counts primarily on escapements, the number of fish that avoid being caught and safely return to their spawning grounds, and redd counts, which are the easily observable nests that female salmon dig in river-bottom gravel to lay eggs.

DOC.HEAD: Return To Public Office Removes Bennett From High-Earnings Course
DOC.TEXT: Drug policy director William J. Bennett was on course to earn more than $500,000 last year before he returned from private life to public office, according to financial disclosure forms released Monday. During the first 2{ months before he took office March 10, Bennett earned $80,246 from speeches and consulting work plus $25,962 in salary as president of The Madison Center, a private policy research group he created. If the $106,208 income from the early months had held up throughout 1989, he could have earned about $550,000, not including interest on savings. Instead, the government started paying him after March 10 at the rate of $99,500 for a full year, or about $80,000 for the rest of 1989. Adding that salary to the earnings of the first couple of months plus his declared interest earnings gave Bennett an approximate income of $191,209 to $201,208 for 1989. His interest earnings totaled between $5,001 and $15,000. Bennett, known as one of the poorest members of President Reagan's Cabinet when he was education secretary, saw his income zoom after he resigned that job Sept. 20, 1988, thanks to The Madison Center and invitations from across the country to speak. He realized before he became President Bush's director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy that his earnings would nosedive, saying at the time, ``Well, we had a good Christmas.'' Bennett still does not own a home, despite his few lucrative months. He and his wife Elayne, who works for a project at Georgetown University funded by the Bradley Foundation, live with their two young sons in a rented home in suburban Maryland. His assets went down somewhat last year, according to the form, which does not mention personal property such as automobiles and which lists assets only in ranges. In 1988, Bennett's assets ranged from $301,003 to $356,002 and up. Bennett stated his net worth in early 1989 was about $432,600, not including cars, in a financial statement provided to the Senate Judiciary Committee that handled his confirmation hearing. For 1989, Bennett's assets ranged from $150,002 to $350,000. The form as filled out by Bennett indicated assets of $65,002 to $150,000, but spokesman Don Hamilton, responding to a query regarding the dramatic drop, said the form had been filled out in error and would be amended to reflect the higher asset level. Even at the higher level, the maximum assets would be about $82,600 less than they were in 1988. Bennett signed a contract in late 1988 with Simon & Shuster publishers to produce two books, and he received advanced royalties of $187,500. His current financial disclosure form says he will receive royalties from the publication of a book, yet no book has been published. Hamilton said that although Bennett completed the manuscript for one book, it will not be published until he is out of office.

DOC.HEAD: Schwarzenegger's `Total Recall' Muscles to Top of Box Office
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Schwarzenegger went to Mars and came back with a $25.5 million box office for ``Total Recall,'' muscling his way to the biggest weekend take of the year, according to figures released Monday. The latest hot release of the summer movie season earned more in three days than the $23.7 million taken in by ``Back to the Future Part III'' in four days over the Memorial Day weekend. Set in the year 2084, ``Total Recall'' depicts Schwarzenegger as an Earth laborer who signs up for a memory-implant vacation and soon finds himself enmeshed in a civil war on Mars. The special effects-laden movie cost an estimated $50 million to make. Other box-office benchmarks claimed by Tri-Star Pictures, which released ``Total Recall'': the highest three-day opening weekend for an ``R'' rated film and the largest opening of a Schwarzenegger film in history, outdrawing the $12 million opening for ``Predator'' two years ago. The summer movie season begins with the four-day Memorial Day weekend; the latest figures are for the latest regular weekend of the summer season. The biggest regular weekend opening ever remains ``Batman,'' with nearly $48 million. ``Back to the Future Part III,'' about the final adventures of time travelers Marty McFly and Doc Brown, was in second place with $10.3 million, according to figures compiled by Entertainment Data Inc. and Exhibitor Relations. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections when figures aren't immediately available. ``Bird on a Wire,'' with Goldie Hawn and Mel Gibson, earned $6.3 million in its third week. Fourth was ``Pretty Woman,'' taking $4.7 million in its 11th week. The movie has now earned nearly $127 million. In fifth and sixth place were two faltering early-summer releases, ``Cadillac Man,'' with $2.8 million and ``Fire Birds,'' with $2.6 million. Holdovers from spring made up the rest of the Top 10, with ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' earning nearly $2 million for seventh place; ``The Hunt for Red October'' with more than $1 million for eighth and ``Tales from the Darkside'' in ninth with half a million dollars. In tenth place was ``Joe Versus the Volcano,'' earning more than $400,000. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Total Recall,'' Tri-Star, $25.5 million, 2,060 screens, $12,395 per screen, $25.5 million, one week. 2. ``Back to the Future III,'' Universal, $10.3 million, 2,025 screens, $5,105 per screen, $38 million, two weeks. 3. ``Bird on a Wire,'' Universal, $6.3 million, 1,963 screens, $3,235 per screen, $42.2 million, three weeks. 4. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $4.7 million, 1,791 screens, $2,655 per screen, $126.7 million, 11 weeks. 5. ``Cadillac Man,'' Orion, $2.8 million, 1,878 screens, $1,536 per screen, $19.5 million, three weeks. 6. ``Fire Birds,'' Disney, $2.6 million, 2,006 screens, $1,302 per screen, $10.1 million, two weeks. 7. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $1.9 million, 1,777 screens, $1,099 per screen, $121 million, 10 weeks. 8. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $1 million, 933 screens, $1,122 per screen, $112 million, 14 weeks. 9. ``Tales from the Darkside,'' Paramount, $560,566, 618 screens, $907 per screen, $15.4 million, five weeks. 10. ``Joe Versus the Volcano,'' Warner Bros., $413,166, 566 screens, $729 per screen, $38.1 million, 13 weeks.
