DOC.HEAD: Indiana Counties Declared Disaster Area
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday declared 19 Indiana counties a major disaster area from severe storms, flooding and tornadoes that have struck the state since May 15. The declaration makes federal funds available to help individuals and businesses recover in the counties of Brown, Dearborn, Franklin, Gibson, Greene, Harrison, Jackson, Jefferson, Knox, Martin, Ohio, Orange, Pike, Posey, Ripley, Scott, Switzerland, Warrick and Washington. The federal government pays up to 75 percent of the cost of repairing or replacing public facilities damaged by storms in disaster areas. Other aid includes temporary housing, grants and low-cost loans to cover uninsured property losses. Ronald Buddecke of the Federal Emergency Management Agency's regional office in Chicago was named to coordinate the federal recovery efforts in Indiana.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey's Communist Party Applies for Legal Status
DOC.TEXT: Turkish Communists tried to legally register their party on Monday despite a constitutional ban of Marxist and religious parties. Two leaders of the United Communist Party, Nihat Sargin and Haydar Kutlu, registered the United Communist Party of Turkey at the Interior Ministry. The party's charter calls it a Marxist, revolutionary workers party based on class struggle, the same words mentioned as a cause for banning in Turkey's legal code. The chief prosecutor's office will now study the application, which could make the party legal for the first time in 70 years. Sargin, 64, a physician who is the party chairman, and Kutlu, 36, party secretary-general, were released from prison a month ago. They had been arrested in November 1987 upon their arrival from exile in West Germany. The two have been barred from foreign travel while their trial on attempting to stage a Communist revolution in Turkey continues. Sargin and Kutlu told a news conference Monday their aim was ``a Turkey without fear, exile or censorship'' and that the party will advocate human rights and ethnic rights for Turkey's Kurdish minority. Kurds are estimated to constitute 20 percent of the country's total population of 56 million, but are not recognized as an ethnic minority by the government. The Communist Party was forced into exile in 1920. For the past several years there has been a debate in Turkey on whether the amend laws barring Marxist and religious parties. Legalization of such parties is considered necessary for Turkey to succeed in becoming a full member of the European Economic Community.

DOC.HEAD: Former Idaho Lt. Gov. Tapped for Nuclear Waste Job
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Monday President Bush will nominate David H. Leroy, former lieutenant governor of Idaho, as the negotiator charged with launching a new search for a palce to put the nation's growing inventory of highly radioactive nuclear waste. Leroy, 42, of Boise, Idaho, will canvass governors, Indian tribal leaders and others in hopes of uncovering a site willing to become a temporary or permanent high-level nuclear waste repository. In a telephone interview from his law offices, Leroy said the task could make him ``the most unpopular person in America.'' But he called it an important mission that could help solve a problem fraught with ``moral, political and scientific ramifications.'' He promised to mount ``an aggressive effort to search the country'' and U.S. territories for localities that may have an untapped interest in accepting a nuclear waste repository. Congress ordered the president to appoint an independent nuclear waste negotiator in 1987 at the same time it designated Nevada's Yucca Mountain on a nuclear weapons testing range as the most likely site for a repository. The 1987 legislation ordered the Energy Department to drop work on two other candidate sites in Texas and Washington State, and to begin the expensive detailed subterranean geological investigation necessary to see if Yucca Mountain is suitable for an installation that must confine the waste for at least 10,000 years. Underground research has not yet begun. The state of Nevada has refused to grant permits for it and the question is tied up in court. Leroy, a Republican who narrowly lost a bid to unseat Democratc Gov. Cecil Andrus in 1986, said, ``Congress felt very strongly that an aggressive effort should be made to determine whether there were any locations with a technically sound repository site that might be willing to assume a larger role'' voluntarily. If the search produces a willing taker, Leroy is also charged with recommending acceptable terms to Congress. The legislation gave the negotiator until 1991 to complete the search. Leroy said, ``A quick start is essential.'' If confirmed, he will operate independently from the Department of Energy, but will not be responsible to the department. It is a part-time post, and Leroy said he will keep up his law practice in Boise. Leroy was Idaho's attorney general from 1979 to 1983 and its lieutenant governor from 1983 to 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Cheers, Capitalistic Fervor Greet Soviet Chief at Stanford
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite pockets of protest, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev charmed a university crowd of thousands with handshakes, smiles and waves Monday to cheers of ``Gorby! Gorby!'' Gorbachev's 50-car motorcade reached Stanford University shortly before noon, about an hour behind schedule. The Soviet leader, who delivered a speech on global affairs at the campus, was greeted by former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, university President Donald Kennedy, and California's two U.S. senators, Alan Cranston and Pete Wilson. As he walked across campus, two students in the cheering audience held up a sign reading, ``Gorby 4 President.'' He waded into the audiences at various times, shaking hands, clapping and clasping his own hands, smiling, and through an interpreter telling a woman in a wheelchair with a video camera, ``You are so well-equipped.'' ``I shook his hand. ... It was amazing. He was definitely just a real person, but he was Gorbachev. He was leading the pack, hoping his bodyguards could keep up,'' said Alex Levy, a 21-year-old political science major. ``He was great. He came up and grabbed my hand,'' added Erik Jorgensen. ``I think sometime in the future we'll all be united together in one big team,'' said Louie Arciga. But hundreds of demonstrators remained immune from the ``Gorbymania'' gripping others. Protesters, supporting independence for Lithuania and other Baltic states and angered over alleged human rights violations in the republics, said they were trying to show the American public that Gorbachev isn't a hero. ``People have been so much taken by their Gorbymania that I don't think many are hearing us. The people have been taken by the charm of Gorby,'' said Lithuanian-born Algis Zemaitaitis, who drove six hours from Santa Monica to join the protest at Stanford. As the Gorbachev motorcade rolled down Stanford University's Palm Drive, the demonstrators intensified their chants of ``Out of the Baltic states!'' Onlookers, disgruntled that the protesters were blocking the view of the Soviet leader, chanted in response, ``Out of the way!'' In the face of the Soviet leader's visit, capitalism flourished as some students who won a lottery for tickets to see Gorbachev traded their prizes for fistfuls of hard cash from the wealthy. Other students scrambled to pick up some of the remaining tickets that went unclaimed after the official university lottery last week for the 1,700 seats at Gorbachev's talk and 6,000 others to the rest of the events on his university visit. ``Gorbachev probably would have felt right at home this morning,'' said Jorgensen, a 21-year-old student who waited for tickets beginning at 2 a.m. ``The lines we stood in were very much like the food lines in the Soviet Union.'' Though Jorgensen hung onto his ticket, other students said they had friends who scalped theirs for up to $1,400 each. There were rumors passes had gone for up to $1,800 apiece. Two sophomores, Jeff Vierling, a 19-year-old electrical engineering major, and Marlowe Johnson, a 21-year-old international relations major, sat on a curb at the university Monday asking for serious offers only of $1,000 or more cash for each of their two tickets. The tickets are ``worth a great deal to me, but the only value here is sentimental. I can probably see him better on TV,'' said Johnson, who wants to finance a trip to Europe. Added Vierling: ``It's airplane tickets. It's a lot of things. It's a CD player.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says United States Will Pay Its Dues To United Nations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said on Monday the United States soon will pay its $62.5 million dues to the United Nations and plans to deal with the huge unpaid bill to the world body accumulated during Ronald Reagan's presidency. The subject of U.S. payments to the U.N. came up during a meeting between Bush and U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Afterward, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush regards money owed to the U.N. as ``solemn international obligations made by the United States after full consultation with Congress.'' Beginning in 1985, the Reagan administration began withholding some of its the U.S. dues to protest what it said was the U.N.'s anti-Western bias, inefficiency and budget overruns. In September 1988, Reagan announced he was pleased with the world body's progress toward budget reform, staff cutbacks and a new spirit of consensus and cooperation. But he left the details of paying the arrears to Bush. Bush said he hopes Congress will provide money to pay off approximately $460 million in delinquent dues. Bush has proposed a five-year payoff scheme to Congress. U.S. dues to the the U.N. run about $240 million. In addition to the regular budget, there also are fees for peacekeeping activities.

DOC.HEAD: Midwest Temperatures Dip, Southwest Simmers
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped in parts of the Midwest on Monday and could get cooler, while the southwest simmered and the central Gulf Coast was slapped by thunderstorms. Rainshowers were scattered along the northern Pacific coast, northern New England and parts of the mid-Atlantic coast. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 44 degrees at Bradford, Pa., to 108 degrees in Palm Springs, Calif. Warm, humid weather reigned in the east and south, with temperatures in the 70s and 80s. Readings climbed into the 90s in Florida and Texas. A record high of 94 was set in Corpus Christi, topping a 1953 mark of 93. Daytona Beach tied its 1985 record high of 95. Cloudy skies and northerly winds kept temperatures in the 40s, 50s and lower 60s across much of the upper Mississippi and Ohio valleys, as well as the Great Lakes region. Temperatures could fall further Tuesday. Thunderstorms ranged from the central Gulf Coast to Florida. A severe storm dropped dime-size hail in northern Florida. The low temperature for the nation Monday morning was 31 degrees, registered in Truckee, Calif., and Marquette, Mich. An overnight frost advisory was posted Monday for the northern mountains of Pennsylvania, much of western and central New York state and parts of Michigan, where lows were expected to fall into low 30s. Most of the nation was expected to be sunny or partly sunny Tuesday, with showers likely from North Dakota to Wisconsin and along the Oregon and Washington coasts. A high wind warning was posted for Rocky Mountain areas in northern Montana, where west winds gusted to 65 mph Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Anniversary of Chinese Suppression Marked throughout World
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Paris-dated item on AM-News Digest
DOC.HEAD: With AM-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: People by the tens of thousands jammed Hong Kong's Victoria Park on Monday at a candlelight vigil in remembrance of those killed in the suppression of China's pro-democracy movement in June 1989. Commemorations also were held in Mongolia, France, Czechoslovakia, Sweden Taiwan, Japan, Canada, Britain and the United States. A hunger strike in May 1989 began the occupation of Beijing's Tiananmen Square by student activists. It ended when the army stormed the square June 3-4, killing hundreds _ perhaps thousands _ of protesters near the plaza. In Beijing on Monday, police with rifles blocked roads to the university area and heavy security elsewhere in the capital ended the possibility of any public dissent on the first anniversary of the suppression. Police estimated 80,000 people attended the Hong Kong vigil, where demonstrators sang patriotic songs and demanded China release jailed dissidents. Rally organizers put the figure at about 150,000. The British colony reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. China pledged to retain Hong Kong's capitalistic and legal systems for 50 years after the takeover, but fear mounted in the territory that Beijing may renege on its promises. Rally organizers laid wreaths and screened videotapes of Chinese dissidents in exile during the three-hour rally, urging local residents not to forget the Beijing massacre. Many wept at the speeches. Student leader Wu'er Kaixi, who escaped to the West after the crackdown, said from Paris, ``There are many children like us who are unable to see our parents. Please remember we have a long road ahead.'' In Paris, seven protesters outside the Chinese Embassy continued to refuse food Monday after an overnight vigil. Dozens of bouquets of white flowers were delivered to them. Yvon Thomas, a 19-year-old student participating in the symbolic 36-hour fast, said he was horrified by the Tiananmen events and ``I decided to do something concrete for the anniversary, so that we won't forget what happened, and that political prisoners in China may be released.'' A group of dissidents, including Wu'er, tried to deliver a letter seeking a meeting with embassy officials but police kept them away. In the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, 20 Mongolian students protested Monday outside the Chinese Embassy, staging an hourlong sit-in to deliver a petition, the East German news agency ADN reported. They left after pasting on the mission's wall a poster condemning the June 4 bloodshed, ADN said. The official Vatican Radio marked the anniversary with a commentary. ``A year has passed, the entire world hasn't forgotten and still wants to have hope and faith in China,'' it said. The state news agency CTK said hundreds of youths in Czechoslovakia observed the anniversary, including students who took part in demonstrations last year that contributed to the downfall of the nation's Communist regime. CTK said no incidents were reported as the demonstration wound its way from Old Town Square in central Prague to the Chinese Embassy, where it dispersed. In Stockholm, hundreds of Swedes demonstrated Monday downtown and outside the Chinese Embassy. In Taiwan, organizers set up an altar for last June's victims at a rally in a park attended by about 400 Taiwanese standing in the rain. Demonstrators in Tokyo gathered in a park with wreaths and banners saying, ``Long live freedom and democracy in Tiananmen Square'' and ``The June 4 massacre is the world's shame.'' Rallies were held in cities across the United States, Britain and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says China Continues to Ignore Human Rights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to include detail on demonstrations around country,
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that China continues to violate human rights a year after the Tiananmen Square massacre, but a Democratic leader said Bush is all talk and no action on the issue. Bush incurred the wrath of many members of Congress last month by extending for a year most-favored-nation trading status under which Beijing receives low tariffs on its goods. On Monday, Bush issued a statement critical of Chinese leaders, calling on them to ``turn decisively away from repression.'' But he did not alter his stance on trade benefits to China. Bush said his administration values ``good relations with the Chinese people and government'' and is ready ``to develop this relationship as China resumes a ... path of reform.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell also used the anniversary to speak out on the issue, reiterating Democratic complaints that Bush actually is lending support to Beijing by continuing it most-favored trade status. ``The Chinese people must be told that the president's silence does not represent the view of all Americans,'' Mitchell said. Diane Dewhirst, Mitchell's spokeswoman, said later that the majority leader had not seen the president's statement and would have no comment. Bush, a former U.S. envoy to China, praised China for reforms undertaken from 1978 to 1988, but said he remained ``deeply concerned by the lack of respect for internationally recognized human rights in China today, and urge a rapid return to the more positive course set before Tiananmen occurred.'' He said the Chinese government, in suppressing demonstrations, was denying its citizens ``the freedom of expression, freedom of the press and freedom of association.'' ``These are freedoms that are enshrined in both the U.S. Constitution and the Chinese Constitution,'' Bush said. Some sanctions Bush imposed on China in the aftermath of the Tiananmen Square crackdown, including a ban on military sales, remain in force. Mitchell, who said it was a mistake to renew the most-favored-nation status, said he would try to block the extension when Congress returns Tuesday from its Memorial Day recess. ``Students in Beijing have risked their freedom and perhaps even their lives to demonstrate their memory of last year's events,'' Mitchell said. ``Americans know that if we let this anniversary go by unmarked, we will share in the shame the Chinese government brought on itself.'' More than 1,000 people reportedly were killed in the crackdown June 4, 1989. Mitchell plans to meet with dissident students later this week. One of those dissidents, a 24-year-old woman who hid from Chinese authorities for 10 months after leading student protests in Tiananmen Square, appealed Monday for American and international pressure to curb human rights abuses in her homeland. Chai Ling said at a news conference that she wants to meet with Bush to tell him that his decision to renew the most-favored-nation status disappointed the survivors of China's democracy movement. ``I plea to the people of the world: You must not forget those who gave up their lives for freedom and democracy; let your words of support be heard,'' she said. Meanwhile, Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee joined about 150 lawmakers in signing a letter asking Chinese Prime Minister Li Peng to release jailed protesters, halt torture, prohibit secret executions and stop using lethal force against peaceful demonstrators. The letter was drafted by Amnesty International Elsewhere, the anniversary was marked in this country with demonstrations in Los Angeles, Atlanta and Salt Lake City. Some 200-300 people attended those rallies. In New York, Lu Jing-hua, a participant in the Tiananmen uprising last year, tried without success to deliver a pro-democracy letter to the Chinese mission to the United Nations on Monday. ``I've never once regretted taking part,'' she said. ``My experience was the most significant action of my life and gave me a taste of freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Thomas Root, Others Charged with Securities Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to CORRECT that plane crashed in July sted September.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer whose private plane crashed into the Atlantic last year with him wounded at the controls was charged Monday with 455 counts of securities fraud and related charges. A Nash County grand jury returned indictments with a total of 2,695 counts against Thomas Root, Sonrise Management Services, Telemedia Inc. and three other men identified as co-owners of the two businesses. The charges stem from claims allegedly made by Sonrise that investors would get help applying for federal licenses for radio stations. In announcing the indictment, North Carolina Secretary of State Rufus Edmisten said only a handful of the company's investors ever received licenses from the Federal Communications Commission. Root's attorney, Eugene Propper, said from Washington, D.C., he couldn't comment in detail on the indictment, ``except to say that my client is not guilty of any securities fraud.'' The companies named no longer maintain offices in the area. Edmisten said: ``In all, 1,018 people in North Carolina contributed more than $8 million to this organization. Nationally, more than $16 million was invested by people from 25 states.'' Root, a Washington-area lawyer who has been indicted on federal charges involving his work for Sonrise, drew national attention in July 1989 after he reported blacking out in the cockpit of his single-engine plane on a flight from Washington to Rocky Mount. He was followed by military planes during the 800-mile odyssey down the East Coast which ended when he crashed in Bahamian waters off Florida. Rescuers pulled Root from the ocean and discovered he had been shot in the abdomen. It was never determined exactly how he was injured. Root told investigators he could recall nothing after reporting by radio that he was having trouble breathing. He said he did not know how he got shot, but said the wound was not self-inflicted. Edmisten said his office, which regulates the securities industry in North Carolina, had been investigating Sonrise for more than two years. The others charged were SMS Chairman Ralph Savage, SMS President Eugene White and Carl Hurlebaus, who is co-owner of Telemedia Inc. with White and Savage.

DOC.HEAD: Victim's Mother Accused of Shooting at Defendant in Courtroom
DOC.TEXT: The mother of a slaying victim allegedly pulled a gun from her purse in a packed courtroom Monday and fired at her daughter's accused killer from the witness stand. Pearl Marie Abraham was charged with attempted murder after she allegedly fired a single shot from a .38-caliber pistol at Stuart Martin Elliott during the third day of his murder trial in Lincoln County Circuit Court. Elliott, 25, of Hamlin is charged with killing Mrs. Abraham's daughter and raping her 10-year-old granddaughter in September. Witnesses said prosecutor Jay Hoke had just finished questioning Mrs. Abraham when she pulled the gun from her handbag. The bullet hit the defense table and ricocheted into a door, but missed everyone in the standing-room-only courtroom. Mrs. Abraham of West Hamlin was subdued by a bailiff and the chaotic courtroom was cleared. The judge ordered court officials to refrain from discussing the attack with the press; this account is compiled from witnesses reports and the complaint filed by state police. Elliott suffered a twisted knee in the brief melee. He was treated at Boone Memorial Hospital in Madison and returned to jail. Lincoln County Magistrate Helen McCormick released Mrs. Abraham after she posted $25,000 bond. She was whisked away by family members through a rear door without commenting to reporters. Elliott is accused of murder, sexual assault, two counts of attempted murder and attempted arson in the death of Annette Abraham and the attack on the girl. State police said presiding Judge W. Jack Stevens told officers to refer all questions to Hoke until it could be determined at a meeting scheduled for Tuesday morning whether the shooting would force a mistrial. Hoke was unavailable in his courthouse office and his private law office Monday afternoon. Elliott's attorneys contend that co-defendant Danny Ray Dotson, 43, of Carlisle, Pa., committed the crimes while Elliott watched in a drunken stupor. Dotson is scheduled to be tried in late June.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Too Busy to Mourn Neighbors, Loss of House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `In Ohio...,' to UPDATE that 1,600 homes and businesses damaged.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Storms-Glance
LaserPhoto CS3
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Jack Kinman was too busy leading cleanup efforts Monday to mourn six neighbors and the loss of his home in a tornado that tore through this southwest Indiana city last weekend. ``We haven't had any time to worry about our loss. We just have to think about everybody here,'' said Kinman, 70. Petersburg was hit hardest by weekend storms that left 14 people dead throughout the Midwest and caused damage as far south as Texas. All of Petersburg's 3,000 residents were without water Monday. President Bush on Monday authorized federal disaster assistance to 19 Indiana counties ravaged by floods last month and tornadoes during the weekend. Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio asked for similar assistance to two counties in his state. After a tour of the stricken area on Sunday, Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh said Petersburg looked like it had been bombed. Saturday's tornado turned Kinman's house on its foundation and tore off the roof. Next door, the duplex where Giles Evans and Emma Willis lived was leveled. They were among six people in the Petersburg area who died in the storm. ``Those two were wonderful people,'' Kinman said. ``I've lived here all my life, so of course I knew them all.'' Eight people died in Indiana as a result of tornadoes that drove across central and southern portions of the state Saturday night. Two boys, ages 6 and 8, died Sunday in a second wave of storms that spawned one tornado. The weekend storms also were blamed for two deaths in Wisconsin and one each in Illinois and Missouri. Tornadoes also were reported in Minnesota, Kentucky and Michigan. In Indiana, the American Red Cross estimated that 824 homes were damaged, including 240 that were destroyed. In Petersburg alone, 114 homes were destroyed and 270 sustained more moderate damage. In Kentucky, 47 homes were damaged and a spokesman for the state Department of Disaster and Emergency Services said storm destruction could total as much as $5 million statewide. In Ohio, at least 1,600 homes and businesses in three southwestern counties were damaged. Kinman said the scope of the tragedy was difficult to comprehend. ``I think most people are still stunned. They're in a state of shock,'' he said. About 5,000 homes and business in Petersburg and Bedford, which also was heavily damaged, were without electric service, said Pamela K. Chapman, a spokeswoman for PSI Energy. She said power would be restored to most areas by Tuesday. For the third consecutive week, Petersburg residents were urged to boil all drinking water once service was restored. The city lost its fresh water supply two weeks ago when floodwater broke the main water line. In Petersburg and Bedford, people sorted through rubble and carried away debris. A steady stream of dump trucks hauled away tree limbs. The Red Cross and several churches offered meals and drinking water. Mark Kraner, a Red Cross spokesman in Bedford, said the agency was making an appeal for donations. ``We're not asking for clothing or food,'' Kraner said. ``We want money so the money can come back into the local economy.'' Two radio stations in Bloomington, 60 miles to the northeast, launched a fund-raiser for victims. Vince Garmon, a spokesman for WTTS-WGCL, said about $10,000 had been raised. ``Everybody's pulling together,'' said Valerie Zimmerman of Petersburg. ``We have to or nobody will make it.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Democrats Nominate Cuomo for Third Term
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo was nominated Monday to run for a third term, but some at the state Democratic convention wondered if he'd serve out the term if re-elected or take a run at the White House. With the convention band breaking into ``I Love New York,'' the 57-year-old governor was nominated by acclamation. Cuomo, considered a potential 1992 Democratic presidential candidate was scheduled to address the delegates Tuesday. Last week, New York Republicans chose Manhattan economist and businessman Pierre Rinfret, a political unknown, to challenge Cuomo. Making appearances at the convention were New York Mayor David Dinkins, Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan and former vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro, who spoke out for abortion rights. The former Queens congresswoman who ran on the 1984 Democratic presidential ticket with Walter Mondale is considering a 1992 run for the U.S. Senate seat currently held by Republican Alfonse D'Amato. Another speaker was actor Christopher Reeve, who pressed for greater efforts to clean up the environment. Most speakers stressed the party's goal of claiming majority control of the Republican-dominated state Senate. Delegates nominated Lt. Gov. Stan Lundine to run again with Cuomo. If re-elected, it would be Lundine's second term as lieutenant governor. The governor, refusing to rule out a possible bid for the presidency in 1992, announced his re-election plans Sunday. He considered a presidential campaign in 1988, but ultimately bowed out. Ms. Ferraro said Democrats nationwide favor Cuomo. ``They believe that he can be the person who can carry the Democrats to the White House in 1992,'' she said of party followers she's met across the country.

DOC.HEAD: Cartel Ringleader Writes Bush, Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Convicted Colombian drug kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas says he wrote letters to Mikhail Gorbachev and President Bush to gripe about prison conditions. Lehder, a onetime leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, told Bush the presidential dog Millie lives better than he does and urged Gorbachev to visit the federal prison in Marion, Ill., which he called the American ``Gulag.'' Marion spokesman Joe Snoddy said Lehder receives the same treatment as other prisoners at the high security prison. Copies of the letters, dated May 28, 1990, were mailed to The Associated Press by Lehder. Lehder is serving a life term plus 135 years for smuggling more than 20 tons of cocaine into the United States in the late 1970s. At Marion, he is confined to a 8-foot by 9{-foot cell and is allowed seven hours of exercise a week, Snoddy said. It is the nation's only federal lockup designated a ``high security'' prison, meaning about two-thirds of the inmates are never allowed to mix with other inmates, Snoddy said. In his letter to Bush, he complained he has been ``subjected to a constant battery of psychological torture and sensory deprivation as a matter of official treatment here.'' The letter to Gorbachev was mailed to the Soviet Embassy in Washington, he said. ``I, Carlos Lehder, as a socio-political prisoner, knowledgable of your paramount defense of Human Rights and the under-privileged of the World ... wish to invite Your Excellency, and the Soviet News Media, to visit the American `Gulag,' known as Marion,'' he wrote. The ``Gulag'' statement referred to the infamous Soviet system of prisons and work camps where thousands died during the Stalin era. In his letter to Bush, Lehder said dogs deserve better treatment. ``I submit Mr. President, that if someone were to confine your lovely dog, Millie in a solitary cell for three years; you would see those responsible for such acts were arrested and punished for animal cruelty,'' he wrote in the letter that bears his signature, a Marion postmark and a prison stamp. Lehder was extradited to Florida in February 1987 and convicted in May 1988 of smuggling tons of cocaine into the United States. He recently filed a federal suit in Jacksonville claiming prison officials were prohibiting him from exercising, studying and learning German. Snoddy said the only foreign language taught at Marion is Spanish.

DOC.HEAD: Election Official Accuses Carter of Intervention
DOC.TEXT: A senior election official on Monday accused former U.S. President Jimmy Carter of intervening in Domincan affairs and of being partial to ex-President Juan Bosch, who says fraud marred the May 16 elections. President Joaquin Balaguer held a slim, 21,694-vote lead over Bosch in unofficial results, which gave Balaguer 669,063 votes; Bosch, 647,369; and Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, a former Santo Domingo mayor, 438,647. Carter was one of 30 international observers here for the balloting. He was invited by Froilan Tavares, president of the Central Election Board. On Monday, Tavares said Carter was ``misinformed'' by aides who observed a review of tally sheets, carried out last week to determine if there was fraud. Bosch, 80, had accused Balaguer, 83 and blind from glaucoma, of ``colossal fraud'' and said Tavares was in league with the president, who has served five terms in this Caribbean nation of 7 million people. Tavares on Monday suspended the tally review, saying a survey of 60 percent of the totals showed no errors or evidence of fraud. He said the review was not mandatory under the country's election law. The next step would be for the Election Board to announce an official winner, an action that can be formally challenged by Bosch. Tavares said Carter was ``misinformed by his inexperienced'' representatives Mark Feierstein and Alejandro Canton, of the Atlanta-based Carter Institute. He said the two ``met only officials from one party and gave Carter wrong and biased information.'' He scolded Carter for writing Balaguer a letter on May 22 that ``ignored the autonomy'' of the Election Board and was a ``virtual intervention in the internal affairs of our country.'' The contents of the letter were not divulged. Before returning home, Carter said the thin lead made it impossible to determine a winner and recommended the tally sheets be scrutinized for possible ``fraud or honest errors.'' Several international observers and Dominican politicians have accused Balaguer's Social Christian Reformist Party of buying votes and questioned delays in vote-counting.

DOC.HEAD: Iranians Show Little Enthusiasm on Anniversary of Khomeini's Death ^Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to clarify that shrine marks Khomeini's grave. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `While there...'
LaserPhoto TEH1
DOC.TEXT: Spiritual leader Ali Khamenei said Monday that Iran will follow the path set by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, but Iranians showed relatively little enthusiasm on the first anniversary of the patriarch's death. ``Death to America!'' blared loudspeakers. ``Death to Israel!'' Inside the shrine that marks Khomeini's grave, mourners listened as speakers recited Koranic verses. The gray-bearded Khomeini stared sternly at the crowd from pictures hung on pillars. ``While There Is Islam, We Will Not Forget The Imam'' read one banner. Khomeini was considerd the imam, or supreme spiritual leader. Addressing the crowd, Khamenei said: ``The imam's line is that same line which we pledge to follow.'' Khomeini was 86 when he died June 3, 10 years after his Islamic revolution toppled Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi. He was buried at the shrine in the Behesht-e Zahra cemetery, 10 miles south of Tehran. The first anniversary of Khomeini's death stood in sharp contrast to the bizarre outpouring of grief during his June 6 funeral last year. At that time, 6 million frenzied mourners poured into the streets, pounding their heads with clenched fists, beating their chests and scratching their faces to draw blood. Monday's event, the culmination of a four-day mourning period, brought about 3 million people to the shrine on the outskirts of Tehran, according to foreign reporters who flew over the scene in helicopters. That was far fewer than expected. Iran's official news media, however, said 8-9 million people participated. Tehran, normally a hodgepodge of activity, was quiet and streets were deserted. Many residents apparently preferred to stay home than go to the shrine. At Khomeini's tomb, the atmosphere was that of a social gathering. Only a few mourners beat their chests in the traditional Shiite Moslem expression of grief, although larger groups of mourners would occasionally tap their chests in symbolic fashion. Inside the shrine, segregated by sex, a few people fainted in 90 degree heat and guards sprayed water to cool the crowd. At Khomeini's funeral, about 28,000 people passed out because of heat, dehydration or exhaustion. Disabled men in wheelchairs, reminders of the Iran-Iraq war, were pushed into the shrine by Revolutionary Guards wearing black armbands to mark the occasion. A young soldier with blisters on his feet from three days of walking to reach the shrine said: ``I came last year, and I had to come again this year.'' Thousands of mourners were bused in from villages, towns and other cities. Soldiers and other civil servants were ordered to attend the ceremonies. Hundreds of Shiites also came from Pakistan, India, Syria, and Lebanon. Iranian television, which broadcast live coverage of the funeral last year, did not broadcast any of the events live. In commemorations elsewhere, hundreds of mourners gathered inside the mosque at Khomeini's home in Jamaran sobbing and beating themselves as they looked at a chair on a small balcony from which Khomeini would address his people. The ayatollah had long suffered heart problems and died after surgery for intestinal bleeding. A year after his death, many followers who participated in the Islamic revolution have become disillusioned, disgruntled with high inflation, official corruption and the unfulfilled promises of the revolution. Most of the economic woes are from the eight-year war with Iraq and from Khomeini's implacable anti-Western stance, which blocked foreign investment and Western technology. Khomeini's staunch followers, such as his only surviving son, Ahmad, an important figure in the so-called radical camp within the leadership, want no deviation from his teachings. But others, such as President Hashemi Rafsanjani, have indicated they want revolutionary fervor dampened in favor of economic reconstruction. In a veiled attack on proponents of that policy, Ahmad told ideologically committed Revolutionary Guards recently: ``Do not deviate from the imam's path. If others do, I trust you will not let them.'' Meanwhile, the largest exile Iranian opposition group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, said in asociated Press in Nicosia, Cyprus, there were anti-government demonstrations in Iran. In the telex from its office in Baghdad, the group said clashes between students and government sec telex to The Asurity forces were reported in Tehran, Tabriz, Esfahan and Orumiyeh. It said at least 300 students were arrested in Orumiyeh. The government did not comment on the reports and there was no immediate way to verify them.

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Mulroney, Provincial Premiers Meet on Meech Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with meeting adjourned, new quotes. Picks up 3rd graf, `Quebec refused...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney met with the 10 provincial premiers on Monday for the third time io seize buses and terminals as the company struggled into the fourth month of a drivers' strike. Officials said the filing would not affect service at the only nationwide bus company. ``We have taken this action to enable Greyhound lines to continue operation of its of its total system,'' said J. Michael Doyle, senior vice president and chief financial officer. The petition was filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Texas in Brownsville. The filing under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code allows the company to continue operating under court supervision while it tries to reorganize its finances and pay off creditors. Union officials were not immediately available to comment on the bankruptcy filing. Greyhound has been struggling since bus drivers walked out March 2. The company has been operating a reduced schedule, but the sliced revenue and increased expenses of fighting the strike have siphoned off cash needed to operate. The company lost $56 million in the first quarter. It has missed more than $16 million in principal, interest and lease payments since the end of April, putting it in default on numerous agreements with creditors. ``In the past few days, there has been a lot of pressure by creditors'' who own buses and terminals that the company leases, said President Frank Schmieder. ``We tried to stay out (of bankruptcy) as long as possible,'' Schmieder said. ``There will be no interruption of service,'' Doyle said, adding that the company had asked the bankruptcy court to honor tickets already purchased. ``For the passengers, (bankruptcy) ought to be pretty transparent,'' Schmieder said. ``The network is up in full and we're going to need all the employees that we currently have.'' Two weeks ago, the company proposed repurchasing $225 million of its junk bond debt at a steep discount, provided it could find enough financing to pay about $90 million for the bonds and leave the company with about $35 million in operating capital. ``We have asked creditors for patience so that we could devote all available resources to running maximum service during the peak summer travel season,'' Doyle said. ``While most have been cooperative, we were faced with the threat of a `run on assets' that could have crippled our ability to operate,'' he said. ``We are highly confident we will be successful in restructuring our debt,'' Doyle added. Schmieder said negotiations are continuing on financing the debt restructuring, but ``it will take longer now because the courts will have to approve any financial restructuring.'' The company did not estimate when it hoped to emerge from court supervision. The filing covers Greyhound and five subsidiaries including Eagle Bus Manufacturing Co., which is based in Brownsville. The other subsidiaries are GLI Bus Operations Holding Co., BusLease Inc., Trailways Commuter Transit Inc. and GLI Food Services Inc. Most of Greyhound's 6,300 drivers walked out over wages and job security. The company has been operating a reduced schedule with nearly 3,000 newly hired drivers. After attempts to reopen negotiations collapsed early last month, Chairman Fred G. Currey said May 7 the strike had become ``irrelevant'' because the carrier had enough drivers to operate. Just two weeks later, however, the company acknowledged severe financial difficulties and said the proposed repurchase of junk bonds was necessary to avert bankruptcy. The company's total debt stood at $384 million at the end of March. The debt is the legacy of a leveraged buyout three years ago led by Currey that took the company private. Currey and other investors paid $270 million for the bus operations of Greyhound Corp., since renamed Greyhound Dial Corp. A few months later they paid an additional $80 million for Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc., then the nation's largest operator of Trailways buses. Greyhound's future also was clouded recently by a finding by the National Labor Relations Board that Greyhound engaged in unfair labor practices by implementing its contract proposal immediately after the strike began. An administrative law judge has scheduled hearings on the matter in Milwaukee on Sept. 17. The procedure could result in the bus company being forced to pay about $10 million a month in back wages. Greyhound has said it is confident it will win once the case gets in court.

DOC.HEAD: Bronx Will Get 917; Manhattan Will Have 212 To Itself
DOC.TEXT: The Bronx will get its own telephone area code _ 917 _ in 1992 under a plan filed Monday with the Public Service Commission, leaving Manhattan with sole use of existing area code 212. The new code is necessary because available numbers in the 212 area code, now shared by the Bronx and Manhattan, could run out by 1993, New York Telephone officials said. The phone company said the telephone numbers in the 212 area code are disappearing quickly because of growth in businesses that use computers, facsimile machines, cellular telephones and pagers.

DOC.HEAD: Man Loses Half of Herd to Lightning Bolt
DOC.TEXT: A bolt of lightning in the night killed 30 pedigreed black Angus cattle huddling in the rain. George Ahlfield said heard the loud crack of thunder, but wasn't prepared for the grisly scene Monday morning. Heaps of dead cows lay scattered in the field, with the surviving animals hovering nearby. The thunderstorm Sunday night killed about half his herd. ``This is a very severe loss. It's just one of those things a person never counts on and that you think will never happen to you,'' he said. ``But when it does, it hurts.'' No other storm damage was reported in the area. ``But it's extremely odd for that many cattle to be killed,'' said National Weather Service meteorologist Bill Comeaux.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Company Files for Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with detail, minor editing. A version moving on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday, saying it was worried creditors would try to seize buses and terminals as the company struggled into the fourth month of a drivers' strike. Officials said bus service would continue on routes where it hasn't been curtailed because of the strike. ``We have taken this action to enable Greyhound lines to continue operation of its total system,'' said J. Michael Doyle, senior vice president and chief financial officer. The petition was filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Brownsville. The filing under Chapter 11 of the hristmas.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Release Anytime

DOC.HEAD: Business Leaders Impressed by Gorbachev Remark on Loyalty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES last two grafs, which duplicate grafs 8-9.
DOC.TEXT: Despite Mikhail S. Gorbachev's note of urgency, there will be plenty of opportunities in the Soviet Union later for companies unwilling to deploy their dollars now, one big Soviet trading partner said Monday. ``It always pays one to be first,'' said Whitney MacMillan, chairman of Cargill Inc., the giant commodities company that is the Soviets' largest private trading partner. But, he said, ``the facts are that the opportunities won't disappear.'' John Block, former U.S. agriculture secretary, agreed. ``The first wave that goes in there is vitally important,'' Block said. ``But that doesn't mean there won't be a second wave. They'll need a second and third wave as the economy progresses.'' In a 90-minute meeting Sunday in Minneapolis, the Soviet leader told about 100 business leaders that ``those who are with us at this time have a good prospect of cooperation in our great country.'' Then he added: ``But those who just stand on the sidelines, who do not want to risk, who want to wait and see, who don't want to risk their dollars, well, they will remain, I think, observers for years to come. ``We'll make sure that that is so,'' Gorbachev said. Robert Price, a former chief executive officer of Control Data Corp., which has long had a relationship with the Soviet Union, said the inability to convert rubles to dollars or other hard currency must be overcome if Gorbachev is to win new U.S. investment in his country. ``Everything is the money problem,'' Price said. ``He (Gorbachev) can't wish it to go away. He can't and we can't.'' Gorbachev said help from U.S. companies in management, agriculture, transportation, medicine and computer technology is needed to stabilize the U.S.S.R. as it moves to a market-driven economy. ``I think he is just stating a true fact of human life. That loyalty is important,'' said Dwayne Andreas, chief executive officer of Archer Daniels Midland Co. of Decatur, Ill. ``It brings to my mind the girl who says `I'm going to go home with the man who brought me.''' Cargill's MacMillan said he did not take Gorbachev's remark seriously. Opportunities in the Soviet Union will grow, he said, as the decision-making process becomes decentralized _ thus reducing the possibility of bureaucratic revenge. ``I took it that they are eager for investment. And I guess I take it much as a statement of fact rather than a threat,'' said Allen Jacobson, chief executive officer of 3M Co. ``If you don't get in early to most places, you get left out.'' But business leaders with less experience in U.S.-Soviet trade were more shaken by Gorbachev's remark. ``They do try to keep track of who they consider their friends,'' said Winston Wallin, chairman of Minneapolis-based Medtronic Inc., the world's largest maker of cardiac pacemakers. ``He did say it in kind of a humorous way, but it did have a little teeth in it.'' Dwight Opperman, chief executive officer of West Publishing Inc. in St. Paul, said companies that don't invest in the Soviet economy now may indeed be left out when the country is prospering. ``Help him now and you may get in on the golden pot at the end of the rainbow,'' said Opperman, whose company has never done business in the Soviet Union. ``It's a carrot. You give him a carrot and a whip both.'' Curt Carlson, founder of Minnesota-based Carlson Companies, said it would be unfair for the Soviets to discriminate in the future against companies not ready to answer his call for help because current conditions for trade between the United States and Soviet Union are difficult.

DOC.HEAD: Raisa Comparison Shops at the Kims
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hea Kim was at the counter of her family's store Monday, watching television coverage of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the San Francisco Bay area, when in walked Raisa Gorbachev. ``I didn't know about it at all,'' Mrs. Kim said of the Soviet first lady's impromptu shopping stop. ``I was surprised.'' Mrs. Gorbachev, scrapping announced plans, suddenly embarked on her own whirlwind tour of San Francisco, including a visit to the New Terrace Market in the Twin Peaks neighborhood. Accompanied by an interpreter and several Secret Service men, Mrs. Gorbachev spent about 10 minutes asking Mrs. Kim questions and doing a bit of comparison shopping as her limousine drew a crowd of onlookers. ``I think she was just checking the items we carry in this small market,'' Mrs. Kim said of the store she and her husband own and operate in an upscale neighborhood. ``She looked at what items we carry and how they move. Especially the fresh and frozen foods,'' she added. Mrs. Gorbachev also specifically checked the market's supply of vodka. ``I think she wanted to know if we carry Stolichnaya,'' Mrs. Kim said of the popular brand imported from the Soviet Union. ``Then she looked at the Smirnoff, the kind made in the U.S.'' The wife of the Soviet leader wanted to know why there were only a few bottles of Stolichnaya left on the market's shelves. ``I told her it was because Stolichnaya is the best-selling vodka we have,'' Mrs. Kim said. ``She smiled.'' Mrs. Gorbachev also was interested in bread, asking Mrs. Kim about her customers' preferences and learning they prefer whole-wheat to white. Despite her interest in the merchandise, Mrs. Gorbachev didn't buy anything and explained through the interpreter that she couldn't take anything from the store with her, as Mrs. Kim offered. But the Soviet first lady left plenty of friends behind. ``She was very friendly, and she's very pretty ... and she held my hand afterward,'' Mrs. Kim said. Patty Corwin, who lives nearby and shops at the Kims, was about to pick up her children from school when she noticed the limousine outside the market. She went with a neighbor to investigate and saw Mrs. Gorbachev leave the store. Mrs. Gorbachev spent a few minutes outside talking with neighborhood residents and construction workers from nearby condominium projects who gathered as close as security personnel would allow. ``She walked around and shook my hand and shook my neighbor's hand,'' Mrs. Corwin said, adding, ``She said something like `Pleased to meet you' '' in English.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules That L.A. County Discriminated Against Hispanic Community
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment from attorney general, others, possible effects of ruling. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors violated the rights of Hispanics in 1981 by drawing voting districts that keep them from getting elected, a federal judge ruled Monday. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon, ruling in a voting rights case, said the board's five members conspired to ``protect their incumbencies and that of their allies'' when they redrew the county's five voting districts in 1981. In so doing, Kenyon said, the supervisors violated the 1965 federal Voting Rights Act and the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment to the Constitution. Hispanics make up about 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million people. No member of any minority group has been elected to the board since 1875. The Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund and the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation of Southern California expressed jubilation at the ruling and demanded the results of two elections set for Tuesday be invalidated. County Counsel DeWitt Clinton was in budget hearings Monday and unavailable for comment. But Fifth District Supervisor Mike Antonovich, who is not up for re-election, said the ruling would be appealed. MALDEF, the civil liberties group and the U.S. Justice Department had sued in 1988, accusing the supervisors of deliberately spreading the Hispanic population across several districts to keep Hispanics from getting elected. ``This is truly a great and historic day,'' said Marc Rosenbaum, an attorney for the civil liberties group. ``For 115 years, the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors has been an exclusive male, all-white club. Today that club membership is open to everyone.'' In Washington, U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh hailed the decision ``as a victory against discrimination in the most important role citizens play in our democracy _ the right to vote in free and fair elections in districts drawn without bias.'' Representatives of both sides said it wasn't immediately clear how the issue will be resolved. MALDEF officials said they would demand the immediate creation of a largely Hispanic district. ``We want a remedy that encompasses a fair opportunity for our community to represent itself and to elect representatives who will represent its interests,'' said Antonia Hernandez, president and general counsel for MALDEF. She and Rosenbaum also said new elections should be held in the First and Third supervisorial districts, where voting takes place Tuesday. Ed Edelman, who is seeking re-election in the Third District, declined comment on Kenyon's ruling. In the First District, retiring Supervisor Pete Schabarum said he had not read Kenyon's decision. ``I continue to believe, however, that district lines should not be based on ethnic factors,'' he said, ``and I find it incredulous that a 1981 plan can be overturned based on 1990 demographics.'' In his ruling, the judge concluded that Hispanics and non-Hispanics are widely polarized when it comes to voting. Hispanics vote in large numbers for fellow Hispanics, he said, and non-Hispanics rarely vote for Hispanics. ``Given the estimated levels of polarization, including the effects of non-Hispanic bloc voting, an Hispanic candidate is unable to be elected to the board under the current configuration of supervisorial districts,'' Kenyon said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Says She Was Charged to Say in Homeless Shelter
DOC.TEXT: A woman who angered neighbors and got in trouble with zoning authorities for taking in homeless mothers charged the young women, despite repeated claims to be sheltering them for free, a former resident says. Charlene Luther, a 22-year-old unwed mother, also said Donna Russell told her to give a phony address to Bridgeport's Welfare Department so she could continue to receive welfare checks after she moved to Russell's home in Trumbull. Luther, who stayed at the house during her pregnancy from January to March, said in Sunday's Bridgeport Post that Russell charged her and two other pregnant residents one-third of their monthly welfare checks and took their food stamps and other assistance. ``It was a requirement of living there,'' Luther said. ``We were no more than maids who cooked and cleaned for Russell and her two sons, and a way to pay the bills.'' Russell on Monday denied the allegations. ``We're in the process of preparing a rebuttal,'' she said. In an interview in April, Russell said she had been ``called by the Lord'' to open her house to the homeless. She said that she was not charging families to live with her but that they bought some of their own food. Last week, on the nationally syndicated TV show ``Hard Copy,'' she said, ``Those girls have not paid five cents to live in that house.'' Town zoning officials, acting on a complaint from a neighbor, had ordered her to stop taking in young homeless mothers and had threatened her with arrest. The Zoning Board of Appeals scheduled a hearing for Wednesday on Russell's request for a variance to continue using her house as a shelter. The zoning law in this community of 33,000 requires that three-quarters of the people living in a single-family dwelling be related by blood, marriage or adoption.

DOC.HEAD: SAN FRANCISCO: important project.
DOC.TEXT: The other of their colleagues from the committee of Soviet scientists against the nuclear threat ... and others thank you very much. ... I take advantage of this opportunity to thank you most warmly and I hope that you will join me in this. ... We don't want new weapons to come to replace nuclear weapons. ... I think that the warning is quite necessary and quite approriate and timely at this moment. We would like scientists and engineers to work on these issues and other disarmament problems. ... President Bush and I had to note that it is not that easy to destroy those weapons. Once we've decided to scrap them we need technologies for destroying dangerous weapons ... make sure there is no damage to the environment and to people's health. ... I hope that we will lick those problems by joining our efforts. I've heard that Stanford scientists would like to cooperate closely with their Soviet colleagues on the problem of the environment. ... I must also note Stanford's contribution to Soviet-American cooperation on highly important superconductivity. Our countries are leaders in this field. ... The Soviet Union and the United States are leaders in such things as the fundamental properties of matter, solid state physics, mathematics, physical chemistry, astronomy and space research and biological sciences. Cooperation in these knowledges ... would also be of great interest. ... Ladies and gentlemen, for our country we have opted for fundamental changes. Our perestroika is the result of profound trends taking place. In our society in the last five years our country has become different, but I also think that all mankind is entering a new age and that the world is beginning to obey new laws and logic we have yet to adjust ourselves (to). ...

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Fugitive Terrorist Leader in Custody
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of belonging to an anti-Castro terrorist group was arrested Monday in the 1981 bombing of the Mexican consulate in Miami. Jose Ignacio Gonzalez, 48, was arrested by FBI agents at Miami International Airport after he was expelled from Guatemala, the FBI announced. Arrest warrants described Gonzalez as a leader of Omega 7, a militant group opposed to Cuban President Fidel Castro. Gonzalez had been sought since 1984 in the bombing of the Mexican consulate in Miami and other charges. He was the last member of the group at large, the FBI said. Gonzalez is accused of planting the bomb that heavily damaged the consulate Sept. 11, 1981. He is also charged with transporting a bomb to the Nicaraguan consulate in Miami on Sept. 2, 1982, but the device didn't explode. Omega 7 claimed responsibility for a bombing the same day at the Venezuelan consulate in Miami. The FBI has said Gonzalez, a U.S. citizen, fled to Central America in 1984. He was taken into custody early Monday by Guatemalan authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Four Top Contra Leaders Demobilize
DOC.TEXT: Four high-ranking Contra leaders demobilized on Monday and became representatives in government ministries that will help rebel fighters return to civilian life. The four were the highest-ranking Contra leaders to demobilize, but it appears total rebel disarmament by the June 10 deadline is unlikely. An agreement signed by the Contras and the government on Wednesday specifies Contra representation in government ministries. But the agreement to disarm at least 500 Contras a day has not been met, and even if it were, half the contras would remain under arms by June 10, the day agreed to by the rebels following talks with the new government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Top Contra leader Israel Galeano blamed the limited numbers of U.N. peacekeeping troops and Organization of American States officials, who have been processing rebels who want to disarm, for the slow pace of the demobilization. But U.N. peacekeeper Lt. Col. Luis Alejandre, who is in charge of Security Zone Six, said many Contras show up at the zone without their weapons and are turned back. Alejandre said the rebels had probably buried their weapons. ``You can imagine the traffic in illegal weapons there would be'' if the U.N. troops accepted rebels who did not hand over a weapon, Alejandre said. He said that since Sunday the Contras have started turning in high quality weapons. ``The ones before were all rusted out,'' Alejandre said. Galeano said the Contras had left 7,000 weapons behind in Honduran camps before returning to Nicaragua. The four Contra leaders who demobilized on Monday were: Miguel Angel Sosa, the Contra army general staff inspector also known as Commander Emiliano; Enrique Zelaya, the medical chief of staff also known as Commander Henry or Dr. Henry; Contra political advisor Bernardo Pastora; and political advisor Boanerge Matus. Zelaya, a medical doctor, is to join the Health Ministry, Sosa and Pastora are to go to the Repatriation Institute, and Matus is to join the Agrarian Reform Institute. Of an estimated 13,000 rebels, only about 4,000 have disarmed. Galeano said that although it was unlikely that the demobilization would be completed by June 10, ``we have embarked on an irreversible process.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds: Hitman a Brutal Butcher and Drug Dealer
DOC.TEXT: A prolific Mafia hitman who allegedly killed a mob stool pigeon as a favor to reputed Gambino crime family boss John Gotti was arrested along with some 30 members of his gang, federal authorities said Monday. Thomas ``Tommy Karate'' Pitera, a 35-year-old martial arts expert in the Bonanno crime family, headed a gang of killers and drug dealers who dismembered their victims, stuffed them into suitcases and plastic bags and buried them in a Staten Island bird sanctuary, the authorities said. Federal authorities accused the defendants of at least seven murders in the last three years and said they might be responsible for about two dozen more. A raid of Pitera's Brooklyn apartment yielded a library of underground publications with such titles as ``The Hitman's Handbook'' and ``Kill or Be Killed.'' Law enforcement authorities say Pitera carried out the 1988 assassination of Wilfred ``Willie Boy'' Johnson, who died in a barrage of gunfire outside his Brooklyn home. The ex-boxer, gambler, loanshark and longtime associate of Gotti's crew, reportedly turned informant in 1966 and provided reams of information to law enforcement authorities over the years under the code name Wahoo. ``Mr. Pitera believed he was doing a favor for John Gotti with the extermination of Willie Boy Johnson,'' said Andrew J. Maloney, U.S. attorney in Brooklyn. Pitera apparently carried out the hit to increase his prestige and standing within the Bonanno family, the prosecutor said. Pitera was arrested Sunday. The others were picked up on Sunday and Monday. The defendants were charged with numerous racketeering and drug charges and face life in prison if convicted. Pitera and his associates allegedly dealt in large quantities of cocaine, marijuana and heroin. They often arranged drug transactions, but instead ripped off the suppliers ``and left the bodies behind,'' Maloney said.

DOC.HEAD: East German Prime Minister to Meet Bush on June 11
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with Kohl visit to White House, Harvard address. Picks up 4th pvs, `Bush and...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany will meet with President Bush in Washington on June 11 during his trip to the United States, the government news agency ADN said Monday. De Maiziere scheduled his visit this week _ his first to America as leader of East Germany's first democratically elected government _ to speak to Jewish leaders in New York. He will leave Thursday and return on June 12. Bush and de Maiziere likely will discuss the strategic future of a united Germany. The two German states are to combine their economies on July 2, but the global role of a united Germany has yet to be resolved. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is scheduled to meet Bush at the White House on Friday to discuss the summit and German unification, said Detlef Peters, press attache at the West German consulate in New York. Kohl is to deliver the commencement address at Harvard University on Thursday. Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev failed to resolve their differences over German unification at a weekend summit in Washington, but said they discussed new ways of approaching the question. West Germany spearheads NATO and East Germany is part of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Bush and West German leaders want a united Germany to be in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Gorbachev strongly opposes this. However, Gorbachev said he and Bush agreed that Germans had the right to decide whether a united Germany should be in NATO, an apparent softening of Gorbachev's stand, a U.S. official said in Washington. De Maiziere has generally sided with the West and said a united Germany could be a NATO member. But he says the military alliance must be altered to reflect the political changes in the East bloc and wants an eventual new European security system.

DOC.HEAD: SAN FRANCISCO: ourselves (to).
DOC.TEXT: ... We are witnessing an evolution in international relations of increasingly open and mass-scale human communication. ... For a new type of progress throughout the world to become a reality, everyone must change. ... I'm convinced that we are on the threshold of revising the concept of alliance building. Until now alliances have built on a selective and in fact discriminatory basis. They were based on setting countries against each other. They divided countries and peoples much more than they united them. This system that was perfected during the years of the Cold War ... of the North Atlantic Alliance and the Warsaw Pact. But we are approaching a time when the very principle of alliance building should become different. ... I think that both the United States and the Soviet Union have to understand the need for this. ... I see many young people here. There are many more young people outside this room, of course, and I'm glad I was able to greet them, too. When I conclude my remarks I would like to address them, I would like to address young people. Your generation will not only begin creating a new world but will also live in it. Much of it will certainly be different from whatever we can imagine now from what I've been saying to you here from this rostrum. The challenge is to make sure that people in that new world live a better life in greater freedom. Much will depend on you, the men and women of science. I wish you success in this great and unprecedented undertaking. Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Offers to Send Dependents Home from Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military has offered to evacuate soldiers' families at government expense following the recent slayings of Americans and rebel threats of more attacks, a military spokesman said Tuesday. Adm. Huntington Hardisty, commander of U.S. forces in the Pacific, has approved the voluntary return of military dependents from the Philippines, said Lt. Col. Ron Rand, spokesman for Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. There are more than 20,000 U.S. dependents in the Philippines. Rand said servicemen at any of the six U.S. bases in the Philippines may request their families be sent home at government expense before the tour of duty ends. Communist rebels killed two American airmen near Clark Air Base last month and vowed more attacks until all U.S. troops leave the country. Rebels also were suspected in the shooting death of a Marine sergeant near Subic Bay naval base on May 4. The Philippine government has responded to the recent killings by increasing police protection around Clark Air Base. Since Friday, U.S. Defense Department civilians and military dependents who live at the air base have been barred from leaving because of threats from Communist guerrillas. Those living off-base have been ordered to limit travel to essential business. The restrictions affect about 20,300 Americans at Clark but do not apply to the other five bases. About 40,000 Americans _ servicemen, civilian workers and dependents _ are stationed at Clark, Subic and four other American bases in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Lt. Gov. Candidate Was Reprimanded as County Judge
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez named a South Florida lawman as his running mate Monday even though J. Allison DeFoor II was reprimanded by the state Supreme Court in 1986 while sitting as a county judge. DeFoor, now the Monroe County sheriff, was charged with improperly taking part in other political races, using his office for private and financial gain and establishing a policy allowing speeders to pay double the fine to keep traffic offenses off their driving records. Martinez's press secretary, Jon Peck, said the Republican governor was aware of DeFoor's ethical run-in. ``The governor knew about it and didn't believe it would be a problem for the campaign,'' said Peck. Martinez, who hoped a fresh face in the lieutenant governor slot would help jump-start the first week of full-time campaigning, described DeFoor, 36, as a ``proven performer ... uniquely qualified to represent the Florida of tomorrow.'' The governor's campaign manager, J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich, said of the reprimand: ``We deemed it inconsequential. We don't think any defense is required.'' The Judicial Qualifications Commission, in 1986, charged that DeFoor: _Improperly aided the candidacies of two friends, Richard J. Fowler, who was running for circuit judge, and Randall Winter, who was running for public defender. _Improperly used his office to promote an ``electronic leash,'' monitoring device in which he held a financial interest. The device was used to keep track of probationers under house arrest. _Violated Florida rules by allowing speeders under 70 mph to avoid judgment by signing a waiver and paying the clerk of court twice the statutory fine. The court agreed with the commission's finding that DeFoor's public reprimand was sufficient punishment because of his contrition and acknowledgement of wrongdoing. DeFoor left the Monroe County bench and returned to private law practice in 1987 and was elected sheriff in 1989. Key campaign issues, he said, include crime and the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Whale had Plastic Debris in Stomach
DOC.TEXT: A dead gray whale was found to have plastic bags, rubber gloves and other manmade refuse in its stomach, but that probably didn't kill it, an expert said Monday. Months of lab tests may be needed to determine what killed the whale dubbed spot by animal lovers who tracked its movements through Puget Sound for about 10 weeks. The 39-foot whale was found dead Wednesday near Hartstene Island, in the sound about 35 miles southwest of Seattle. Meanwhile Monday, the Coast Guard warned vessels to avoid two other dead whales spotted in the Strait of Juan de Fuca. Pieces of wood, bark, plastic bags, cloth rags and two rubber gloves were found in Spot's stomach during a necropsy Sunday, said John Calambokidis of the Cascadia Research Collective in Olympia. ``Certainly nothing that we could see in that odd series of items would account for a death threat,'' Calambokidis said. Analysis of tissue samples taken from Spot's carcass over the weekend could take weeks to several months to complete, according to a statement issued by Cascadia and the Marine Animal Resource Center of Seattle. Gretchen Steiger, a Cascadia research biologist, said Spot seemed to be behaving normally and showed no sign of distress or injury before dying.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of May 29-June 4:
DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Would Have To Use Recycled Paper Under New Law
DOC.TEXT: The nation's toughest newspaper recycling law has been approved in Suffolk County on Long Island, where all major papers will be required to use 40 percent recycled newsprint in their editions by the end of 1996. The measure was approved May 29 by a 12-6 vote in the county Legislature. A group representing 64 daily papers in the state criticized the law. ``Any use of recycled paper should be market driven,'' said John Kutzer, executive director of the New York Newspaper Publishers Association. ``We feel local government is perhaps going overboard with these requirements.'' The law would apply to all daily and weekly newspapers printed, sold, or distributed in Suffolk County, provided their Suffolk circulation is 20,000 or more a week. Advertising circulars are included if they meet the circulation requirement. The bill requires that newspapers be printed on stock containing at least 40 percent recycled paper by Dec. 31, 1996. Papers that do not comply would face a $500 fine each day. The publisher of Newsday, the largest circulation daily on Long Island, plans to challenge the law in court, said spokesman Sam Ruinsky. Newsday says it uses 17 percent recycled paper for printing. William K. Adler, manager of corporate relations for The New York Times, cited a voluntary agreement approved by the publishers' association in which they agreed to gradually increase the use of recycled paper. That plan set a goal of 40 percent by the year 2000. ``Since the state has initiated a coordinated program, attempts by individual counties to legislate their own timetables for recycled newsprint are counterproductive,'' said Adler. The Times is using 8 percent recycled fiber, he said.
DOC.HEAD: Florida Supreme Court Removes Newspaper Sales Tax Exemption
DOC.TEXT: The Florida Supreme Court ruled May 31 that the sales tax paid on the purchase of magazines should also be applied to newspapers. The court, in a 6-0 opinion, rejected an effort by magazine publishers to get the protection enjoyed by newspapers, and went further, deleting the newspaper exemption. ``Florida's statutory differentiation between ... magazines and newspapers for purposes of sales taxation burdens rights protected by the First Amendment,'' wrote Chief Justice Raymond Ehrlich. William Hyde, an attorney who represented the Florida Press Association, said an appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court is likely. ``It's making the acquisition of knowledge more difficult,'' he said. Laura Besvinick, an attorney representing The Miami Herald, said Florida's largest newspaper was considering an appeal to the nation's high court. ``We think that a tax on the press impermissibly burdens the First Amendment,'' she said. Only magazines sold over the counter were taxed before 1987, when the state extended the sales tax to a variety of services and to the sale of newspapers. The services tax was repealed in a political firestorm a few months later, but the status quo was not re-established. Newspapers regained their exemption while the tax was extended to the sale of all magazines. The Magazine Publishers of America, Inc., The Hearst Corp., Time, Inc., Golf Digest-Tennis, Inc. and others went to court to challenge the distinction.
DOC.HEAD: Daily News Lays Off Machinists
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News blamed reduced advertising revenue May 29 in announcing the layoff of 17 machinists as it continued bargaining over expired contracts at the tabloid. ``This is the beginning of the planned strategy of provoking the unions into strike action,'' said Theodore Kheel, adviser of the Allied Printing Trades Councils, the 10 unions negotiating with the News. ``No doubt there will be more of the same sort to come.'' The News said laid-off workers would get between two and six weeks pay, and three months medical coverage. This was to be coupled with a group outplacement seminar, for a total cost of $80,000, the News said. ``By terms of the existing agreements, management is permitted to determine the manning level in this department,'' said John T. Sloan, the News vice president of human resources. ``Our decision couldn't be further delayed in light of slowing economic conditions in the New York advertising marketplace.''
DOC.HEAD: Proposed Techs' Contract Goes to Union Vote
DOC.TEXT: Communications workers at The Associated Press will vote on a tentative contract agreement that management called fair but union leaders said was inadequate. The AP announced June 2 that it and Local 1314 of the Communication Workers of America had reached a tentative agreement on a contract calling for a ``managed care'' approach to control the cost of the medical plan. The agreement also calls for a $23.50 weekly increase in top-scale technician salaries in the first year and a $24 weekly boost in the second, raising the top-scale technician salary to $612 in 1991. Similar percentage increases were proposed for all other job classifications. D. Byron Yake, AP's director of human resources, called the package fair and predicted it would be approved. Leaders of the CWA local agreed to submit the proposed contract to their 300 members for a vote but said they would recommend it be rejected. Jim Peecook, president of the union local, said the health plan proposals represented ``a severe loss to those employees and their families.'' He also said the proposed increase in pension benefits was inadequate. Terms of the present contract were extended until July 2 pending the vote, the AP said.
