DOC.HEAD: Feds Probe Florida Newspapers' Advertising Network
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Justice Department is investigating the pricing practices at a network of 19 Florida newspapers that have grouped together to sell space to large advertisers. Florida Newspaper Advertising Network Inc., with offices in Orlando, learned of the investigation May 29 when demands for records were sent to member newspapers. Alfred E. Corey Jr., president of the network, said he is puzzled by the request because the group is just now being organized. ``We have never sold an ad,'' said Corey, who is advertising director of The St. Petersburg Times. The Justice Department declined to discuss the case. The network was formed to make it more convenient for big advertisers to reach several markets in the state. The newspapers, which pay membership dues based on their circulation, have hired New York-based Sawyer, Ferguson, Walker Co. as a third party to organize the network. Corey said the Florida group has planned to offer the same prices as on the newspapers' standard rate cards. The Justice Department's ``civil investigative demand'' seeks to receive by June 25 documents and information related to ``possible price-fixing and market allocation in the sale of print advertising in Florida.'' The demand seeks all documents related to production, advertising, rates, sales, discounts, distribution, pricing, promotion or marketing of advertising inserts. The demand also seeks all documents related to any proposed or actual agreement among Florida newspapers related to advertising inserts.
DOC.HEAD: Attorney Wins Damages From Paper
DOC.TEXT: An attorney was awarded $75,000 in damages by a jury who found he had been defamed when his photograph was published as part of a report in the Springfield Union-News on the sentencing of reputed organized crime figures. A jury in Hampden County Superior Court on May 29 found that Anthony J. Scibelli had been defamed by The Republican Co., publisher of the newspaper. Scibelli had claimed that his presence at the federal courthouse was not properly explained in the photograph, which pictured him with one of the defendants, or in the accompanying story, published Dec. 11, 1987. Scibelli claimed mental anxiety and emotional distress in his defamation action. The jury determined the newspaper was negligent and also found for Scibelli in his claim that he had been discredited and suffered mental anguish as a result. Newspaper attorney Joseph P. Pessolano said it is likely motions will be filed asking the judge to set aside the jury's findings, reduce the damage award or grant a new trial. Scibelli did not claim that he had been improperly identified or that he had suffered any loss of income as a result of the publication. He also did not claim that publication of the photograph was malicious. Scibelli told the jury that he went to the proceedings to provide ``aid and comfort'' to his father, Anthony C. Scibelli, 75, who was among the defendants in the racketeering and gambling cases. He testified he believed the publication of his photograph without explanation ``leaves me there as a defendant.''
DOC.HEAD: DA's Office Drops Charges Against Gonzo Journalist
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors asked for dismissal of drug possession, explosives and sexual assault charges against Hunter Thompson, saying their case against the ``gonzo'' journalist was not strong enough. The dismissal motions May 31 said potential witnesses had not cooperated with investigators from the district attorney's office. A statement from the prosecutor's office also said a preliminary hearing May 22 resulted in discrepancies between sworn testimony and previous statements to investigators. Thompson said the decision was ``a huge victory for all of us'' and called for a ``celebratory orgy'' at his favorite hangout, the Woody Creek Tavern in Aspen. Thompson, 53, earlier was ordered to stand trial June 25 on four felony and three misdemeanor charges. The charges stemmed from a visit to his home in Woody Creek last February by Gale Palmer-Slater of Port Huron, Mich., an entrepreneur and ex-pornographic film actress and producer. She claimed that Thompson grabbed her breast and threw a drink at her and that she saw him sniff cocaine during her hours-long visit to his home. Authorities subsequently searched Thompson's home and said they found LSD, cocaine, tranquilizers, marijuana and explosives. Thompson claimed the drugs had been left by guests over the years and were only turned up because his home was searched with a thoroughness inappropriate for a misdemeanor assault charge. Thompson is an author and journalist known for his accounts of political campaigns, shark hunts in Hawaii and the Hell's Angels. He often has laced his exaggerated first-person reports with accounts of his own drug and alcohol abuse.
DOC.HEAD: Affiliated Publications Acquires 80 Percent of ASM Communications
DOC.TEXT: Affiliated Publications Inc., parent of The Boston Globe, agreed to acquire 80 percent of the common stock of ASM Communications Inc., which publishes periodicals on the advertising and marketing industry. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. ASM publishes Adweek, which is a national network of seven weekly magazines covering the marketing and communications businesses, with a total circulation of 83,000. ASM also publishes Adweek's Marketing Week, Photo District News. Other properties include Marketing Computers, Adbank and Marketer's Guide to Media. The ASM publications will become part of Affiliated's specialty publishing and information subsidiary, BPI Communications Inc. BPI now publishes 15 specialty magazines, 29 annual directories, publishes and distributes specialty books under five imprints, and operates two book clubs.
DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Says Some Doonesbury Stamps Appearing
DOC.TEXT: ``Doonesbury'' protest stamps are starting to appear in the mail, the Postal Service said May 30. Cartoonist Garry Trudeau included a sheet of mock stamps, featuring Zonker Harris of the Doonesbury comic strip, in Sunday papers May 20. The stamps carry the legend ``Mad as Heck'' and ``Ticked Off'' and show a value of -5, which the comic strip indicates is -5 cents. The stamps were intended to protest the coming increase in postal rates from 25 cents to 30 cents. Postal Service spokesman Lou Eberhardt said an empty envelope from California bearing two of the stamps arrived at Postmaster Anthony Frank's office and that a few others have also been delivered.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Legal Threat Silences Student Editorial
DOC.TEXT: Two Saguaro High School science teachers threatened legal action to pressure the school newspaper to withhold an editorial exposing science department turmoil, editors said May 29. Editors of the Saguaro Sabercat said they decided not to publish an editorial because of the threats. Principal Herman Serignese acknowledged the existence of an power struggle in the department but would not commment on the cause. The paper's May 25 edition carried a headline, ``Department Suffers from Internal Conflicts,'' above a small box reading, ``Editor's Note: Due to the controversial nature of the staff editorial which was to appear in this space, we opted to remove it from this issue.'' The editorial says that younger science teachers, who instituted creative teaching methods and organized state science tournaments, excluded most veteran teachers from their activities. It adds that the more tenured teachers responded by banding together, and both factions committed ``one of the most unprofessional acts associated with the job'' by involving students in their squabbling. Serignese agreed that teachers had talked to students about the infighting but denied that the lines of strife were clearly drawn between new and veteran teachers.
DOC.HEAD: AIDS Columnist Assaulted in Restaurant
DOC.TEXT: A man who writes a newspaper column about his daily struggles with AIDS was thrown through a restaurant window, police said. Clifford Moyers, who writes a ``Living with AIDS'' column in the Columbia Tribune each Sunday, was hospitalized in stable condition, police said. Moyers said he was discussing gay rights with friends at a restaurant early May 27 when men at a neighboring table ``started making `faggot' remarks against us.'' He was thrown through a plate-glass window in the foyer. Two men were arrested and released on bond, police said.
DOC.HEAD: Soviet Business Weekly Begins U.S. Publication
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. edition of a private Soviet business weekly made its debut to coincide with the Bush-Gorbachev summit. ``The idea is to give practical information and objective information, which is more or less unusual for the Soviet press,'' said Vladimir Yakovlev, editor-in-chief of Commersant. The paper, aimed at the Soviet and foreign businesses in the Soviet Union, started publishing in Russian and English in January. It has a domestic circulation of 350,000 and the new Soviet-American edition is expected to attract up to 60,000 subscribers at an introductory rate of $165 a year. Commersant covers topics such as the launch and failure of joint ventures, the accurate but unofficial dollar exchange rate and Soviet government decisions affecting business. One piece in the summit issue compares the Soviet economy to a cramped leg _ ``you can move it neither forward nor backward nor can you remain still because of the pain.''
DOC.HEAD: Professor Tries To Take Mystery Out of Economics Through Column
DOC.TEXT: Economics professor Allen Smith, worried that people know too little about the policies that affect their financial lives, has started a new class _ with 825,000 potential students. Smith writes a common-sense economics column carried by 13 newspapers from Alabama to Oregon. ``People see (economics) as a very complex, mystical thing,'' said Smith, a professor of economics at Eastern Illinois Univesity. ``But, it's not that complex. Much of economics is just basic common sense.'' For Smith, it is a crusade. Most Americans do not understand the fundamental rules of economics, and their ignorance is bad for the nation, he said. Smith wants to affect national economic debate by teaching the public, and he's fascinated by the potential. ``I think more people are interested in economics and how it affects their future than some give them credit for,'' said Smith. ``I'm amazed at how many people you can have access to through newspapers.'' Smith said presidents and Congress have ignored the fundamental rules of economics at the nation's expense. He blames elected officials _ Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives _ for passing faulty economic programs for political gain and failing to tell the public the hard truth about taxes and spending.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Formalizes Dallas Jury Verdict; Denies Mistrial
DOC.TEXT: A state district judge has denied a request for a mistrial in the Dallas Times Herald's antitrust suit against The Dallas Morning News. State District Judge David West in Houston denied the request May 30 and entered a judgment against the Times Herald formalizing the May 8 verdict of Houston jurors against the newspaper. During jury deliberations, and in the motion for mistrial, attorneys for the Times Herald argued that West incorrectly defined antitrust law in a manner that was ``tantamount to an instructed verdict'' against the Times Herald. Layne Kruse, one of the Times Herald's trial attorneys, said the formal judgment was a necessary step for any appeal. The Times Herald had accused The Morning News and its parent company, Belo Corp., of violating state antitrust laws through a transaction with Universal Press Syndicate to acquire publication rights to 26 features and comics that were appearing in the Times Herald. The Times Herald alleged that the contract was an attempt by Belo Corp. to acquire a monopoly in the Dallas market. A Houston jury voted 10-2 against the Times Herald's claim.
DOC.HEAD: American Publishing Buys Beatrice Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: American Publishing Co. bought the Beatrice Daily Sun from Stauffer Communications Inc., the companies announced May 31. Kent Thomas, publisher of the Daily Sun the past 14 years, has elected to remain with Stauffer and probably will be reassigned after a brief ownership transition, said Stanley H. Stauffer, Stauffer board chairman. Neither the name of Thomas's successor nor the sale price was revealed in the announcement from Stauffer and Larry J. Perotto, president of American Publishing. Purchase of the 10,500-circulation daily newspaper gives American Publishing of West Frankfort, Ill., two dailies in Nebraska. It also owns the Sidney Telegraph. American is a subsidiary of Hollinger, Inc., a Canadian media company based in Toronto. Hollinger owns 80 dailies and 146 weekly newspapers worldwide, including the Daily Telegraph in London.
DOC.HEAD: Sharon Herald To Publish Sunday Edition
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Herald Co. said June 2 it plans to publish a Sunday edition beginning in the fall. Peggy Dunder, a 20-year veteran of The Herald, has been named editor of the Sunday edition, which will begin Sept. 9. The newspaper also plans to switch Saturday's edition from afternoon to morning. The Herald is one of 23 daily newspapers owned by Ottaway Newspapers Inc., a subsidiary of Dow Jones & Co. Inc. Ottaway acquired the 27,500-circulation afternoon paper in 1971.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: State Lawmaker Wants To Alter JOA Law
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. Carl Pursell will propose legislation to alter or repeal the law that allowed the joint operating agreement between The Detroit News and the Detroit Free Press, an aide said. Pursell plans to outline the bill at a news conference June 6, aide Gary Cates said. Pursell at first supported the Detroit JOA, but later opposed what he said could be ``a sweetheart relationship between the newspapers and the federal government.'' Under the Newspaper Preservation Act, JOAs let competing newspapers merge circulation, advertising, production and other business operations while maintaining separate news and editorial operations. Under the act, one of the newspapers must be defined as failing. Cates wouldn't discuss details of Pursell's proposed legislation, but existing JOAs likely would be unaffected.
DOC.HEAD: PhotoStream Advisory Panel Named
DOC.TEXT: An industry committee of editors, photo editors and production specialists will advise The Associated Press on the startup of its high-speed photo delivery and electronic darkroom systems. ``They represent the departments or sections of a newspaper that will be most involved with the new photo technology,'' said Hal Buell, assistant to the president for PhotoStream and the electronic darkrooms. PhotoStream is the name for the news cooperative's new, high-speed photo delivery system. The electronic darkrooms will replace current picture receivers at AP member newspapers. Buell said the advisory panel will offer guidance on the workaday aspects of newspaper editing and printing to ease the transition from classic print-handling to electronic picture-handling. The committee represents newspapers of all sizes. Its members, announced on May 29, are: Merle Becker, director of corporate development, Thomson Newspapers, Des Plaines, Ill.; Mark Bussell, photo editor, The New York Times; Charles Carroll, director of operations, Sarasota (Fla.) Herald-Tribune. Randy Cochran, graphics director, Scripps Howard Newspapers, Cincinnati; Michael Evans, photo editor, The Journal and Constitution, Atlanta; Stanley Farrar, assistant managing editor-graphics, The Seattle Times; Scott Harmsen, graphics editor, Kalamazoo (Mich.) Gazette. Barbara Henry, editor, Democrat and Chronicle, Rochester, N.Y., representing APME; Larry Hoffman, vice president of production, Ottaway Newspapers, Inc., Campbell Hall, N.Y.; Michael Jones, director of information systems, Knight-Ridder Inc., Miami. Bob Lynn, assistant managing editor-graphics, The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star, Norfolk, Va.; Kurt Mutschler, photo editor, The Times-Picayune, New Orleans; Bill Rinehart, retired ANPA vice president-technical and now an ANPA consultant. Barry Rothfield, senior managing editor, Westchester Rockland Newspapers Inc., White Plains, N.Y.; Gary Schell, assistant manager-quality, The Milwaukee Journal; Stephen Seidl, production manager, The Times Record, Brunswick, Maine. Larry Smith, vice president, Alexandria (La.) Daily Town Talk; Greg Stewart, production department, Tampa (Fla.) Tribune; Larry Strutton, president, The Sun, Baltimore. George Sweers, news illustration director, St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times; Tom Tondee, photo-graphics editor, The Inland Valley Daily Bulletin, Ontario, Calif.; Paul Willis, color technology manager, News and Sun-Sentinel, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
DOC.HEAD: Gabelli Raises Stake in Media General
DOC.TEXT: Money manager Mario J. Gabelli has boosted his stake in Media General Inc. to 17.84 percent of the communications company's class A common stock. Through several of his investment firms, Gabelli increased his interest by buying 269,000 shares between May 11 and May 24, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission on May 31. Gabelli's Gamco Investors Inc. and other Gabelli investment firms now control more than 4.5 million of the class A common shares in the Richmond, Va.-based company. His firms bought the stock at prices ranging from $27.54 a share to $28.50. Also during the period, Gamco sold 4,000 shares at a price of $27.62 to $28.12 each, the SEC documents said. Before the recent purchases, Gamco and the other Gabelli firms had 4.2 million shares, or a 16.77 percent stake in the family-run company. Media General's holdings include The Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader. Gabelli, Media General's largest class A shareholder, has maintained he is interested in the company only as an investment.
DOC.HEAD: Lindsey Sells Idaho Weekly to Idaho Press-Tribune
DOC.TEXT: Lindsey Publishing Inc. has sold the weekly Messenger-Index of Emmett to the Idaho Press-Tribune of Nampa. The sale was announced June 1. It leaves Lindsey, which once owned 16 newspapers mostly in Wyoming, with just the weekly Saratoga Sun in Saratoga, Who.
DOC.HEAD: Contract Rejected at Suburban Seattle Paper
DOC.TEXT: Employees of the Bellevue Journal-American, owned by Persis Corp. of Honolulu, rejected a contract offer recommended by their union. The vote was 28-4 at a meeting June 1, said Art Joyner, administrative officer of the Pacific Northwest Newspaper Guild. The offer included pay raises totaling 6 percent _ 2 percent pay in July followed by annual 1 percent increases until January 1993 _ plus signing bonuses of $250 for full-time employees and $200 for part-timers. The previous three-year contract expired Dec. 31, but most provisions remain in effect. Top scale for reporters is currently $471.01 a week.
DOC.HEAD: Fremont Tribune Employees Reject Union
DOC.TEXT: Employees at the Fremont Tribune rejected formation of a union 29-23 on May 31. The Graphic Communications International Union Local 520 wanted to organize a union. Publisher John McDougal said the union would have affected about 60 employees in production, advertising mailroom and news departments.
DOC.HEAD: Reporter Says He Didn't Commit Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Reports of his death have been greatly exaggerated. Not Elvis, but close; the King's friend James Kingsley, a longtime reporter for The Commercial Appeal. In ``E Is For Elvis,'' the new guide to the king of rock 'n' roll, there is a premature announcement of Kingsley's death _ by suicide. ``I was shocked,'' said Kingsley. ``I didn't know what to think.'' According to the book, ``James Kingsley, a friend of Elvis Presley who had grown up in the same North Memphis neighborhood as the star, was a reporter for the Memphis Commercial Appeal. ``Kingsley wrote about Elvis frequently and broke many news stories concerning his activities. On Feb. 22, 1989, Kingsley died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.'' The person who actually died of a gunshot wound on that date was another James Kingsley, 51, who was a friend of Elvis' and a movie stuntman. The reporter Kingsley said he did not grow up in Memphis, but his family and the Presleys knew each other in Tupelo, Miss. The two Kingsleys were not related.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Global Research Institute Announced During Gorbachev Visit
DOC.TEXT: British publishing magnate Robert Maxwell is putting up $50 million to help establish a global research center named for Mikhail Gorbachev. The $100 million Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology was announced June 3 during the Soviet president's visit to Minnesota. The institute will mix American, Soviet and European scientists and will be in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area. It will cope with issues ``that matter to humanity,'' such as environmental warming, communications, health and food, Maxwell said. The remaining $50 million is to be raised by Gov. Rudy Perpich and a committee of Minnesotans. The project got an immediate lift from Dwayne Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland Co., who donated $1 million.
DOC.HEAD: Policeman Ordered Arrested in Journalist's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A court on June 1 ordered the arrest of a high-ranking policeman in connection with the abduction and shooting death of a journalist who crusaded against human rights abuses in Sri Lanka. The order came after the mother of journalist Richard de Zoysa claimed Senior Police Superintendent Ronnie Gunasinghe was one of the six men who kidnapped her son from his home on Feb. 18. De Zoysa, a correspondent for the Rome-based Inter Press Service, was found dead two days later.
DOC.HEAD: Two Journalists Gunned Down After Filing Reports
DOC.TEXT: Two journalists were killed June 2 just minutes after completing reports about the ethnic violence that has turned Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province into a battleground, police said. No one claimed responsibility for the slayings of Ahmed Khan Kamal, a correspondent for Pakistan Press International, a small, privately owned news agency, and Muthair Naqpit, a reporter for Nawa-e-Waqt, a leading Urdu-language daily. The slayings occurred outside the telegraph office in Larkana, Ms. Bhutto's home town. They had just finished sending stories to their editors about a news conference with Sindhi nationalists when they were surrounded by gunmen and shot. For nearly three weeks ethnic violence has plagued southern Sindh Province, where more than 350 people have died and thousands more have been wounded. The trouble is rooted in deep hatred between native Sindhis and the Mohajirs, descendents of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. Sindhis accuse the better-educated Mohajirs of taking the best jobs and most valuable land.
DOC.HEAD: Valvano Agrees to Three-Year ABC Deal
DOC.TEXT: Jim Valvano, forced out last winter as North Carolina State basketball coach, has agreed to a three-year deal with ABC for a reported $900,000. Dennis Swanson, the president of ABC Sports, said June 4 that Valvano will be teamed on basketball telecasts with Brent Musburger, who recently signed with the network after being let go by CBS. Keith Jackson and Dick Vitale will be the other team for ABC. Valvano agreed to a buyout of his contract on April 7 following unsubstantiated allegations that State players had been involved in fixed games. Valvano had also been criticized about a lack of academic progress in the program, which was placed on probation for violations involving complimentary tickets and sneakers. He finally agreed to have his lifetime contract bought out for $600,000. Swanson said he doesn't think Valvano will present image problems for the network. ``We think the keys are a knowledge of basketball and the ability to communicate,'' he said. ``We think Jim has both.''
DOC.HEAD: CNN Book Tells All on Turner and Company
DOC.TEXT: A new book on the birth of Ted Turner's Cable News Network recalls some of the most famous stories about early days at the all-news channel. Author Hank Whittemore's ``CNN: The Inside Story'' was released June 1 by Little, Brown and Company to coincide with the network's 10th birthday. Among the stories it tells is the time a light bulb exploded in the CNN Washington bureau and ignited the clothing of on-camera reporter Dan Schorr. And the time weatherman Stu Siroka was victimized by the Chromakey process, which allows one picture to be placed behind another. All viewers saw was Siroka's bald head, suspended above the CNN weather map. Whittemore spent six months interviewing present and former CNN producers, reporters, anchors and administrators. It's a spirited and sometimes bizarre tale of how Turner, equipped with $100 million and even more chutzpah, screamed, bullied, sued, cajoled and bankrolled his way into television history by launching the first 24-hour all-news network. Whittemore, the author of a best seller called ``The Super Cops,'' magazine articles and television documentaries, is on a tour to promote the book. He still finds it difficult to explain Turner's complex personality, though an encounter at an awards dinner in Kansas City may provide some insight: ``He comes up to me and says `What are you going to write about me? Just don't make me out to be an ass,''' Whittemore said. ``Then he looks around and kind of beams, and says `Well, maybe I was.' ``I felt like I was in a Harold Robbins novel,'' Whittemore said. ``The man will say the most outrageous things and you wonder `Is the man just not thinking or is he being very calculating?'''
DOC.HEAD: TV Cameraman Bitten by Tiger but Not Seriously Injured
DOC.TEXT: A cameraman for television station KTVH escaped serious injury May 30 when he was bitten in the leg by a Bengal tiger while doing a story at a local circus. Mark Tee said he was perched on a stool and was petting the tiger, with its trainer nearby, when the big cat began to rise up as if it were going to put its head in his lap. Tee tried to protect himself and the tiger sank its fangs into his left thigh. The animal let him go on an order from the trainer, Tee said.
DOC.HEAD: Biloxi Former Mayor Files Suit
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Gerald Blessey, who was prosecuted for an alleged corruption scandal, filed a $20 million libel lawsuit May 31 against WLOX-TV and its network, American Broadcasting Companies Inc. The lawsuit claims Blessey was maliciously defamed in two broadcasts: one on a national TV special titled ``Lying, Cheating and Stealing in America'' in June 1989, and a report on the WLOX evening news in February that said government investigators had implicated the former mayor in a kickback scheme. Blessey has twice gone on trial on charges that he abused public office as mayor. In March, he was acquitted on federal extortion and conspiracy charges. In August a jury failed to reach a verdict in his trial on mail fraud and conspiracy charges. WLOX President John Hash declined to comment on specifics of the lawsuit, but said: ``Gerald Blessey is entitled to his belief that he's been wronged. And we are entitled to our belief that we have not wronged Gerald Blessey. We're sure that all the facts will come out and that we will prevail.'' ABC lawyers were not immediately available for comment. The former mayor says the ABC show on lying and cheating severely damaged his reputation and ability to earn a living.
DOC.HEAD: Televangelist Buys Two Florida TV Stations
DOC.TEXT: A company headed by televangelist Paul F. Crouch has purchased Channel 21 in Fort Pierce and Channel 13 in the Florida Keys from Palmetto Broadcasting, Federal Communications Commission documents show. Channel 21's sale price was $630,090. The price for Channel 13 was not disclosed. Both sales need FCC approval. Since Channel 13's launching last September, the station has broadcast only one program: ``Praise the Lord,'' an evangelical Christian education program from Crouch's Trinity Broadcasting Network. Otherwise, Channel 13's frequency is used by the Voice of America to broadcast TV Marti to Cuba. Papers filed with the FCC stress Crouch's intent to provide an array of education programs on Channel 21, from high school and vocational courses to anti-drug shows. Crouch has said his network has 165 stations worldwide.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev emerged from the summit with the trade agreement he wants, but members of Congress say it won't do him any good until he relaxes his pressure on breakaway Lithuania. In fact, a leading House Democrat said Sunday that President Bush can expect challenges from Congress on how he handled the U.S.-Soviet summit in general. ``In other words, is the Congress of the United States going to ratify the Bush approach to the Soviet Union, which is not to jam it to them while they're weak, to lay back a little bit, not to try to squeeze every drop out of that lemon?'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. Aspin, appearing on NBC-TV, said that even before Bush signed the trade pact Gorbachev desperately sought, the American president faced a ``growing unhappiness'' from right-leaning Republicans who see Bush's actions as too conciliatory towards the Soviets.

In his first trip to the nation's heartland, Mikhail Gorbachev charmed and cajoled, then got down to business _ the business of renewing old corporate ties and building new ones to revive the Soviet economy. In a seven-hour visit to the Twin Cities on Sunday, the Soviet leader, fresh from the Washington summit, was both showman and salesman, making impromptu forays into crowds chanting ``Gorby! Gorby!'' and then urging corporate luminaries to invest in his country. Mrs. Gorbachev, meanwhile, took an unexpected shopping trip, stopping at a Mexican deli and a drugstore, where she bought bubble gum and macadamia nuts, but turned away a Snickers bar, saying, ``Nyet, Nyet, I'm on a diet.'' She also got some insight into the mechanics of capitalism, questioning workers about salaries and work policies. The Gorbachevs flew late Sunday to San Francisco for a day before heading back to Moscow in the evening.

Mechanical problems are starting to take a toll on NASA's shuttle schedule, and the space agency is wondering whether the troubles are random or somehow related. Columbia stands silently at Launch Pad A this week, grounded first by a bad cooling valve and now by a mysterious hydrogen leak that threatens to push its astronomy mission into July or later. Hardly a month before, one of Discovery's power units had to be replaced at NASA's other shuttle launch pad, an unprecedented job that delayed the Hubble Space Telescope's ride into orbit. Despite the breakdowns, few blame the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

``City of Angels,'' a satire of gumshoe fiction and Hollywood, was named best musical of the Broadway season, and the Tony Award for best play went to an adaptation of John Steinbeck's ``The Grapes of Wrath.'' ``City of Angels'' won six Tonys overall, more than any other production, in a ceremony Sunday at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. The event was televised by CBS. The big loser was August Wilson's ``The Piano Lesson,'' which won no Tonys despite five nominations, including best play, and the Pulitzer Prize for drama. Tyne Daly, formerly of television's ``Cagney and Lacey,'' was named best actress in a musical as the brassy stage mother Mama Rose in ``Gypsy,'' a role originated by Ethel Merman 30 years ago. The show also won as best revival.

DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III headed for Copenhagen on Monday to take up a nine-point Western plan on Germany's military future with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. The plan would allow the Red Army to keep troops in East Germany for now. The goal is to induce the Soviets to drop their objections to NATO membership for the new and stronger Germany that will emerge when East Germany is combined with West Germany. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev registered his concerns about his country's mighty neighbor and onetime deadly foe in his summit talks here with President Bush. They parted agreeing to disagree, but with the Soviet leader also saying he had surveyed some ``new possible perspectives'' with Bush.

Former San Francisco mayor Dianne Feinstein got encouraging news Monday from two new polls in the California governor's race as she and scores of candidates played out the final hours of primary campaigns in nine states. In the often nasty Democratic primary campaign, Feinstein maintained a lead over state Attorney General John Van de Kamp in the latest statewide surveys. For months the two candidates have attacked each other on issues ranging from abortion and crime to who could best handled the state's fiscal affairs. Other new polls showed close races Tuesday for gubernatorial nominations in Alabama, Iowa and New Mexico. In North Carolina, a runoff between two Democrats will determine who challenges Republican Sen. Jesse Helms, while four Montana Republicans were vying for the chance to run against Democratic Sen. Max Baucus. Baucus was among seven incumbent senators facing token primary opposition at most on Tuesday.

Police with rifles blocked roads to Beijing's university area Monday and heavy security elsewhere in the city stifled dissent on the first anniversary of the bloody demise of China's democracy movement. All gates to Beijing University, a center of last year's political activism, were locked at 8 p.m. The public was barred from Tiananmen Square, the center of the protests, for the fourth day. The few individuals who tried to protest the military crackdown were quickly arrested. Outside China, people from Mongolia to Paris and Czechoslovakia remembered the anniversary with hunger strikes, marches and candlelight vigils. The largest commemmoration was in Hong Kong, where tens of thousands of people jammed Victoria Park and watched videotapes of Chinese dissidents in exile urging people not to forget the Beijing killings.

Help Wanted. Baylor College of Medicine seeks 16 good sleepers to spend a month lying down. Salary uncertain, but benefits include breakfast in bed _ lunch and dinner, too. It sounds like a couch potato's dream, but there's a catch to the deal being offered by researchers David Cardus and Wesley McTaggart. When they say the sleepers will be confined to bed, they're not kidding. The people they select won't be allowed to get up for the the entire month, and they'll spend part of their time spinning around in a space-age sleep chamber that looks like something straight out of the movie ``Aliens.'' The experiments also will require the research subjects to be hooked up to sensors that monitor a dozen bodily functions.

It's raz, dva, tri strikes, ``You're out!'' at Moscow State University, where Soviets were learning the American national pastime while President Mikhail S. Gorbachev toured the American heartland. The Soviets started playing baseball four years ago, hoping to field a team at the Summer Games in 1992 when it will be a medal sport for the first time. But hopes are not high on the Astroturf at a 1,000-seat baseball stadium built on the university grounds last September. ``I don't think a Soviet team will make it to the Olympics this time around,'' said Alexander E. Semyonov.

DOC.HEAD: Denial of Holocaust Raises Free Speech Issue
DOC.TEXT: Professor Bernard Notin wrote last year that the Nazi gas chambers never existed. French Jews who lost relatives in the Holocaust decided in March to teach him a lesson. Minutes after Notin began an evening economics lecture, about 60 Jewish leaders, students and survivors of the death camps walked into his classroom at Jean Moulin University and took over. They sat Notin in the second row and informed him he could not leave, then told the 20 students their professor had defiled the memory of 6 million Jews who perished in Hitler's extermination program. ``Look, Mr. Notin,'' an aging woman said, revealing the number Nazi guards had tattooed on her forearm. ``How do you explain this tattoo? We are part of the 80,000 French at Auschwitz and only 3 percent came back.'' Notin, a leading member of Jean-Marie Le Pen's far-right National Front, looked at his shoes. Some of his students wept, horrified by the survivors' accounts. The confrontation was a high point in the ``Notin affair,'' which has provoked debate on political interference in schools and whether laws against bigotry restrict freedom of speech. A recent wave of anti-Semitic vandalism contributed an extra bitterness. It included desecration of graves and mutilation of a corpse in a Jewish cemetery at Carpentras, southern France. ``All this was bound to happen,'' said Jean Levy, a Jewish leader in Lyon. ``The proposals of Le Pen are so racist ... his language is the point of no return.'' After the classroom takeover, Notin was suspended as an associate law professor at the Lyon university and asked to resign from its science council. He continued to teach economics, however. Michel Noir, mayor of Lyon, threatened on April 19 to block the university's expansion into a publicly owned building unless it acted against Notin. That prompted one of Notin's few public statements. He insisted on ``the right of everyone to his liberty of opinion, to defy the powers that be, to criticize and to doubt.'' No one accused him of preaching his ideas in class, but university officials feel he should not have lent the institution's name to those ideas. On May 14, the 48-member Administration Council of Jean Moulin University voted to begin proceedings to dismiss Notin. It also suspended granting a doctorate to Georges Pinault, a lecturer in Celtic languages who once described Adolf Hitler as the ``greatest man of the 20th century.'' ``They can't write in the name of history and academic freedom that the gas chambers didn't exist,'' Noir said in an interview. ``These aren't opinions. They are crimes.'' Unlike the U.S. Constitution, which guarantees free speech, France's charter allows the government to curb expression. A 1972 law sets fines for racist or anti-Semitic statements. The National Assembly recently extended it to cover ``revisionism'' _ denying the Holocaust occurred. Violators would be barred from public jobs or elected office for five years. Le Pen, who has called the gas chambers ``a detail'' of history, considers the law undemocratic. ``Who is charged to say what one can and cannot say in a free country?'' he asked in an interview. As for Jews, he said, ``if they are French, there's no problem. I'm not anti-Semitic.'' Le Pen insists his party's main political targets are immigrants. Daniel Drai, 25, a soft-spoken medical student who led the invasion of Notin's classroom, said: ``There's only a small difference between revisionism and Carpentras. Revisionism erases the dead. Desecration kills them all over again.'' For him, Mayor Noir and others, a critique of the media that appeared under Notin's name in the August 1989 edition of the academic review Economy and Society fits the description of revisionism. One paragraph says visiting concentration camps is a ``hardly credible'' way to prove gas chambers existed, and describes accounts of survivors as ``hearsay.'' Indignation over the article eventually led to allegations that many members of Le Pen's National Front were among the 400 faculty of Jean Moulin University. At least 10 known members of the party teach there, including Notin and Bernard Gollnisch, a member of the European Parliament. The university, which overlooks the Rhone River, is named for a Resistance leader tortured to death in Lyon in 1943 by the Gestapo. It was born of tensions at the old University of Lyon II during the 1968 student upheavals in France. Lyon II split in 1973. A new, left-wing school with the original name offered social sciences, and rightist Jean Moulin took business, finance and law, plus history, philosophy and languages. Critics say the university was a natural choice when the National Front sought to broaden its intellectual base. Colette Demaiziere, dean of French, geography, history and letters, said the criticism was overblown and accused Noir, the mayor, of political opportunism. ``How can we reproach someone for belonging to a legal party?'' she asked. ``We've never been able to prove someone here proselytized for the Front, and if they did, I'm not sure the students would respond.'' For students, sipping soft drinks in the university cloister, the Notin affair took a back seat to impending final exams. ``We don't even think about politics,'' said Philippe Cumunel, a 23-year-old finance major. ``They've put burdens on our backs we don't even care about.'' Cumunel said he saw nothing wrong with firing Notin and added, to nods from others: ``They should get the communists out of here too. These Stalinists who deny the Gulag are no better than the Nazi regime.''

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Thursday, June 14, the 165th day of 1990. There are 200 days left in the year. This is Flag Day. Today's Highlight in History: Fifty years ago, on June 14, 1940, German troops entered Paris during World War Two. The same day, in German-occupied Poland, the Nazis opened their concentration camp at Auschwitz, where an estimated three to four million people, many of them Jews, were exterminated as part of Hitler's ``Final Solution.'' On this date: In 1775, the United States Army was founded. In 1777, the Continental Congress in Philadelphia adopted the Stars and Stripes as the national flag. In 1801, former American Revolutionary War Gen. Benedict Arnold died in London. In 1841, the first Canadian parliament opened in Kingston. In 1846, settlers proclaimed the free republic of California at Sonoma. In 1917, Gen. John Pershing arrived in Paris during World War I. In 1922, Warren G. Harding became the first president to be heard on radio, as Baltimore station WEAR broadcast his speech dedicating the Francis Scott Key memorial at Fort McHenry. In 1928, the Republican National Convention nominated Herbert Hoover for president on the first ballot. In 1954, President Eisenhower signed an order adding the words ``under God'' to the Pledge of Allegiance. In 1967, the space probe Mariner 5 was launched from Cape Kennedy on a flight that would take it past Venus. In 1982, Argentine forces surrendered to British troops on the disputed Falkland Islands _ on the 74th day of a conflict that claimed some 1,200 lives. Ten years ago: Some 3,000 dignitaries attended a private memorial service for Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, who died two days earlier at age 70. Five years ago: The 17-day hostage ordeal of TWA Flight 847 began as a pair of Lebanese Shiite Moslem extremists seized the jetliner shortly after takeoff from Athens, Greece. The plane flew to Beirut, then to Algiers. One year ago: House Democrats chose Richard Gephardt of Missouri to be majority leader and William H. Gray of Pennsylvania to be majority whip. Actress Zsa Zsa Gabor was arrested for slapping a Beverly Hills motorcycle patrolman. Former President Reagan received an honorary knighthood from Britain's Queen Elizabeth II. Today's Birthdays: Singer Burl Ives is 81. Actress Dorothy McGuire is 72. Actor-director Sam Wanamaker is 71. ABC newsman and former White House news secretary Pierre Salinger is 65. Author Jerzy Kosinski is 57. Real estate developer Donald Trump is 44. Actor Eddie Mekka is 38. Olympic speed skater Eric Heiden is 32. Singer Boy George is 29. Thought for Today: ``One may no more live in the world without picking up the moral prejudices of the world than one will be able to go to hell without perspiring.'' _ H.L. Mencken, American author and journalist (1880-1956).

DOC.NOTE: $Adv16
For Release Saturday, June 16
DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, June 16, the 167th day of 1990. There are 198 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: Fifty years ago, on June 16, 1940, a pro-communist government was installed in the Baltic state of Lithuania, following an invasion of Soviet forces. (Neighboring Latvia and Estonia underwent a similar fate in the days that followed.) On this date: In 1567, Mary, Queen of Scots, was imprisoned in Lochleven Castle in Scotland. In 1858, in a speech in Springfield, Ill., Senate candidate Abraham Lincoln said the slavery issue had to be resolved, declaring, ``A house divided against itself cannot stand.'' In 1883, baseball's first ``Ladies' Day'' took place as the New York Gothams offered free admission for women to a game against the Cleveland Spiders. (New York won, 5-2.) In 1903, Ford Motor Company was incorporated. In 1932, President Hoover and Vice President Charles Curtis were renominated by the Republican National Convention in Chicago. In 1933, the National Industrial Recovery Act became law. (It was later struck down by the U.S. Supreme Court.) In 1955, Pope Pius XII excommunicated Argentine President Juan Domingo Peron _ a ban that was lifted eight years later. In 1961, Soviet ballet dancer Rudolf Nureyev defected to the West while his troupe was in Paris. In 1963, Valentina Tereshkova became the first female space traveler when Vostok 6 was launched from the Soviet Union on a three-day mission. In 1970, 20 years ago, Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, N.J., became the first black to win a mayoral election in a major Northeast city. In 1976, riots broke out in the black South African township of Soweto. In 1976, U.S. Ambassador to Lebanon Francis E. Meloy Jr. and an aide were kidnapped and shot to death in Beirut. In 1977, Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Leonid Brezhnev was named president, becoming the first person to hold both posts simultaneously. In 1978, President Carter and Panamanian leader Omar Torrijos exchanged the instruments of ratification of the Panama Canal treaties. Ten years ago: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled, 5-4, that newly created biological organisms could be patented under federal law. Five years ago: On day three of the hijacking of TWA Flight 847, the hijackers released a letter signed by 29 passengers, appealing to President Reagan to refrain from launching a military rescue. One year ago: Hungarians paid homage to former Premier Imre Nagy and four associates who were executed for leading the anti-Soviet revolt of 1956. Today's Birthdays: Washington Post Chairman Katharine Graham is 73. Author Erich Segal is 53. Author Joyce Carol Oates is 52. Actress Joan Van Ark is 47. Boxer Roberto Duran is 39. Thought for Today: ``History teaches us that men and nations behave wisely once they have exhausted all other alternatives.'' _ Abba Eban, Israeli diplomat.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Confronts a New Era of Soviet Political Power
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Like many an embattled politician before him, Mikhail S. Gorbachev took a crack at Congress, worked his smiling way through crowds, counter-punched his critics and made the most of incumbency. During his week in the West, the Soviet president rebuked those who call him weak or consider his nation enfeebled by the throes of economic change. He scolded the American Congress for double standards and told its leaders they should not meddle in the affairs of his legislature. It was a telegenic combination of grand ceremony and feisty politics, and it would have played well for an American politician in Moscow. That may not apply in the opposite direction. The overwhelming Soviet concerns are domestic and economic. It is a time of wrenching change from communism to a market system Gorbachev said his government is trying to build from the ground up. It is no easy matter. ``It is difficult to be a politician nowadays, because a politician used to be a guy who sat in his study and was an analyst,'' Gorbachev told congressional leaders, ``but now one cannot divorce himself from the populist sentiments, from the sentiments of those who do not want to be simple bystanders.'' Senate and House leaders can understand that. They have their political problems, too. But for them, it is traveled territory and they know the rules. In the changing Soviet system, it is new terrain. Gorbachev talked with remarkable candor about his problems in what he called a genuine revolution. He also warned the West against seeking to take advantage of it, saying that turmoil in either system will mean trouble for the other. When congressional leaders complained about his clampdown against independence in Lithuania, Gorbachev countered with Panama. ``Why do you allow, for example, your own government, your own administration, to invade Panama, which is a sovereign country, if you love freedom so much?'' he demanded. ``Where were you when Panama was invaded, and why that double standard?'' It didn't match the 1959 kitchen debate with which Richard M. Nixon, as vice president, gained political capital in a Moscow argument with Nikita S. Khrushchev. But it had the flavor. More substantively, Gorbachev went home from his summit journey Monday night with a preliminary trade agreement, a pact he sought in his effort to ease Soviet economic problems. It is conditional and will not take effect before the Soviet parliament passes a law guaranteeing the right of Jewish emigration. But he got a deal, unexpectedly. In the scoring system of American politics, all that should serve to strengthen his hand at home, at least for a while. But those rules don't necessarily apply. Nor can the Soviet system be measured the old way. Gorbachev and his allies have changed it too drastically. That is both their achievement and their problem. One product of the reformed system is the rise of Boris N. Yeltsin, Gorbachev's leading rival, newly _ but narrowly _ elected president of Russia, the biggest of the 15 Soviet republics. Putting a Gorbachev spin on that situation, Vitaly Churkin of the foreign ministry said in Washington that Yeltsin might actually turn out to be an asset to the central government, helping to mobilize popular support for radical economic reform. The administration position is that the United States wants perestroika to succeed, but that American policy is not tied to Gorbachev or any other single leader. Bush advisers keep close watch on ups and downs in Soviet politics; trying to assess what one called the blips and instabilities of the situation. While Bush has said that it is not his role to try to sort out who should lead the Soviet Union, there is an administration stake in Gorbachev's survival as leader of the other superpower. At and after the summit, Bush emphasized his personal relationship with Gorbachev. He said Sunday they have agreed to meet on a regular basis, perhaps annually. The Soviet reform policies the administration supports are Gorbachev policies. One of Bush's top advisors said Gorbachev may be as strong as any recent leader in terms of Kremlin politics. But administration analysts admit they do not have a good handle on the relationship between the old fashioned system of Kremlin leadership and the new era of political power in the country. They doubt their Soviet counterparts understand it very well, either.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Entertainment Prez Iger Talks Programming
DOC.TEXT: It's a tough time of year for television executives. First, there was the May sweeps period. Now, it's time for the network affiliates' annual conventions, where the questions often come loaded. Sandwiched between were the all-important fall schedule announcements, an event tantamount to a presidential candidate picking a running mate _ and not one of the Big Three wants anything in the fall lineup that gets the reception Dan Quayle got. So here is Robert Iger, entertainment president of No. 2-ranked ABC, coming off his first year in his big new job. He likes it, thank you very much, even if things are a bit hectic of late. And almost as much as he likes the job, it appears, Iger likes to take chances. He calls them gambles ``where we have nothing to lose.'' But in the high-stakes, out-of-kilter television world, there always is something to lose. Most of the time, it's your job. The 39-year-old former weatherman who now runs programming at ABC has an affinity for the weird. This is the man who brought you ``Twin Peaks'' and is about to bring you singing police officers in ``CopRock.'' This is the man who says, ``I don't believe in being No. 1 at all costs.'' Do the guys over at parent company Capital Cities know this? They must. They put him in this position last March. Iger's predecessors include Walt Disney Co. Chairman Michael Eisner, producer Fred Silverman, Fox Inc. Chairman Barry Diller, and, most recently, Brandon Stoddard. No, Iger says, he doesn't have a quick plan to bump off NBC as the top-rated network. ``You don't walk in and say we're going to be No. 1 this year.'' Rather, Iger says, you shoot for innovative programming, for winning certain time periods, for incremental battles that eventually add up to winning the war. So how did Iger, a 15-year ABC veteran who came up through its sports division, devise the upcoming season? ``There were time periods we weren't going to worry about,'' he says. Such as? ``Thursdays at 8'' (when ``The Cosby Show'' is on NBC), and ``Sundays at 7'' (when ``60 Minutes'' is on CBS). The time periods ABC targeted, Iger says, were Saturday and Wednesday nights. To the former, it moved ``China Beach'' and ``Twin Peaks.'' On the latter night will be ``The Wonder Years'' and ``Growing Pains.'' Conversations with Iger these days tend to center on ``Twin Peaks,'' the much-hyped nighttime soap opera created by film director David Lynch and former ``Hill Street Blues'' writer Mark Frost. Most questions about the series that gives new meaning to the adjective ``surreal'' pertain to why it closed this season without solving the murder of homecoming queen Laura Palmer. Obviously that caused some concern, Iger says in his Century City office. ``I called Mark up _ that was before we had ever aired the pilot. I wanted to maximize the show's potential. And to do that, I thought there should be more viewer satisfaction. I was pretty forceful about it in terms of expressing my thoughts. ... But I never told them what to do,'' he says. Iger calls himself a ``Peaks freak.'' And he was the driving force in getting the show on the network, even when some bigwigs at Cap Cities thought it sounded crazy. ``Peaks'' has been picked up for fall, despite recent lackluster ratings. Will it do better? ``I hope so,'' Iger says. The upcoming season presented a number of problems for ABC. Namely, what do you put on after ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' the hottest show on television? ``Elvis'' died there, as did other programming tries. Iger's solution? He cloned it. In the fall, ``America's Funniest ... Part II'' will be broadcast at 8:30 p.m. EDT Sundays. And despite a glut of home video hybrids on other networks and local affiliates, Iger said he's not worried about his own show. ``I think `Home Videos' has proven to be an extremely durable product,'' he says. Asked to explain how he decides when to cancel a show that is a critical success but a ratings loser, Iger replies: ``It's very difficult. That's probably one of the most difficult things we have to do. Yes, we're in this business to be No. 1 and yes, we're in this to make money, but if a show is still successful demographically (i.e. in certain age-group audiences), that can't be ignored.''

Elsewhere in television ... ANOTHER TV FIRST: Greg LeMond, Sports Illustrated's 1989 ``Sportsman of the Year,'' will do his first national commercial, pedaling his bicycle for Taco Bell's ``Tacos-to-Go'' summer campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Justin Wilson, A Man for All Seasonings, Opens New Cajun Cooking Show
DOC.TEXT: Justin Wilson, the celebrated Cajun raconteur and cook, had just spent the day moving into his new house north of New Orleans, across Lake Pontchartrain. The man for all seasonings had poured himself a dollop of merlot, a wine he favors, to talk to a telephone caller. ``How'm I doin'? I'm feelin' so good it mus' be illegal,'' he said, lapsing into the famed Cajun accent thicker than file gumbo. Wilson has been helping make an obscure regional cuisine a fundamental part of American cooking since his first cookbook in 1964. His first PBS series, ``Cookin' Cajun,'' aired nationwide on PBS and cable for more than 10 years. At 76, Wilson is launching his fourth TV cooking show, ``Louisiana Cookin': Home Grown,'' showcasing the fish, game, vegetables, spicy culinary style and anecdotes of Acadiana, his beloved south Louisiana homeland. Wilson, who's appeared on commercial TV for ``Cajun flavor'' potato chips, is proud of the new show, his first in five years. It is running or will run on more than 200 public television stations across the country. ``Cajun cooking is the ability to take what you have and create a good dish and season it right, with salt, pepper and a few good things like mint or garlic, bay leaf, cayenne pepper, bell pepper, onion, celery,'' Wilson said. ``It isn't all that hard, but so few people know how to take what they have and put it together and season it properly,'' he said. ``It's creative cooking _ that's all it is.'' ``Home Grown'' is not a show to watch hungry. The opener features brown rice pudding with meringue; other ``guest stars'' are shrimp, oysters, catfish, crawfish, rabbit, venison, mirliton, andouille and boudin sausage, crab, okra, pecans, 'gator, greens, sweet potato and duck. ``I am a gourmet, but I am more of a gourmand,'' he explained. ``A gourmet is somebody that's an epicurean. But a gourmand is somebody that's a P-I-G hog and that's what I am.'' ``JOOS-tahn'' is more than that. Wilson, who has recorded 27 albums of Cajun humor, also is the author of five cookbooks (the latest due out this month) and co-author of two Cajun humor books and a children's book, ``Cajun Fables.'' At an age when many people have been retired for a decade, Wilson makes about 200 personal appearances a year. ``I'm not slowing down,'' he said. ``They might catch up with me.'' A celebrated after-dinner speaker, Wilson began his career in public speaking in 1935. A safety engineer, consultant and lecturer, he's also taught ``human relations'' to police in six states, including Louisiana. ``I met Will Rogers in 1935,'' Wilson said. ``I guess he had more influence on me than anybody to keep telling Cajun stories. He told me always to tell 'em clean, and always tell your audience something serious _ or they'll think you're a complete fool.'' Wilson calls himself a ``half-bleed'' Cajun. His father was Louisiana's commissioner of agriculture for 32 years, and his mother, Olivet, was Louisiana French who taught him how to cook. ``She was a great improviser,'' Wilson said. ``She'd cook a dish and we'd go `Mama, w'at's this here, hanh?' And she'd say, `Children, that's a mus-go. It mus' go down yo' t'roat.''' Here's Justin Wilson's recipe for a shrimp dip to snack on while watching ``Home Grown:''
DOC.HEAD: Ingredients:
DOC.TEXT: 8 ounces cream cheese, softened one-quarter cup fresh lemon juice 1 pound shrimp meat, boiled, peeled and coarsely chopped 2 cups finely chopped green onions 1 cup mayonnaise Louisiana hot sauce or ground cayenne pepper, to taste 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce salt, to taste
DOC.HEAD: Preparation:
DOC.TEXT: Stir together the cream cheese and lemon juice. Stir chopped shrimp and green onions into softened cream cheese. Add enough mayonnaise to give mixture the consistency of a dip. Stir in the hot sauce, Worcestershire sauce and salt. Put into a serving dish and chill. This dish is a lot better if made a day or several hours ahead. Serve with crackers, melba toast or chips. Serves 12.

Elsewhere in television ... BEASTIES ALERT! DEPT.: ``Beauty and the Beast,'' the lush CBS romance about a girl and her man-beast that attracted a cult of fans but low ratings, returns to the airwaves this summer in ``selected rebroadcasts,'' the network says. ``B&B,'' which stars Linda Hamilton and Ron Perlman, respectively, will air at 9 p.m. EDT Saturdays beginning June 9. ``Wiseguy,'' another low-rated series with a loyal fan following that has been relegated to backup status on the network's fall schedule, will be rerun Thursdays at 9 p.m. EDT beginning June 28.

DOC.HEAD: Shuffling `Dead' Liven Up Zombie Remake
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Old zombies never die, they just stagger back for remakes. The flesh-eaters that grossed out movie-goers in 1969's ``Night of the Living Dead'' and its two sequels are back, as the low-budget black and white horror classic is remade at an abandoned dairy farm about 45 miles southwest of Pittsburgh. The remake's plot, like the original's, is as simple and slow-moving as the shuffling dead themselves: Boy meets girl in cemetery. Boy and girl meet zombie. Zombie gets hungry, eats boy. Girl flees. Girl crashes Mercedes, meets other survivors in desolate farmhouse. Many more zombies get hungry. People in farmhouse nail boards over doors and windows. People bicker over escape plans. Zombies descend on farmhouse and break through boarded-up doors and windows. ``This is not a splatter movie. It's like film noir _ but it's in color,'' says rookie director Tom Savini, formerly a special effects whiz. The hue of choice, it seems, is blood red, according to stills viewed at the Washington County set. One of the farmhouse-bound survivors can't cope and eats a shotgun blast. A creature deemed ``the autopsy zombie'' wears a coroner's handiwork on his chest, and another wanders around with a crowbar impaled in his forehead. Even so, special effects supervisor John Vulich says Savini is trying to keep the gore to a minimum. ``We're using the idea that less blood is worth more. I think a film's more scary if it's realistic _ like the girl next door coming after you,'' he said. Vulich delights in unsettling visitors with textbook photographs of actual gaping wounds, his best source material. He based the makeup of one zombie on a photo of a 14-year-old who died when her face was caught in an escalator, while another was modeled after an emaciated survivor at a Nazi death camp. The original ``Night of the Living Dead'' cost $130,000 and was shot using a crew of eight people in Evans City, another western Pennsylvania city. ``We spend that much in one day now,'' producer Russ Streiner says of the remake's $4.2 million budget and crew of 100. Filming is scheduled for completion early this month, and a Halloween release is anticipated for the new ``Night of the Living Dead.'' George Romero, director of the first ``Dead,'' is keeping a low profile as executive producer. Back to produce are John Russo, who wrote the script, and Streiner. Director Savini says he's concerned the undead seen lurking on movie and TV screens these days just don't inspire terror anymore. ``The living dead have become comic. Look at Michael Jackson's `Thriller' or Joe Piscopo in the beer commercial. People laugh at that. That's not what we want,'' he says. ``I don't even like the word `zombie.' It conjures up images of voodoo and all that _ mystical stuff. If you look at our script, we only use the word `zombie' once. We call them `the dead people' or `the dead things.''' But this remake isn't without touches of comic relief. A roving band of rednecks revels in taking potshots at the undead, blasting off their heads. ``That's the only way to kill them,'' Streiner says. Humor pervades behind the camera, as well. Zombie extras staggering across a cow pasture in the film's climactic scene marched on for coffee, but quickly were rounded up for another take during late-night shooting. Others plowed into a barbed-wire fence before an assistant director could yell, ``Cut!'' Graffiti near a telephone spoofed a recent film comedy: ``Honey, I Ate the Kids.'' Locals and traveling horror groupies perched on car and truck hoods, watching the filming from a nearby ridge. The crew says more gawkers appear on Friday and Saturday nights. ``I've become jaded as an actor, but being out here really rejuvenates me,'' says Tony Todd, who plays Ben, an insurance salesman-turned-zombie killer. ``I watch these extras, and it's so important to them. It's the most major thing they've done in their lives, and they're putting a lot into it.'' Enthusiasm isn't the only good quality in a ``dead thing.'' Penny Venners, an assistant casting director who narrowed hordes of hopefuls from Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia down to 150 extras, says it helps to have hollowed-out eyes, a pale complexion and a vacant stare. The ideal turned up in Charles Berry, 77, a retired paper mill worker discovered by Savini in a Washington diner. ``He didn't even need makeup,'' Venners says. Clad in a flannel shirt and overalls, his white tufts of hair streaked back, Berry showed visitors his zombie walk, a slow-motion version of the Hunchback of Notre Dame. ``My rubber legs help me,'' he says. ``I got them from dancing. I love to dance.'' What started as Berry's big break soon became a family plot to get all the Berrys in the flick, including Charles' sons, Walter and Phillip, his daughter, Ludwina, and grandson, Shawn. ``I've never seen a zombie movie in my young life,'' Charles Berry says, ``but Walter told me to just go ahead and do it.'' Tim Carryer and his wife, Babs Bailey, professors of dramatic movement at Pittsburgh's Carnegie Mellon University, were hired to teach the zombie shuffle to the Berrys and other extras. ``If you died and came back to life, you would move in a shadow of how you once moved,'' Carryer says. ``But you're learning to work with a brand new body, and you don't know how it operates, and that's difficult.'' He encouraged extras to be creative and avoid the zombie cliche of walking with stiff legs and extended arms. Human nature made the teaching task easy, he says. ``I find,'' says Carryer, ``there's a little zombie lurking inside all of us.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ It's an underground sea of fresh water that helped transform The Great American Desert into fertile farmland that last year produced $20 billion worth of food and fiber. But can the Ogallala Aquifer survive the onslaught of man's insatiable hand on the spigot and chemical barrel? Maybe yes, maybe no.

OGALLALA, Neb. _ A sign of terrible times on an abandoned sod hut in the 1800s on the treeless, dry, heartless heart of America: ``90 miles to wood, 20 miles to water. Gone back East to wife's family.'' A westbound migrant, aglow with his future on the High Plains: ``This would be fine country if it just had water.'' A bitter sodbuster in reply: ``So would hell.'' Little did they know that only feet below their dusty wagon ruts lay an underground ocean, one of Earth's miracles. It is called the Ogallala Aquifer. In its sands and gravel and strata is buried enough fresh water to inundate all 50 states beneath almost 1{ feet. It holds as much water as Lake Huron plus one-fifth of Lake Ontario. The Ogallala stretches from South Dakota and Wyoming south through Nebraska (which overlies two-thirds of its volume), Colorado, Kansas and Oklahoma to Texas and New Mexico. Once this was all dismissed as The Great American Desert. Modern irrigation has transformed it into an 800-mile green belt made possible by, in effect, upside-down rain. The Ogallala region today produces up to 40 percent of America's beef, from 20 percent to 25 percent of its food and fiber, notably feed grains and cotton. This output that helps feed and clothe a nation was worth upward of $20 billion in 1989 and fuels an ancillary economy that may reach $50 billion. Without irrigation, says Nebraska Sen. Loran Schmit, the state's gross product would drop 70 percent. During the Dust Bowl's historic drought, haggard plainsmen watched red-eyed as their farms and ranchland blew away in the sleepless wind. Salvation lay but a pipe's length beneath their very feet. But they didn't have the tools to reach it. They do now. Irrigation can produce as much as three to four times more than dry-land farming. The Ogallala became found money. Pumping on a grand scale began in Texas where the High Plains became a mammoth cotton plantation. Envious farmers peered over their fences at what their irrigating neighbors were doing and the practice moved inexorably northward. In one region of southwest Nebraska, 111,600 acres were irrigated in 1950. By 1983, 973,000 acres were. In Yuma County in northeast Colorado it was 11,000 acres in 1959, 446,000 in 1987. The Lubbock, Texas, area had 3,627 irrigation wells in 1953, 46,906 in 1989. Between 1940 and 1980, 400 million acre-feet of the Ogallala's 3.6 billion acre-feet were pumped to the thirsty wells. (An acre-foot covers an acre with 1 foot of water and equals 325,848 gallons.) The result was predictable. Water levels declined up to 200 feet in Texas, with 23 percent of the water gone as of 1983. Kansas has pumped 38 percent of its water by one estimate. Its farmers pumped 4.4 million acre-feet in 1985. About 40 million acre-feet remain underground. In Kit Carson County in Colorado, water tables have been dropping up to 5 feet annually. Good rainfall, dramatically rising costs of pumping fuel, state regulation, federal farm programs and a greater awareness of conservation have combined to stem the flood. Ground water use declined 19 percent from 1980 to 1985. Many echo grain farmer Ed Ediger of Hampton, Neb.: ``Let's leave some for our grandchildren. In Scott City, Kan., Keith Lebbin, state water district manager for west-central Kansas, describes the local situation as ``bleak.'' But even something as ancient as agriculture is feeling the effects of technology. New techniques, new irrigation devices are coming from, of all places, Texas, where irrigators used to irrigate most Texanly. Innovations there promise to set a pattern that conceivably will make the aquifer a self-sustaining resource, or at least prolong its future unto Ed Ediger's grandchildren's grandchildren. ``Today's farmer is much better educated about water,'' says Bill Kastner, a U.S. Geological Survey hydrologist. It took eons for geology and climate to make this national treasure. In less than a lifetime irrigation has pumped some of it dry. Since World War II new technology has released a flood far, far beyond nature's drip-by-drip ability to replace it. Water thickness in the Ogallala ranges from a few feet in Kansas and Colorado to 1,300 feet in the Nebraska Sand Hills. The average is 200 feet. Perhaps 11 percent of the aquifer has been pumped since the late 1930s. The maximum decline by 1980 was 200 feet in Floyd County in the Texas Panhandle. By one estimate a quarter of the aquifer will be gone by 2020. The aquifer has been both mindlessly squandered and utilized with great intelligence, foresight and self-restraint. In places, it is also slowly being contaminated. In 1987, Nebraska farmers and ranchers put 775,000 tons of fertilizer on the land. And 16,500 tons of pesticides and uncounted tons of herbicides. Cows and hogs produced an additional 235,000 tons of manure. Gradually quantities of this leached downward toward the water. Can the Ogallala survive the onslaught of man's insatiable hand on the spigot and chemical barrel? To be cautiously Delphic, maybe yes, maybe no. It depends if what CAN be done WILL be done. It is past high noon atop the Ogallala. But it is not, in most places, too late. Being underground _ hence invisible _ aquifers are not readily identified nor easily understood once discovered. A pioneer in Nebraska Territory could, and did, hit water digging a post hole. He can be forgiven for crediting good luck, the deity or a forked dowser's stick. His mind-set was local, hardly geological. Wiser heads than his had dismissed the region's potential outright. Maj. Stephen H. Long explored the High Plains in 1819-20 to utter an all-time wowser in the annals of soothsaying: ``In regard to this extensive section of the country, I do not hesitate in giving the opinion that it is almost wholly unfit for cultivation, and of course uninhabitable by a people depending on agriculture for their subsistence.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ It was once thought of as an elitist clique of affluent young white women preoccupied with balls, bazaars and fashion shows, ``WASP to the max,'' as one puts it. But the Junior League these days is taking some social stands that puts it at odds with the conservative establishment. And lobbying on Capitol Hill in behalf of the League's 188,000 members is a black woman.

Bone china and brooches and sterling silver for sale. Special guest rooms at New York's Waldorf-Astoria. Cookbooks and calligraphy and a fancy private boarding school in the Virginia hunt country. It's no surprise to find these advertisements in a recent issue of the Junior League Review. But there's another side these days to the genteel club founded by turn-of-the-century debutantes to improve the lot of poor children. More often than not, today's league members work full time. They're crusading for ``membership diversity.'' They've got a black lobbyist on Capitol Hill. And they're promoting things like mandated job leaves for new parents, pitting themselves against conservatives and corporations. That's not exactly the profile that comes to mind when one thinks of the Junior League. ``WASP to the max'' is the more apt description given by Karen Hendricks, the lobbyist. But she is living evidence that league membership is no longer reserved for ``the white, upper-middle-income woman who doesn't work outside the home, has two kids and a Volvo.'' Nonetheless, much work remains if the group is to cast off its image as an elitist clique preoccupied with balls, bazaars and fashion shows. ``There's a lot of old baggage,'' sighs Hendricks, director of the league's 4-year-old public policy office in Washington. She knows this firsthand, thanks to repeated encounters with people who are nonplussed simply by the color of her skin. Once Hendricks was waiting to see a senator with two other visitors _ a white woman and a white man. An aide arrived and approached the white woman. ``You must be with the Junior League,'' the aide said. The woman demurred. The aide next went over to the white man. Wrong again. It finally dawned on her that, yes, a black person was representing the league. The Junior League did not get its white-gloved, upper-crust image for nothing. But members say the substance of the organization has been ignored by society reporters less interested in service projects than the cookbooks and cotillions that pay for them. Their purpose, they maintain, is far from frivolous and has not wavered since 1901. That was the year Mary Harriman, sister of the late New York Gov. Averell Harriman, and her friend Nathalie Henderson founded the Junior League to aid the slum tenement movement begun by Jane Addams. The young women and their debutante friends were in such demand as fund-raisers and volunteers that by 1907 their mission had shifted to a broader goal of neighborhood improvement. Now there are 277 Junior Leagues with 188,000 members in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Great Britain under the auspices of the Association of Junior Leagues International. More than half of the active members (as opposed to sustainers, who have ``graduated'' at age 45 to different types of community work) are employed full time. Individual leagues run the gamut from two that have gone on record in favor of abortion rights to others that stick to tea and symphonies. Museum programs and historical preservation remain hallmarks of some local leagues. But others pursue grittier tasks that take them into the nation's shelters, schools, hospitals and juvenile courts. They are working with AIDS babies, foster children, handicapped children, the homeless, battered women, alcoholic women and high-risk adolescents. They are trying to prevent teen-age pregnancy and serving as mentors to disadvantaged young girls. They have founded and staffed child care centers and referral networks. They are even fighting pollution. Reflecting the times, the association has a special program to help volunteers translate their skills into paying jobs. But the greatest shifts in recent years have been efforts to broaden membership and develop some lobbying clout. Since forming a diversification committee in 1978, the association has been phasing out onerous entry requirements and stressing the need to attract minority women. In the past, according to former association president Maridel Moulton of Moraga, Calif., leagues could impose a residency requirement of any number of years and some sought eight or nine sponsors and letters of reference. The most a league can now require from a prospective member is a year of residency and four sponsors, who usually serve now as mentors rather than gatekeepers. Incoming members also must be under 40 and committed to voluntarism. There are no demographic statistics available, so it's hard to say whether the membership is less white or wealthy as a result of the changes. According to Moulton, black women have been members for decades but ``the numbers haven't been there. ... You will still probably find some Junior Leagues that have no blacks. And there are some with a representative number from their communities.'' Local leagues concerned about foster care prompted the association to take its first political positions in 1978. Since then, guided by initiatives from its grass roots, the association has pressed the federal government on welfare reform, civil rights, child care and other social issues.
