DOC.TEXT: A staid reputation, close community ties and well-placed corporate and political connections make the Junior League a valued ally. ``They are the backbone of upper-middle class voluntarism. They bring the stamp of approval of mainstream America,'' says Judith Lichtman, president of the Women's Legal Defense Fund. ``Their women represent some of the more establishment sectors of society. Very often they have entree to members of Congress that we don't have. They are truly non-partisan. They don't necessarily just speak to progressives or liberals.'' The High Point, N.C., league brought many of these qualities to bear in a successful battle to prevent chemical dumping in a creek feeding the city's primary water supply. At issue was a permit sought by Ashland Chemical to build an industrial chemical repackaging plant. Alerted by Water Watch, a tiny local citizens group, league members researched Ashland's record and the effect of the chemicals in question. They announced a hearing on the permit in a newspaper ad, at PTA meetings and church suppers, in flyers and phone calls. They even offered to chauffeur people who were afraid to go downtown at night. ``The publicity was terribly important because most people in town were not aware of the danger this particular plant represented,'' says June Stackhouse, acting president of Water Watch. ``We were a small core group of 35 or 40. They had a lot of contacts ... a lot of connections with people with clout. They helped us pack the hearing and it really paid off.'' Hendricks attributes much of the league's effectiveness to ``who people think we are, rather than what we do.'' Many leagues are at the cutting edge of social issues, she says, despite the persistent image of ``little ladies'' donating time to innocuous, insignificant projects. One illustration of the image gap: In 1986, the association was pushing for bills to expand the federal child care role and require businesses to make unpaid, job-protected leaves available to new parents. Both measures gave conservatives apoplexy. But that was also the year a Washington lecture agency advertised in the league magazine that it specialized ``in the unique needs of Junior League Programs'' with speakers such as Charlton Heston and Phyllis Schlafly, both rock-ribbed conservatives. Which is not to say a more traditional league wouldn't welcome speakers such as Heston and Schlafly. Maybe the one in Richardson, Texas, for example. The 450-member league in a Dallas suburb cares for a historic home, tutors illiterate adults and helps pay for and run a summer recreation program for handicapped children. Recently it sponsored a benefit performance by a troupe of disabled puppeteers. It also gives money to hard-pressed community groups serving battered women, the homeless and others. What pays for all of this? An annual charity ball. Last year it netted $175,000, said league president Meredith McClure. McClure, 37, a part-time administrative assistant with two children, characterized her members as ``very conservative'' and said they are not particularly active in politics. But she says the league is in close touch with the national association and generally supports its positions. ``The one thing we can always seem to agree on is child welfare,'' she says. McClure says that even includes support for the federal parental leave bill, a favorite target of conservatives and the business community which co-sponsors or underwrites many league projects and with which so many members are closely associated. ``These women are business owners or are married to business owners. They can do what they do because of money from business,'' Hendricks explained. Nevertheless, when parental leave came up in the House in May, Hendricks was at the entrance to the chamber, grabbing members to champion the bill _ right next to lobbyists from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and other business groups intent on blocking passage. They were unsuccessful. League officials maintain their alliance with feminist and medical groups on parental leave is nothing unusual, given an 89-year tradition of concern for children and families. But they do acknowledge an evolution in tactics since the long-ago day that Mary Harriman walked into a tenement house in New York City. ``You start wondering how you can change the system,'' says Sally Orr of New York City, a member for nearly 35 years. ``The Junior Leagues realized they had to influence the regulatory and legislative process to get changes in their community.'' Suzanne Plihcik of Greensboro, N.C., who became president of the association in May, says political muscle is now very important to the leagues' mission. Among the reasons: women have less time to volunteer, while social problems are increasingly broad and complex. ``We have looked at more comprehensive and effective approaches to doing the same things,'' Plihcik says. ``It is imperative that we change with the world. But our basic values and goals remain the same. Everything is aimed at community improvement.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ He's seen the money roll in and the money roll out. He's shed a boozing habit, a fear of flying and a shaggy toupee. Pete Fountain is still playing the kind of Dixieland jazz his customers want to hear, but all in all he'd rather be rich.
DOC.HEAD: For The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Pete Fountain still has to blow his clarinet for a living, and he blames it all on ``zaps'' from God. There Pete stands, coming up on age 60, short, square, with white goatee and mustache. Bald as a peeled onion. He's fronting a seven-man band onstage in a lush saloon and regaling a convention crowd with smooth Dixieland jazz. Fountain calls it a saloon, which is his right since he owns the joint. Nightclub might be a more accurate term. It's a jewel of a bandbox, crimson and black with gold trim, 500 seats, located in a thriving hotel beside the Mississippi River at the center of New Orleans. Sounds like he's all set, right? But heck, you always got a pea under the mattress. Fountain's pea is that he has played the stuff the crowd likes thousands of times. ``Bourbon Street,'' ``Up a Lazy River,'' ``Pleyel's Hymn,'' ``New Orleans,'' ``Memphis Blues,'' ``Basin Street Blues,'' ``Columbus Stockade Blues,'' ``The Yellow Dog Blues''...and on and on. All grand old tunes, but enough already. What Fountain had rather do is be a millionaire, lounging beside an Olympic-size swimming pool behind a plantation house, a cool glass of sparkling water in hand (no more bourbon, please, hide that vodka). No worries. If he plays, he plays what he likes, not what the crowd likes. Pete might be relaxing by that pool right now except for a slight flaw in character _ he can lose money faster than he can make it. During 30 years as a saloon owner, slaving over a hot clarinet onstage or in a recording studio, the money rolled in _ and the money rolled out. ``I've made it,'' he says, ``but I have also made some very bad investments.'' The worst one was the purchase of a handsome hotel overlooking the blue Gulf of Mexico in Biloxi, Miss., some 70 miles east of New Orleans. ``I thought owning a hotel would be the greatest thing in the world,'' he says. ``Then I lost it. Down the tube.'' A chunk of Fountain money went into the 1984 New Orleans World's Fair. The fair wound up losing all investor input and about $100 million besides. Other ventures along the way included a string of convenience stores. Zap. There was something called Pete's Wieners and Famous Frozen Custard. Zap. ``I could write a book on a lot of the things that I got into,'' he said. ``I used to say if I had the hotel I could play just one day a week. But, naaah. It's like, you know, you're gonna play. Any time I try anything else God zaps me. It's like He said, `I've given you this talent and, damn it, you're gonna DO it. You're gonna play, no matter what.''' Fountain was playing with trumepter Al Hirt in a French Quarter nightclub 32 years ago when his big break came. It was a call from, of all people, Lawrence Welk, a shrewd entertainer whose square, upright musical style was a joke in the jazz circles where Pete Fountain labored. Would Mr. Fountain bring his clarinet and join the Welk band as a featured sideman? Yes indeedy. Maybe it wasn't jazz, but the Welk musical hour was a top television show of that day. The audience was in the millions. ``You didn't get rich with Lawrence Welk but you got a lot of exposure,'' Fountain says. ``And he loves jazz.'' He spent two years on the show, working jazz clubs on the side. ``Welk always said he would make my name a household word. He taught me a little. I used to want to play the things I wanted to play. But I realized you have to play the things that people want to hear you play, not what you want to hear you play.'' Fountain has hewed to this philosophy through an output of 85 record albums, three of them achieving gold status, and 54 guest stints on Johnny Carson's TV show. Fountain and his band made their fifth command performance for the president at a state dinner in Washington on April 26. A popular guy around New Orleans, Fountain has one big annual blowout that has become a fixture of Mardi Gras. The Half Fast Walking Club is a sight to behold as Fountain and about 150 old buddies put on masks and fancy dress and stagger four miles through the tremendous crowd packed along the Rex parade route. In addition to working at his own saloon four nights a week, Fountain and his band do one-night stands at conventions or concerts here and there. To do this, he overcame a desperate fear of flying. Friends said the only way you got Pete Fountain on an airliner in the old days was to fill him full of booze, carry him on board and dump him in his seat like a sack of potatoes. No more. You have to travel fast if you want to work fat extra gigs in faraway places. Those lucrative extras are even more necessary if your hobby is acquiring and caring for classic cars. ``If you want to play with the cars, the Rolls Royces and different things, you have to fly to pay for it,'' Fountains says. ``I'm a car junkie, a car nut.'' In giving up on getting rich, Fountain also gave up hard likker. Maybe a little wine now and then. Long before he gave up booze, Fountain gave up hair. He snatched off his toupee and threw it at the drummer during a stand in Las Vegas 20 years ago. ``What happened, I wanted to keep up with the kids. I got two or three toupees made a year. Each time the hair was a little longer. It got down over my shoulder. I finally realized, what the hell am I trying to do? You can't keep up with these kids. So that night in Vegas I got rid of it. It was soaking wet with sweat. It was like wearing a mop on your head.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ They are mostly descendants of the Tartars, the ``Golden Horde'' of barbarians that galloped out of the Crimea in the 13th century to vanquish Russia and pillage Poland. Tiny enclaves of Moslems hang on in overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Poland, clinging desperately to their ethnic traditions.

It is possible to face Mecca even from this remote hamlet hard against the Soviet border. Two Moslem families live on here, tending a tiny wooden mosque and a hillside cemetery where gravestones topped with crescent moons bear names like Kozakiewicz etched in Polish and Arabic. The 3,000 Moslem Poles are a little-known enclave in a noticeably homogenous nation now more than 93 percent Roman Catholic. But Moslems have lived in Poland for six centuries and, they say, form the world's oldest such community in lands never ruled by Moslems. Most are direct descendants of the Tartars who galloped out of the Crimea, vanquished Russia and pillaged Poland. The note ``destroyed by the Tartars'' describes monument after monument in Polish guidebooks, and Polish radio plays daily the broken-off call of a Krakow trumpeter sounding the alarm of a Tartar attack before being felled by an arrow to the throat. Every schoolchild learns the date _ April 9, 1241 _ when the Tartars' first conquest of Poland reached as far west as Legnica, 130 miles from Berlin. The battle there left the most powerful Polish prince, Henryk the Pious, chopped into so many pieces it is said his mother could only identify him by the six toes on one foot. This onslaught of the ``Golden Horde'' left a terror of barbarian invaders from the East that echoes through Polish political life to this day. But when the Tartars did not battle the Poles, they fought alongside them _helping defend Poland against every invader from the Teutonic knights at Grunwald in 1410 to the Germans in 1939 ``I am Polish, of Moslem background,'' emphasizes Ali Popluwski, hobbled by a German bullet to his leg inflicted while the occupiers turned the Kruszyniany mosque into a World War II field hospital. Popluwski is the mosque caretaker but there is no imam, or religious leader, anymore. One comes to lead prayers on the highest holidays from Bialystok, a city an hour away where the several hundred Moslems hold services in an apartment living room. More frequent are the tourists' visits, up to 1,000 a day on holidays. They are mainly the Middle East Arabs who, shunned elsewhere, were particularly welcome in Poland while its Communist regime snubbed the West. Some set up tents in nearby cow pastures, but most come and go in glossy foreign cars, bumping down the single-lane dirt and cobbled lane after leaving their Polish brethren a little money on a silver tray. It is enough to keep the mosque in prayer rugs, but not to fulfill the life wish of a 77-year-old Moslem trying to mind his religious heritage in a village of a couple of dozen farmers without phones or indoor plumbing 144 miles east of Warsaw. ``Everybody dreams of going to Mecca but you need 2,000 green ones (U.S. dollars) to go to Mecca, not red money,'' Popluwski says. Still he proudly thumbs the register of visitors, many bringing messages from the Holy City. He has seen seven thick books filled. ``I hope someone will maintain the tradition when I go,'' he says. There are only two other mosques in Poland. One is equally remote, tiny and wooden, also dating to the 1670s, and located in the nearby border village of Bohoniki, where five or six Moslem families remain. The other opened this spring in Gdansk, made possible by the donations of Arab students and funds raised by organizing trips to Turkey for Poles who go to trade, not tour. The new mosque, the first in the country for nearly 200 years, is less a sign of a resurgent community than of the determination of the 120 or so Moslems who settled in the Baltic port city as postwar refugees from Soviet-annexed eastern Poland. The Stalin-drawn border cut through a cluster of Moslem villages in what had been eastern Poland, leaving all but Kruszyniany and Bohoniki in the Soviet Union. Many Moslems were deported with other Poles to Siberia, but others fled west into modern Poland. By 1947, they had held their first registration, counting 1,100 from a prewar population of about 5,500. A Moslem historian who participated in the first postwar count in Gdansk won't allow his name to be used. He's tired, he says, of having his faith treated as an exotic curiosity in Poland. But he speaks proudly of his people's accomplishments against the odds of religious and political repression. Tartars, many prisoners of war, began to settle Polish lands during the 15th century, becoming loyal subjects of their adopted kings. Largely through royal reward for military service, they began to accumulate wealth, land and the civic rights of the nobility, writes Warsaw University's Jan Tyszkiewicz. But poverty set in during the 16th century when a law was passed barring non-Christion landowners from having Christian serfs. Tartars had to sell off their lands. Many sought military careers, or entered professions or trade, living on as an identifiable community through Poland's disappearance from the map at the end of the 18th century. Living under the Russians through the 19th century, Moslems suffered with the rest of the Polish nation. In the graveyard at Kruszyniany, the headstones of Moslem Poles who died during the 1800s are written, as required by law, in Russian Cyrillic letters. Many Moslem and Arabic texts, including the Koran, were translated into Polish and Lithuanian, but the ability to speak the Tartar tongue was largely lost. ``There are very big difficulties because the Moslems in Poland have been cut off from contacts with the Moslem world for 300 years,'' the Gdansk historian said. In Kruszyniany, the Golden Horde Cafe is closed, and Arabic writing on the bus ticket kiosk has been painted over. Popluwski's granddaughter has moved with her mother to Bialystok where she can learn Moslem traditions. But in Warsaw, where 150 to 200 Moslems live, a blueprint for a mosque has been drawn and construction is to start this year, funds permitting. And in Gdansk, the historian is optimistic the centuries of Moslem tradition will continue in Poland. ``Unquestionably, I am convinced it will survive,'' he said. ``The traditions are very highly developed. This tradition once was connected with noblemen and now it is more connected with ethnic pride.''

DOC.TEXT: Dawnn Lewis, star of NBC's ``A Different World,'' got her start on the show writing the lyrics for the theme song. ``The composer, Stu Gardner, didn't know me as an actress,'' says Lewis, who broke into show business singing jingles for commercials. ``When I auditioned for the role I didn't tell them I co-wrote the theme until I was hired.'' She also has been asked to sing the national anthem at the World Series, provided the San Diego Padres win the National League pennant first. That invitation came from Tom Werner, the team's new owner and partner in Carsey-Werner, the production team that created ``A Different World.'' Lewis plays Jaleesa Vinson, an older, divorced student at fictional Hillman College who got her degree at the end of the season. She says she doesn't know what her graduation means for Jaleesa's future. ``Whether that means I come back as a graduate student or a teacher or get a job hasn't been decided,'' she says. ``We're getting some new writers and we'll meet with them in the summer to talk about our characters.'' Lewis is the only member of the cast from the pilot who's still with the show. It made its debut three years ago as a spinoff of ``The Cosby Show'' starring Lisa Bonet. Bonet, married to musician Lenny Kravitz, left at the end of the first season when she became pregnant and has since returned to the Bill Cosby show. The show also stars Jasmine Guy as a spoiled debutante, plus Kadeem Hardison, Cree Summer, Charnele Brown, Darryl Bell, Glynn Turman, Sinbad and Lou Myers. ``Jaleesa is honest, young at heart, sassy and always has something to say about someone else's opinion,'' Lewis says. ``She makes comments that you can't get mad about because they're true. ``Jaleesa's in focus. She has a game plan. She wants to be stylish, although she doesn't always hit the mark.'' Lewis grew up in Brooklyn, and during high school rode the subway for an hour and 20 minutes every day to attend New York's High School of Music and Art in Harlem. ``I'd get to school an hour early,'' she says. ``I'd meet my friends for breakfast, and no matter how early I got there I was always late for my first class.'' She was accepted by several colleges, but chose the University of Miami and graduated magna cum laude in 1982 with a degree in music. ``I applied to Brooklyn College to please my parents,'' she says. ``I graduated from high school when I was 16 and I wanted to leave New York. The temptation to get a job was too strong if I stayed there, so I wanted to get away. My grandmother had recently moved to Miami, so that made it easier on my parents. ``I was Miami's first musical graduate,'' she says. ``I was the kind of kid who would figure out something and make it work. You couldn't tell me I couldn't do it.'' Although Lewis lives in Los Angeles, where she is active in community volunteer work, she still considers New York her home. She has bought a house here and is working on music for a new album. ``I thought when I came here that being on television would be my biggest adjustment,'' she says. ``Just being here is the biggest adjustment. I'm not an L.A. person. It's so different. The energy's different. ``The standards are different. A 16-year-old here can have a car. At 16 I was worried about having enough tokens for the bus and subway. ``And coming here as a celebrity makes it even harder because you have to fit into a mold. You have to drive the right kind of car, you have to see the right people, you have to say the right thing.''

DOC.TEXT: The miracle, to hear Eileen Atkins describe it, is that she succeeded as an actress at all. ``It's incredibly hard, and I don't care what anybody says, for people from my kind of background to get into the theater and become a classical actress,'' says the British star of ``Prin,'' currently playing off-Broadway at the Manhattan Theater Club. That background refers to the British working-class. Atkins's father read gas meters; her mother made dresses. To both her parents, acting meant entertainment in the most lowbrow sense _ not the meaty, wide-ranging roles that have distinguished her career. ``My mother wanted me to be a chorus girl because I tap-danced,'' she recalls. ``When I got to 12 and said, `I'm going to do Shakespeare,' people thought I was crackers.'' More than 40 years later, the joke's on them. A veteran of Broadway and the West End, last year she won London's equivalent of the Tony Award for her performances in Shakespeare's ``Cymbeline'' and Harold Pinter's ``Mountain Language'' at the Royal National Theater. At 55, Atkins belongs to that world class of British actresses that includes Vanessa Redgrave, Glenda Jackson, Judi Dench and Maggie Smith. She shares with them a distinctively unglamorous British beauty _ face sharp and angular, eyes suggesting inner strength and wisdom. How did she reach the top? ``Sheer bloody obstinacy,'' she says, and a teacher named Mr. Burton. ``My mother sent me with a note to school saying I would do better if I spoke nicely, as she put it,'' Atkins recalls. The main drama teacher wanted 7 shillings and sixpence a week, then about $2.50, to iron out young Eileen's Cockney accent. ``My mother said, `We can't afford it.' This man caught hold of me in the corridor and said, `I'll teach you for nothing if you come whenever I tell you to and stay for as long as I want you to, and there's no argument about anything,''' she said. Atkins spent an hour after school with Mr. Burton for the next five years, and he first took her to the legitimate theater. Today, her voice betrays no trace of her roots. She has lost touch with Burton, and as far as she knows, he has never come to see her on stage. In ``Prin,'' by Andrew Davies, Atkins plays a lesbian headmistress of a women's teacher training college whose exacting idealism brings about her collapse. Sheila Hancock won acclaim, and an Olivier Award nomination, for originating the role in the West End last winter, but Atkins plans a fresh approach. ``I cannot bear playing something I have seen somebody do,'' she says. She says she has heard ``Prin'' dismissed as a cross between ``The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,'' about an autocratic Scottish teacher, and ``The Killing of Sister George,'' the play that broke the taboo on portraying lesbianism on the British stage. But she remains fascinated by the title character's mixture of charisma and cruelty. ``She only cares about standards, about going for the truth...Some people won't like her and some people will, but I'm certainly not going to woo the audience to like me.'' Atkins hasn't acted in the United States since her harrowing performance as the schizophrenic ``Mary Barnes'' at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Conn., in 1980. She has appeared four times on Broadway, starting with her 1966 debut in ``The Killing of Sister George,'' opposite Beryl Reid. That role earned her a Tony nomination for best actress as did her Elizabeth I to Claire Bloom's Mary Queen of Scots in the 1972 ``Vivat! Vivat Regina!'' Atkins has consciously eschewed stardom, preferring British repertory to star vehicles and passing up the chance to act in ``Upstairs, Downstairs,'' the acclaimed television series that she and Jean Marsh co-created. She was the producers' first choice for the part of Sarah, the maid, which made a star out of Pauline Collins. Atkins doesn't regret it. ``You get known as Hudson or Rose and then it takes you forever to get out of it again,'' she says. ``I would find it boring to play the same part continuously for a long time. ``To me, the interesting thing about work is finding the character, and the rehearsal. I like licking each part, and once you've done that, all you have left is learning it every week.'' Film roles have included vivid supporting performances in ``Equus'' (1977) and ``The Dresser'' (1983), but she lost a part in ``Room with a View'' to her friend Judi Dench. ``I didn't really think about the cinema when I was young, because if you looked like me, you weren't a film star,'' she says. ``I was brought up to think I was extremely plain; now I look back and say, `You're adorable.''' Her self-deprecating manner drops only once, when she gloats about finally getting a driving license. ``It's pretty good at 55 to learn to drive,'' she says. ``I think I'm prouder of that than anything.''

DOC.HEAD: On Father's Day, One Daughter Remembers Dad As He Lived, And Died
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Today is a day to remember fathers with phone calls, ties and greeting cards. Associated Press Regional Reporter Tad Bartimus remembers her dad, James L. Bartimus, with a love story as she recounts his final days.

March 19, Monday: My father is dying. It is my worst childhood dread, the terror in the night come true. I sit by his bed and hold his hand, trying to ward off my fears. I am failing in my duty. I cannot save him. There is a scene in the film ``Terms of Endearment'' where the mother stands at the nurses station and screams for another pain shot for her terminally ill daughter. Now I, too, stand at a nurses station and say quietly, politely: ``I think it is time for my dad's shot.'' They look up at me, these kids, many of them young enough to be my own daughters, and say, ``OK, we'll get it in a minute,'' and then go back to talking about last night's date, a friend's birthday party. I feel my face contort. I have become Frankenstein. I stand there and fidget, my hands balling into fists, my eyes welling with tears. My eyelids are already so swollen I can hardly bear to touch them. I say aga Association, 50 E. Huron St., Chicago, Ill. 60611. Checks should be made payable to A.L.A.-Romanian Relief Fund.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT: Metamorphosen; Duet-Concertino for Clarinet & Bassoon; Prelude to Capriccio, Op. 85; by Richard Strauss (CBS) _ New Stockholm Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Esa-Pekka Salonen; Paul Meyer, clarinet; Knut Sonstevold, bassoon. Strauss (1864-1949) wrote these works in the 1940s, during the last decade of his life. Long gone were the years of his tremendous success as an opera composer, his reputation as a master of ever-increasing orchestation, his fame as a conductor and even his decline in critical opinion into a composer of mere talent and no longer genius. John Cage was in his 30s, Arnold Schoenberg was in his 60s and 70s, and music being composed at the time bore little resemblance to the early world of Strauss, who began writing music when the giants were Brahms, Saint-Saen, Dvorak, Tchaikovsky and Bruckner. In these last years, Strauss didn't change nor did the power of his music. The Metamorphosen are a distillation of his swirling, lush, Romantic style. The funeral march from Beethoven's Eroica symphony appears throughout, and at the end of the score Strauss wrote ``In Memoriam,'' presumably for a destroyed Germany. Salonen produces a sinewy, subtle interpretation of this work of extraordinary richness and intensity. He suddenly lifts out a brief line and puts it back in favor of another. The dynamic range is broad, though the recorded sound somewhat dry. The Duet-Concertino is a rarely heard gem. Its sunny, airy quality provides a nice contrast. The soloists play freely and with an openness of character. The prelude to Capriccio, Strauss' final opera, serves as a nice reconciliation of the Metamorphoses' intensity and the duet's lightness. We are back to the style of Der Rosenkavalier, a clear reminder of a different world. _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.

``Songs For Drella'' (Sire) _ Lou Reed and John Cale
Lou Reed and John Cale's ``Songs for Drella'' is the rare rock performance that would sound more appropriate in a drawing room or theater than on an album. The two former members of the Velvet Underground were commissioned to honor Andy Warhol, their artistic co-conspirator in the 1960s. They returned with a 15-song tribute that is part brilliant, part aggravating and always compelling. It's a tribute without tears. Like theater, it works far better as a single musical piece to be experienced in one sitting than on a disc that can be returned to frequently. ``Songs for Drella'' loosely chronicles Warhol's life and the artist's influence on the Velvets, from the explosive creativity in the 1960s to the disillusionment of Warhol's final years. Enough artistic license is taken for Reed and Cale to label the work ``a fiction.'' The best moments are the two Reed songs that bookend the disc. ``Small Town'' describes an artist's young life in a town he yearned to escape. The album closes with Reed figuratively standing over Warhol's grave. He admits to resentments ``that can never be unmade,'' but expresses the universal wish he'd talked more with his friend while he was still alive. Musically, the limited palette used by Reed and Cale does not invite repeated listenings. The instrumentation is essentially guitar and keyboard, with a few added colorings. Neither Red nor Cale is a strong or expressive singer and their deliveries are sometimes deadening. One consumer note: With records dying, here's a good example of the type of creative CD packaging that could stop any pining for album covers. It's a handsome grouping of words and pictures with sharp black packaging. The CD itself is set apart as a fluorescent portrait of Warhol. It looks terrific. _ By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.

Star Watch: Directing Is Like Getting ``Pecked to Death''
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Forget all those high-flown comments about the joys of directing movies. Now hear plain-talking Bob Hoskins: ``It's like being pecked to death by a thousand pigeons.'' The London actor makes his directorial bow with ``The Raggedy Rawney,'' which drew mixed reviews in New York and now is being released slowly across the country. ``It wasn't my idea,'' says Hoskins. ``I was in Australia, and the producer, Bob Weis, was talking about ideas for films. I told him the old gypsy legend, I think from the 100 Years War. I told him the story and said, `This would make a good film.' ``He leapt up in the air and said, `Right! Give me a script. You'll direct it. We'll do it in Czechoslovakia.' I said, `Oh? Will we?' It all came about through nepotism. He's a close friend of mine, and the crew was all family, close friends.'' Hoskins and Nicole De Wilde wrote the script, concerning a young soldier who deserts in wartime and joins a band of gypsies, disguising himself as a ``rawney,'' a gypsy term for a half-wit with unusual powers. George Harrison's Handmade Films provided the $5 million budget, and Hoskins and crew went off to Czechoslovakia for the filming. Hoskins, who had done some directing in the theater, was not fazed by the tight budget. ``You can film an epic if you can figure out a way of doing it,'' he reasoned. For instance, he staged a horse race ``in a small yard'' by carefully selecting camera angles. Concerning his ``pecked to death'' comment: ``Everybody's got questions for you. They follow you into the loo (toilet), they're banging on the door. `What pair of shoes d'ya want?' `I dunno; wear the shoes that fit ya.' ``There's no break at all. The minute you get up, questions. They go on all the time. Some can't do their job until they've had an answer from you.'' He partly solved the problem when the cast presented him with a hat that was marked ``actor'' on one side and ``director'' on the other. ``When I wore the `actor' side, the crew wasn't allowed to ask me questions,'' said Hoskins, who plays the leader of the gypsy band. ``The Raggedy Rawney'' was filmed before the ``velvet revolution'' toppled communist rule. Hoskins and the rest of the company came to admire the Czechs who worked on the film, but they recognized certain barriers. ``My translator was a wonderful guy who translated into Czech three words behind me,'' said Hoskins. ``Sometimes I would go on about the regime, and he said to me, `Bob, don't say those things in front of me. I'm supposed to report you. And if I don't, they're going to report me.' So we figured out that every time I wanted to say something, I'd scratch my head and we'd go for a walk.'' One factor helped Hoskins survive the hard days of filming: ``Great beer there, wonderful beer. I asked the guy who picked the locations: `How come there's always a really good bar near these places?' And there was. Great beer! That's where the original Budweiser comes from.'' Bob Hoskins was born in Suffolk on Oct. 16, 1942, and his parents moved to London two weeks later, just in time for a German bombing. His life has been somewhat rambunctious ever since. He quit school at 15, wandered from job to job until he happened into an acting audition by mistake. He won a lead role and he hasn't stopped working. While his fellow actors boast of training at drama academies, Hoskins says, ``I actually learned from watching women. I never had a class or was taught to act. What I realized was that women have had to keep their mouths shut for thousands of years, but they can express themselves very clearly without saying a word. ``But a guy always hides. What drama is is about the private moment. It's very difficult for a man to show the private moment. It's got nothing to do with femininity; it's a language. I wouldn't say a body language. It's just a language. Telepathy maybe.'' Hoskins has had a busy schedule. He has finished ``Mermaids'' with Cher and a thriller, ``Shattered,'' and next plays a detective in ``Plastic Nightmare'' with Tom Berenger. Most of his work has been in this country, but he declines to change his London base _ ``I couldn't take the kids away from their grandparents.'' He commented ruefully that his wife dislikes his many absences and his kids Rosa, 6, and Jack, 4, ``are beginning to call me `uncle.''' Though nominated for an Academy Award for his work in ``Mona Lisa,'' Hoskins' most successful film has been the blockbusting ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit?'' Will he be around for a sequel? ``I don't think they (Disney) will make one. It was wonderful, an experience I wouldn't miss for the world. But to do it again? By the time we finished, everyone was on their knees. Oh, that was tough!''
