DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: ``Today's Lesson Is Sponsored By...'' ^LaserPhoto NY701
DOC.TEXT: These days, it's possible to find public school students getting music appreciation lessons from Hershey's chocolate, reading lessons from Pizza Hut, or tips on fighting air pollution from Arco. Alarmed at the slow pace of school reform, big business and educators are putting aside long-standing suspicions to join in common cause to help students become the intelligent, productive workers the nation needs to remain competitive. But this ever-closer relationship is posing tough choices for educators _ perhaps nowhere more so than in the area of curriculum. Scores of corporations, labor unions and other outside groups _ no one knows exactly how many _ are making tempting offers of curricular materials to schools, either free or at a nominal charge. The catch is that such materials sometimes amount to free advertising, may contain subtle propaganda, or simply do not fit the educational goals or objectives of a given school or school district. Some critics worry that schools are becoming marketplaces for commercial messages, not ideas. Among the most recent offerings: a curriculum on labor history by the United Auto Workers, and a flashy educational video called ``Car Smart'' by Atlantic Richfield (Arco) featuring stars like Olivia Newton-John and Melissa Gilbert urging students to fight pollution by driving less, maintaining cars carefully and traveling light. Another hot new offering is a brochure, ``How to Enjoy a Symphony,'' issued by Hershey Chocolate USA designed to help youngsters enjoy their first musical encounters. Not coincidentally, the brochure bears the name of Hershey's new ``Symphony'' candy bar. The debate intensified earlier this year when Channel One began beaming educational newscasts into thousands of classrooms around the country. Whittle Communications, which produced the programming, offered schools free video equipment. Schools, for their part, had to guarantee students would watch it, commercials and all. Arthur Lebowitz, principal of South Mountain High School in Phoenix, says his school had explored using Channel One, ``but we have been reluctant to pursue that because we have to obligate a certain amount of class time.'' But his school is using an applied economics curriculum plugging the theme of free enterprise put out by Junior Achievement. ``There are some curricula that are downright misleading and we have urged schools to be very, very cautious in adopting them,'' says Gordon Cawelti, executive director of the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development, which recently recommended guidelines to help schools choose. According to ASCD, schools should be sure that any such material: _ ``is consistent with the values, goals and objectives of the educational program''; _ ``responds to a clearly understood educational need''; _ ``supports and does not undermine implicity or explicitly an existing curriculum and instruction message;'' _ ``has been considered and assessed by groups with different views.'' Daniel Merenda, executive director of the National Association of Partners in Education, which fosters school-business partnerships, adds this caution: ``Our premise is that materials should be developed jointly, with teachers, so that you take the question of bias out of it.'' Some business-generated curricula are considered excellent and have caught on phenomenally. Pizza Hut's three-year-old ``Book It!'' is a reading incentive program for grades one through six. Dr. Carolyn Hughes, Oklahoma City's assistant superintendent in charge of curriculum and program development, says the district generally shys from using corporate-produced curricula. ``Just because it's free doesn't mean we're going to use it,'' she says. But ``Book It!'' is a welcome exception in her district. ``It obviously has marketing value, but it does motivate kids to read,'' she says. More recently, more than 20,000 public schools have snapped up the ``Healthy Choices for Young Americans'' curriculum offered two months ago free of charge by the Washington state Apple Commission. At the 9th Street Elementary School in Los Angeles, for example, fourth-grade teacher Mike Romero is using that curriculum to get his pupils to keep food journals, brush their teeth after meals and do sit-ups and other exercises. In Tulsa, Okla., Amoco has for years supplied local elementary and middle schools with science curricula aimed at promoting experimentation. Utility companies were early pioneers in developing curricula _ not always to universal applause. In 1979, a book titled ``Hucksters in the Classrooms'' by Sheila Harty, criticized corporations, including utility companies, for offering schools one-sided, propagandistic lessons. Since then, utilities have learned some lessons, says Janet White, educational services representative of the Edison Electric Institute in Washington. ``The curricula we are most proud of are developed cooperatively, with the utility being one player, along with the state department of education or school district,'' says White. For example, Pennsylvania Power and Light worked with an advisory panel of teachers to develop a ``power concepts'' curriculum for kindergarten through 12th grade. It includes lessons in how to measure energy, the pros and cons of different energy options, including nuclear energy. It's designed to fit into existing general science curricula. Likewise, Puget Sound Power and Light in Washington state and Boston Edison in Massachusetts have worked with educators to develop environmental curricula. Even though such corporate-sponsored curricula have improved in recent years, critics like Harty still counsel caution. ``We must take precautions now to curb commercial exploitation in the schools, lest our schools fall farther and farther from their intellectual and social purposes,'' Harty wrote earlier this year. ``Do we really want the Jolly Green Giant teaching nutrition, Reddy Kilowatt teaching energy, and chemical companies teaching about the environment?''
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Lee Mitgang has covered education for the AP
DOC.TEXT: since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: BC-SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Teacher
LaserPhoto NY700
DOC.TEXT: Ask Marilyn Alberts what she does for a living, and she sounds like an agent for novelists, Nobelists and poet laureates. She is an English teacher who is convinced that all of her classes are filled with the greatest minds in the world. ``I come to school every day and I read the greatest works that have ever been written about the greatest ideas that people deal with _ love, honor, death, pain, sharing, gratitude _ with people who are interesting and intelligent and happen at the moment to be 17 years old,'' she says. ``I should trade this for a computer, a bank tellers' job, a set of law books, whatever? For mere money? Please!'' Alberts, a fast talker with a sense of humor, developed this ``formula answer'' while at a cocktail party ``when someone discovered I was a high school teacher and was quickly looking for an exit to find someone more interesting.'' She teaches 11th- and 12th-grade students at Bethesda-Chevy Chase High School in a Washington, D.C., suburb. In April, she received an honorary doctorate of humane letters from Georgetown University, after being nominated by 16 of her former students who are now undergraduates there. ``I don't think the teacher teaches the students,'' says Alberts, whose gray hair forms bangs that give her a youthful look. ``I think it's `a community of scholars.' That's the phrase I like to use with the kids at the beginning of the year. ``I also tell the kids at the beginning of class, `I will come to know who you were as you grew because of what you write about' ... but I also have a sense of who you will become. This is a continuum. You are the whole person that is both past, present and future.' ``That's why it's nice when the future comes back and says `See,''' she says of the Georgetown honor. Alberts began working at Bethesda-Chevy Chase in 1978 and teaches English, advanced composition and advanced placement English. This year, she teaches all honors classes, and she is not too happy about it. ``I think it's important to teach every level in the curriculum,'' she says. ``I don't think you should get far away from that for longer than a year.'' But she enjoys working with juniors and seniors. ``They are finally willing to be free of that early adolescent need to be like everybody else,'' she says. ``They really are tentatively ready to trust themselves not to do that. It's fun to watch them come out of that.'' And she likes ``watching people learn to express themselves'' from the class scholars to ``frankly the ones who may not make it out of school.'' ``I know that sometime in that semester every person will write at least one good line of poetry,'' she says, raising her forefinger for emphasis. ``It just has to happen. If you can speak words it's going to happen at some point. It always does.'' Alberts was inspired to teach by a high school English teacher who cried over a poem during class. ``We were all crucified with embarrassment for her,'' she says of that experience, which later led her to write a poem: ``But what could I do but become an English teacher too.'' Bethesda-Chevy Chase is one of the oldest high schools in Montgomery County, Md., and the English curriculum is literature-based. Classwork includes discussions of Shakespearean plays, Greek tragedies and other classics. While seniors work mainly on essays and poetry, juniors focus on drama and fiction. It is in the junior year when students learn how to write college-quality papers, she says. While Alberts will not use abridgements or ``easy versions'' of the classical works, she is working to ``expand the canon'' by including more works by women and minorities. Alberts seldom uses the word ``wrong'' and often allows students to express their opinions as long as they can thoroughly support their view. Some of the best work comes from students who don't do well in English, she says, explaining that those students usually have trouble with sequential or logical material but are clearly imaginative. ``All of a sudden he hits this class and he puts these crazy things together _ things that in the past teachers have said, `No that's crazy, you're not logical' _ and I say, `God that's wonderful!''' Chuckling at the thought, Alberts denies that her expectations alone spurred the student to excel. ``It's there to be discovered.'' The biggest disappointment for Alberts is knowing ``you've lost a few.'' ``If reality weren't reality, you'd hope you could save them all,'' she says. ``There is always a sense of whoever didn't become all he or she could be and if you could have done anything to change that.'' Alberts grew up in Sacramento, Calif. Her mother, now 93, was a teacher in a one-room schoolhouse in Patterson, Calif. Her father was general secretary of the YMCA. She received a bachelor's degree in English from the University of California at Berkeley and was a fellow of the National Endowment for the Humanities at Stanford University in 1986. Over the years, Alberts' teaching style has changed. ``I certainly was a lot more directive as a teacher than I am now,'' she says. ``My preferred method now is to work with a book that I have not read or not made up my mind about. I read it at the same time the kids do. We really do deal with it together as a `community of scholars.' ``I think I'm less judgmental than I used to be. I used to say this is what you should learn, and I will test you on it. I think that's a means to an end now. It's not an end in itself.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Counselor
DOC.TEXT: Daniel, a California teen-ager, was performing down to expectations when he started high school. His typical grades on tests and report cards were Ds and a few Fs _ just what his middle school teachers had warned his high school teachers to anticipate. But what they didn't look for is that on standardized test scores, Daniel (not his real name) performed at 12th-grade level in English and 10th-grade level in mathematics. His grades, obviously, didn't match his intelligence. The school counselor was asked to step in to find out why. He discovered that the boy's mother had a hands-off attitude about her son's schooling and that Daniel had such low self-esteem that his laziness and poor grades seemed to be a way of telling himself that he was no good. ``Building success is really the parents' job,'' says Darryl T. Yagi, counselor at the Casa Grande High School in Petaluma, who has been named Counselor of the Year by the American School Counselors Association. ``They should have expectations of the kids. A lot of times the parents won't do this.'' Yagi, who also serves as counseling advisor to the Sylvan Learning Centers, says that sometimes parents think the school will take care of all learning problems. But sooner or later, they have to acknowledge that a problem exists. ``The counselor is in a really good position to help because he can call on a body of resources,'' says Yagi. He knows how to get help from school staff, community agencies and the parents, among others, to identify the problems and recommend solutions. At the same time, he serves as a non-judgmental and non-emotional intermediary for the student. ``Kids respond to the counselor because he can tell them how to recognize and deal with problems. The kids feel good about themselves.'' In Daniel's case, the counselor pointed out the high test scores to him, then worked with both the youngster and his mother to raise their expectations of his abilities. He was enrolled in a pre-algebra class far more complicated than the general math class he had been failing. With this more positive view of himself, he improved his work habits and took on even more challenging assignments. The counselor can be a key figure in turnarounds like this one, and Yagi says that it usually takes only two or three visits with a student before ``the problems tend to take care of themselves.'' The student, whose confidences are respected, may initiate the consultations. A request for help also might come from a teacher or parent who's too closely involved and needs a disinterested third party to help a child put a problem into perspective. The mother of a girl Yagi calls ``Tina'' was concerned about the slipping grades of her freshman daughter because she knew she was upset about the father's disability from a recent illness. Tina's mother asked the counselor to intervene, without letting Tina know who suggested it. The counselor helped Tina realize that she wouldn't lose control of her life like her father and that she could get on with her schooling and her future. School counselors usually have a background in psychology or social sciences. Yagi says they should be good communicators and knowledgeable about resources available in the community, at school and at home that can be brought into play for problem solving. They also should be able to recognize when long-term attention such as psychotherapy is appropriate and recommend it. At lower grade levels, one counselor will be responsible to 500 students, and in high school the ratio narrows to one for 400. Yagi says most problems seem to occur at transitional points _ the first grade, the first year in junior high or high school, or when the curricula changes. ``It's usually a combination of academic concern, peer pressure, the family situation, and other changes. The student is changing _ personally, psychologically, and emotionally as he or she develops and grows.'' Warning signs for parents include when the child has poor self-esteem, doesn't do homework or the work at school, or gets into the ``wrong'' crowd and drifts into behavior problems. Yagi wrote a pamphlet, ``How to Talk to Your School Counselor,'' for Sylvan, a national group of supplemental learning centers that has developed tests and educational services for exceptional students or those with learning deficiencies.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Conservation
LaserPhoto NY705
DOC.TEXT:
Earth Day didn't end on April 22 for many college students around the country. They continue to be conscientious about conservation because ``it's on the shoulders of my generation and those to come,'' says Scott Moats, president of Students Concerned About the Environment (SCATE) at Buena Vista College in Storm Lake, Iowa. A majority of college students believe they can do something to protect the environment, according to a recent survey by the National Wildlife Federation, the nation's largest conservation organization. The survey of 500 undergraduates found 76 percent of those polled said they thought there was something they personally could do to help protect the environment, such as not littering, reducing their use of environmentally harmful products and taking part in environmental organizations. ``College students are expressing a deep concern for the environment, and the overwhelming majority are clearly willing to do something about it,'' said Jay B. Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation. When Oneonta, N.Y., imposed strict recycling regulations on the community two years ago, Hartwick College devised its own program with penalties and rewards. Residence halls and administrative buildings were equipped with containers for different waste products and each floor in each residence hall was rated. Students who didn't follow the recycling rules were fined, up to $2 a day. Rewards, for four consecutive ratings of 10, included dinner served by Dean of Students Donald Brown and another dean.
Some of the environmental efforts around the nation's campuses: _ Students at Manhattanville College, Purchase, N.Y., persuaded the school's food service provider to choose a tuna fish distributor who doesn't use dolphin-ensnaring nets. A campus environmental group known as EARTH, for Education, Action and Resources are Tomorrow's Hope, campaigned to ban the use of plastic foam cups at an on-campus cafe. _ Trashcapade II at Dartmouth in Hanover, N.H., gave students the opportunity to see how much trash they created over a five-day period. As a result, they persuaded one of the student dining rooms to switch from plastic to silverware. _ The Refuse Derived Fuel Project at Dordt College in Sioux Center, Iowa, was recognized by the U.S. Department of Energy because it produces an effective, efficient fuel source for the campus. _ Chemistry students at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine, Merrimac College in North Andover, Mass., and Ramapo College in Mahwah, N.J., are reducing toxic emissions in the laboratory and cutting air pollution by conducting ``micro-scale'' experiments.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Business
DOC.TEXT: The business of many American schools these days is business. Especially international business. ``It is increasingly urgent that all executives have an international orientation, whether or not they leave the United States,'' says William Voris, president of the American Graduate School of International Management. ``It's only recently that international education has caught on. The U.S. is playing catch-up with the rest of the world,'' he says. The international business courses have become a part of undergraduate as well as graduate and business schools, says Rusty Garth, vice president of the Council of Independent Colleges, a national service organization representing the private liberal arts colleges. He says liberal arts colleges are integrating business and economics with traditional liberal arts courses in foreign language and the social sciences. Business from another point of view is the focus of a money management summer camp at The Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla., run by the securities brokerage firm of Gruntal and Co. For an enrollment fee of $600, 30 future Wall Street brokers aged 12 to 15 can sign up for a week to learn about how stocks are bought, sold and delivered; credit card use; stock market ethics, and how to read the Wall Street Journal. At the end of ``camp,'' students can invest $100 of their enrollment fee and establish their own stock portfolio.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Tools
DOC.TEXT: Pencils and a notebook apparently are no longer enough for today's students. Instead of the traditional stapler or folder for those bulky theme papers, there's now a desktop plastic binding machine. The ``No Problem'' machine from General Binding Corp. binds up to 30 pages, needs no electric power source and weighs 2 pounds. For the student who can't succeed without a spell checker, thesaurus and calculator, Seiko has combined them into one hand-held electronic instrument, the MultiPower 4. Other Seiko electronic gadgets for students include French and Spanish vocabulary translators and voice station translators that help teach pronunciation.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Pay
DOC.TEXT: Keeping good teachers is simple, say two academics who've studied the problem of faculty turnover. Pay them more. Keeping good math and science teachers is simple, too. Pay them even more than that. ``The lesson is very simple. If we want good teachers, particularly in science and math, we have to raise their salaries,'' says Randall J. Olsen, professor of economics and director of Ohio State University's Center for Human Resource Research. Olsen and Richard J. Murname, a Harvard professor, were co-authors of a study of schools in three states that appeared in The American Economic Review. They examined records of nearly 18,000 teachers in Colorado, Michigan and North Carolina who began their careers in the 1970s. They found that high school chemistry and physics teachers had the shortest schoolroom careers. In Michigan, for example, they stayed only an average of 4.9 years, and mathemathics teachers were next, averaging 7.4 years in the classroom before quitting. Elementary school teachers stayed longest: 16.4 years. ``Science and mathematics teachers often have better job opportunities outside the classroom, so they're more likely to move. Elementary school teachers and those who aren't specialized don't always have those oppiortunities,'' says Olsen. The researchers say that similar results were found in Colorado and North Carolina. Olsen admits that the idea of paying science and math teachers more than others who teach social studies or elementary grades may not be popular with teachers' unions. But he says the fact is that science and math teachers show a greater willingness to leave teaching for better-paying jobs in industry and are the least likely to return to the classroom later.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Women
DOC.TEXT: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. (AP) _ That women are better students than men is more than popular wisdom, says a King's College professor who's made a study of their habits and academic records. Charles I. Brooks, a psychology professor, studied 283 women and 312 men in his introductory psychology classes over a six-year period and found that women miss fewer classes, sit closer to the front, and make better grades. He found that 71 percent of the women sat in the first four rows, compared with 44 percent of the men; 70 percent of the women had four class cuts or fewer during the term, compared with 54 percent of the men; and the women made better grades, on the whole, than the men. Women in the second row averaged close to a B while men in the same row averaged a B-, for example. He says he thinks students who are more interested, confident and competent sit toward the front.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Roommates
DOC.TEXT: If you've ever been assigned a college roommate by the luck of the draw, you know the meaning of ``odd lots.'' Freshmen enrolling in Wilson College sign contracts with their roommates at the beginning of the term to avoid conflicts. ``The roommate contracts force students to sit down and talk about things they wouldn't discuss otherwise,'' says Margie Taylor, spokeswoman for Wilson, a liberal arts college for women. Students typically discuss how they feel about smoking, visitors, privacy, study time, and borrowing each other's clothes. Or how the room will be arranged, and which cleaning chores will go to whom. Taylor says that many students have never lived with another person outside the family before, and they often make the mistake of being too polite about little annoyances until the problems build up. ``The contracts get a lot of stuff laid out ahead of time,'' she says. Students also discuss how they feel about issues like sex, alcohol, religion, and which ``Odd Couple'' character they most resemble _ the fastidious Felix Unger or the sloppy Oscar Madison. They end by listing issues they agree on, topics that need further discussion, and subjects on which they will agree to disagree. Kathy Boyd, a communications major who graduated last year, says the agreement saved her a lot of grief. ``My roommate was my best friend from high school, but I was afraid that we could destroy our friendship by living together in college. I'm a `Felix' and she's an `Oscar.' The contracts provided a good framework to live by.'' She and her roommate, Angela Spahr, a fine arts major, agreed not to share clothes but to do laundry together to save money. ``The success of the contract really comes down to communication skills, and we do a lot of things in both academic and student life to build those skills,'' says Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Study Habits
LaserPhoto NY702
DOC.TEXT: Until students adopt good study habits, they're not going to learn a thing, no matter how they stare at the book, says a Chicago learning executive. ``Too many parents see their child hunched over an open book and assume he is learning,'' says Robert Baseman, president of American Learning Corp. ``But often just the opposite is true. ``He doesn't have to have the radio or television on to have his attention drift away from his reading.'' American Learning, a division of Encyclopaedia Brittanica Inc., operates Brittanica Learning Centers, which offer individualized instruction in reading and math. Baseman offers some study habit tips that he says can improve grades in school and increase the level of learning by 20 to 30 percent. _ Establish a goal to focus on daily, either in writing it, reading it or saying it aloud. _ Set aside certain hours just for studying. Avoid late hours or study times right after meals; morning hours or right after classes are the best for learning. _ Eliminate distractions and thoughts about other interests or activities.. Study in a quiet place. Don't study if you're hungry or thirsty. _ Take rest periods. Short, five-minute breaks are good if you're working on one set task, otherwise 10- or 15-minute breaks are refreshing. Do something physical on your break. _ Chart your progress. _ Work as quickly as reasonable, while concentrating and focusing on what you are doing. _ Re-read the notes you took in class the same day you took them, while they are still fresh in your memory. Developing good study habits should be a joint effort of child and parent, Baseman says.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Study Abroad
DOC.TEXT: A Loyola University professor suggests that students preparing to study abroad should also consider what it will be like to come back home. More students have problems with culture shock and readjustment when they return than when they begin their study abroad, says Michael Cornet, professor of communications who has traveled extensively in Europe and taught for two years at Loyola's Rome Center campus. ``Tourists, especially if they're only in Europe for a short period of time, don't generally experience the culture shock that many students go through upon their return to the United States,'' he says. Part of the reason, he says, is that most other people aren't very interested in hearing the details of the trip. ``Either their family and friends are looking for a pat `It was nice' answer, or they want an excuse to tell about their own European adventures,'' he says. The returning students often don't have anyone to share their experience with and many realize how much they have grown up in comparison with their peers, says Cornett. Still, Cornett is a strong advocate of study abroad programs. ``It gives students a unique opportunity to examine their own relationships, goals and interests,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Health
DOC.TEXT: Back to school can often mean back to minor health problems for children, but it's nothing parents should worry about, says the chief of pediatrics at a New York hospital. ``Many school children go through a period of getting sick again after a relatively healthy summer,'' says Dr. Joseph Abularrage, of New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital. ``This is because school and day care programs put children in big groups in confined areas, unlike their comparatively open surroundings in the summer.'' The result is often a mild cold or other easily transmitted minor health problem, he says. Abularrage says a healthy diet and plenty of rest are the best ways to prevent minor illnesses like the common cold, but parents should be sure to have their children vaccinated. Parents may also have to deal with school phobia. ``If a youngster is extremely fearful of going to school and does everything to resist going,'' Abularrage says, ``the best way to handle the situation is to work out the problems of separation anxiety very slowly with the child, perhaps using the help of a counselor or the family doctor.'' According to Richard Oberfield, a clinical associate professor of child psychiatry at New York University Medical Center, there are some common signs of ``first day jitters'': _ unusual clinging behavior; _ toilet problems; _ stomach aches; _ insomnia; _ new fears; _ any behavior that seems regressive for your child, such as whining or crying. He suggests that parents go over in detail ahead of time exactly what will happen in school and assure the child that you or a family member will be there at the end of the school day. Oberfield says parents should consider their own fears as well. Children pick up on unspoken tensions and frustrations, he says, and it is not uncommon for parents to have mixed feelings about sending their child off to school. Coming to grips with your own fears should give your child the necessary positive reinforcement, he says.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Urban Colleges
LaserPhoto NY703
DOC.TEXT: The images of a college education usually include ivy-covered walls, tree-lined campuses and football Saturday afternoons. But some see more educational values in the ``real-world surroundings'' of a big city college. ``A city provides cultural and intellectual resources such as museums, theaters, great libraries and galleries, while also maintaining itself as a center of professional and economic growth,'' says Jim Harrison, president of the Association of Urban Universities. ``Broadcast centers, newspapers, corporations, hospitals, banks and stock exchanges are all, literally, in a city's back yard.'' Harrison says cities also can offer a large pool of executives for part-time teaching. ``The city has always been the natural place to study,'' says Harrison, who points out that ``the university began in Athens 1,400 years ago and revived in Paris 800 years later.'' ``Eighty percent of the American population currently lives in a city and the urban campus is where the future workforce of our country is and will be trained,'' says Nevin Brown, assistant director of urban affairs, National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges. ``The advantages of getting an education in an urban environment are three-fold: a city has the great economic and cultural centers; it will provide the best job opportunities in the future; and, it has the best representation of the population as a whole,'' says Brown. Michael Gold recently transferred to the urban Columbia College in Chicago from William and Mary College in Virginia. ``I have a better shot at connecting with a great internship and with the right job after graduation,'' says the 24-year-old marketing major, ``because of our faculty's expertise and involvement in the industry.'' He says the concept of college is changing. ``The world is speeding up and I believe there's a need to forgo some of the traditional college frills to compete in the marketplace and achieve career success,'' says Gold.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: TV Watching
DOC.TEXT: Children's television viewing habits can be an early indicator of hearing and vision problems, say doctors at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. ``One of the first signs of vision problems is if your child squints while looking at television,'' says Dr. Calvin Roberts, assistant professor of ophthamology at the hospital. ``Since children will not necessarily be aware of their own problems, at the first sign of squinting, parents should bring them to a physician for a checkup,'' he says. Another sign of visual problems, he says, is when children complain they can't read the print on the TV set, a possible indication of nearsightedness. ``If children have astigmatism, the signs will be different,'' says Roberts. ``They will typically mistake 3s for 8s and 8s for 3s. Sometimes they will also confuse 4s and 5s.'' Television viewing habits may also indicate hearing problems. Children may increase the TV volume, show inattentiveness while watching their favorite shows, and say ``what'' more often when comments are made to them, according to Dr. W. Shain Schley. ``These signs do not automatically mean a child has a hearing loss, but they do indicate the need for a physical examination,'' he says. Schley is associate professor of clinical otorhinolaryngology and director of the Eye, Nose and Throat Service at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Lunch
DOC.TEXT: The lessons children learn in the school cafeteria will last them a lifetime, says a hospital nutritionist and dietitian who lurges parents to instill good eating pattersn in their children. ``The main culprit is fat,'' says Carol Sherman, director of food and nutrition services at New York's Beth Israel Medical Center. ``If we could only teach our children to stay away from high-fat foods, or to consume them in moderation, we would be making major progress in the fight to prevent many health problems that affect so many adults. ``We need to make sure that healthy, active kids develop the right eating patterns now,'' she says, ``as their bodies are forming. It's never too early to learn about healthy eating.'' She offers these tips for parents of children going back to school: _ ``Everything in moderation'' should be the rule. A plate of macaroni and cheese is OK for lunch, provided dessert is fresh fruit, not ice cream. _ Serve plenty of bread in a wide variety, but stick to whole grain breads. _ Learn to read labels carefully on all foods. Look for low-fat and low-sodium content. _ Urge your children to drink pure fruit juice, skim or low-fat milk _ or water _ instead of soda. _ Parents who pack their children's lunch should provide a variety of foods, such as sandwiches, low-fat yogurt, fresh vegetables and fruits.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Service
DOC.TEXT: A trend toward more student participation in community service is apparent on the nation's campuses, according to several recent surveys, leading some to refer to this college population as the ``We Generation.'' On the national level, a study of incoming freshmen attitudes found that levels of participation in political activism and community service for freshmen in 1989 were greater than those of the last 1960s. The survey was sponsored by UCLA and the American Council of Education. Campus Compact, a coalition of colleges and universities committed to providing service opportunities for their students, has grown from 12 institutions to 230 in the five years since it was founded in 1985. ``In recent reports from our members,'' says Laina Warsavage, project coordinator at Campus Compact, ``we've seen participation up 15 to 20 percent in established programs all the way up to 300 percent for newer ones.'' At Concordia College, a survey showed, ``Young people are more likely to feel they have a future in their community when they are involved in service activities and feel they are valued by the community,'' says Paul Dovre, president of the Moorhead, Minn., school. The survey of 2,000 ninth and 12th-graders was conducted by the Central Minnesota Leadership Program. At the University of Rochester, roughly one of every six undergraduates is involved in some kind of public service activity, says James Case, director of Career Services and Placement at the upstate New York school. Case says much of their community service goes unheralded because it is done quietly and through established programs instead of carrying placards and staging marches. ``It's time we gave credit to today's undergraduates for taking student activism from the picket lines into the homeless shelters, from just marching against apartheid to raising money for scholarship funds for South African students,'' says Marsha Duncan, vice president for student affairs at Lehigh University in Pennsylvania. She says about one-fourth of the undergraduates at Lehigh volunteer time at charitable organizations or raise money for the March of Dimes, Easter seals, or the Red Cross. ``Today's students are certainly challenging the status quo,'' says the Rev. Dr. Gary Miller, chaplain at Lafayette College, Easton, Pa., ``but instead of storming the symbols of power and indifference, they are attempting to build a more just and caring future, brick by brick, meal by meal, child by child. ``And they are doing it with their most precious resource, their time.''

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Safety
DOC.TEXT: Teaching children about the 10-foot ``danger zone'' surrounding school buses can be more important than teaching them about reading, writing and arithmetic. It can, in fact, be a matter of life and death. With more than half the nation's school-age children being transported to their classrooms by bus, traffic experts say they should be taught safety procedures by parents. ``The most important place to learn about safety is in the home,'' says Gary Anderson, national driver-safety manager of Miami-based Ryder Student Transportation Services. Noting that the vast majority of serious accidents involving children and school buses occur in the 10-foot-wide area surrounding the bus, Anderson suggests parents instruct their children to remain at least 10 feet from an approaching bus until it has stopped completely, and then board in a single file line. When leaving the bus, he says, they should walk at least 10 feet away and wait until it has left the bus stop. ``Because young children can see a bus, they assume the driver can see them,'' Anderson explains. ``So they often try to retrieve objects they've dropped near the bus, and that's a dangerous situation. ``Parents should teach their children that drivers may not be able to see them, and that the sweaters and lunch boxes they're running after aren't as important as their safety.'' Ryder, which transports more than 400,000 students each school day in 15 states, conducts safety and training programs for student passengers, including one that utilizes a miniature robotic school bus. Parents are advised their children should be at the bus stop several minutes before the bus is scheduled to arrive, wait for the bus in a safe place away from where the bus stops and avoid horseplay. Other suggestions include: _ Never chase a bus after it has pulled away from the bus stop, because even with multiple large mirrors a driver may not see a small child who is very near the body of the bus. _ When entering the bus, go directly to an available or assigned seat. Remain seated and facing forward at all times while the bus is moving. _ Do not extend hands, elbows or head through the windows, or throw or pass objects to someone outside the bus.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Child Care
DOC.TEXT: An increase in two-income families and in the number of working women with children has encouraged the growth of child care centers across the nation, figures show. It is estimated that by 1995, more than 80 percent of the women between ages 22 and 44 will be working outside the home, representing close to 15 million preschoolers with working mothers, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. As a result, child care has become sophisticated, with increasing emphasis on educational programs, says John W. Quaintance, president of the Rocking Horse Child Care Centers of America. Parents see the licensed and regulated child care center not as a place just to leave children for the day, he says, but as a learning environment. ``Many parents are now selecting child care based on curriculum,'' says Quaintance. Rocking Horse, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., has programs designed for infants, toddlers, preschoolers, pre-kindergarten and school age, he says. Child care centers are also appearing in office developments, as ``a way for the corporation to attract skilled women who can have their children cared for close by,'' says Quaintance.

DOC.HEAD: SPECIAL EDITION
Back to School: Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Videos and computers in today's classrooms place even more emphasis than in the past on schoolchildren's ability to see, according to the American Optometric Association. Recommending a back-to-school eye examination, the association says children hampered by undiagnosed vision problems have to work harder to learn and may have so much difficulty they are categorized as learning-disabled. Parents are cautioned, however, that examinations that check only to determine if a child sees clearly may miss many vision problems that interfere with learning, such as eye coordination, eye focusing and eye movement. The examination should include tests for nearsightedness, farsightedness, astigmatism, crossed-eyes, lazy eye and color vision deficiencies, according to the industry trade group.

Freshmen participation in community service and political activism in 1989 was greater than that of the late 1960s, according to a survey sponsored by the American Council of Education and UCLA. The study of incoming freshmen attitudes also showed that student concern for the environment rose for the fifth straight year. A record high 44.1 percent of the students reported that it is a ``very important'' goal for them to ``influence social values.''

``Don't get into the habit of calling home once a week for more money. College is an opportunity to be responsibly independent, to become a mature adult, to do your own laundry.'' That's one of the bits of advice in the booklet ``How to Survive Your Freshman Year'' by Loyola University Chicago. It also suggests: _ ``Be extra considerate of your roommate. It's like a marriage _ learn how to give and take.'' _ ``When traveling to and around campus, develop your `sixth sense' and be aware of what's going on around you. If someone bothers you, don't keep it a secret. Nothing discourages a pest faster than the loud announcement that you want to be left alone.'' (For a free single copy, or to find out the mailing cost for multiple copies, write ``How to Survive Freshman Year,'' Loyola University Chicago, 820 N. Michigan Ave., Chicago, Ill. 60611.)

President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev signed a new trade pact that would lead to normalized economic relations between the two countries for the first time in nearly a half century. But the Bush administration emphasized the provision most prized by Gorbachev, granting lower tariffs on Soviet products sold in the United States, will not go into effect until the Soviet legislature passes a law providing free emigration. At a White House signing ceremony, Bush said Friday that he and Gorbachev were ``looking forward to the passage of a Soviet emigration law.''

The hiring of thousands of temporary census workers helped push the nation's unemployment rate down slightly to 5.3 percent in May, the government said. The civilian jobless rate fell slightly in May from April's 5.4 percent rate, the Labor Department said Friday. But analysts viewed the report as a sign of a sluggish economy because private sector job growth slowed to a near standstill. There were 164,000 new jobs created last month, according to a separate survey of business establishments, but the number was artificially inflated by the federal government's hiring of 145,000 temporary census workers.

Two judges supervising hundreds of asbestos injury lawsuits ordered the Manville Corp. bankruptcy case reopened to overhaul a financially ailing trust fund designed to compensate victims of asbestos-related diseases. In a joint order, a federal judge and a New York state judge on Friday said the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust was out of money and suggested the company advance it $200 million to $300 million so it can resume payments to victims. The trust was formed in Manville's 1988 reorganization, six years after it was driven into bankruptcy court by lawsuits over production of asbestos, the insulation and building material found to cause severe and sometimes fatal illnesses.

Construction spending fell 0.7 percent in April for the second consecutive month, the government said. Analysts said the report signalled a weakening building industry. The Commerce Department said Friday that residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $432.4 billion in April. The revised 0.7 percent March decline was improved from the 1.4 percent drop first reported last month.

A survey of purchasing managers indicated an improvement in manufacturing in May, but economists said the report was overshadowed and contradicted by government unemployment numbers. Gains in production and new orders led the increase reported Friday in the National Association of Purchasing Managment survey, the second in as many months. Economists also said the report probably was influenced by increased automobile production not being matched by sales.

International Business Machines Corp. said it has signed its biggest contract yet with the Soviet Union, under which it will supply over 13,000 personal computers for use in schools. The value of the contract was not disclosed Friday. IBM said the Soviets will pay in a convertible currency and that they received a discount comparable to one IBM offers other customers for computers bought for educational use.

The bankruptcy trustee for Eastern Airlines met with the federal prosecutor in Brooklyn in an effort to head off possible criminal charges against the carrier for allegedly falsifying maintenance records, a source said. The trustee, Martin R. Shugrue, met for ``an hour or two'' Friday with Andrew J. Maloney, the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District, said the source, speaking on the condition of anonymity.

Possible rear-seat defects in some Chrysler minivans are being investigated as the result of the death a 2-year-old boy in a crash, a government spokesman said. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration probe, announced Friday, was prompted in part by a coroner's complaint that the seats are unsafe. Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski said the company was cooperating with the investigation.

Argentina is to resume negotiations next week with creditor banks over the possible resumption of interest payments for the first time in two years on its $60 billion foreign debt, local newspapers reported. But creditor banks apparently are seeking more than the Argentine government is offering to pay, the reports Friday said. The daily Clarin said the government is prepared to pay $70 million a month for three months, but creditor banks want a minimum $100 million monthly for the rest of 1990.

Stock prices hit a new high Friday, reaching the 2,900 level in the Dow Jones industrial average for the first time. The Dow average of 30 blue chips rose 24.31 to 2,900.97, stretching its gain for the week to 80.05 points. Bond prices soared on the government's weak job growth report. The dollar gained against the West German mark and Swiss franc and lost ground to the Japanese yen and British pound. Precious metals futures plunged; grain and soybean futures fell; livestock and pork futures were higher, and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Electronics Show Gives Look at What's on Horizon, As Well As What's Arrived
DOC.TEXT: Technology junkies will have to dig deep to buy the latest in self-tuning televisions and digital audio tape players, but the fancy features eventually will reach middle-class buyers, industry players say. The world's largest consumer electronics show offers a look at the latest innovations including ``fuzzy logic,'' a primitive kind of artificial intelligence that can automatically fine-tune a television set's color, brightness, contrast and sharpness. It may be out of reach for most consumers now, but prices could come down fast, marketers say. ``You can bet that fuzzy logic will become the buzzword of the consumer eletronics industry in the 1990s,'' says Brian Klosterman, marketing director of Sony Corp. of America. ``Already there are products being introduced that contain the circuitry,'' he said at this weekend's opening of the 1990 International Summer Consumer Electronics Show. The show runs through Tuesday and is closed to the public. Among the tens of thousands of audio, video, home-office and home-automation products on display for retailers and their representatives are Sony's two large-screen color TV's with fuzzy logic. Sony's 27-inch XBR50 (retail $1,449) and the 32-inch XBR50 (retail $2,699) contain circuitry that automatically adjusts the picture on the screen 60 times every second. ``More fuzzy logic devices will proliferate across our line,'' Klosterman said. Such ``high-end'' televisions now represent only 1.3 percent of all color sets purchased, but the features they contain ``are always incorporated into the ultimate products first, and gradually come down into core-line production,'' Klosterman said. Sony and Technics said over the weekend that they would bring long-awaited digital audio tape players to the U.S. market this year. The products, which already are sold in Japan, will cost around $1,000 at first, but not for long, a Technics spokesman predicted. ``I foresee DAT eventually replacing all of the standard cassette business,'' said Mike Aguilar, a spokesman for Technics, a Secaucus, N.J.-based division of Matsushita Electric Corp. of America. ``I anticipate it following the same exact course as compact disc players. ``In 1983, they cost $1,000 plus. As the market grew and production expanded, prices came down rapidly.'' Added Aguilar, ``It is going to be the future of home taping.'' Don Krueger of Sanyo Securities of America, the U.S. arm of a major Japanese brokerage, said he foresees video laser disc players as the next hot item on the consumer electronics front. ``Everybody will have one of those in their homes a few years from now, just as they have a VCR in their homes now,'' he predicted. Video laser discs allow higher resolution than video tape and are virtually impossible to wear out. The devices that play the discs already have reached ``a fairly standardized, stable technology,'' Krueger said. ``You'll probably see the product coming down in price. Now, they're $600 to $700. I'll bet you'll see them at around $400 to $500 by the end of the year.''

DOC.HEAD: Toshiba Machine Lost Track of High-Tech Equipment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf pvs, An official ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Ministry of International Trade and Industry official. Picks up 18th graf pvs, Exporting certain ... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Toshiba Machine Co. admits it doesn't know what happened to a shipment of high-tech equipment that is reported to have gone to China in 1985 in violation of bans on sales of such machinery to Communist countries. Three years later, Toshiba Machine was penalized by the United States and Japan for exporting sensitive machinery to the Soviet Union despite an agreement by Western countries prohibiting such shipments to Communist nations. Japan got a black eye for its trading practices, from which it has still not recovered, though regulations have been tightened. The revelation of the China deal appears likely to raise the question of whether other high-tech transactions slipped through in the years of less stringent supervision. Tracing such deals a half-decade later can lead to dead ends, as an Associated Press investigation showed in following up a report in a Japanese magazine that machinery used in manufacturing computer memory chips had gone to China via Hong Kong. The Hong Kong buyers have vanished now. And there is no factory, at least now, in the building where the equipment was sent. Toshiba Machine's earlier problem came from exporting, via Norway, sophisticated milling equipment in 1984. It allegedly permitted the Soviet Union to make submarines quieter and more difficult to detect, and Washington was furious when the story emerged in 1987. In 1988, Washington barred the parent company, the electronics giant Toshiba Corp., which holds 50 percent of Toshiba Machine, from bidding on U.S. government contracts for one year, and Toshiba Machine was banned from exporting anything to the United States for three years. Japan blocked Toshiba Machine indefinitely from exports to Communist countries. The possible diversion of equipment to China is coming to light two years after the expiration of Japan's statute of limitations for violations of export law. On May 19, the new monthly general-interest magazine Foresight, published by Shinchosha, a major book and magazine publisher, reported that Toshiba Machine's electron beam lithography system went to China via Hong Kong in 1985. The system is able to manufacture vital parts for the mass production of memory chips, and at the time it was prohibited for sale to China under Japan's export regulations. The AP obtained copies of documents showing the price paid, acceptance by the Hong Kong company and a receipt by the Shanghai Metal Research Institute dated Sept. 11, 1985, for the EB-105 RB40 system. Toshiba Machine officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents with the exception of the purported receipt by the Shanghai Metal Research Institute, which was issued to the name of a Chinese individual as seller. ``All we can say is we sold the device to a Hong Kong company under proper procedures, but we have no way of knowing what happened to it afterwards,'' Kinji Matsumoto, a director of Toshiba Machine, told the AP. Matsumoto and other company officials said two men had tried to blackmail the company over the transaction last year. The company refused to pay and reported the entire incident to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in May 1989, Matsumoto said. In March this year, the ministry's export division requested a full explanation, he said. ``The ministry appeared satisfied with our explanation, though its officials were not happy to hear about such an incident,'' he said. ``We were told we have to be more careful.'' A Ministry of International Trade and Industry official acknowledged today that Toshiba Machine had sold the machinery to the Hong Kong company without completing a full check of the end-user. The official also conceded that his ministry should have examined the deal more closely. ``But at that point, the export control was not as strictly enforced as it is today, and we can't really blame Toshiba Machine or export control staff of the ministry,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Exporting certain high-tech equipment to Communist countries violates Japanese export control law and the COCOM, an international agreement of the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Control aimed at keeping certain sophisticated technology out of Communist hands. The regulations also require strict identification of the end-user of such equipment in countries to which export is permitted. But in the sale to Hong Kong, the middlemen and buyer of record have all apparently disappeared. Toshiba Machine officials say they sold the equipment to a Hong Kong company called Scientific Instruments Ltd. But such a company does not exist at the address stated in the contract. The AP telephoned a company by the same name, located at a different address in Hong Kong, but officials there said their company specializes in handling medical equipment and never had such a machine. A Hong Kong trading company that financed and mediated the transaction, Tradecity Investment, also was not located at the address stated in the contract. Toshiba Machine officials said their staff in Hong Kong made inquiries but could not find the factory where Scientific Instruments said the sensitive equipment was to be installed. The officials explained that Scientific Instruments had not prepared a suitable factory and did not permit Toshiba engineers to install the equipment, so Toshiba Machine refused to guarantee performance of the machinery, worth 451 million yen, then equivalent to $2 million. ``Last time we saw the machine was when unopened wooden boxes were placed in a factory in Hong Kong in May 1985,'' said Takanori Yamada, director of the corporate planning department of Toshiba Machine. ``We never saw the machine after then.'' There was no further contact with Scientific Instruments, he said. Toshiba Machine officials said they believed the machine wouldn't be resold elsewhere because Hong Kong authorities gave the import permission on condition that it be used only in Hong Kong. ``We are quite confident that we did every possible check back then,'' Matsumoto said. ``If you tell us today that our machine is not in Hong Kong, all I can say is it is way beyond our control.'' He stressed that the company had tightened its export control system in 1987, and the Hong Kong deal ``could not have happened under the present system, but the atmosphere back then was somewhat looser than today.'' Japanese law also was tightened after the 1987 scandal, and while some COCOM violations have been reported, the severe penalties on Toshiba Machine and Toshiba are widely thought to have had a deterring effect. AP attempts to trace the machinery quickly reached a dead end. Luo Tengjiao, an official at the Shanghai Metal Research Institute whose name appeared on the purported receipt as one of several people accepting delivery of the machine, denied in a telephone interview the purchase of such equipment. But a Shanghai daily, Wen Hui Bao, reported the institute succeeded in manufacturing 16-bit CPUs _ computer central processing units _ on Aug. 14, 1986, 15 months after the machinery was shipped to Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Savings and Loan Customers Close to a Settlement with Keating
DOC.TEXT: Investors who paid about $200 million for now-worthless junk bonds through Lincoln Savings & Loan are close to reaching a settlement with the collapsed thrift's parent, lawyers say. Attorneys for Lincoln head Charles H. Keating Jr., and the Irvine-based thrift's parent, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, are negotiating with lawyers for bondholders who have sued to recover their losses. Nearly 22,000 small investors, many of them elderly people who lost their life savings, purchased American Continental bonds at Lincoln's 29 Southern California branches. The bonds became worthless after the company went bankrupt last April and federal regulators seized the thrift. The bondholders filed 10 federal lawsuits, which were consolidated into one. The suit contends bondholders were led to believe their investments in American Continental bonds were federally insured, like regular deposits at S&Ls. A settlement could be finalized as early as Tuesday, said Ken Feinberg of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays and Handler Inc., the firm representing Keating. Joe Cotchett, a San Francisco lawyer representing bondholders, said, ``For all intents and purposes, (Kaye, Scholer) has settled.'' Any settlement, however, is subject to final approval of federal and state judges hearing the bondholders' lawsuit. Lincoln's collapse is expected to be the most costly S&L failure ever, with taxpayers footing a $2 billion bailout bill.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Banks Might Force Trump To Sell Assets
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's main bank creditors are likely to force the developer to sell part of his vast empire to help cover his roughly $2 billion in bank debts, a newspaper reported today. Trump hasn't missed any interest or principal payments, but bankers are concerned many of his properties, including the just-opened Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, N.J., and the Trump Shuttle airline, aren't producing enough revenue to ensure future payments, the Wall Street Journal said in today's edition. Trump recently announced 450 employee layoffs at the Taj and another 50 to 100 at the shuttle. But at least one banking source told the Journal that wasn't enough. ``He will have to trim the fat: get rid of the boat, the mansions, the helicopter,'' the banker said. Unidentified bankers involved in negotiations with the Trump Organization, told the Journal the creditors might also pressure management changes and a more conservative operating style. A spokeswoman for the Trump Organization did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment today. Trump, who owes another $1 billion to bondholders, is due to make about $30 million in payments on the bonds in mid-June. The bankers, however, want to be assured they also will be paid before the payment is made, the Journal said. One solution to Trump's reported problems would be for the banks to lend him more money and allow him to resolve his cash flow problems on his own. However, the banks reportedly have the upper hand in the negotiations, and could take the other extreme of calling in Trump's loans, a move that could force Trump into federal bankruptcy court. Negotiations between Trump executives and the banks have taken place daily in Trump Tower overlooking Central Park, the Journal said. Trump's self-promotion and tendency to emblazon his name on everything he bought had helped him convince banks that a property's resale value would be secure because he made properties, trophies as he has been fond of calling them, seem special. The properties' cash-flow potential was irrelevant, Trump argued, because he would be able to sell them at a profit. In April, Trump said he was considering selling the shuttle, but insisted that his intention was to become ``king of cash'' so he could buy more properties if the real estate market worsened. Trump strongly denied he was having any cash flow troubles.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count This Week Down By 18
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and natural gas rigs fell by 18 to total 983, snapping four consecutive weeks of gains that had pushed the weekly tally over the 1,000 mark, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. A year ago, the Houston-based company's count stood at 784. Last week's total of 1,001 marked the first time since January that the widely watched industry index of drilling activity topped 1,000. It also marked the first time since 1985 that the 1,000 mark was exceeded in May. The count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, Oklahoma this week posted the largest decline with eight, followed by Louisiana with seven. Colorado, New Mexico and North Dakota each dropped three. Among states showing gains, Texas and Wyoming each were up three while California increased by two and Ohio by one. Kansas, Michigan and Pennsylvania showed no change.

DOC.HEAD: Government Reports Lower Inflation, Tighter Financial Controls
DOC.TEXT: The government reported Monday that tighter financial controls and increrased farm and industrial production had brought down inflation during fiscal 1990. The Finance Ministry's Economic Survey was unveiled as a prelude to Thursday's announcement of the national budget for fiscal 1991, which begins July 1. The survey said inflation declined to 5.69 percent annually, compared to 10.4 percent in fiscal 1989. But private economists disputed the government's rate, maintaining inflation was more than 15 percent. They said the low government figure was based on on defective and incomplete statistics of consumer goods on which the official statistics are based. The survey also said the gross domestic product rose 5.2 percent and included a 4 percent increase in farm output and a 7.9 percent rise in industrial goods. The GDP growth in fiscal 1989 was 4.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: These Fifty Separate Economies
DOC.TEXT: Regional fortunes seem to be constantly shifting, said Janet Norwood, labor statistics commissioner, in her monthly employment report to Congress. The striking stability of the national jobless rate over the past two years, she told the Joint Economic Committee, has disguised substantial and important regional shifts. During the past 12 months, for example, the nation's official monthly jobless rate has varied from 5.3 percent only three times _ in May 1989 and in March 1990 when it read 5.2 percent and in April 1990 when 5.4 percent was recorded. Remarkable stability indeed. But only when you average things out, and averages are not what people live by. The jobless rate in New England, for example, had been unusually low a year or so ago, in some communities as low as 3 percent, which statisticians believe is about as low as you can get. But in the past year, unemployment in that six-state New England region has risen 2 percentage points, bringing the situation there close to the national average. The Southern region also has been closing in on the national average, but from a different direction. Rates there, which had been among the highest in the nation, have been improving, i.e. going the opposite way. It is out of such differences that national averages come into being. They are official. They are highly publicized and analyzed. They produce profound documents on possible policy implications. But to residents of those two huge areas of America, especially jobseekers and jobholders, those official statistics mislead. Generally speaking, said Norwood, ``the last year has seen some convergence of state and regional unemployment rates, with the worse-off areas improving and the best deteriorating.'' This is a big country, statisticians explain, and some of them say it is about time the differences were recognized. U.S. regional economies, they say, are as big as the economies of major industrialized nations. Geographical differences aren't the only ones. Sector differences are just as pronounced. Job growth in manufacturing has been weak, but until the past few months it had been strong in services. Health-care costs and employment have been beating an independent path upward for years. It is in the geographical area, however, where the vastness of the separate American economies is most pronounced. While homebuilding is off in New England, where it had been booming, it is up in Houston, where it had collapsed. While economies of some Rocky Mountain and Southeast states are depressed, several Midwest states are well off. One well-known market research firm, Sindlinger & Co., claims that it is only a specific interpretation of statistical evidence that keeps the Commerce Department from recognizing that a national recession might already exist. It's not the first time such a situation has existed, says Albert Sindlinger, whose research suggests there are far more states in recession than are free of it, but that the national averages disguise their plight. Vivid contrasts always can be found among geographical and sectoral areas, and that poses an enormous challenge to those who handle the economic levers, such as Federal Reserve officials. The Fed mechanism, it has been demonstrated in the past few years, can be very sensitive to national statistics; it has used them, for example, to skirt the fine line between economic growth and shrinkage. But it is not nearly as adept at handling regional or sectoral statistics. One of its most effective tools, for instance, is the fine tuning of interest rates nationally, but interest rates and the availability of funds still vary greatly from area to area. National economics, not microeconomics, is its specialty and, with regional economies growing and going their independent ways, microeconomics might be the big challenge to be met.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Weather Continues to Influence Market
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower in trading Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as the weather continued to be the guiding force of the market. Soybean futures were sharply lower as a result of rapid soybean planting in recent days, said Steve Freed, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Corn futures were also pushed lower by anticipation that planting will be completed rapidly because of mostly dry conditions. DOC.HEAD: Ford Tells Dealers to Perform Warranty Work on all Company Cars
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. has told its dealers that it expects them to perform warranty service on all Ford, Lincoln or Mercury cars, even if the car was purchased elsewhere, a company spokeswoman said Monday. The new policy will take effect on September 1, said Anne Doyle-Farrell, spokeswoman for Ford's warranty division. Most dealers already follow this policy, but Ford's directive will ensure they all do, Doyle-Farrell said. It's become more of an issue in recent years as consumers began to shop more for prices among different dealers, she said. But New York state Attorney General Robert Abrams, who announced the change, said a Ford dealer's decision to provide warranty service on cars purchased elsewhere is the exception rather than the rule. Abrams said Ford agreed to change its policy following negotiations with his office. ``Car buyers will be able to shop around for the best purchase price, while still being able to use their auto warranty at a convenient location,'' Abrams said. But Doyle-Farrell said Abrams was one of several different people to bring the policy to Ford's attention and he wasn't the key to the change. ``We were already interested in changing because of customer satisfaction,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Chevron's Soviet Deal Appears on Fast Track, But Road Is Long
DOC.TEXT: Chevron Corp. appears to be on a fast track toward developing the huge Tengiz oil field in a joint venture with the Soviet government, but it faces a long road before the deal is complete, analysts said Monday. Chevron has agreed with the Soviet Ministry of Oil and Gas Industry to study the feasibility of developing the field, with reserves estimated at more than 25 billion barrels _ about 2{ times those of Alaska's Prudhoe Bay. The ``protocol of intentions'' agreement signed Saturday is the first step toward an eventual joint venture to extract the oil. But long negotiations are expected before any joint venture agreement is reached. Complicating the dealmaking are the tangled Soviet bureaucracy and a history of questionable success _ even in cases where joint venture agreements formally are reached, only 15 percent actually go into operation. Nevertheless, the Soviets appear highly motivated to ensure that the Tengiz development and similar projects actually occur. The Soviet Union is the world's biggest oil producer, but production has fallen in recent years, and U.S. technology and capital are needed to reverse that trend, said Warren M. Shimmerlik, a senior oil analyst for County NatWest USA in New York. ``It's clear that this is a huge resource,'' Shimmerlik said. ``And this is the kind of asset that if opened up to the West could be very significant.'' However, he said, success is years away. Furthermore, while Chevron may expect to make a profit, it's unlikely to get a windfall. ``They will negotiate a reasonable deal,'' Shimmerlik said. ``The Soviets want this work done, and both sides will benefit from it.'' Eugene Nowak, who heads the energy group at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., warned that the protocol is just a first step in what could become a significant project for Chevron. He said there appeared to be no way Chevron could lose _ the worst that could happen is nothing, Nowak said. ``Based on what company officials are saying about the timetable, Chevron appears to be on a rather fast track,'' Nowak said. ``The uncertainty is that this is a new venture for the Soviets, and it's the business side that's questionable rather than the technical side,'' Nowak said. Shimmerlik said he expects the Soviets ultimately to allow several more companies into similar projects. ``There will be plenty of companies doing this, and it's a question of who winds up with the best properties,'' he said.
