DOC.HEAD: Alabama Business Tax Left Intact by High Court
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday left intact an Alabama tax attacked as ``grossly discriminatory'' against out-of-state businesses. Arguments that the tax interferes unduly with interstate commerce and violates equal protection rights were rejected by the court without comment. In other action, the court: _Agreed to study the government's power to lift price controls on some natural gas, a case that has tens of millions of dollars at stake for consumers. The federal regulations were struck down by a federal appeals court but will remain in effect until a Supreme Court decision is announced, likely in 1991. _Strengthened the government's power to keep the taxes withheld from businesses about to declare bankruptcy. Voting 9-0, the justices ruled that the trustee of bankrupt American International Airways is not entitled to recover $700,000 in taxes paid to the Internal Revenue Service. _Ordered a lower court to reconsider a ruling that exempted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission from collective bargaining with its employees over salaries. The justices said the lower court should restudy the case in light of a high court ruling May 29 that the Army must bargain with unions over wages and fringe benefits paid to civilian teachers at Army-run schools for the children of military and civilian personnel. _Ruled that nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue their employers under state personal injury laws. The court unanimously said such lawsuits are not pre-empted by a federal law protecting whistleblowers. _Agreed to decide whether passengers on international flights may sue airlines for emotional distress allegedly suffered in near-crashes that cause them no physical harm. The court said it will review a ruling that Eastern Airlines may be forced to pay passengers on a flight that landed safely in Miami after all the plane's engines failed briefly in the air. In the Alabama tax case, the state Supreme Court had concluded that the tax was valid while acknowledging that it was more onerous for out-of-state businesses. ``There is no unconstitutional unequal treatment of foreign corporations and no unconstitutional discrimination against them,'' the state court ruled last Dec. 21. The tax was challenged by Detroit-based General Motors Corp. and its subsidiaries and by Reynolds Metals Co., which is based in Richmond, Va. Alabama imposes a franchise tax on all business conducted in the state. Companies based outside the state pay a tax of $3 for every $1,000 worth of capital in the state. In-state companies pay $10 for every $1,000 worth of all outstanding stock. Lawyers for GM and Reynolds Metals told the justices that the two methods of calculating the tax result in enormously higher taxes for out-of-state businesses. ``The reason ... is that while the amount of business activity conducted and total capital employed in Alabama means everything in determining the foreign corporation's tax liability,'' GM's appeal said, ``business activity and total capital employed mean nothing in determining the domestic corporation's liability.'' For 1982 and 1983, Alabama collected $94 million in franchise taxes from out-of-state businesses based on 28,792 tax returns and less than $10 million from in-state businesses based on 81,698 returns. Adjustments to the tax law took effect in 1984 but that year out-of-state businesses paid $49.6 million in franchise taxes and in-state businesses paid $14.7 million. Reynolds Metals paid about $1.2 million in franchise taxes for 1982 and 1983, the years for which it sued for refunds. GM sued over the years 1983 through 1988, in which it paid $6.3 million in Alabama franchise taxes. The two appeals were supported by the State Tax Council of the State Chambers of Commerce and an organization called the Tax Executives Institute. ``The broad implication of the (state) court's holding is that ... discrimination against out-of-state taxpayers will be tolerated,'' lawyers for the Chamber of Commerce's council said. ``If interstate business is to be protected from discriminatory state taxes, the decision of the Alabama Supreme Court must be reviewed.''

DOC.HEAD: Organization Helps Poor Women Go Into Business In Countries Worldwide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Since it...,'' to CORRECT figures to show 46 sted 49 affiliates and 35 sted 44 countries; PICKS UP 7th graf, ``Each affiliate...''
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: To finance their businesses, women fish dealers in Ghana had to pay 100 percent interest to moneylenders _ until Women's World Banking opened an office in Accra and backed loans to them from a local bank. The New York-based group since 1980 has been providing financial support and guidance in less-developed nations for women who may have good business ideas but lack capital, management skills and confidence. The non-profit organization's goals are equality for women in economic development, as well as helping women achieve dignity from financial independence. Michaela Walsh, a former Wall Street investment banker who helped found WWB, said banks in many countries traditionally have had little interest in small loans. Bankers may object to having to perform too much paperwork for too little profit, or believe that a lack of confidence by a loan applicant indicates they're a bad risk. Besides guaranteeing loans, WWB trains women to run their businesses and publishes a trade atlas with profiles of 38 countries, explanations of transactions and a glossary of trade terms. Since it backed its first small loan for a bicycle repair shop in Cali, Colombia, in 1981, WWB has handled $12 million in loans _ some 45,000 loans averaging from $500 to $1,500 _ through 46 affiliates in 35 countries in Asia, the Americas, Europe and Africa. Each affiliate is run by people from the country it serves. In the Ghanian capital of Accra, for example, the affiliate was founded by an appeals court judge, an economist and several manufacturers. Part of the work is convincing local banks to make the small loans to women who are poor and often illiterate. WWB guarantees half the loan, the local affiliate guarantees 25 percent, and the local bank assumes 25 percent. The borrower pays interest at the going market rate. WWB's repayment rate has been 99 percent, better than for most banks that lend in developing countries, Ms. Walsh said. In some cases, the affiliates act as advocates for women within their own families. Officers will talk to a man who controls the family's capital, said Christine Hayanga, a Nairobi lawyer and regional officer for WWB in Africa, during a recent visit in New York. ``We tell them, `We don't want you to die of a heart attack. Share some of your responsibility with your wife.''' If the woman has no male relative with money to fund her business proposal, WWB will guide her through the borrowing process. ``One of the major things that attracted me to this was discovering in 1975 that women in most countries didn't even have credit,'' Ms. Walsh said. She said banks generally did not want to deal with women because they lacked credit history, collateral or legal standing. Ms. Walsh said she learned about the credit problem in 1975 at the United Nations International Women's Conference in Mexico City. She also found that women worldwide accounted for 10 percent of income but owned less than 1 percent of assets. The answer to changing the imbalance, she thought, was entrepreneurship. At the same time, she was inspired by the work of Ela Bhatt in India, a member of India's Planning Commission, who helped start a cooperative bank for poor women in India in 1974. The WWB capital fund was built up by investors and support from the governments of Canada, Sweden, Norway, the Netherlands and the United States, as well as some corporations and foundations and the United Nations. WWB expects to branch out soon with larger loans through a new venture fund with limited partners making direct investments of up to $1 million. WWB also is growing through new affiliates that include Akron and Yellow Springs, Ohio; Philadelphia; and Charleston, W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says States Not Immune from Refunds on Unlawfully Paid Taxes
With AM-Scotus-Business
DOC.TEXT: States sometimes may be forced to pay refunds on money collected under taxes later ruled unlawful, the Supreme Court said Monday. The court unanimously ruled in a Florida case that states are not immune from being sued for refunds on unlawfully paid taxes, and that the states can be ordered to provide some remedy. But by a 5-4 vote in a case from Arkansas, the justices said businesses are not entitled to refunds on money paid under such unlawful taxes if state officials had no way of knowing the taxes interfered unconstitutionally with interstate commerce. And the court said in the Florida case that refunds are just one option in a panoply of remedies states may provide if successfully sued over taxes. The court also stopped short of allowing full retroactivity for court decisions striking down state taxes. Instead, it said refunds are possible if taxed activity occurred after the tax was invalidated or after state officials should have suspected the tax was flawed. The justices were told that a highway-use tax at issue in the Arkansas case also is a controversy in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, New Jersey and Vermont _ with potential refunds of at least $630 million at stake. But for other controversies, the effect of Monday's decisions is unclear. For example, the justices last year struck down a Michigan law that taxed the pension benefits of retired federal employees but not the pensions of retired people who had worked for the state or its local governments. The court said states must tax all government pensions or none, but its decision left unanswered whether states must refund to pensioners the taxes already collected. Lawsuits seeking refunds have been filled in about half the states, and the potential refund liability is about $2 billion. The Arkansas case decided Monday was one of several in which the American Trucking Associations challenged the validity of a state highway-use tax. The associations sued Arkansas in 1983, attacking the state's Highway Use Equalization Tax. A flat tax, it resulted in a higher cost per mile for out-of-state truckers than for in-state truckers. The Arkansas Supreme Court upheld the tax, but in 1987 the nation's highest court struck down as unconstitutional two very similar taxes imposed on truckers by Pennsylvania. The Arkansas Legislature then repealed its state highway-use tax. The state Supreme Court, however, ruled that the trucking association's members were entitled to refunds only of the $4.9 million in taxes paid into a special escrow account created in 1987. About $160 million in flat-use taxes had been collected by Arkansas before the escrow account was established in the wake of the Supreme Court decision on the Pennsylvania taxes. Led by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the court Monday made clear that its 1987 ruling in the Pennsylvania case was intended ``to apply only prospectively.'' ``Flat highway taxation was permissible for highway use that occurred before the date of our decision but not after,'' O'Connor wrote in the court's main opinion. She was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Antonin Scalia joined in the result but for differing reasons. Justices John Paul Stevens, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun dissented, voting to impose greater retroactive liability on the states. The court sent the case back to the Arkansas Supreme Court for further study. ``We are not in a position to determine precisely the nature and extent of the relief to which (the truckers) are entitled for their 1987-1988 HUE tax payments,'' O'Connor said. ``That determination ... lies with the state courts in the first instance.'' In the Florida case, the state's tax structure at one time granted preferential treatment to alcoholic beverages made and bottled in Florida from crops grown there. The state Legislature, responding to a 1984 Supreme Court decision that struck down a similar tax setup in Hawaii, amended the law so that it granted preferences only for alcoholic beverages made from, among other things, citrus fruits. The Florida Supreme Court struck down the amended tax preference as unconstitutionally discriminatory against out-of-state businesses. But the state court ruled that distributors who had paid higher taxes were not entitled to any refunds. The justices Monday reversed the state Supreme Court ruling, and sent the case back for a determination of what relief is required. ``The state is free to choose which form of relief it will provide, so long as that relief satisfies the minimum federal requirements,'' he added. The cases are McKesson Corp. vs. Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco, 88-192, and American Trucking Association vs. Smith, 88-325.

DOC.HEAD: Robert Campeau, Bank Reach Agreement on Payment Extension
DOC.TEXT: National Bank of Canada said Monday it has extended the deadline by which Robert Campeau must pay 40 million Canadian dollars to regain the Campeau Corp. stock that the bank seized from him last January. The bank announced that Campeau received the reprieve after missing a Thursday midnight deadline. Bank spokesman Carole Gagne would not say how long the extension was for but published reports put it at 30 days. In Monday's trading, the U.S. dollar was trading at about 1.175 Canadian dollars, making the value of the payment Campeau faces worth about $34 million (U.S.). The bank had seized the securities after Campeau missed payments on about 150 million Canadian dollars in loans earlier this year. But Campeau, who has lost much of his personal fortune with the plunge in the company's stock in the past year, surprised financial circles with a deal to buy the shares back. Transfer of the securities would return control of the Toronto-based company to Campeau. Under the deal, Campeau, who is still chairman of the company he founded, agreed to pay 80 million Canadian dollars in two equal installments. The first payment was due last Thursday in exchange for the securities. The deal, which had been disclosed in filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, said the second payment was due at the end of 1991. Under the original agreement, if Campeau fails to make the payments the bank can seize the securities again. The agreement also included a provision whereby the two sides could mutually postpone the deadline, which they have now decided to do. Campeau owns two extensive U.S. retailing companies operating under bankruptcy court protection. The restructuring of the Canadian parent has no direct bearing on the bankruptcy reorganization of Cincinnati-based Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc.

DOC.HEAD: ``Gorby Tech'' Research Institute Proposed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gorbachev Maxwell, no hyphen, is CQ
DOC.TEXT: Students won't roam the campus of the Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology, and its initial proposed endowment of $100 million is paltry compared with those of other world-class research facilities. But supporters say the institute would bring together the world's top scientists to solve problems ``that matter to humanity.'' ``Everybody in the world would love to have an institute of this kind,'' Robert H. Smith, chairman of the institute's board, said Monday. Plans for the institute, which is to focus on research into communications and the environment, were announced Sunday during Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the Twin Cities. British publishing magnate Robert Maxwell has pledged $50 million if state officials raise a matching amount. Smith conceded that the institute's mission is vague, but said it's premature to set specific goals until funds are raised and scientists are recruited. ``You can't do the last part first,'' said Smith, who is also vice chairman of Maxwell Communications North America, the nation's second-largest printer. Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich, who at times has been criticized for dabbling in foreign affairs, is credited with lobbying Maxwell to fund the institute. Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota at Perpich's invitation provided the momentum for the project, and the Soviet president gave his blessing to the institute that will bear his name. Spokesman Robert Finn of California Institute of Technology said the project might be difficult to get off the ground, but predicted it would have a fair chance of success. ```Gorby Tech' is going to have certain advantages,'' Finn said. ``Scientists would be free of teaching responsibilities, and that's attractive to many people. There may be freedom from one of the things that scientists hate most _ grant applications.'' Finn said the Twin Cities institute would likely have more success if it focused on specific goals, such as the environment and communications. ``Environmental research is not one of the most heavily funded areas of science these days,'' he said. ``Scientists in those specific fields might be interested.'' Smith said he's confident the funds can be raised and the institute opened. He predicted the initial $100 million would be raised by the end of 1991, but said there is no firm date projected for the facility to open. Maxwell wouldn't have pledged $50 million for the project if he didn't believe it could succeed, Smith said. ``He is a guy who believes that communications and the ability to transcend ethnic and nationalistic boundaries is an extremely important idea for getting along in the world to come,'' Smith said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rolled up another broad gain to record highs Monday, picking up where they left off last week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 80.05 points last week, jumped 34.22 to 2,935.19. Since April 27 the average has soared 290.14 points, or 10.97 percent. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,105 up, 477 down and 439 unchanged. Analysts said the market still was benefiting from catch-up buying by money managers at investing institutions who were holding sizeable cash reserves when stocks began their spring rally. These managers are widely presumed to be anxious to show heavy commitments in stocks when they make their midyear reports to clients and bosses at the end of this month. Meanwhile, interest rates declined a bit after taking a sharp drop on Friday prompted by new signs of sluggish economic growth. Prices of long-term government bonds rose about $2 for each $1,000 in face value, reducing their yields to the 8.41 percent-8.45 percent range. The continuing slippage in interest rates sparked buying of banking and other financial stocks. Among money-center bank issues, J.P. Morgan gained | to 39{; Citicorp | to 24|; Chase Manhattan { to 27{, and Bankamerica 1\ to 32|. In the mortgage sector, Federal National Mortgage climbed 2 to 43| and Federal Home Loan Mortgage 3] to 79~. Wal-Mart Stores rose 2\ to 60|. On Friday Chairman Sam Walton projected a doubling in the number of the company's stores by the end of the 1990s. Gainers among the blue-chip industrials included Philip Morris, up 1\ at 44{; American Express, up 1~ at 31|; Boeing, up 1| at 86]; Coca-Cola, up 1\ at 46{, and General Electric, up ~ at 70]. Precious-metals issues were a notable weak spot as the price of gold dropped. ASA Ltd. fell 1{ to 46[; Newmont Gold 1[ to 41}; Homestake Mining ] to 18[, and Battle Mountain Gold ] to 12[. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 175.52 million shares, against 187.86 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 211.48 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $35.49 billion, or 1.02 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.18 to 200.21. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 4.29 to 428.24, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 4.24 at 367.40. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 3.48 to 465.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 364.40, up .57.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed; Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined Monday against most major currencies except the British pound and Japanese yen in domestic trading after a mixed performance overseas. Trading volume was light because most European markets were closed for a holiday. Gold prices posted minor to moderate losses. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's comments implying that U.S. interest rates could be heading lower knocked the dollar down as trading ended in New York. The result was that the dollar closed near its lowest levels of the session. Brady, speaking at the International Monetary Conference luncheon in San Francisco, expressed optimism that a budget agreement between Congress and the Bush adminstration could be reached that would reduce rates. Currency dealers said the impact of Brady's remarks was exaggerated because of the low liquidy in the market. Markets in continental Europe were closed for the Whit Monday holiday; only London's markets were open in Europe. ``For the most part it was a very quiet, dull day with the dollar stuck in a narrow range,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior currency trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York. Attention generally was focused on trading between the dollar and West German mark. Speculation about possible intervention by West Germany's central bank to prop up the mark restrained the dollar. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen. But dealers in New York and London said the gains reflected momentum from earlier Asian buying rather than a fundamental improvement in sentiment toward the U.S. currency. The dollar's trading day began in Tokyo with a gain of 0.25 Japanese yen to a closing level of 152.42 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 152.65 yen, which was the same level as late in New York. On Friday in New York, the dollar traded late at 151.85 yen. Weakness in the British pound favored the dollar. A pound fetched $1.6745 late in London, down from $1.6840 late Friday. Sterling lost strength in New York with a pound falling to $1.6770 from Friday's $1.6810. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.6905 West German marks, down from 1.6985; 1.4340 Swiss Francs, down from 1.4375; 5.696 French francs, down from 5.7295; 1,243.00 Italian lire, down from 1,250.375; and 1.17475 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17465. Other late dollar rates in London, compared with late Friday's levels were: 1.6940 West German marks, unchanged; 1.4390 Swiss francs, up from 1.4358; 5.7080 French francs, down from 5.7180; 1,245.50 Italian lire, down from 1,247.25; 1.9068 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9073; and 1.1763 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1728. Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for June delivery edged down 60 cents to close at $358.60. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $357.40 a troy ounce for gold bullion, $1.35 lower than Friday. In London, gold fell to a late bid price of $356.05 a troy ounce from $361.25 late Friday. Zurich markets were closed for Whit Monday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 68 cents to close at a bid of $360.68 an ounce. Silver prices finished mixed. Silver for June delivery rose to $5.049 a troy ounce on New York's Comex from $5.046 Friday. In London, silver fell to a late bid price of $5.03 a troy ounce from $5.05 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Expected to Postpone Drilling Off California, Florida
DOC.NOTE: EDs: First 10 grafs new with length of postponement for each area, picking up 11th graf pvs, Oil activity ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is expected to postpone new oil drilling off the California and Florida coasts, for up to 12 years in some areas, so additional environmental-impact studies can be done, administration officials said Monday. The officials said the president appeared ready to endorse a course that would ban new exploration off Florida until 2002, off Northern California until 1997 and off Southern California until at least 1992. Although the sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, cautioned that Bush still could change course and allow some leasing, one official closely involved with the decision said, ``I would be surprised'' if he did not go forward with the overall delay. An election-year decision to delay the leasing would play well among Republicans in California and Florida. Many have urged the delay, voicing concerns about a negative reaction from voters if Bush opened any areas to new drilling before the November balloting. Environmentalists have argued that the threat to the environment off both states has been shown and that new drilling should be banned altogether. ``We will be very disappointed if all we're offered (by Bush) is a delay,'' said Lisa Speer, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council. ``The public has moved far beyond where delays are going to satisfy people. It's time to move to protect some of these areas permanently.'' The long-pending presidential decision was anticipated in the next few days. While Bush still had a range of options before him, the consensus among officials who have worked on the decision is that Bush will approve a delay in leasing for all three areas, according to the administration sources. Postponing new drilling would conform to conclusions of a task force Bush appointed last year to study the problem. Oil activity would be banned in all the areas until at least 1992, when the Interior Department is to produce its next five-year plan for oil leasing around the country, if Bush keeps to the decision his aides expect. The five-year plan includes a broad outline of what areas will be considered for leasing and how the department will deal with leases for those five years. The president still had before him a variety of options ranging from opening the coasts to new offshore oil activity to imposing a moratorium. The options that the president has expressed most interest in involve postponing any new drilling, with the possibility of differing delay times, the officials said. They cautioned, however, that Bush, a former Texas oil executive, could switch courses at the last minute and back an option that would permit some new leasing activity. Bush named a task force last year, headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, to work with the National Academy of Sciences in studying the environmental impact of opening the three areas to oil leasing _ off northern, southern California and the Florida keys. The task force, in its report to Bush in January, cited a need for further study on the environmental and socioeconomic ramifications of new lease sales, sources have said. The broadest set of options initially placed before the president by his staff ranged from allowing immediate drilling in the study areas to permanently barring oil companies from the regions. Environmentalists have long opposed oil drilling in the three regions _ a 6.7-million acre section of ocean off Southern California, 1.2 million acres off Northern California, and 13 million acres in the Gulf of Mexico near the Florida Everglades. The environmentalists' concerns about damage to beaches and endangering of wildlife from leaks intensified after the Exxon Valdez tanker spill off Alaska a year ago. The Florida congressional delegation unanimously asked Bush to bar new drilling off their state. Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, who faces uncertain re-election prospects this year, is a strong moratorium proponent. In California, the political positions are a bit more mixed, but even conservative Republicans now call for protection of environmentally sensitive areas from oil drilling. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., who faces only token opposition in the GOP primary Tuesday but a bruising campaign for governor of California, is a strong moratorium backer who bucked the Reagan administration's efforts to open new leasing areas off the state's coast. The policy initiated by then-President Reagan's interior secretary, James Watt, opened to drilling the entire 1.4 billion-acre Outer Continental Shelf. But leasing has been blocked over the years by congressionally imposed moratoriums. In Florida, the government sold 73 leases in the affected area in the early 1980s for $108 million. The cost of buying the leases back could be closer to $200 million, according to some Interior Department officials. Southern California is the only region of the country other than the Gulf of Mexico where offshore oil development is underway; 22 oil platforms are operating. The current five-year lease program had anticipated additional lease sales last September, but those sales were put off pending the president's decision. The northern California leases, some 90 miles north of San Francisco and off Eureka, had been scheduled for sale early last year, but the sale was postponed.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Weather Continues to Influence Grain Market
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as the weather forecast continued to be the guiding force of the market. On other markets, precious metals were mixed, energy futures were lower and livestock and pork futures were mostly higher. Soybean futures were sharply lower as a result of rapid soybean planting in recent days, said Steve Freed, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. The amount of rain during the past weekend was not as great as expected, allowing planting to proceed, analysts said. Competition in the export market from South America also weighed on the soybean market, with the dock strike in Brazil not expected to last long enough to cause soybean business to shift to the United States, Freed said. Corn futures were pushed lower by anticipation that planting will be completed rapidly because of mostly dry conditions. The National Weather Service's six- to 10-day forecast, released late Friday, calls for dry, cool weather for the rest of the week. Wheat futures were boosted by reports that the Peoples Republic of China has entered the market for the grain. Wheat settled 1\ cent to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.31 cents a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2\ cents lower with July at $2.73} a bushel, oats were 1 cents to 2 cents lower with July at $1.43 a bushel; and soybeans were 8 cents to 10\ cents lower with July at $5.92} a bushel. Precious metals were mixed in trading on the New York Commodity Exchange. The price of gold slipped, extending last Friday's late decline. Craig Sloane, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said there were no news developments guiding the market, only continued concern about the U.S. economy. Sloane said that overall, commodity prices are weak, which he attributes to the good showing being made by the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average reached another record high on Monday. The strong stock market is also weighing on precious metals prices. Other analysts said gold prices are retreating because of continued concern over the cash flow problems of the Soviet Union, which raise the possibility that the Soviets will sell gold to pay for imports. Silver finished higher on buying by professional traders. Gold was 60 cents to $1.80 lower with June at $358.60 a troy ounce; silver was .20 cent to .30 cent higher with July at $5.082 a troy ounce. Energy futures settled lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange in quiet trading. Crude oil was trading up about 25 cents a barrel before falling back in the afternoon. Robert Baker, an analyst with Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said there was an absence of news to influence the market. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 17 cents to 43 cents lower with July at $17.14 a barrel; heating oil was 65 cents to 1.14 cents lower with July at 47.59 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.20 cents to 1.82 cents lower with July at 59.58 cents a gallon. Livestock and pork futures were higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Hog futures prices rose on professional and commercial buying prompted by expectations of higher cash prices this week. Expectations of a light slaughter also was a boost to hog prices. After the close of trading, the U.S. Agriculture Department released a slaughter estimate of 252,000 heads. Pork bellies were higher due to belief that last week's drop in prices was overdone. Cattle prices were higher, spurred by active boxed beef sales as retailers restocked after brisk Memorial Day business. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .25 cent higher with June at 74.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .65 cent higher with August at 85.02 cents a pound; hogs were .08 cent lower to .50 cent higher with June at 66.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .57 cent lower to .25 cent higher with July at 65.30 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Fall On Supply Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices skidded lower Monday as traders grew more pessimistic about the oversupply of crude on world markets. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 36 cents to $17.14 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with other contract months also dropping. Madison Galbraith, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, summed up the market's problems: ``There's too much crude.'' Energy futures prices slumped last week because of supply concerns, and Monday's decline was a continuation of that downturn, Galbraith said. ``It's anybody's guess where it will end,'' he said. Among refined products traded on the mercantile exchange, wholesale gasoline for delivery in July plunged 1.20 cents to 59.58 cents a gallon, with subsequent months also falling. And the July contract for home heating oil tumbled 1.14 cents to 47.59 cents a gallon. Later months also declined. Prices have been falling since the beginning of the year as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been unable to stop some of its members from exceeding their production quotas. At this point, even if OPEC members do cut back their output, bearish traders believe this will only slow, and not reduce the oversupply of crude, Galbraith said. Natural gas prices were little changed Monday. The July contract closed at $1.582 per $1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.585 on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Four Ford Motor Co. Execs Killed in Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: Four Ford Motor Co. executives were killed in a light-airplane crash this weekend, the automaker said Monday. The four were killed when the airplane flown by one of them crashed about noon Sunday shortly after takeoff from Otsego County Airport near Gaylord on Michigan's Lower Peninsula. The four were the only people aboard the airplane headed to Oakland Pontiac Airport. They were identified as Richard G. Bentley, 51, of Birmingham, executive vice president for finance, and Robert L. Decker, 50, of Livonia, vice president for employee relations, both with Ford Motor Credit; James A. Hewitt, 56, of Birmingham, employee relations manager for truck operations, and Ben Muns, 62, of Bloomfield Hills, director of the compensation planning office at Ford Motor World Headquarters. ``The employees who lost their lives in this tragedy were outstanding men and significant contributors to the company,'' said Ford President Philip Benton. A National Transportation Safety Board investigator arrived Sunday in Gaylord to determine a cause of the crash. State Transportation Department records showed the plane was registered May 17 to Tradewinds Aviation Inc. in Pontiac. Company President Rick Nini said Bentley was one of several people who owned the plane under a partnership. Bentley was the pilot when the plane left Friday for Gaylord. ``It was just him and three buddies going up to Gaylord for a golfing weekend,'' Nini said Monday. ``It's tragic.'' Nini said there were no known mechanical problems with the plane, a single-engine, Beechcraft A-36 Bonanza. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Mort Edelstein in Chicago said the plane was making a left turn when it stalled. Edelstein said winds, which had been gusting up to 40 mph, could have been a factor in the crash.

DOC.HEAD: NBC News Chief Promises To Make `Today' Show a Winner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, ``Welcome to ...' to delete extraneous word `former,' add background on Garagiola. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The head of NBC News conceded to affiliates Monday ``we screwed up'' the ``Today Show'' with changes that led to Jane Pauley's leaving in December. However, Michael Gartner told the annual NBC affiliates' convention that key changes have been made, including a new executive producer for the show, Tom Capra. ``Now, with the dust settled, he'll make it, we'll make it, another winner,'' he said. The show has been second in ratings to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for 21 weeks. The affection of affiliate executives for Pauley _ succeeded on ``Today'' by Deborah Norville _ was amply illustrated when they gave her a standing ovation as she appeared on stage at the National Theater where Gartner spoke. ``I have never been happier in my work,'' said Pauley, who is preparing a series of prime-time specials for NBC and is substitute evening news anchor when Tom Brokaw is away. Gartner didn't specify the mistakes that caused the slump. But seeking to make amends to executives of NBC's 208 affiliated stations, Gartner also tried to show progress on two other news fronts. He said a new 24-hour news service, the NBC News Channel, will start serving affiliates in January, providing international, national and regional news for use in their own newscasts. The service won't transmit stories on a non-stop basis as does Cable News Network. Nor will it have news anchors, as some industry observers thought it would. It is intended to help NBC stations compete with CNN's newscasts, and to ward off further encroachments by CNN on NBC stations. CNN says it has 216 broadcast affiliates, of which 52 are NBC affiliates. Gartner also introduced the new executive producer of the third-in-ratings ``NBC Nightly News,'' Steve Friedman, calling him a ``show doctor'' who will ``make `Nightly' sparkle.'' Friedman is a former executive producer of ``Today'' credited with making that show first in ratings before leaving it in 1987 to create what turned out to be a costly, syndicated flop, ``USA Today on TV.'' ``Welcome to NBC News' version of `Back to the Future,''' Friedman joked, alluding to his return and the re-hiring of Joe Garagiola as a co-host on ``Today'' with Norville and Bryant Gumbel. Garagiola was a ``Today'' co-host from 1969 to 1973. Garagiola, who is not scheduled to start on ``Today'' until June 11, appeared on stage with Gumbel, Norville, weatherman Willard Scott, and other new additions _ anchor Faith Daniels and correspondent Katherine Couric. Capra, appearing separately, said Garagiola ``will be the glue that holds the show together.'' In speaking of Capra's hiring last year, Gartner said: ``We know we screwed up the `Today Show.' ... He knows what the show needs and he knows how to provide it.'' The usually-brash Friedman was cautious and didn't promise a fast ratings rise for ``Nightly News.'' However, he said there would be changes to make the newscast more of a ratings contender. He didn't outline the changes, citing competitive reasons. Newscasts ``no longer just index the day's events,'' he told an audience of 1,100. ``We can't come on and say, `These are the top stories.' People have heard them already.''' ``We are going to do a show of interest, not the show of record,'' he added. ``We are going to be active, not reactive.'' The opening of NBC's three-day session began the same day as Fox Broadcasting's convention in Los Angeles. Atlhough some NBC station executives chatted among themselves about next fall's Thursday night face-off between NBC's powerhouse ``The Cosby Show'' and Fox's cartoon hit, ``The Simpsons,'' NBC president Robert C. Wright warned them a battle was beginning on several fronts. NBC, first in prime time for five seasons, is ready for next fall, he said. ``We've got victories in the future. But they'll be smaller victories than the ones we enjoyed in the past.'' Cable has become strong, ``Fox is probably even stronger than we had anticipated'' and is rapidly moving toward a seven-night schedule, and ABC and CBS have been rejuvenated, he said. To stay a financially strong network, ``we must gain an equal footing with our unregulated competitors,'' he said. Cable was de-regulated by Congress in 1984 but is facing some possible re-regulation.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Company Files for Chapter 11 Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf pvs, `The filing ...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that filing affected five Greyhound affiliates sted subsidiaries, parent not affected; picks up 20th graf, `Most of ...
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday, saying it was worried creditors would try to seize buses and terminals as the company struggled into the fourth month of a drivers' strike. Officials said the filing would not affect service at the only nationwide bus company. ``We have taken this action to enable Greyhound lines to continue operation of its of its total system,'' said J. Michael Doyle, senior vice president and chief financial officer. The petition was filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Texas in Brownsville. The filing under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code allows the company to continue operating under court supervision while it tries to reorganize its finances and pay off creditors. Union officials were not immediately available to comment on the bankruptcy filing. Greyhound has been struggling since bus drivers walked out March 2. The company has been operating a reduced schedule, but the sliced revenue and increased expenses of fighting the strike have siphoned off cash needed to operate. The company lost $56 million in the first quarter. It has missed more than $16 million in principal, interest and lease payments since the end of April, putting it in default on numerous agreements with creditors. ``In the past few days, there has been a lot of pressure by creditors'' who own buses and terminals that the company leases, said President Frank Schmieder. ``We tried to stay out (of bankruptcy) as long as possible,'' Schmieder said. ``There will be no interruption of service,'' Doyle said, adding that the company had asked the bankruptcy court to honor tickets already purchased. ``For the passengers, (bankruptcy) ought to be pretty transparent,'' Schmieder said. ``The network is up in full and we're going to need all the employees that we currently have.'' Two weeks ago, the company proposed repurchasing $225 million of its junk bond debt at a steep discount, provided it could find enough financing to pay about $90 million for the bonds and leave the company with about $35 million in operating capital. ``We have asked creditors for patience so that we could devote all available resources to running maximum service during the peak summer travel season,'' Doyle said. ``While most have been cooperative, we were faced with the threat of a `run on assets' that could have crippled our ability to operate,'' he said. ``We are highly confident we will be successful in restructuring our debt,'' Doyle added. Schmieder said negotiations are continuing on financing the debt restructuring, but ``it will take longer now because the courts will have to approve any financial restructuring.'' The company did not estimate when it hoped to emerge from court supervision. The filing covers Greyhound and five affiliates including Eagle Bus Manufacturing Co., which is based in Brownsville. The other affiliates are GLI Bus Operations Holding Co., BusLease Inc., Trailways Commuter Transit Inc. and GLI Food Services Inc. Greyhound's parent, GLI Holding Co., wasn't included in the filing. Most of Greyhound's 6,300 drivers walked out over wages and job security. The company has been operating a reduced schedule with nearly 3,000 newly hired drivers. After attempts to reopen negotiations collapsed early last month, Chairman Fred G. Currey said May 7 the strike had become ``irrelevant'' because the carrier had enough drivers to operate. Just two weeks later, however, the company acknowledged severe financial difficulties and said the proposed repurchase of junk bonds was necessary to avert bankruptcy. The company's total debt stood at $384 million at the end of March. The debt is the legacy of a leveraged buyout three years ago led by Currey that took the company private. Currey and other investors paid $270 million for the bus operations of Greyhound Corp., since renamed Greyhound Dial Corp. A few months later they paid an additional $80 million for Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc., then the nation's largest operator of Trailways buses. Greyhound's future also was clouded recently by a finding by the National Labor Relations Board that Greyhound engaged in unfair labor practices by implementing its contract proposal immediately after the strike began. An administrative law judge has scheduled hearings on the matter in Milwaukee on Sept. 17. The procedure could result in the bus company being forced to pay about $10 million a month in back wages. Greyhound has said it is confident it will win once the case gets in court.

DOC.HEAD: `Gorby Tech' Research Institute Proposed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new graf 5, ``Gov. Rudy,'' re first matching donation, recasts grafs 6, 8 to conform. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Students won't roam the campus of the Gorbachev Maxwell Institute of Technology, and its initial proposed endowment of $100 million is paltry compared with world-class research centers. But supporters say the institute would bring together the world's top scientists to solve problems ``that matter to humanity.'' ``Everybody in the world would love to have an institute of this kind,'' Robert H. Smith, chairman of the institute's board, said Monday. Plans for the institute, which is to focus on research into communications and the environment, were announced Sunday during Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the Twin Cities. British publisher Robert Maxwell has pledged $50 million if state officials raise a matching amount. Gov. Rudy Perpich said Monday an initial $1 million donation from Dwayne Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland Co., boosted the state's effort to match Maxwell's pledge. Smith said it's premature to set specific goals for the institute. ``You can't do the last part first,'' said Smith, vice chairman of St. Paul based-Maxwell Communications North America, the nation's second-largest printer. ``Now that there's actually life and there's blood flowing and there's excitement, it's on to that task.'' Perpich, who at times has been criticized for dabbling in foreign affairs, is credited with lobbying Maxwell to fund the institute. Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota at Perpich's invitation provided the momentum for the project. Perpich on Sunday compared the project with California Institute of Technology and Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But officials of those schools said Monday they see big differences between their institutions and the Gorbachev Maxwell institute, which would depend entirely on private funding and would not award degrees. ``That would be a sharp departure from MIT, where teaching and research are both very important,'' said Robert C. DiIorio, associate director of the MIT news office. ``I think it would be apples and oranges.'' MIT scientists conducted research projects valued at $285.7 million in fiscal 1989, DiIorio said, and the school's endowment as of June 30, 1989, was $1.25 billion. Caltech spokesman Robert Finn said the project might be difficult to get off the ground, but predicted it had a fair chance of success. `` `Gorby Tech' is going to have certain advantages. Scientists would be free of teaching responsibilities, and that's attractive to many people. There may be freedom from one of the things that scientists hate most _ grant applications,'' he said. Finn said Caltech's 1989 budget for education and general expenditures was nearly $181 million, not including a billion-dollar budget for a separate Jet Propulsion Laboratory funded primarily by NASA and the Department of Defense. Finn said the Twin Cities institute would likely have more success if it focused on specific goals, and the environment and communications might be good choices. ``Environmental research is not one of the most heavily funded areas of science these days,'' he said. ``Scientists in those specific fields might be interested.'' Smith said the $100 million would be raised by the end of 1991, but said there is no date projected to open the institute.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp To Cut Municipal Bond Underwriting
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp said it will stop underwriting, distribution and trading of municipal securities, cutting 35 jobs in another sign of Wall Street's slowdown. Glen Sergeon, managing director of Citicorp Securities Markets Inc., said Monday the municipal finance division would cut about half of its 70 jobs but is trying to find jobs for displaced workers in other areas of the big bank holding company. ``We are having an honest react to current market conditions,'' he said. ``The marketplace has a lot of excess capacity in it that isn't going away quickly.'' Sergeon said Citicorp would concentrate on creating and offering derivative products in municipal finance rather than underwriting. Such products typically allow issuers to hedge interest rate and other risks. Citicorp is the latest of major underwriters to scale back its business in the municipal bond field because of a slowdown in issuing tax-exempt securities stemming mainly from the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Sergeon said the market peaked in 1986 when $320 billion in municipal bonds were issued and underwriters received $11 a bond. In 1989, the total number of issues was $118 billion and underwriters made $7 a bond. ``The amount of human and capital capacity dedicated to this marketplace has not adjusted commensurate to the size of the market,'' he said Citicorp said the cuts will not affect other services to municipal bond issuers, such as investment agreements, shorter-term distribution agreements and various credit services.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Griffin Debt Plan Statement
DOC.TEXT: A bankruptcy judge has approved a Resorts International Inc. statement outlining how the company plans to shed much of its $927 million debt, the casino company announced. The approval is a major step toward confirmation of Resort's proposed financial restructuring plan, Christopher Whitney, the company's executive vice president, said in a statement Monday. U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Rosemary Gambardella, who heard arguments on the statement last week, requested minor language changes in approving it, Whitney said. The judge ordered Resorts to submit the revised statement by June 11 and Whitney said the company expects to mail the disclosure statement to Resorts creditors in mid-June. Last month, committees representing two groups of Resorts bondholders approved Resorts proposed restructuring. The plan still must win approval of two-thirds of the bondholders in a formal vote, Gambardella, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission and the government of the Bahamas. In addition to Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, Resorts owns casino property in the Bahamas. Resorts' plan, filed under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, would give bondholders 78 percent of the company, dropping Griffin's stake from 100 percent to 22 percent. In exchange, the bondholders will swap their $927 million in bonds for a reduced amount of debt. The plan also sets aside a legal kitty of $5 million to pursue a possible ``fraudulent conveyance'' action against Donald Trump, who swapped Resorts to Griffin for the newly opened Taj Mahal Casino Resort next door on the Boardwalk.
